HEADLINE: Dow Up 35.77, to 3,019.45, on Light Volume

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Stocks notched substantial gains yesterday in light holiday trading, with analysts saying investors were buoyed by several better-than-expected corporate earnings reports and by heightened enthusiasm about the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average leaped 35.77 points, or 1.2 percent, to 3,019.45, propped up by gains in a number of groups, including technology, oil, chemicals and airlines. 
 "When the market does well and those groups do well," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer for the First Albany Corporation, "it's a sign that people are becoming somewhat optimistic about the outlook for the economy in the fourth quarter and 1992."
Not a True Test
But Mr. Johnson cautioned against attaching too much significance to yesterday's session because many investors stayed away because of Columbus Day; a light 130.1 million shares were traded on the Big Board, compared with an already slow 148.9 million on Friday.
"We'll really find out what Monday's market was made of when most investors return to work Tuesday," Mr. Johnson said.
Nevertheless, advancing issues trounced those that declined yesterday, 1,090 to 463.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks jumped 5.02 points, to 386.47. The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.50, to 212.57, and the American Stock Exchange market-value index climbed 3, to 372.66.
The Nasdaq composite index, which tracks the performance of smaller stocks traded over the counter, was up 6.61, to 525.66.
One of the biggest percentage gainers on the Big Board was USAir, up 1 1/8, or 14 percent, to 9 1/8. The airline announced a third-quarter loss of $81.4 million, or $2.06 a share, compared with a loss of $120.3 million, or $2.87 a share, a year ago. The loss for the 1991 period, analysts said, was smaller than expected.
USAir also announced a plan designed to cut operating costs by more than $400 million in 1992 and later said it planned to increase the size of its fleet by 5 percent and its available seat miles by 4 percent in 1992.
Other airlines, analysts said, rose partly on USAir's news, including AMR, the parent of American Airlines, up 2 1/2, to 60 3/4; UAL, the parent of United Airlines, up 3 1/8, to 127 3/8, and Delta, up 1 7/8, to 67 3/4.
The only stock on the Big Board with a bigger percentage gain than USAir was the Argentina Fund, which rose 2 7/8, or 21.9 percent, to 16. The closed-end fund went public Friday at $12 a share, and later closed up 1 1/8, to 13 1/8.
The biggest net gain on the Big Board belonged to Great Lakes Chemical, up 10 5/8, to 96 7/8. Great Lakes rose on the announcement that it would increase its stake in Octel Associates and the Associated Octel Company, from 51.1 percent to 87.8 percent.
Great Lakes said its bigger stake in Octel, an international producer of motor fuel anti-knock compounds, would provide a non-cyclical flow of earnings into the future and lead to opportunities for growth.
Other chemical companies that rose included Du Pont, up 1 3/4, to 45; Dow Chemical, up 2, to 52 1/2, and Monsanto, up 3/4, to 70.
 
Earnings Surprises
 In addition to USAir, analysts said, several other stocks rose in part on corporate earnings reports that were better than expected, including Primerica, up 3/8, to 34 7/8, and NCNB, up 1 3/4, to 36 1/8.
Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, said those who predicted October would be a "difficult, dangerous, down month" compared with September should note that yesterday's market exceeded the close of 3,016.77 on Sept. 30.
"Now those of us waiting for the great bear market," Mr. Stovall said, "are analagous to Charlie Brown waiting for the Great Pumpkin, who, of course, never came."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Life Partners Group Appoints Key Officer

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Gene H. Bishop, a powerful Texas banker before turmoil in oil and real estate ruined the region's economy and financial institutions in the late 1980's, was named chairman and chief executive today of Life Partners Group Inc., a life insurance firm with assets of $2.7 billion.
Life Partners was organized in 1990 when Hicks, Muse & Company, a Dallas investment firm, acquired seven life insurance companies from the financially troubled ICH Corporation for $495 million, with $410 million raised from loans issued by the General Electric Credit Corporation. 
 The insurance operations were consolidated into three companies with operations based in Englewood, Colo.: the Massachusetts General Life Insurance Company, the Philadelphia Life Insurance Company and Wabash Life Insurance Company.
Mr. Bishop, 61 years old, headed the second-largest banking organization in Texas, Mcorp, before most of its banks were seized by regulators in October 1988. He retired in 1990 from Mcorp, which he had led as chief executive since 1975, and since last year has been vice chairman of the Lomas Financial Corporation, a financial services firm that has been in bankruptcy proceedings since 1989.
Mr. Bishop said he would direct investment decisions for Life Partners as well as acquisitions from the Dallas headquarters of Hicks, Muse. Marketing operations will continue to be directed by John W. Gardiner, president of the Life Partners companies. He was a senior executive at ICH before the buyout by Hicks, Muse.
"We will be very prudent, cautious and maybe semiconservative on the asset side," said Mr. Bishop, referring to his approach to investing premiums paid by policyholders of the Life Partners' companies. "We want to make sure, first and foremost, that we maintain quality."
The three companies, with a combined $30 billion in life insurance outstanding, have good, or A, ratings from the A. M. Best Company, an insurance research firm in Oldwick, N.J. "They have been culling out the poor credits," said Larry Mayewski, a Best analyst.
He said the companies had few troubles with real estate assets. ICH kept most problem property loans as part of the 1990 buyout. Philadelphia Life suffered some losses on high-risk high-yield "junk" bonds, which amounted to about 20 percent of Philadelphia Life's assets at the end of last year, according to A. M. Best.
Life Partners's junk bonds now are about 7 percent of assets, said Thomas O. Hicks, chairman of Hicks, Muse. He said the company had pared its loans to G.E. Credit by $60 million because of comparatively low operating costs, aided by sales agreements with independent brokers and marketing companies.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Northwest Air Ends Talks On Financing by Minnesota

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines has ended talks over $740 million in financing from Minnesota, raising new questions about the future of the nation's fourth-largest carrier as it seeks to expand.
After months of private and public wrangling, the final snag was the Minneapolis-St. Paul Metropolitan Airports Commission's inability to come up with the full amount of a $390 million loan that was to make up more than half of the overall package, commission officials said. 
 "We ran out of gas," said the panel's chairman, Hugh K. Schilling. "I have to believe what Northwest is telling us, that it's over."
Northwest, which is based in Eagan, Minn., issued a brief statement calling the loan shortfall "an obstacle that neither Northwest nor the M.A.C. can overcome."
The plan would have paid for new maintenance operations in Duluth and Hibbing, in northeastern Minnesota. Northwest said it would begin examining other potential sites.
Mr. Schilling said the commission, which oversees the operation of Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, realized about 10 days ago that it could not issue $120 million in revenue bonds that were to have been part of the $390 million loan. He said the commission was unable to persuade Northwest to accept a smaller loan.
"We simply reached a level that we couldn't go any further," said Jeffrey Hamiel, the commission's executive director.
Gov. Arne Carlson was informed Sunday night that talks between Northwest and the commission had reached an impasse, said John Riley, the Governor's chief of staff.
Mr. Carlson talked by telephone early today with Alfred Checchi, Northwest's co-chairman, who told him that the carrier was looking elsewhere to build the maintenance bases, Mr. Riley said.
Minnesota had been negotiating a separate $350 million financing package for Northwest, a unit of NWA Inc. Mr. Riley said the carrier had insisted that the package and the $390 million loan from the commission were inextricably linked.
The announcement came after months of debate, negotiation and scrutiny of the incentive package. It had been portrayed by supporters as an economic boon to northeastern Minnesota and by skeptics as a risk to taxpayers, who would be asked to underwrite much of the deal.
Northwest, burdened by heavy debt, has been seeking to expand so as not to be overwhelmed by its biggest competitors: American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines.
 
British Air Report
 Today, Advertising Age, the industry publication, reported that Northwest and British Airways, Europe's largest carrier, were negotiating a partnership that would have the airlines team up on frequent-flier programs, as well as scheduling and route coordination.
One proposal being considered would dissolve the Northwest name and replace it with some form of the British Airways name, Advertising Age said, citing a person involved in the talks who was not identified. The report said a partnership could give Northwest an improved image and British Airways an expanded global presence.
Neither airline would comment on the report.
Last week, Northwest reached a $174.7 million deal to buy Midway Airlines, a carrier based out of Midway Airport in Chicago, that had filed for bankruptcy protection last winter. The move came shortly after Northwest was unable to make final a deal to buy the Trump Shuttle, which caters mostly to business travelers flying between New York, Boston and Washington.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Sets A Record

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Just as the world's top-ranking finance officials issued warnings about Japan's climbing trade surplus, the Government said today that its monthly imbalance in September hit a record high of $9.76 billion and that the long-term trend toward a shrinking surplus might have reversed.
September was the ninth consecutive month in which Japan's trade surplus expanded from levels a year earlier. 
 The increase was attributed largely to currency changes and slowing Japanese imports helped by lower oil prices since the end of the Persian Gulf crisis.
 
Possible Reversal of Trend
 Economists have been saying for months that the trend toward smaller surpluses had reversed, but a Finance Ministry official today for the first time raised the possibility that the direction "may be changing."
The official, who by custom spoke on condition of anonymity, said the future direction of Japan's trade surplus must be watched cautiously. Previously, ministry officials have insisted the overall surplus was still headed downward.
For the first half of the fiscal year, the trade surplus rose to $39.92 billion, up 38 percent from $28.92 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported. It was the fifth-highest half-year surplus ever.
September's trade surplus with the United States came to $4.62 billion, up 7.1 percent from $4.31 billion in September 1990. In August of this year, the surplus with the United States had risen from levels a year earlier for the first time in five months.
Exports to the United States in September rose 2.9 percent from a year earlier, to $8.52 billion, while imports dropped 1.8 percent, to $3.9 billion.
At the meetings of world financial officials in Bangkok, Thailand, Pierre Beregovoy, the French Economics Minister, said on Sunday that he hoped the recent increase in the yen's value would continue. Eventually that could cut into Japan's surplus by making foreign products more competitive.
After their meeting on Saturday, the finance ministers and central bank governors of the seven major industrial democracies also made a point of saying they wanted Japan's trade surplus reduced. 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Surplus for Germany
 WIESBADEN, Germany, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- The trade balance of the former West Germany returned to a surplus in August after a deficit in July, as imports fell faster than exports, the Federal Statistics Office said today.
Exports from western Germany fell 13 percent from July, to 50.2 billion marks ($29.6 billion), but imports declined by an even larger 17 percent, to 47.6 billion marks ($28.1 billion).
On Oct. 4, the statistics office announced that imports for all of Germany in August had declined for the first time since German unification, to give a trade surplus of 3.1 billion marks ($1.8 billion), up from 200 million marks ($118.1 million) in July.
In July, the trade balance of western Germany showed a revised deficit of 31 million marks ($18.3 million) after a surplus of 186 million marks ($109.8 million) in June. The office originally reported a July deficit of 26 million marks ($15.3 million).
In the first eight months of 1991, west German imports rose by 20 percent, to 422.4 billion marks ($249.4 billion), while exports fell a slight nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 427.2 billion marks ($252.2 billion).

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Drug Prices Draw Political Scrutiny

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
CRITICS of the pharmaceutical industry are again urging drug makers to slow their increases in prices, which keep rising much faster than inflation. But most drug executives are keeping their heads down and their prices up. With sales growth sluggish, raising prices aggressively is still the main way most drug companies keep profits growing.
Senator David Pryor and others are expected to renew their attacks tomorrow when the Senate Labor Committee takes up Senator Edward M. Kennedy's bill to force drug makers to provide price rebates at community health centers, AIDS clinics and other federally financed agencies. 
 With help from the Bush Administration, Mr. Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who heads the Senate Committee on Aging, pushed through a measure in 1990 that requires drug makers to provide rebates to state Medicaid programs. Mr. Pryor said he had hoped the companies would see the measure as "a strong message that skyrocketing price increases would no longer be tolerated."
But the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics says drug prices rose 10.2 percent in the 12 months ended in August, the latest available data, or nearly triple the 3.8 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index. Mr. Pryor said that to put pressure on the drug makers Congress should review the $2 billion in tax credits that he says drug companies get.
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group in Washington, says prices have to be high to cover the $9.2 billion a year that the industry spends on research. It contends that drugs save lives and money by shortening patients' time in hospitals and sometimes eliminating surgery.
A few pharmaceutical executives warn that the industry risks retribution from Congress if prices are not voluntarily restrained. Seeking to set an example, Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, pledged to hold price increases below the annual growth rate in consumer prices. But industry consultants say no other company has followed his example.
"The price of drugs is the industry's major vulnerability from a public policy perspective," said Wayne Pines, director of medical issues in Washington for Burson-Marsteller, a consulting and public relations firm. Mr. Pines, a former associate commissioner with the Food and Drug Administration, said that even after the F.D.A. approved a drug, companies often had difficulty persuading insurers and hospitals to accept it.
St. Mary's Health Services, a 330-bed hospital in Grand Rapids, Mich., recently barred the door to sales representatives from seven drug companies that it said had raised prices by more than 9.8 percent, the increase in the index of all medical prices. On another front, pressure from Government officials and advocates for people with AIDS influenced the pricing of DDI, a new AIDS drug approved last week by the F.D.A. The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, which developed DDI, said the factory price would be $1,745 for a year's supply at the most common dosage, or about $2,000 retail. DDI will cost about 20 percent less than AZT, made by the Burroughs-Wellcome Company, which had been the only approved treatment for slowing the progress of the AIDS virus.
Bristol-Myers licensed DDI from Federal researchers who held the patents, so the company had to agree to set a "reasonable" price. In doing so, it attracted support from AIDS groups that had attacked Burroughs-Wellcome, which at first had charged $10,000 for a year's supply of AZT. Burroughs has cut the price twice and lower AZT dosage levels were approved, again reducing the cost.
But Bristol-Myers Squibb said it was not signaling a general pricing policy with DDI. Jerry Parrott, a Bristol-Myers spokesman, said each new product was different and would be priced according to development costs and potential market.
L. John Wilkerson, chairman of the Wilkerson Group, a health products consulting firm, said the increases might be less steep as more drugs faced competition. But Hemant K. Shah, an independent securities analyst, said the companies would still raise prices "to show sales growth and meet Wall Street expectations" as a growing number of drugs lost patent protection and faced price competition.
Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a professor of pharmaceutical economics at the University of Minnesota, said some drug companies see price controls ahead. "Many have accelerated their rate of price inflation, hoping to get all they can before the threatened price control might come into play," he said. "But if they followed the Merck pattern of restraint, it would take a lot of the steam out of the proposals for controls."

HEADLINE: Brady Says Soviet Pact on Union Is the Key to Aid

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, said today that an agreement on the relationship between the Soviet republics and the central Government would be a breakthrough toward financial aid from the West.
"That's the key that will unlock the door toward assistance," Mr. Brady said in an interview after three days of intensive talks in Bangkok between a delegation of Soviet economic officials and the financial leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies. 
 On Sunday, the Group of Seven announced what was described as a "historic" agreement with the Soviets to participate directly in formulating a reform program for transforming their collapsing Communist system into a market-based economy. The Western financial leaders said the task was immense, but were generally upbeat because of the new openness of the Soviets, represented here by the radical reformer Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a top Kremlin economic adviser.
 
Contrast in Tone
 But over all, Mr. Brady was more sober today in assessing how difficult it will be for the West to shore up the faltering Soviet economy and help preserve the union, and how much work the Soviets themselves have to do before the West can act.
He was frank in acknowledging differences between some of the Group of Seven countries on strategies for dealing with a looming financial crisis in the Soviet Union. The United States suggested over the weekend that the West should consider a deferral of Soviet debt payments to ease a financial squeeze, but the proposal was rejected by the Europeans. Officials here did indicate, however, that while no specific debt relief plan was completed, they did agree that they would be willing to provide short-term assistance if the Soviets threaten to default on their debts to the West because of a shortage of hard currency. In addition to the United States, the Group of Seven includes Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan.
Mr. Brady also indicated that though aid could be important, money for the Soviets was not the key element in the lifeline the West was offering. "There aren't great gobs of money they are going to get," he said, adding that even after all the talks here it was still not certain how much might be needed.
"In truth, what happened here was not a watershed; it's a way station," he commented, while still underscoring the great opportunity that he felt had been opened for cooperation between the West and its one-time enemy. The next step in the process will come in a few weeks when the deputy finance ministers of the Group of Seven go to Moscow and begin deeper consultations.
The Western countries did not detail any proposals, however, or agree on financial assistance at this time. They also took a risk by throwing their prestige behind a basic reform program that would preserve a large role for a central Government, something many of the Soviet republics are rejecting.
Mr. Brady's statement today about the importance of a clear-cut agreement on the relationship between the republics and Moscow, and one that works in practice, came as the Soviets were preparing to take an important step toward that end with the signing of an economic cooperation pact by 10 of the 12 remaining Soviet republics.
[The pact is set to be signed Friday, three days later than scheduled, a spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today in Moscow. The signing appears to have been delayed by political events in several republics, Reuters reported.]
Mr. Gorbachev has called the pact vital to national reconstruction after the failed coup in August.
 
Yeltsin Aide Not Optimstic
 The depth of the complexities being faced were underscored here today by officials from some of the Soviet republics. Oleg Bogomolov, economic adviser to Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, said of Mr. Yavlinsky's reform plan, "I am not sure if it will be accepted by republican parliaments, and if it is accepted, it is very unlikely that it will be implemented."
He added that the country had so lost faith in the central monetary authorities that it was unlikely the republics would agree to retain a single currency, something the Western leaders have encouraged.
In addition, Viktor Geraschenko, chairman of the Soviet central bank, told reporters that foreign currency reserves were "close to zero." Against this difficult backdrop, Mr. Brady said he had been most impressed by three aspects of the three days of talks with the Soviet delegation. First, he said, he felt more certain than ever that little progress could be made before the terms of the union were sorted out.
Second, Mr. Brady said he was impressed with how radical has been the shift from a closed society to an open one. Nonetheless, the West needs far more and more accurate information before it can completely engage in the reform process, he said.
Third, he said that one reason Mr. Yavlinsky had pressed the Group of Seven to get involved was because the current central authorities in Moscow had almost completely lost credibility with the Soviet people.
French and German officials here today criticized the American effort to arrange an immediate postponement of debt payments to Western banks and governments in coming months.
The Soviets have total foreign debt of nearly $70 billion. That is not regarded as overly burdensome for a country with the resources of the Soviet Union, but the recent economic turmoil has disrupted the economy, trade and the flow of hard-currency earnings to the central Government. That means there could be a temporary inability to meet debt payments. The Soviets have indicated that they may be unable to meet $5 billion or more of payments due in coming months. And the Western leaders are underestood to have indicated that they would be willing to help tide the Soviets over that shortfall with some kind of special loans or a temporary easing of repayment terms.

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS NOMINATION;
Compelling Evidence on Both Sides, But Only One Can Be Telling Truth

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The Senate takes up the debate on Tuesday on the fitness of Judge Clarence Thomas to serve on the Supreme Court with public-opinion polls running in his favor, but with the stain of charges that he sexually harassed Prof. Anita F. Hill undispelled for now, and probably forever, legal experts and Senate aides said today.
The failure of three long days of hearings to thrash out the truth behind the accusations is not unusual, those experts said. But it confronts the Senate with the ugliest of choices. It can reject Judge Thomas's nomination, blotting his record without proof of misbehavior. Or it can confirm him, and run the risk -- however small -- that evidence will emerge later to show that the nominee had baldly lied to a Congressional committee under oath. 
 Each side comes to the debate on Tuesday morning armed with powerful arguments that it is the truthful one, say criminal lawyers and Judiciary Committee aides who have scrutinized more than 30 hours of sworn testimony on the harassment charges.
 
Witnesses for Both Sides
 Professor Hill has a battery of witnesses who swear that she told them of his approaches years ago, soon after they were said to have occurred. Judge Thomas has no known history of harassment and a recent reputation that friends call spotless.
She has no known ulterior motive for making charges against him, and has suffered considerably for having done so. He says she waited nearly a decade to speak against him, while two Senate committees reviewed his background and confirmed him to Federal appointments three times.
Michael Schatzow, a top Baltimore criminal defense lawyer who was a Federal prosecutor for seven years in the 1980's, said that in legal terms, Professor Hill had a jury-swaying aura of credibility and the weight of much of the evidence in her favor.
 
Power of 'Indignant Anger'
 But a Democratic aide on the Judiciary Committee said today that the judge had political and public-relations advantages, among them, a proven record of public service and a "very strong, indignant anger."
In his testimony on Friday evening, when Judge Thomas accused the Judiciary Committee of conducting a "high-tech electronic lynching," the aide said, "There was something very powerful in it."
Neither Mr. Schatzow nor others could predict who would have won this argument in a court of law. Nor would they predict how the Senate would vote when it records its own verdict at 6 P.M. Tuesday.
Nathan Lewin, a Washington lawyer who headed the legal team that assisted former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in two Federal investigations of his conduct, said the Senate faced the same quandary that juries regularly faced in white-collar criminal cases.
"With all the moaning about this conflict in their stories, people in the business of trying cases see that all the time," he said. "It's only on TV that a witness breaks down on the witness stand and confesses.
"Obviously, somebody is lying, and that happens all the time. People get up on the stand and lie, and lie persuasively, and each side has corroborating witnesses. And the jury goes out and comes back with result which, as a trial lawyer, I often find to be unexpected."
Following is the evidence, or information, that the jury of the Senate will be considering when it debates the Thomas nomination on Tuesday:
 
THE CASE FOR PROFESSOR HILL
 Mr. Schatzow, Mr. Lewin and others said Professor Hill's accusations gained their greatest weight from two powerful supporting factors: the inability of critics to prove the existence of any hidden motive for her actions, and the presence of four credible witnesses who, in general, corroborated her account by saying she had made the same complaints to them years ago.
Judge Thomas's supporters sought last week to raise several possible motives for Professor Hill's decision to bring her explosive testimony to the Judiciary Committee. Through the testimony of Judge Thomas's friends, they cast her as a scorned suitor who had sought revenge; as a bitter opponent of Judge Thomas's views against racial quotas as a remedy for discrimination; as a tool of "slick lawyers" running the liberal opposition to the Thomas nomination; as a gold digger who planned to parlay her celebrity into a book contract, and finally, as emotionally unstable.
Her supporters and allies managed to poke holes in each of the ideas, and none of the theories appears to have stuck with the committee, legal experts said. That was in large part because of Professor Hill's own calm performance before the Judiciary Committee and the impressive performance of witnesses who supported her, legal experts said.
The four -- Ellen M. ells, an official of the American Public Welfare Association; John William Carr, a New York lawyer; Susan Hoerchner, a California administrative law judge, and Joel R. Paul, a law professor at American University -- all testified that Professor Hill had told them of harassment by her boss.
 
A Major Piece of Evidence
 "People who are experienced in prosecution or defense would look at what happened and say that the most telling piece of evidence is the nearly contemporaneous reporting that Professor Hill made of the incident," Mr. Schatzow said. "I think it's just preposterous to think that 10 years ago, she was planting the seeds of coming forth to derail his Supreme Court nomination."
Professor Hill's case was further bolstered on Sunday by the release of the results of a polygraph test indicating that she was telling the truth about the accusations. Among the questions the tester asked her were whether she had deliberately lied about the allegations, whether Judge Thomas had described sexual acts to her and whether he had talked about pornography.
"Ms. Hill is truthful," Paul Minor, a former polygraph expert for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who conducted the tests, said later.
 
Questions on Polygraphs
 Others noted, however, that polygraph exams are not considered conclusive and are not admissible in court.
Professor Hill's account was also supported in part by a statement made over the telephone by another former employee of Judge Thomas, Angela Wright, who said that he had made "inappropriate" remarks about her body when she headed the public affairs office at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in 1984 and 1985. "Actually, what he said was, 'What size are your breasts?' " she said in the description of a conversation that reportedly occurred at a banquet the two attended in 1984.
Ms. Wright also stated, as has Professor Hill, that Judge Thomas asked her for dates and once showed up unannounced at her apartment. A former co-worker with Ms. Wright, Rose Jordain, also stated to the committee that Ms. Wright had admitted to her at the time that Judge Thomas's remarks about "her figure, her body, her breasts" had bothered her.
Judge Thomas's supporters have argued that Judge Thomas dismissed both Ms. Wright and Ms. Jordain and that their testimony must be discounted because they had reason to be angry with him.
Finally, Professor Hill's account is underscored, although not directly substantiated, by reports that Judge Thomas has talked with others about pornographic movies that he had frequently attended while a student at Yale Law School in the late 1970's. A Washington lawyer who is a friend and supporter of Judge Thomas, Lovida Coleman Jr., said in a statement that Judge Thomas had described and joked about the movies he had seen in conversations with her and others at Yale.
She said that she was not offended by the remarks and that she believed many Yale law students had seen similar movies at the time.
 
THE CASE FOR JUDGE THOMAS
 Judge Thomas has argued that he cannot ultimately disprove the charges because there are no witnesses. Much of his case has rested on the indignation he has expressed over the charges, and on efforts by him and his supporters to cast doubt on Professor Hill's honesty.
But lawyers and Senate aides said that his strongest defense so far is the dated nature of the allegations and the fact that his own public record until now has been unblemished by sex-related incidents.
"He's a sitting Federal judge who has been confirmed by the Senate before -- once at the E.E.O.C., again for his reappointment there, once for the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals," one Senate aide said. "And by the time he first came to the Judiciary Committee only a year and a half ago, everyone knew he was being groomed for this nomination.
"Why she didn't come forward sooner is a legitimate question in many different ways -- earlier in previous nominations, or earlier in this process."
Professor Hill has said she tried to forget the incidents, adding that she agreed to speak to the Judiciary Committee only after being approached by staff members who asked specific questions about rumors of harassment.
But the absence of potential detractors over the last decade suggests to some that Professor Hill's charges are exaggerated or untruthful.
"My own experience is that when you identify people like that, you usually would be hard pressed to find a person who hadn't experienced similar behavior," Mr. Schatzow said. The lack of a credible second or third victim, he said, "weakens her charges."
 
Testimonials on Character
 Judge Thomas's character witnesses -- he presented 16 at Sunday's long hearing on Capitol Hill -- testified to his character or sought to soil Professor Hill's. Pamela Talkin, Judge Thomas's chief of staff at the E.E.O.C., said he possessed "a feminist's understanding of sexual politics." A former aide to Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is Judge Thomas's former employer and his chief supporter in Congress, said that Judge Thomas had shown sensitivity when helping her get over an incident of sexual harassment.
While the testimonials were impressive, however, they did not refute Professor Hill's allegations, in large part because whatever occurred between her and Judge Thomas took place in private.
Potentially more damaging to Professor Hill's case are seeming inconsistencies in her statements that Judge Thomas's supporters have pounced upon and that she has not always rebutted effectively.
Chief among them is the fact that Professor Hill followed Judge Thomas from a post in the civil-rights division of the Education Department to another job at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, even after the time she says she was harassed by him. In testimony, Professor Hill has said that she was only 25 years old at the time, that the harassment had temporarily stopped and that she feared for her job at a time of a deep national recession. Her critics have responded that she effectively was guaranteed a job at the Education Department had she chosen not to follow Judge Thomas.

LENGTH: 548 words

HEADLINE: An Old Irish Tale of Leaving Echoes Bittersweetly Today

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Oct. 14

 BODY:
With more than 100,000 Irish citizens estimated to have mailed their entries for Washington's immigration lottery that in the next year will provide 16,000 of them with the green card needed to work legally in the United States, the subject of departure from Ireland was once again on the minds of those who wanted to go and those who were staying behind.
As she left Saturday on a 10-day unofficial visit to the United States, President Mary Robinson touched on the issue, saying emigration was one of her principal concerns. Mrs. Robinson, whose post is largely ceremonial, noted that she was from Mayo, in the west of Ireland, where the the famines of the 19th century were particularly hard and where emigration is a tradition.
"One of the criticisms was that once you left Ireland somehow all links were cut, and I think that most of all I'll probably be trying to say all links are not cut," she said of her trip. 
 While many Irish may consider emigration unavoidable, given an unemployment rate that recently moved beyond 20 percent, it remains a bittersweet subject. This was reflected by a sign someone posted last week at the General Post Office on O'Connell Street here in Dublin, where thousands of last-minute hopefuls, worried by a two-day postal workers' strike, lined up to mail applications. The sign said, "Rounds off our history pretty neatly standing on the spot where Ireland's independence was declared, sending off letters to America to take us out of here." The reference was to the Easter Uprising in 1916.
In his column in The Sunday Business Post, Damien Kiberd said, "It is difficult to imagine any other self-respecting Western economy in which the main item on the news would focus on the possibilities for emigration." He cited a study that showed unemployment would reach 25 percent by 1993.
Brian Friel, the nation's most prominent playwright, returns constantly to the subject, from his first major success, "Philadelphia, Here I Come!" to "Dancing at Lughnasa," which was acclaimed in Dublin and London before it moved to New York last week.
After several years of relative prosperity, the Irish national economy slid in the last year, to a degree a reflection of the world recession, and net emigration has virtually stopped.
In the boom of the late 1980's, about 35,000 emigrants a year left the country to work abroad, mostly in Britain, Australia and the United States. They sent back millions to their families and kept unemployment relatively low, but the rate is still one of the highest in the European Community.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Millions Apply, U.S. Says
 MERRIFIELD, Va., Oct. 14 (AP) -- United States postal officials said today that two million applications for green cards had been processed so far from immigrants in a lottery to become one of 40,000 new legal residents.
"We have approximately another four million to five million waiting in the wings to either be processed or verified," said a Postal Service spokesman, Robert Faraq. Many immigrants tried to improve their odds by delivering more than 1,000 petitions each over the weekend.
The State Department, in total, is accepting the first 40,000 valid applications for immigration visas received after 12:01 A.M. today.

HEADLINE: Palm Beach Journal;
New for Season: To-Do at Post Estate

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 12

 BODY:
In another town, the construction of eight mansions on $2 million lots might not be viewed as bringing down the neighborhood's property values. But in this enclave of wealth and privilege, Donald Trump's proposal to turn his 17.8-acre Mar-a-Lago estate into a subdivision for the elite has been met with a crusade to keep the town's most famous property intact.
By a unanimous vote on Oct. 8, the town council refused to allow the financially pressed real estate tycoon to break up the former Marjorie Merriwether Post estate, built in the 1920's and designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1980. A spokesman for Mr. Trump said he was pondering the council's suggestion that he revise his plan. 
 "We frankly don't know what he is going to do," said Frank Chopin, a lawyer for the Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, one of the groups leading the opposition. "He once threatened to sue if the town did what it now has done. But you have to believe he knows he has to do something different from what he's done."
Mr. Trump bought Mar-a-Lago in 1985, happier days for him, paying $10 million for the grounds, buildings and sumptuous antique furnishings in the main house, reports said. He initially used the estate as a weekend and winter getaway. But in February, amid divorce proceedings and mounting financial woes, he asked for approval to build eight homes, each on 1.5 acres of land, while retaining for himself the main house and its sweeping ocean-to-lagoon view.
Residents here say they have mixed feelings about the 118-room mansion, which is built in Hispano-Moorish style and includes 58 bedrooms, three bomb shelters, a five-story observatory, a park and a golf course. A council member, Paul Ilyinsky, calls the estate "a monument to man's indulgence," while Lillian Jane Volk, head of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, describes it as "a symbol of the elegant era of Palm Beach and the life it represents."
Mr. Trump's two closest neighbors have hired lawyers to fight the project. But the strongest opposition has come from architectural, preservation and landscape groups, including the National Park Service, which inherited the property after Mrs. Post's death but later gave it to her heirs.
Another council member, Hermine Wiener, said she initially expected "no great hue and cry over this" because "a few years ago, a plan vastly inferior to this was approved one, two, three" when the Post heirs were trying to sell the property to a Texas land developer. Other beachfront properties in the neighborhood have also been approved for subdivision recently, including one, according to Mr. Trump's lawyer, that has local landmark status.
Others here are certain that Mr. Trump's status as a brash and flamboyant newcomer has hurt him. "There's a double standard in this town, and that's what this is really all about," one official said. "It's not necessarily Donald Trump himself. Anyone who is not part of that clique would be in the same situation."
Mrs. Volk of the landmark commission denied that the Palm Beach establishment was trying to block Mr. Trump because they regard him as a parvenu. "I would think that is really complete hogwash," she said. "We want to do the best for the town. It wouldn't occur to me to treat him any different than anyone else."
But she added: "If he has aroused ire in this town, it's his own doing. He creates this atmosphere."
Mr. Trump antagonized some here last month when he challenged the $17.5 million property assessment on Mar-a-Lago and the $376,101 he would owe in taxes at a time when his creditors have put him on a tight budget. .
The situation was further complicated when Mr. Trump submitted an alternative plan in late September that would allow him to build as many as 11 homes on the site and seek approval through different channels. Mr. Chopin described the action as an attempt to "circumvent the whole process," but Mr. Trump's lawyer, Peter S. Broberg, said his client was merely considering "two different remedies, both of which are designed to achieve the same thing."
Mrs. Volk said the ideal solution to the controversy would be for Mr. Trump simply to sell the estate intact. "There seems to be very large money around," she said. "A miserable little house right up the street just sold for almost $15 million."
But Mr. Trump's advisers describe that idea as "improbable," pointing to the state of the economy and the estate's high maintenance costs.
Mr. Trump's architects are apparently willing to draw up a revised plan that would incorporate some design changes demanded by preservation groups. But both sides recognize that the dispute could end up in court.
From the town's perspective, the most important thing is to make sure it does not inherit the property by default. "Otherwise, Trump will get wiped out," said Charles E. Kimball, a real estate economist based in Palm Beach County. "Nobody, not even the town, could maintain that house without a substantial tax increase."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald Trump's proposal to turn his 17.8-acre Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., into a subdivision for the elite has been met with a crusade to keep the town's most famous property intact. (Bob Shanley)

HEADLINE: Poor Youths Swarming to Las Vegas Are Blamed for Rise in Gang Violence

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
Two months ago, at the age of 16, Cesar Lara decided a change of scene would be good for him. He had been arrested and put on probation in Southern California for carrying a dagger and rifle and wanted to get away from his gang, the El Centro Dude Boys, whose main activities, he says, were "getting drunk and looking for trouble."
So he came to this sprawling casino city to stay with his uncle and look for a job. He has ended up jobless, watching the gang violence on 28th Street, a dusty road of rundown homes and frequent shootings just a few miles from the city's glittering Strip. 
 "I was trying to get out of trouble from down there in El Centro," he said, idly inspecting the three tattoos on his left arm as he sat on the step outside his uncle's one-bedroom home. "But it's worse here. Everywhere you go, it's the same gangs."
Gang violence, which has claimed more than 3,500 lives in Los Angeles over the last decade, is spreading throughout the West to cities like Phoenix; Portland, Ore., and Seattle. In Las Vegas the spreading gang violence has been accompanied by a doubling of the metropolitan area's population to 800,000 in the last 10 years, creating pressure to relieve shortages in schools, housing and other services that could lead to more gang violence.
 
Nine Killings in Nine Months
 Today the police say they are far more preoccupied with gang violence than with the dwindling presence of organized crime linked to the Las Vegas casinos.
On Sept. 4, for example, one man was killed and another wounded outside Cesar Lara's home in a gun battle between two Hispanic gangs, the Sanchucos and the 28th Street Gang. Gang-related homicides and gunfights have surged, with nine killings and 135 shootings in the first nine months of this year, up from seven killings and 97 shootings in all of 1990.
The Sept. 4 incident formed part of "a worsening spiral of gang shootings, stabbings and beatings linked to the spread throughout the West of youth gangs from Los Angeles," said Lieut. Charlie Davidaitis of the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department.
As in Los Angeles, where 690 people died in gang conflicts last year, the police say gang battles in Las Vegas are generally over drugs, territory and old vendettas. They see poor youths, raised in troubled homes and largely unschooled, increasingly drawn to gangs because of the status that comes with membership.
"The gang problem is going from here to Las Vegas and all over the country," said Sgt. Wes McBride of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. "These kids are generally born and bred in poverty, their familes are busted up, they have a series of fathers and no internal discipline. Gangs give them a sense of belonging."
 
Rise in Gang Membership
 Lieut. Mike Hawkins, who heads the Las Vegas police department's gang unit, estimated the number of youths belonging to gangs in the Las Vegas area at 5,000. This compares with about 1,500 three years ago. Many have come here from the Los Angeles area, where gang membership is estimated at more than 100,000.
Among the gangs now in Las Vegas are the rival black Crips and Bloods, the Asian Kickboxers and several Hispanic groups.
"There's an epidemic of gang violence, and it's probably going to get worse over the next few years because of the shortage of schools and homes," Lieutenant Hawkins said. "Obviously, we are very concerned that it could spill over to downtown and the Strip, because tourism is our No. 1 industry here."
Up to now, however, very little of the violence has reached the Strip from places like 28th Street and North Las Vegas, where the gangs are concentrated. Tourists are generally oblivious.
Cesar Lara, at his uncle's house on 28th Street, starkly described the divide between his world and the tourists' world: "This is the underworld; this is hell," he said. "The Strip is heaven."
 
A City's Growing Problems
 Still, Robert R. Maxey, chief executive of the MGM Grand Hotel and a prominent Las Vegas businessman, described the gang situation as disturbing. "Some of the problems are related to the simple fact that we became a large city," he said. "We were a cow town."
Indeed, the population growth -- attributed largely to inexpensive housing, low taxes, a good climate and a resilient economy -- has been so intense that the Las Vegas School District was obliged to build 18 new schools last year.
Despite this effort, "our schools are way overcrowded," said Carmen Cunningham, a demographer in the school district's planning department.
Karen Layne, the planning director for the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department, added that all the city's services were under heavy pressure because tax dollars lagged behind the population influx. For example, she said that despite a costly recruitment drive aimed at insuring that there were 1.7 police officers for every 1,000 residents, the ratio was now 1.4 per 1,000, well below the national average of 2.7.
"Every city agency I know is facing problems," she said, "and this is the backdrop in which the gang problem grows."
 
Federal Legislation Urged
 The rapid growth of youth gangs throughout the West has led Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, to propose legislation that would provide Federal support for a national statistic information center and other programs to fight against gangs. But the bill, the Outlaw Street and Motorcycle Gang Control Act of 1991, was rejected in committee.
"I believe a national campaign against this problem is essential," Senator DeConcini, said, "and so far the Federal Government has done nothing."
He added: "In Phoenix, gang violence is the highest it has ever been this year. These kids can't find jobs but they can join gangs. We are paying the price of rejecting our municipalities."
Sergeant McBride of the Los Angeles Sheriff's Department has been angered by the Government's attitude. "If I had to blame one sole source for gangs spreading across the country, it's the inaction of the Federal Government. We need schools, social programs and enhanced law enforcement, but that costs big bucks, so politicians hate to address the issue."
Meanwhile, everyone seems to think the situation will get worse. In Las Vegas, the schools have recently started a program intended to convey to children up to seventh grade the idea that joining a gang is a dead end. But Lieutenant Hawkins of the Las Vegas police conceded that the program, up to now, undermined what he called "the strong mystique of gang membership."
As for Cesar Lara, he does little more than watch the day go by with his uncle, Jose Flores, who is unemployed. "I sit here all day and do nothing, and at night I get drunk," he said. "If I do join a gang I'll join the 28th Street gang. But if my girlfriend mails me some money I'll go back to El Centro."

LENGTH: 352 words

HEADLINE: Message to Myanmar

 BODY:
By awarding the 1991 Peace Prize to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the inspirational leader of Myanmar's democracy movement, the Norwegian Nobel Committee gives fresh hope to a people oppressed by one of the world's ugliest remaining tyrannies.
This recognition may shame Asian nations like China and Thailand into withdrawing economic and political support from Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's jailers, the State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc. Even if these neighboring regimes remain unmoved, Myanmar's democrats can be heartened by the examples of previous Peace Prize winners like Lech Walesa and Archbishop Desmond Tutu, whose causes passed from hopelessness toward splendid triumph. 
 To be heartened, Myanmar's people have to learn the news. The Slorc, which holds Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest, will make that as difficult as possible. So tight is its grip that her husband, now residing in the U.S., cannot be certain that his wife is even alive.
Her prestige has probably spared her. She is the daughter of the man who led the country then called Burma to independence, and she carried her party to overwhelming victory in last year's parliamentary elections. Yet thousands of others have been killed in Myanmar's struggle for democracy. And the Slorc still brazenly refuses to honor those decisive election results.
Fortunately, the world is now too small for tyrants to feel protected by the old conventions of absolute national sovereignty. The U.S., thanks in large measure to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, now pressures the Slorc with economic sanctions. The European Parliament, which awarded Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi its Sakharov Prize, and now the Nobel Committee exert another kind of useful pressure.
This faith that Myanmar's people are as entitled as any other to share in the emerging new world of democracy and basic human rights will eventually be vindicated. If China and Thailand believe that too, they have it in their power to accelerate democratic change. How long will they choose to hold themselves apart from the conscience of the world?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Lasting Tragedy and Trauma for the Country;
Lowest Kind of Politics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While it may be true that Judge Clarence Thomas acted improperly and that Prof. Anita F. Hill was truly offended by any sexist comments on the part of Judge Thomas, the context, timing and volume of the accusations are nothing short of the lowest political campaign this country has ever seen. This is the real issue. 
 While morality and politics seem to be ever more exclusive, smear campaigns like this one insure that only the incompetent or the amoral hold the most important offices in this country.
At a time when we face greater threats to our economic and intellectual well-being than ever before, the special interest groups only serve to divide us against ourselves. A Congress that chooses to overlook such accusations and the high crimes and misdemeanors of its members is not only unfit to judge others, but also must have its own fitness questioned.
 
MATTHEW T. HOLZMANN
Newport Beach, Calif., Oct. 10, 1991

HEADLINE: Coke Bottler Has First Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Coca-Cola Enterprises, the largest bottler of Coke products, today reported a $1.9 million loss for the third quarter, its first quarterly loss in its five-year history.
The company also said a special board committee was considering whether it should go through with its previously announced proposal to buy the Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group Inc. in Chattanooga, Tenn., for Coca-Cola Enterprises shares valued at the time at about $440 million. 
 The loss in the three months ended Sept. 30 compares with a profit of $18 million, or 13 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Its operating revenues edged up almost 1 percent, to $1.07 billion from $1.06 billion.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, the bottler's shares rose 25 cents, to $12.375.
Coca-Cola Enterprises, which became public in 1986, is 49 percent owned by the Coca- Cola Company.
Brian G. Dyson, Coca-Cola Enterprises' president, attributed the loss to "the economic impact of the recession, combined with the competitive environment."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Mixed Results in Philadelphia Plan to Curb Business Flight

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
THE decision of a record retailer to expand its distribution center in northeast Philadelphia rather than move to another city illustrates the mixed results of a tax policy this city uses to help it compete with suburban industrial parks.
Under the tax policy, adopted in 1985 to help stem the flight of companies and jobs out of the city, companies pay taxes only on the portion of sales or net income generated within the city limits. 
 "The business privilege tax is indifferent to whether a company is profitable, since it's based on volume," said William P. Hankowsky, president of the Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation, a quasi-public agency.
While that policy has been a factor in retaining some business, it has not stopped all from moving elsewhere.
For Wee Three Record Shops Inc., the tax policy and other incentives adopted by the city have been a benefit. Because only one of its 63 stores is in Philadelphia, the company largely avoids paying city taxes. In addition, the company's warehouse space in the city has a tax abatement that helps lower the net rent.
Such benefits were also a factor in the decision of Ikea, the Swedish home furnishings retailer, to lease 430,000 square feet in Philadelphia in the late 1980's, but they did not stop Sears, Roebuck & Company from announcing last summer that it would move its retail distrbution center from Philadelphia to Wilkes-Barre, Pa.
The building used by Wee Three is in the Roosevelt Business Center in northeast Philadelphia, an industrial park on land purchased by the city's development corporation to lure back manufacturing and warehouse companies that had left the city in the early 1980's. Using tax abatements and subsidized property, city officials tried to offset the high taxes that drove companies away.
Mark Andreassi, president of Anvil Construction, which built the building occupied by Wee Three, said that in the past, the program of incentives and tax abatements helped city developers like himself compete with out-of-town sites.
He said that city land valued at $50,000 or $60,000 an acre could be bought at substantial discounts from face values because of Federal and city subsidies. Comparable suburban land had cost $100,000, he said.
"In their day, those subsidies programs were the only things going for you," Mr. Andreassi said. "It was great for Philadelphia while it lasted."
Such subsidies are no longer widely available, but the city still provides a five-year delay in assessing real estate taxes of $1 a square foot on newly occupied developments.
At Wee Three Records, Peter Bamford, the president, said the company remained in Philadelphia largely to retain employees who joined the company since its acquisition in 1989 by the W. H. Smith Group P.L.C., a British retailer. At the time it was acquired, Wee Three had 19 stores and an 11,000-square-foot warehouse in Philadelphia's Manayunk section.
About a year after it was bought by Smith, Wee Three moved into 32,000 square feet of space in a Roosevelt Center building just completed by Anvil Construction. It has since expanded to take all of the building's 52,000 square feet. Mr. Bamford would not discuss rent figures, but the property carries the five-year city real estate tax abatement.
Wee Three, which now operates stores under four names from Boston to Pittsburgh to Norfolk, Va., had considered many options in its move from Manayunk. Popular suburban sites like Lansdale, Pa., about 45 minutes northwest, had suitable access to Interstate 95, the Pennsylvania and New Jersey turnpikes and other major arteries, but few would have allowed the company to hold its 90-employee work force intact, Mr. Bamford said.
"We built up a team of people when we were in Manayunk who we wanted to remain with us," he said. "After a year and a half in the business we didn't want to rebuild. If we had put our distribution center in Lansdale, probably none of our employees would have traveled out there, so that wasn't an option."
While the city's business incentives provide substantial initial benefits, they do not last forever, according to one of Wee Three's neighbors in the Roosevelt Business Center that is nearing the end of its tax holiday.
Kenneth Shaw of Fred Hill & Son, a maker of materials-handling equipment, said that if he had to make the same decision again, he might have relocated his company outside Philadelphia. The end of Fred Hill's five-year tax-free window next year will mean an eightfold increase in city taxes, Mr. Shaw said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Higher In Absence of Fed Moves

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against major currencies yesterday as traders re-evaluated their earlier speculations that the Federal Reserve might push interest rates lower.
Gold prices fell, with a troy ounce slipping $1.20 on the New York Commodity Exchange to $357.70. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356.85, off $1.55. 
 Analysts said the Fed's failure to ease monetary policy and nudge interest rates downward helped lift the dollar.
The United States currency had fallen recently amid evidence of economic weakness -- signs the foreign exchange markets believed would prompt the Fed to act.
Mike Faust, a currency analyst with MMS International, said there has been "some dampening of easing expectations" as the days have passed and there has been no move from the central bank.
The dollar is supported by stable or higher rates, so inaction by the Fed has turned into a buy signal for currency traders.
 
Looking to the Mark
 Mr. Faust said that if the dollar could climb to 1.7150 German marks, an important threshold for traders, it would likely advance further. But, he warned, "there's quite a bit of risk out there for an ease" by the Fed.
The dollar rose to 1.71275 German marks in New York trading yesterday, up from 1.70175 late Monday. In earlier European dealings, the dollar climbed to 1.7115 marks from 1.6990.
The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, advancing to 130.10 in New York, from 129.95 on Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 129.72 yen, up 0.67 yen from Monday's 129.05-yen finish, and in London, it was quoted at 130.15 yen.
The British pound fell against the dollar, dropping to $1.7005 in New York, from $1.71225 late Monday. In London trading, sterling was quoted at $1.7010, compared with $1.7145 late Monday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with quotes late Monday, included: 1.4950 Swiss francs, up from 1.4865; 5.8335 French francs, up from 5.79175; 1,280.25 Italian lire, up from 1,239, and 1.12975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.12925.
In the precious metals market, gold fell 75 cents in London to a late bid of $358.25. In Zurich, the bid was $358, down from $358.50 late Monday. Gold dropped $1.52 in Hong Kong to close at $359.19.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Decision for Continental Air's Chief

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
For Robert R. Ferguson, the chief executive of Continental Airlines, the carrier's fate has narrowed largely to two choices -- either it will be taken over by Northwest Airlines or remain independent and come out from under the shadow of bankruptcy by spring.
"Northwest Airlines is meaningfully interested," he said in an interview yesterday at the midtown offices of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., the parent company. 
Talks with Alfred Checchi, Northwest's co-chairman, and his managers are continuing, he added, and Northwest is working with the unions representing its pilots, machinists and flight attendants to bring them around to accept a buyout.
 
Effects of a Forced Merger
 What worries both sides is that a forced merger could end up alienating the airlines' work forces to where service would deteriorate and cause years of turmoil. That is what happened in the takeovers by Northwest of Republic Airlines and by USAir of Piedmont, both in the late 1980's.
Service at Northwest and USAir suffered for a time, causing them to lose the support of many business fliers and earning the Minneapolis-St. Paul carrier the nickname "Northworst."
Mr. Ferguson recalled yesterday that during his days at the Texas Air Corporation, the takeover of People Express and Frontier Airlines in the mid-80's had led to a widespread erosion of service at Continental that took years to repair.
"We've been through a lot of mergers and know how not to do it," he said.
 
Business Travelers Still Wary
 Continental still does not have the same support of business travelers as other leading carriers. Only about 25 percent of its passengers pay full coach and higher discount fares, compared with about 50 percent for American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines.
Although concerns also exist that Northwest may further increase its debt by buying Continental, Mr. Ferguson said, these were smaller worries compared with those that concerned bringing together a largely nonunion work force at Continental with the highly unionized workers at Northwest.
"If we can figure out the labor question, the financial question will work itself out," he added.
Northwest greatly increased its debt when Mr. Checchi led a leveraged buyout of the company in 1989.
There has been concern among some analysts on how Northwest will be able to handle its higher debt, now totaling about $2.7 billion, if the airline industry and the economy should stay in a long recession.
The high debt has also left the carrier at a disadvantage when other large airlines with lower debt, like Delta, United and American, have been able to finance large acquisitions of overseas routes.
 
A Fit With British Air
 To finance a takeover, Northwest may have to attract other investors like British Airways, Europe's largest private carrier. Strategically, the carriers make almost a perfect match with little duplication.
Northwest has a large presence in the Pacific and has a domestic route system that runs largely north to south, with primary hubs in Minneapolis, Detroit and Memphis. Continental has mostly an east-west route network, with major hubs in Houston, Newark and Denver.
If no combination results, Mr. Ferguson said, Continental could go it alone. Airlines and investors who had been interested in the airline like USAir and Marvin Davis, the West Coast investor, have dropped out of the running.
He said Continental expected to file a reorganization plan as early as next month.
If its traffic holds up and its cost- cutting comes out on target, the airline should be bringing in more cash than it spends by spring, Mr. Ferguson said. He predicted that Continental could then have its reorganization plan accepted by the bankruptcy judge.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert R. Ferguson, the chief executive of Continental Airlines, during an interview yesterday. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Yields Fall On C.D.'s and Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts declined for still another week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the North Palm Beach, Fla., publication that covers interest rates.
"There has been no letup in the downward speed of certificate of deposit yields," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. "This evidence continues to suggest that another cut in the Federal discount rate and the banks' prime rate could occur soon." 
 At New York area institutions, rates are still being cut at a rapid pace, The Monitor said.
The largest change in money market funds among New York area banks was made by Astoria Federal Savings, which cut its money market fund yield by 11 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.01 percent. Chemical Banking made the largest cut in three-month certificates of deposit, dropping the yield 11 basis points, to 4.33 percent. As for six-month certificates, First Nationwide made the biggest move, cutting the yield by 25 points, to 5.10 percent.
Among the commercial banks in New York, the average yield on money market accounts has been cut to 4.69 percent, down a basis point; the average yield on three-month certificates of deposit was down 4 points, to 4.88 percent, and it dropped by the same amount for six-month certificates, which now average 4.97 percent.
For depositors at savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut to 5.26, down 3 basis points for money market accounts; to 5.32, down 4 basis points for three-month certificates, and to 5.53, down 6 basis points, for six-month certificates.
The Monitor reported the average yields at 20 major banks outside the New York area had been cut by 2 basis points, to 4.92 percent, on their money market accounts, and by 3 points, to 5.17 percent, for six-month certificates.
By comparison, at the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction yesterday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 4.99 percent, well below the rate the previous Monday, while the six-month bill averaged 5.03, also sharply lower.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lukens Looks Ahead In Naming a President

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Lukens Inc., which specializes in making plate steel, said yesterday that R. William Van Sant, a former president and chief executive of Blount Inc., a construction company that also makes power equipment, would become the steel producer's president and chief operating officer.
Lukens also said that Mr. Van Sant, a director since 1988, would become chairman and chief executive after W. R. Wilson retires next June. 
 The company, based in Coatesville, Pa., is the nation's third-largest producer of plate steel, which is used in construction, shipbuilding and transportation. The company has also developed a growing business making highway products, as well as providing goods and services for the mining and energy industries.
Lukens's financial health has been notably stronger than most steel producers. But a strike that began two weeks ago by the United Steelworkers union might affect results for the rest of the year. Despite the company's lower sales and earnings for the first half of this year, analysts say its performance should improve along with the economy.
Mr. Van Sant, 53 years old, who has extensive experience in manufacturing, aerospace and construction services, replaces Harry I. Skilton, who resigned in September. The company said Mr. Skilton left "to pursue other business interests."
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Van Sant said his primary objective would be to "continue the strategy that has been set for growth and value." He added: "Lukens is a very strong company that is positioned for continued growth. The company's financial health and strength is an asset that we want to be sure to build upon."
Mr. Van Sant joined Blount in 1987 and had been president and chief executive the company, based in Montgomery, Ala., since 1990. Before that, he served as president and chief operating officer of the Cessna Aircraft Company. He had eariler served as vice president of manufacturing and engineering at Deere & Company, where he worked for 26 years.
He holds bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Iowa. He is married and has three sons and two daughters.

HEADLINE: Why Seidman Stayed On For an Extra Year of Duty

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
In his last full day as the nation's senior banking regulator, L. William Seidman said he would have left more than a year ago had he not been assailed by the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu.
"Absolutely no question about it," Mr. Seidman said as he prepared to relinquish the chairmanship of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation. Referring to his visit to the White House in the spring of 1990 and the personality clash with Mr. Sununu, who sought very publicly then to push him out the door, Mr. Seidman said, "I went over there with the purpose of arranging an amicable, friendly and smooth transition." 
 In an interview over sandwiches in his bare sixth-floor corner office overlooking the Washington Monument and the Mall, Mr. Seidman made these other points:
*None of the nation's largest banks are in danger of failing.
*In the first three months of next year, the F.D.I.C. may be forced to consider another increase in the premiums it charges banks to insure deposits.
*The Administration's attack on bank examiners and regulators, accusing them of helping cause tighter credit, could lead to dangerously lax supervisory standards.
*As long ago as 1986, senior regulators, including himself, saw many of the warning signs for the crises now afflicting the banking and savings and loan industries but did not move vigorously enough to contain the problems.
*If the economy grows next year at a rate slower than 3.5 percent to 4 percent, as measured by the gross national product, the costs of bailing out banks and savings and loans might be significantly higher than current Administration estimates. Many economists have forecast a growth rate lower than that, but Mr. Seidman stood by the Administration's estimates today. He did say, however, that the estimates might be revised based on a new F.D.I.C. review that will be sent to the Office of Management and Budget this month.
Mr. Seidman leaves office as the bank insurance fund is on the verge of borrowing tens of billions of taxpayer dollars and regulators are seeking another $80 billion for the savings and loan rescue.
In his six years as its outspoken chairman, he has built the F.D.I.C. from a backwater agency to one of the most powerful institutions in the nation, doling out billions of dollars in contracts and determining the fate of the country's most important financial institutions. He also supervised the growth of Resolution Trust into one of the largest financial institutions in the world, but one that is struggling to unload a huge portfolio of real estate.
At points during the hour-and-a-half interview, the 71-year-old regulator from East Grand Rapids, Mich., recounted his ups and downs with the Bush Administration and his running battles with Congress and its investigative arm, the General Accounting Office. Other times he was politely evasive, clearly saving his juiciest anecdotes for his memoirs.
 
A Rough Draft
 "The first chapter on the Administration," he said, "starts out with the sentences: 'If there was one thing I learned in my first tour of duty in Washington, it was not to get in a battle with the President's chief of staff. Here follows the story of how I was unable to carry that out.' "
He said he would disclose his future plans, besides writing the book, on Wednesday.
He said that while the savings and loan bailout would probably wind up costing $250 billion, as a practical matter, Americans would pay for it forever because of the long-term borrowing costs. He said it would be unwise to pay for the bailout costs now by either raising taxes or cutting other Federal programs, particularly as the economy struggles to rebound.
He also took a swipe at the General Accounting Office, which in recent months forced the F.D.I.C. to drastically lower its valuation of the bank insurance fund from about $8 billion to about $4 billion and refused to certify the finances of Resolution Trust.
While acknowledging the accounting office's legitimate role as as auditor, he criticized it for issuing what he said were misleading news releases. "They should stop acting like they were a part of the ball game instead of an observer," he said.
In looking back at how the banking industry's troubles grew, Mr. Seidman recalled that as early as 1986 he had spoken about how banks were making too many risky loans and that private and public debt was growing at unprecedented rates.
 
Yellow Light, Red Light
 "I said in a speech in 1986 in San Francisco that we must decrease high debt levels and proceed with care and that the flashing yellow caution light is operational," he said. "The mistake was that I should've said the red light is flashing, not the yellow light."
Recalling his speech, which denounced large debt levels, he said, "What I'm saying is: My greatest regret is that I didn't listen to what I said carefully enough."
Of the economy and the weak condition of many large banks, Mr. Seidman observed: "Banks are so time sensitive because the longer recession lasts, the more capital is used up for those who are losing money. If we see an estimate that's higher than $10 billion in losses to the bank insurance fund, then I think we will have to raise bank premiums."
