HEADLINE: Economics Nobel to a Basic Thinker

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Ronald H. Coase, a British-born 81-year-old economist retired from the University of Chicago Law School, was awarded the $1 million Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences yesterday.
The work for which he was cited is almost as remarkable for its brevity and accessibility to non-economists as for its profundity. Unlike many of the recent economics prize winners, Mr. Coase is known for his thinking on the role of institutions in the economy -- work that contains little or no mathematics. 
 One of his key articles explains why companies exist -- why, for example, there is a McDonald's rather than 100,000 individual entrepreneurs selling hamburgers and french fries on every street corner.
 
Regulating Noxious Behavior
 Another important work argues that markets may be better than laws in regulating pollution and other noxious behavior of producers. And while some of his conclusions seem obvious now, they helped redirect thinking in critical areas of economic theory.
The new Nobel laureate was vacationing in Europe and could not be reached for comment. But fellow professionals were eager to sing his praises, crediting him with revolutionizing the way economists and legal scholars analyze the push-and-shove of the marketplace.
"He is the most original thinker I've come across in economics," said Michael E. Levine, dean of the Yale School of Management.
"He knows markets with every fiber of his being," added Daniel Kasper, a researcher at Harbridge House in Boston.
The core of Mr. Coase's work -- the work cited by the Royal Swedish Academy -- is found in just two academic papers. A 1937 article, "The Theory of the Firm," asks why companies exist if production can also be organized as a chain of individual market transactions among people who are buying and selling everything from the labor to mine the iron ore to a finished car.
The answer, that the company eliminates uncertainty and costly one-time negotiations by creating stable contractual relationships, seems too simple to be important. But Michael Levine of Yale points out that by focusing on how companies are constructed around contracts between parties with disparate knowledge and diverse interests, Mr. Coase breathed new life into the stagnant field of industrial organization.
The second article, "The Problem of Social Cost," published in 1960, is the stuff of myth in law and economics. Here Mr. Coase challenged the classic economic logic behind the common law practice of enjoining behavior that damages others.
He offered the example of a steam locomotive that spews sparks as it crosses a farmer's field. By the standard view, laws and courts are needed to settle the question of who is responsible for preventing fire damage. But Mr. Coase argued that a clear assignment of rights and responsibilities was not necessary to minimize losses. What is needed, he said, are low "transactions costs" -- creating a method for the farmer and the railroad to bargain easily and speedily.
The farmer can prevent fires by keeping the right-of-way free of crops. Or the railroad can prevent fires by equipping the locomotives with equipment to suppress sparks. Regardless of the legal equities, it pays both to work out a way to assign the responsibility on whomever does the job at least cost.
 
Complicating Problems
 The real world, of course, is rarely so simple. There may be dozens of farmers along the right-of-way growing a dozen different crops at different seasons. Bargaining may be complicated by the fact that only the railroad knows what it would cost to suppress sparks. And negotiations over even simple issues may fail to achieve low-cost solutions because parties misread each others' intentions.
But by forcing economists and lawyers to rethink the question, Mr. Coase focused the attention of legal scholars on what it takes to make markets work efficiently without government to call balls and strikes. And in the process, said William Landes, an economist at the University of Chicago Law School, it has pushed scholars to think more about how to drive conflict toward negotiation rather than litigation.
Other research by Mr. Coase has had less impact, but was important in its own right. His barely noticed 1950 analysis of the Federal Communications Commission, which introduced the idea that access to the airwaves was a form of property, was decades ahead of its time. Economists now believe that Washington's failure to treat the radio spectrum as a scarce resource, to be allocated via markets to those who value it most, is reducing national productivity by billions of dollars.
His work on regulation attacked the longstanding paradox that "natural monopolies," like telephone systems and electricity grids, could never operate efficiently unless they set prices below cost. Richard A. Posner, a Federal appeals court judge who was formerly a colleague of Mr. Coase at Chicago, credits the argument with "deflecting economists from a research dead end."
Born in England in 1910, Mr. Coase graduated from the London School of Economics in 1932, and taught there from 1935 to 1951. He moved to the Univerity of Buffalo in 1951, and then to the University of Virginia. Since 1964 he has taught at the University of Chicago.
In this six-decade academic career, he published just a dozen research papers of significance. But for Robert Cooter, an economist at the Boalt School of Law at the University of California, that is just one more reason why Mr. Coase is a scholar's scholar. "Most economists maximize the amount they write," he said. "Coase maximized the amount others wrote about his work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald H. Coase, who was named the recipient yesterday of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Net Fell 84.5% In 3d Period

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. came out with some grim earnings numbers yesterday, but after the company indicated that the worst might finally be over, its stock price rose sharply, buoying the whole stock market.
The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, said its third-quarter earnings fell 84.5 percent, on a 5.6 percent revenue decline, but it also said it had made progress in reducing its work force and bringing several important product lines to market. 
 Central to its positive outlook is success in cutting costs. I.B.M. has been struggling for years to reduce its costs significantly and yesterday's report showed that its sales, general and administrative costs declined for the first time in almost 20 years.
 
Cuts in the Payroll
 These expenses were down 1 percent after discounting for the effect of a special $100 million charge to cover the additional costs that arose when more employees than were expected took incentives to leave the company. The company told analysts that research and development expenses also declined by about 1 percent last quarter.
The stock market liked the company's assessment. After an initial decline of $2.125, I.B.M.'s stock recovered strongly, ending with a $3 gain, to $104.25. It was the fourth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than three million shares changing hands. The Dow Jones industrial average followed the leader, rising 21.92, to 3,041.37. [Page D10.]
"The year-to-year numbers were ugly, but under the surface it was a pretty good report," said Stephen Cohen, a computer industry analyst at the Soundview Financial Group. "Expenses were under excellent control."
 
Trouble Is Industrywide
 Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, added, "Any technology company earnings report that is not a disaster is pretty much good news these days."
I.B.M. has been trying to alter its business model in recent years to survive in a more competitive industry by slashing staff through a series of voluntary inducements. The company's work force has now declined by about 50,000 since it peaked at 406,000 in 1985. Yesterday the company said it expected to reduce the head count by about 20,000 this year, almost 3,000 more than it had previously stated.
"Although business conditions remain unsettled, we expect improvement in the pace of our business as shipments of our new product line build," I.B.M.'s chairman, John F. Akers, said in a statement.
For the quarter ended Sept. 30, the Armonk, N.Y., computer maker's revenue was $14.43 billion, down from $15.28 billion. Earnings were $172 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $1.11 billion, or $1.95, in the 1990 period.
A number of analysts said they still saw signs for concern based on continued pressures from price competition and the recession.
Rick Martin of Prudential Securities said he was cutting his estimate for the fourth quarter based on an unexpected decline in gross margins on equipment. He said he estimated that gross margins were probably no better than 47 or 47.5 percent for the quarter compared with an expected 55 percent. He said he spoke to the company yesterday and was told that I.B.M. expects margins to only partly return at the end of the year.
 
'A Nasty Situation'
 "It's really a nasty situation," he said. "I think that Wall Street earnings estimates are going to trail off during the quarter."
He said he attributed the margin decline to pricing pressures, underuse of capacity during the recession and the effect of product introductions, which slow initial sales.
The company appears to be making a strong transition to its new line of mainframes, several analysts said. I.B.M. began shipping its new family of top-of-the-line processors last month, and its strength in the fourth quarter is largely dependent on the success of the new machines. But a number of questions remain on price issues analysts said. If the company is forced to offer deep discounts to sell its new machines, which are for the largest corporations, it will subtract significantly from fourth-quarter earnings.
"The big question is price," Mr. Milunovich said.
 
Aggressive Offerings
 Separately, I.B.M. told analysts in a telephone conference call that it believed its market share in the personal computer market would hold for the year, after a decline in the first half. Several analysts said that the company would show a number of aggressive desktop offerings shortly and that it expected its new machines to make up ground that it had lost recently to clone companies like Dell Computer and Zeos.
During the morning conference call the company said United States sales continued to decline during the quarter, but that the decline was slower than the previous quarter. As a result the company said that the economy might have bottomed out and that it expected an improving economy in the fourth quarter.
I.B.M. also said sales of mainframes, computer storage devices and low-end personal computers had declined so far this year on a year-to-year basis, while its AS-400 minicomputer and RS/6000 work station lines had shown increases.
The company also said its European business declined compared with the second quarter of 1991.

HEADLINE: Iacocca Urges U.S. Limits on Japanese Car Sales

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Oct. 15

 BODY:
Lee A. Iacocca said today that the Big Three auto makers should consider promoting Federal legislation to limit the Japanese car industry to a fixed percentage of the American market.
Speaking at the dedication of the Chrysler Corporation's $1 billion technology center outside Detroit, Mr. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said: "We've never favored a complete restriction, but we'll have to decide our collective position. We have to deal with our own self-interests. At some point, you have to decide what you stand for." 
 The nation is "out of the electronics business, the VCR business, and soon we could be out of the car business," he added.
 
Others Not Consulted
 Mr. Iacocca said he had not discussed the idea with executives of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation or the Bush Administration. A G.M. spokesman said he was not aware of any such proposal under consideration by the company, and a Ford official did not provide an immediate response to a telephone call seeking comment.
The Chrysler chairman's remarks seemed to be motivated by a growing sense of desperation that Japanese competition and a weak economy were mortally wounding the nation's largest manufacturing industry.
But the 67-year-old Mr. Iacocca, who will retire at the end of next year, dismissed questions about Chrysler's viability over the coming 10 months, saying the company thought its new products, including a four-door Jeep that goes into production in early 1992, would increase cash-flow substantially.
"We're in good shape, and have plenty of backstops," he said. "We still have a $1.75 billion revolving credit line that we've paid fees on for 10 years that we haven't touched."
A limit of market share, like the 16 percent cap imposed last summer by the European Community through 1999, would cover all cars and trucks sold by Japanese manufacturers, including those assembled at American factories, or transplants, like the Honda Motor Company's plant in Marysville, Ohio. Japanese producers now sell about 31 percent of the cars sold in the United States.
It was not immediately clear today how Mr. Iacocca's proposal would treat Japanese components, which are found in most domestic models, or vehicles built in joint-venture plants but sold by domestic manufacturers. General Motors's Geo Prizm car, for example, is built in Fremont, Calif., but has an engine made by the Toyota Motor Corporation.
The European laws on market share do not cover Japanese vehicles built in North America, like the Honda station wagon now sold in several European countries.
A ceiling on the number of vehicles that could be sold by Japanese auto makers is the most extreme proposal so far to help ailing American car makers, whose cumulative losses in the last year have totaled about $6 billion. Despite voluntary export restraints by the Japanese starting in 1981, the industry has steadily lost ground against Japanese auto makers.
In recent years, the number of Japanese imports has fallen as the number of vehicles produced by their transplants has increased. Indeed, most Japanese producers are importing substantially fewer vehicles than are permitted under the voluntary restraint agreement.
Democratic legislators have recently been exploring the possibility of following the European model to cap overall sales of Japanese cars. No one has offered a bill yet, but prospects for passage would be uncertain, given the Japanese industry's efforts to build an American infrastructure of plants, workers, research labs and lobbyists.
 
Most Damage to Chrysler
 Chrysler, as the smallest of the Big Three, has experienced the most serious financial damage. Its debt securities have been downgraded to junk-bond status, and it was recently forced to raise equity capital when its stock price was at a 10-year low.
In recent weeks, the car maker's rhetoric against the country's trade imbalance with Japan has grown sharper. Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler president, criticized American trade policy, comparing United States consumption of Japanese-made products to the behavior of an alcoholic.
Separately, Mr. Iacocca acknowledged that Chrysler was close to agreement with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation for the sale to Mitsubishi of Chrysler's 50 percent stake in the companies' Diamond-Star assembly plant venture in Bloomington, Ill.

HEADLINE: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Down 11.4%

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Sales declines of 11.4 percent for domestically built cars and light trucks in early October were reported today.
Analysts said the drop was expected, because widespread incentives helped increase sales late last month. They also noted that car sales over the last 30 days were in line with recent months. 
 "We're in a holding pattern," said Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
 
Ford Battles G.M.
 Some of the biggest incentives last month were offered by the Ford Motor Company, the nation's No. 2 car maker, and the General Motors Corporation, the leader. The Chrysler Corporation also offered incentives on many of its cars and light trucks.
"Now we're getting pay-back for sales shifted forward into late September by Detroit's race for bragging rights," said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco.
Dealers said low consumer confidence remained a drag on sales. Some shoppers are also finding prices of the new 1992 models, which average more than $16,000, out of reach, the dealers said.
"They're saying they'd like to have it, but they can't afford it," said Quitman Tisdale, the sales manager of Andalusia Motor Company, a Ford and Mercury dealership in Andalusia, Ala., near the Florida line.
Tom Webb, the chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, an industry group based in McLean, Va., said: "It's simply a matter of money; people don't have enough. Household net worth continues to erode, job prospects have failed to brighten, and nominal wage gains are modest at best."
 
Brighter Days Ahead
 Nevertheless, many automobile industry experts have predicted that car sales will improve, in part because of the aging fleet of cars on the road -- the mean age is 7.5 years.
George Koulouris, the general manager of J. Thomas Honda in Watertown, Conn., said a growing number of his recent sales had been from so-called need buyers. "We're seeing a lot more older vehicles coming back," he said, some with more than 100,000 miles.
On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.5 million in the Oct. 1-10 period. Last year, cars sold at a 6.5 million rate in early October. Sales have shown gradual improvement in the first three quarters of the year, rising to about 6.3 million in the third quarter, from 6 million in the first.
The 10 domestic car makers sold 160,286 cars in early October, and 79,595 light trucks, a category that includes mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles, as well as pickup trucks.
 
Big Three Down 18.9%
 The Big Three posted a collective sales decline of 18.9 percent in car sales during early October, while Japanese companies with factories in the United States, or "transplants," reported an overall increase of 38.5 percent. Models that posted strong gains include the Honda Accord, for which sales jumped by 60 percent, to 9,481, in the period.
The transplants raised their share of the American car market to 16.8 percent in early October, from 10.6 percent a year earlier.
Of the Big Three, G.M.'s car sales dropped by 19.2 percent, to 71,921, and the company's light-truck sales dropped by 9.7 percent, to 31,828.
Ford reported a drop of 3.4 percent in its car sales, to 47,506, and in its light-truck sales, to 26,447, or 17.5 percent.
Chrysler does not report its monthly sales, but Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication, estimated that the company's car sales dropped by 47 percent, to 13,900. But Chrysler's truck sales jumped 6.2 percent, to 17,800, Ward's estimated.
Of the transplants, the Honda Motor Company reported a sales increase of 45.6 percent in the period, to 13,560, on its cars.

HEADLINE: Japanese Coin Word for Their Unease About U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
A former national security director for Japan, Atsuyuki Sassa, wrote recently that Americans were still "intoxicated with a war-victory mood," though they had done little to overcome economic stagnation, drugs, declining schools and other problems.
Kazuo Inamori, chairman of the Kyocera Corporation, a major high- technology company, also took this general theme, an increasingly popular one, writing in a recent article that Japanese were growing tired of feeling that "America doesn't like us or respect us despite our efforts." 
 In fact, a new word has has been coined here to describe the phenomenon behind these thoughts. The word is "kenbei," meaning "dislike of the United States," and its use appears to be growing.
"There have always been ups and downs in the image of the United States in Japan," said Seizaburo Sato, professor of political science at Tokyo University. "But there is a growing concern in Japan over the decline of American work ethics, moral principles, the quality of American products.
"Most Japanese realize that the world needs a strong, healthy and economically dynamic United States," Mr. Sato said. "So all these trends are a source of concern."
 
New Word for Old Feeling
 The term kenbei has been used only since the beginning of this year, reflecting the pent-up feelings of frustration and criticism of the United States accumulating for many years on the basis of friction over trade issues, cultural differences and a number of other points of disagreement between the two countries.
For Japanese, these feelings were sharply focused by the negative reaction in this country to the seeming eagerness of the United States to go to war in the Persian Gulf. Criticism of Japan's role in the gulf appears to have brought these emotions out into the open, resulting in some criticism of the United States that is unusually harsh and direct by Japanese standards.
Still, the Japanese remain in love with American culture, from jazz to blue jeans to movies with Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger. Moreover, many polls show that there is now a national consensus supporting the existing Japan-United States security treaty.
"Only a small minority of Japanese have a deep-rooted antipathy to the United States," said Yukio Okamoto, a former diplomat who is now a business consultant.
 
U.S. as Bully
 But he added that "there is a growing feeling that on trade issues, the United States is bullying Japan, arrogantly making demands on every trivial matter that does not comply with the American standard of justice."
A senior Foreign Ministry official said the pattern was caused by American pressure on trade issues and accusations that Japan did not respond quickly or generously enough to help the war against Iraq. In the end, Japan contributed $13 billion, or a quarter of the cost of the war.
"We may have been somewhat clumsy and slow, but we did our best," the official said. "Now we in Japan don't like it that the United States is not giving us any credit."
Whether the demand is that Tokyo end its ban on rice imports or that Japanese fishermen stop using big drift nets, or that Japanese stockbrokers and businessmen end what are deemed collusive business practices, the criticism is increasingly seen here as "Japan bashing."
 
See America as Threat
 The Foreign Ministry has become so concerned about the issue that it commissioned a study by Professor Sato this year to uncover the factors involved in kenbei. Professor Sato and others said they were not at liberty to discuss the poll numbers that document the trend.
But just as Americans now have a different view of the world after the cold war, so 24 percent of those polled by the Yomiuri newspaper three months ago said they regarded the United States as a security threat, while only 22 percent said they saw the Soviet Union as a similar threat. Among people in their 20's, the group regarding the United States as a security threat was 33 percent.
The existence of rising kenbei is considered important especially as Japan chooses a successor to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Kiichi Miyazawa, the former Deputy Prime Minister who has the support of the largest faction of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, said he foresaw no major changes in Japan's relations with the United States, but he was said to have been a skeptic on the Persian Gulf war.
 
Hopes for Bush's Visit
 American and Japanese officials are sufficiently concerned about the kenbei trend that they are pinning great hopes on President Bush's visit to Japan, scheduled for November. Diplomats are working on a document reaffirming the alliance, called the "Japan-United States Charter," as a way of rallying popular support for the relationship.
To many scholars and critics, the word kenbei itself tells a lot about the complicated nature of Japanese feelings. The sense of the word is that one can be in favor of the Japanese-American security relationship, for instance, but still feel dislike or distaste about American tendencies perceived here as arrogance and the sense that Japan is being blamed for problems that are of America's own making.
In contrast, Japanese have long had the term "hanbei," roughly equivalent to "anti-American" with a connotation of distinct opposition to the United States; hanbei is a mostly ideological concept, in the context of the cold war. While there has always been a strong left-wing anti-American strain in Japan, hanbei has by all indications declined since the days of anti-American riots in the 1950's and 1960's, only to be replaced by rising kenbei.
In the current Bungei Shunju, a prestigious monthly magazine, Tsuneo Iida, professor of economics at the International Research Center for Japanese Studies in Kyoto, accused Americans of being too critical of Japan's recent stock market scandals.
 
Defense of Scandals
 To American businessmen, the scandals have revealed shocking levels of insider trading, favoritism and market manipulation by big brokers on behalf of their well-heeled clients. Rather than criticize, Professor Iida said Americans should recognize that such practices were once common in the United States.
"American manufacturing in the old days closely resembles Japanese manufacturing today," he wrote. "If Americans call that 'unfair,' they are only spitting on their forefathers."
Discussing kenbei, Professor Iida said: "I personally do not hate America. I am not saying Americans are all bad. But at least I would like to say, 'You Americans have no right to blame us.' "
Mr. Inamori, the president of Kyocera, wrote in one of several symposia in Japanese magazines on the topic of Japanese-American relations that "the debate over the gulf war has only abetted the kenbei tendency, particularly among the young generation that does not know World War II and its aftermath."
In another article, Yoshimi Ishikawa, author of a book on farm workers in California and other non-fiction books, wrote, "In response to the force displayed by America, there is emerging among Japanese a move from fear toward something like nascent hatred."
 
Focus on an Infamous Date
 Several recent articles have focused on plans to observe the anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. Many say they fear that Americans will use the anniversary to revive criticism of Tokyo as untrustworthy and aggressive.
Takanori Irie, a professor at Meiji University in Tokyo, said Japan suffered from the aftermath of three wars: World War II, the cold war and the gulf war. He said Japan had an "Anglo-Saxon neurosis" that made it slavishly follow the views of the West, particularly the United States.
Perhaps the most revealing recent criticism of the United States came in articles by Kazuo Ogura, director general of cultural affairs at the Foreign Ministry. Indeed, the Ministry translated the articles and included them in a pamphlet of "representative" thinking in Japan.
Mr. Ogura wrote in the Gaiko Forum, a Japanese-language magazine published by the Foreign Ministry, that criticism of Japanese investments in the United States showed that "American people are not yet psychologically prepared to accept dependence on Japan."
 
New Suit of Clothes
 Japanese, he said, feel "a vaguely unsettling sensation" when they are asked by Americans to fight and die for such concepts as "freedom, democracy and the market economy." These values, he said, have no Japanese roots and feel like "a new suit of Western clothes" to most Japanese.
"To many Japanese," Mr. Ogura wrote, "the American approach to Japan comes across as an attempt to create a spiritual colony of the United States on Japanese soil." Such an approach, he said, violates "the fundamentals of friendly relations between countries."
Mr. Ogura used such words as "unease," "anguish," "agony" and "despair" to describe Japanese reactions to American pressure nowadays.
"Those on the U.S. side are still leaning heavily on Japan, never reflecting on their own country's shortcomings," he concluded. "And those on the Japanese side are still bowing before the American demands, as if doing so was Japan's fate."

HEADLINE: Chicago Journal;
A Library Opens to Revive and Heal

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
At a time when cities around the country are either closing libraries or cutting their hours to save money, Chicago has opened a $144 million neo-classical library building in an ailing downtown business area.
The new library, the Harold Washington Library Center, is named for Chicago's first black Mayor and, city officials say, is the nation's largest municipal lending library. It is already seen as a healer of political bruises and a symbol of urban revival. 
 The 750,000-square-foot central library is intended to be the first of several renovation projects in the South Loop, an area largely neglected by developers in the boom years of the 1980's. Until recently, the area consisted mostly of fast-food restaurants and parking lots.
The former Goldblatt's department store building, which is a block north of the new library and has been vacant for 10 years, was bought last winter by DePaul University, which plans a $70 million renovation to include classrooms, offices and retail stores. And the nearby former Sears building, also empty for several years, has already been converted into offices.
City officials are working on a development strategy for South Loop property owners, and hope the library, on State and Congress Streets, will fuel a revival of the area.
"The library was located at that site as a revitalization project for that area," said Marcel Acosta of the city's planning department. "We hope to use it as a development catalyst."
The library's other, and perhaps less tangible, role is in healing some of the scars left by the bitter racial politics that Mayor Washington had to deal with in his six years in office.
In the dedication ceremonies and in the news media's coverage of the library's opening, public officials, some of whom were vociferous opponents of Mr. Washington, praised his love for books and his pride in Chicago, and seemingly put aside the divisive politics of that era.
Noting that the former Mayor's name adorns the stone arch above the library's main entrance, Vera Wardlaw, a special-education teacher who sat with her West Side students at the ribbon-cutting ceremony on Friday, said: "Harold Washington is a name that all the children know. This is just going to enhance the name as well as the library."
Although Chicago's budget is stretched as thinly as those of other major cities, officials said the library, which was financed largely by a bond issue, was a priority. The city has budgeted $11 million for book acquisitions this year and embarked on a program to renovate 15 of the system's 84 branch libraries at a cost of $30 million.
The new library houses two million books in 90 languages, a 400-seat auditorium, an 18,000-square-foot children's library and a glass-enclosed winter garden on the ninth floor.
"Yes, budgets are tight, but you have to spend money for some things, and this is something we consider a priority," said Avis LaVelle, the spokeswoman for Mayor Richard M. Daley.
It has taken almost 70 years for the city to get around to building a central library. In 1922 the president of the library board announced that the city's book collection had outgrown its home on Washington Street, and since then succeeding boards have pushed for a new library.
It was not until 1973 that most of the central collection was moved to a temporary site in a warehouse along the Chicago River. After 15 years of debate over where to build a new library, city officials settled on the current site.
The new central library has generated some debate. Librarians at the city's 84 branches contend that it is syphoning money and staff members from the already underfinanced and understaffed branches. And some architects charge say the building's massive brick exterior is intimidating and conservative.
Such arguments are unlikely to deter library users. A dozen people waited outside in 35-degree temperatures for the library to open on Monday.
Carrie Staley, an unemployed sales clerk, was seated in the periodicals section reading a paperback autobiography of the basketball star Magic Johnson. "I've been waiting for this," she said. "It gives me a place to go and sit and read and think about a few things. We all need a place for that."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The children's reading of Chicago's $144 million new Harold Washington Library Center. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Seen Facing New State Budget Gap

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 15

 BODY:
After receiving a State Comptroller's report showing the state with a modest cash imbalance, Cuomo administration officials said today that the state may once again be facing a gap in its budget.
The report, which analyzes the state's cash flow after the first six months of its fiscal year, showed a cash imbalance of $155.2 million in the state's approximately $29 billion general-fund budget. The general fund is the part of the budget financed with state taxes and fees. 
 The $155 million imbalance is considered mild, particularly in light of recent budget gaps that have soared into the billions of dollars. But aides to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo expressed concern about some of the recession-driven trends suggested by the Comptroller's report, particularly softness in personal-income-tax collections and unexpectedly heavy expenditures on Medicaid and other social services.
 
Impact of Recession
 "It confirms what the Governor's been saying for weeks, that our state's economy, like other states' economies, is continuing to feel the impact of the national recession," said Anne W. Crowley, the Governor's press secretary. "We don't think it's incorrect that there's a softness and there may be a gap at the end of the year."
Mr. Cuomo's budget office will spend the next two weeks analyzing the raw data in the report prepared by the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan. The budget office is scheduled to release a midyear economic forecast on Oct. 30 that would project the size of any potential budget gap.
Last year, the Legislature had to return to Albany for a special session in December to close a $1 billion gap in the 1990-91 state budget. Because only three months were left in the fiscal year, which begins on April 1, the lawmakers and Mr. Cuomo had to enact the largest package of midyear spending cuts in state history.
Even then, the cuts did not go far enough. The state ultimately had to borrow $900 million more through the sale of short-term notes to close that deficit at the end of the fiscal year.
 
Largest Source of Funds
 As it did last year, Mr. Regan's midyear report showed that the personal income tax, which is the largest source of state funds, was generating less revenue than anticipated. It was down by $127.5 million.
Some of the softness in the personal income tax was offset by the better-than-expected performance of business and sales taxes. But what has created the most concern is spending on social services. The Comptroller's report showed that disbursements to local governments for social services, which pay for grants to welfare and Medicaid recipients, was up 17 percent over the first six months of last year.
The driving force seems to be Medicaid spending, which has risen by 18 percent. The state had anticipated growth of 3 percent in Medicaid spending for the fiscal year, said Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the State Budget Division.
 
Delayed Reimbursements
 Ms. Hutton said her office could not yet gauge the real impact of the Medicaid and income-tax figures on the size of a potential budget gap.
The Medicaid numbers, for instance, could be skewed by delayed reimbursements from the Federal Government, faster than expected billings from health-care providers, and cost-containment initiatives that will not be felt until the second half of the year.
But they could also be the product of unexpected increases in the Medicaid caseload. The state had budgeted for 7 percent growth in the Medicaid caseload, and it has been 9 percent so far this year, Ms. Hutton said.
The income-tax problem is largely due to a miscalculation of how many jobs would be lost in the recession. The state has lost about 300,000 jobs since May 1990, 140,000 more than the Cuomo administration had projected earlier this year, Ms. Hutton said.

HEADLINE: They Came to California for the Good Life; Now They're Looking Elsewhere

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The enormous migration to California from other states, which brought profound political and economic consequences over the last decade, appears to have slowed substantially.
Demographers and geographers attribute the slowing largely to the recession, which has hit California particularly hard, leaving its once-robust economy to bring up the rear of the national recovery. But they also point to many other factors, including high housing costs, air pollution, traffic congestion, crime, deteriorating social services and fear of earthquakes and other disasters. 
 Most tellingly, for the first time since these figures have been tracked, more young people from the age of 30 to age 44 left California for other states than moved in during the 12 months ending June 30, based on figures from the state's Department of Finance. Among them were Robert and Mara Shlachter, who recently pulled up their roots in Los Angeles, took a cut in income and moved to Portland, Ore.
 
Concern Among Leaders
 "We wanted to be in a smaller community," said Mr. Shlachter, a 44-year-old lawyer. "We wanted to get around more easily, see friends more easily and enjoy the outdoors readily."
The loss of such families is stirring deep concern among California's leaders. "It's troubling when it's people in their productive years," the State Treasurer, Kathleen Brown, said in an interview. "But it's not surprising, given the problems California faces that have not been solved."
She added, though, that the state could benefit from a pause in immigration to allow it to "catch up" in rebuilding roads and schools and other needs.
In addition, the outflow of such younger people comes as a growing number of companies are relocating to other states, galvanizing officials and business leaders in efforts to retain jobs.
 
Total Population Is Up
 Despite the slowing of domestic migration, the population of California continues to grow substantially because of a high birth rate and foreign immigration.
The lure of California has not always been irresistible to other Americans. During two other recent recessions, in the early 1970's and early 1980's, the flood of migrants narrowed to a trickle and then rebounded with a vengeance when the economy improved.
But some economists see the current shift as part of a broader and more enduring movement of population and economic activity inward, away from both the East and West Coasts to the Rocky Mountain, Midwestern and Southern states, where the costs of living and doing business are much lower. If so, the validity of numerous forecasts of continued swelling of the California population may be called into question, with implications for politics, schools and many industries, including housing and retailing.
A slowdown will be welcomed by many Californians, especially environmentalists, who say uncontrolled population growth has caused traffic congestion, pollution and other problems that have ruined a state that many once considered something of an earthly paradise.
 
Working With Assuptions
 On the other hand, numerous business and government agencies, like homebuilders and school districts, have drawn plans based on the assumption that the state's population would continue to grow at extremely high rates.
The new trends emerge from shifts of driver's licenses between states, which demographers say offer a more current picture of domestic migration than the decennial census. According to data compiled by analysts at the California Department of Finance, the number of licenses that were changed to California from the 49 other states and the District of Columbia dropped to 376,000 in 1990-91 from a peak of 437,000 in 1988-89, while the number changed to other states has increased even faster.
Demographers estimate that every change in one driver's license corresponds to a shift of 1.5 people; if so, the net movement of Americans to California dropped to about 55,500 during the last fiscal year from 208,500 two years ago.
 
Big 'Natural Increase'
 This does not suggest that the state has stopped its rapid growth. Even with no domestic migration, California's "natural increase," the term demographers use for the excess of births over deaths, continues to outpace the national average because of the large population of Hispanic residents and other minorities in the state whose birth rates tend to be high.
In addition, there is immigration from foreign countries, both legal and illegal; in recent years, California has received by far the largest number of such immigrants of any state. Recent data from the Immigration and Naturalization Service show that legal foreign immigration to California has remained constant since the current recession started, at a rate of about 185,000 a year.
According to the 1990 census, the state registered a staggering 26 percent increase in population in the last decade, to 29.8 million in 1990 from 23.7 million in 1980. That was more than twice the national average and gave California seven new seats in Congress. Of that growth by 6.1 million, natural increase accounted for about 3.4 million, foreign immigration 1.9 million and migration from other states 824,000.
The domestic migration, about 13 percent of this growth, was important politically because, unlike newborns and foreign immigrants, most of these new residents could vote almost immediately.
The slackening of domestic migration comes against a backdrop of deepening economic troubles here. Even as the national unemployment rate dipped slightly in September to 6.7 percent, California's rate rose to 7.7 percent, with a 9.3 percent rate for Los Angeles County, the most populous county in the United States and about a third of the state's population. The county has been hard hit by layoffs in the military and aerospace industries,banking and retailing. As a whole, the state lost 240,000 jobs during the last fiscal year.
According to a survey for the California Business Roundtable, a group of corporate executives, 14 percent of California's business leaders said they planned to relocate outside the state, and 41 percent said they planned to expand operations out of state.
The population data suggest that Los Angeles County, which has 8.8 million people, accounts for the bulk of the change in migration patterns. For some years now, the net migration to the county from other states has been slowing, and in the last year the flow turned negative for the first time.
 
'People Are Leaving'
 " People are leaving," said Professor James P. Allen, a geographer at California State University at Northridge. "L.A. used to be a mecca for people seeking climate and job opportunities. It has lost that rosy image. That's quite realistic, given problems of crime, pollution, congestion, housing costs and lack of funds for an increasing number of children."
The driver's license records show that Californians are migrating mainly to Nevada, Washington State, Oregon, Arizona and Florida, in that order. California remains a net importer from most other states, mainly from New York, Massachussetts, Texas, Michigan, New Jersey and Illinois. For example, during the last fiscal year, 23,459 New Yorkers converted to California driver's licenses while only 12,188 did the opposite.
While older retired people have been leaving California for cheaper areas for years, the loss of younger families is new. Mr. Shlachter, the lawyer who recently moved to Portland with his wife and two children, ages 6 and 10, originally moved to Los Angeles from Cleveland. He drank deeply in the good California life, but ultimately found it not to his taste.
"We had a very comfortable life and we liked L.A.," he said. "We studied this move for almost a year. I lost a lot of sleep for six months. We were very well established in L.A. and had a lot of friends. The kids were the primary stimulus. We believe in the public-school system, but we put our older child in private school in L.A. We did it reluctantly."
Though he misses friends and the baseball Dodgers, Mr. Shlachter said the family had been pleased by the move. "When I told people that I was leaving, the typical comment was: 'Congratulations, you've got a lot of guts. I've been thinking about something like this for a long time.' " he said. "At least 100 people have told me that."
Many others leapt at the chance to leave when it came. Last October, Smart Telecom Inc., a small company that makes optics and stobe lights for the military, moved from Orange, Calif., to Reno. The company's plant manager, 28-year-old Kenneth J. Miner 2d, married with two children, did not hestitate for a moment.
He had been commuting to Orange from Riverside, about 50 miles, and the drive often took two hours each way. "Some days it would be three, three and a half hours," he said. "We called it the carpool from hell. There would be times when I would not see my kids for days. I'd leave at 4 A.M. and come home at 8 or 9 at night."
In March he bought a 1,800-square-foot home in Sparks, Nev., just a five-minute drive from work, for $98,000. A similar home in Orange County would have cost three times as much.
"We love it up here," Mr. Miner said by telephone. "There's not the traffic. There's no smog. I haven't been on the freeway in months."
Similarly, Adam N. Lane, a 27-year-old Oregonian who moved to Los Angeles seven years ago and worked as a senior consultant at the Price Waterhouse accounting firm's office in the Century City area of Los Angeles, was looking to leave when his boss announced he needed volunteers for a new office in Portland last year. "I knocked people down in the hallway getting to his door," he said. By May 1990 he was gone, buying a house in Portland that he could never afford in Los Angeles and thinking about getting married and having children. As he put it, "I can't even imagine raising kids in L.A."

LENGTH: 1305 words

HEADLINE: Bargains End at Public Colleges As States Force Tuition Increases

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Bargain-rate tuitions for students at state-run colleges and universities have been a source of hope for American families, regardless of their incomes, but the crisis in state financing is pushing lawmakers across the nation to raise tuitions and force students who can afford it to pay more.
Pressed by the recession and budget deficits, states have been unable to fully support their colleges with tax revenues and are increasingly looking to tuition to cover more of the cost of a student's education. Last year, tuition at public colleges increased by 12 percent, the biggest single-year jump since 1983, according to figures released yesterday by The College Board. 
 Average tuition and fees at four-year private colleges is $10,017 and at public colleges it is $2,137, the board said.
At the same time that tuition has been rising, there has been increasing resentment over the fact that the children of upper-income families benefit from low state tuition. As a result, California, Minnesota, New York and other states are treating their universities more like private colleges, where the tuition paid by students from middle- and upper-income families subsidizes financial aid for poorer students. Other states are studying similar plans.
 
Fundamental Tenet
 Some education officials fear that these strategies will prevent many students from attending college and diminish a fundamental tenet of America's system of public higher education.
"The basic issue undergirding all of this is whether we are going to be able to keep our public universities affordable," said James B. Appleberry, president of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. "Every time tuition goes up, some people who are most in need lose hope that they are ever going to go to college."
Supporters of higher tuition, like David Longanecker, executive director of the Colorado Commission on Higher Education, say that asking those who can afford a college education to pay more "is not unreasonable." But critics of the plans assert that higher tuition, even with expanded financial aid for some students, will eventually scare away needy students and hurt the already hard-pressed middle class. They also say states may try to shift even more of the cost of education from taxes to tuitions, thereby decreasing state spending on higher education.
 
Big Growth Over 50 Years
 "My fear is that we're going to end up with a situation of high tuition and low aid, because the states just don't have the financial resources to pay for something like this," said Richard J. Novak, director of the Center for Higher Education Policy and Finance, a not-for-profit research organization in Washington.
The debate over tuition comes at a time of unparalleled success for the state-run colleges, the high point of nearly 50 years of continuous growth since World War II. Those years saw the system expand tremendously and quickly mature. Today, seven of every 10 students in higher education attend a public college.
The public colleges now compete with the private colleges in almost every way, from recruiting the best students to raising money from corporations and alumni. For instance, the University of Houston is expected to announce soon that it has received the largest gift ever given a public university.
But even with such achievements, the public universities have been hurt by the poor financial conditions of the states that support them. Even as the University of Houston was preparing to accept its big gift, it was proceeding with plans, already approved by the legislature, to raise tuition in the 1992-93 school year.
In most state budgets, higher education is given a lower priority than entitlement programs like medical care and social services that must be financed at ever-increasing levels.
Last year, 29 states cut their budgets for colleges and universities in the middle of the academic year by an average of 3.9 percent. Forty-five states either had already imposed or were planning to impose a tuition increase.
 
12 Percent Increase
 Public tuition still lags far behind the rate for private colleges. According to the figures released yesterday by The College Board, tuition at private colleges rose 7 percent last year while public college tuition rose 12 percent. It was the biggest one-year jump since 1983, the end of the last recession.
Some of the biggest increases were in California, where the state budget deficit was $312 million. The cost of attending the University of California system increased 40 percent, or by $650, to $2,274. But accompanying that increase was a package of financial aid that completely shielded students from families with income of less than $30,000 from paying any of the increase. A sliding scale also increased financial aid for families with incomes up to $60,000 to cover part of the tuition increase.
The tuition increases in New York and Washington State were also accompanied by more generous financial aid for low-income students.
 
Debate in Minnesota
 It was Minnesota that most fully debated the tuition question last year. The state's private colleges and universities, which had a competitive stake in seeing public tuitions rise, led the campaign. They argued that across-the-board tuition subsidies had become too big a burden for the state to support.
Minnesota had set tuition at 33 percent of the actual cost of educating a student. A bill backed by the Minnesota Private College Council would have pushed that percentage to 66, with sizable increases not only in the amount of student financial aid but in the number of middle-income families who would be eligible to receive assistance.
The Legislature did not pass the bill, but it did raise tuition to 38 percent of actual costs for this academic year, and 43 percent next year.
"We were pleased and optimistic with the results," said David B. Laird, Jr., president of the council. "The terms of the debate have now changed. People are talking directly about subsidies and equity."
But some educators see the debate as overshadowing a more basic issue.
"Some people are portraying this as a fundamental rethinking of how higher ecucation will be financed," said James R. Mingle, executive director of State Higher Education Executive Officers, a national association based in Denver. "I take a more practical view. This is being done as a result of the states having financial problems. It's cheaper to subsidize a few students than a lot of students."
The theoretical underpinnings of keeping tution low for all students go back to the 1950's, when states were rapidly expanding the public higher education system , in part to handle the increase in students, many of them using the G.I. Bill. Deep subsidies for higher education for all students, regardless of need, were seen as a good investment because they would raise the nation's rate of productivity.
That might represent an ideal, say critics like Thomas P. Wallace, president of Illinois State University. But, they say, the system has gotten too big, the subsidies too deep.
Kent Halstead, president of Research Associates of Washington, a group that tracks financing of higher education, said students had been footing a bigger part of the tab anyway. In 1978, on average, tuition covered 21 percent of actual costs; last year that figure had increased to 26 percent, he said. Some states are far higher: Vermont 73 percent, New Hampshire 53 percent, and Delaware 49 percent.
Mr. Halstead said that while tuition costs had been "creeping higher," tuition at public universities is still modest.
"Even if it goes up to one-third," he said, "imagine anything else in the U.S. today that you could personally buy for one-third of the cost and still benefit so much."

HEADLINE: Schools Go Outside Districts For Money

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Despite a budget increasingly buffeted by recession, the school district of Lancaster has been able to provide programs and services that other school systems have been forced to eliminate because of costs.
By the end of the year, for example, the high school will be outfitted with a $65,000 electronic classroom, with television cameras and monitors that will allow the school to broadcast lessons to other schools or tap into classes broadcast by colleges and universities in the area. 
 These enhancements are not financed by property tax increases, but by the two-year-old Lancaster Foundation for Education Excellence, a not-for-profit organization established by parents and business leaders to help the urban working-class district of 10,300 students plug its budgetary holes.
 
Growing Trend in Country
 "Given the fiscal restraints, the foundation is able to do special things that the school district can't do," said Robert J. Shekletski, the Lancaster school superintendent.
In these penny-pinching times, increasing numbers of school districts like Lancaster are setting up independent education foundations created especially for public schools. About 1,000 foundations have been established around the country in a movement that took root in California after voters there approved Proposition 13 in 1978, limiting tax increases and reducing the amount of money available to schools. The state now has 160 education foundations.
"It's kind of the last opportunity for people to do something for their own public schools," said Allan Odden, a school finance expert at the University of Southern California. "States can't give a whole lot right now, and local property taxes don't go far enough. Foundations are an outlet for people to do a little bit more."
 
Big Interest in Northeast
 Now in the Northeast, the lingering recession and voter animosity to tax increases have forced fiscally strapped schools to look at foundations as financial sources of last resort. About 25 percent of all the foundations now operating have been established in the last three years in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and other Northeastern states, and interest in them continues to grow.
In July, for example, Educational Foundation Consultants, a Williamston, Mich., concern that helps school districts establish independent foundations, mailed 60 letters to New Jersey school districts outlining the benefits of the foundations. So far, 30 have responded.
"I would not be surprised if another 1,000 foundations form in the next two to three years, with a lot of them in the Northeast," said Kenneth A. Grounds, the vice president of the concern, which charges an average of $18,000 to $22,000 to help a school system establish a foundation. "The Northeast is the last untapped area, after the South."
Through money-raising efforts ranging from the raffling of a BMW automobile at one California school district to telethons like the one scheduled later this month in Lancaster, these foundations raise an average of $60,000 to $80,000 by their fourth year, Mr. Grounds said. Overhead expenses average about 5 percent because few of the foundations have large permanent staffs, he said.
As these foundations mature, they have taken up the slack in helping schools to improve curriculums, raise teacher salaries and award small grants to teachers who are testing pilot programs in the classroom. In some cases, foundations have helped finance the construction of new schools or enlarge existing ones.
 
Some Problems Seen
 But the growing popularity of these foundations has disconcerted some education finance experts. They assert that these organizations can upset efforts to equalize school spending between school districts rich in taxable property and poor school districts; that issue has provoked lawsuits in 22 states.
While no foundation has ever been legally challenged, the effect of their contributions on state formulas for supplying financial aid to school districts has been scrutinized by the California Department of Education, among others.
"It raises questions," said Joseph Remcho, a San Francisco lawyer who specializes in school financing issues. "If foundation contributions became exaggerated, they would have the potential to undermine the principle of equal educational opportunity."
Parents in poor school districts, like the Edgewood Independent School District in San Antonio, agree. One parent, Alexander M. Rodriquez, worries that if education foundations spread throughout the state they could upset a new state school financing plan that went into effect this fall that attempts to equalize the spending between rich and poor districts by forcing affluent systems to give up some of their money to poor districts.
"Rich districts could raise more money," said Mr. Rodriquez, who has a 10-year-old daughter and a 5-year-old son enrolled in the Edgewood system, which does not have an independent foundation to help it. "Edgewood would be at a disadvantage."
Mr. Remcho and others believe that in these perilous fiscal times for school systems any community support that helps preserve school programs should be encouraged.
Seizing on the idea, Lancaster citizens and school officials created their school foundation two years ago. The first year was spent organizing the foundation, establishing a wish list and convincing the citizenry in this city of 70,000 people that the idea was worth pursuing.
In its second year, the foundation now has results to show for its work. At J. P. McCaskey High School, for example, science teachers and students this fall have used a garden created last year and financed in part by the foundation for a variety of lessons.
When a blueberry patch failed, students studied the soil and discovered that it needed more acid to grow. The variety of leaves from plants in the garden has provided biology teachers with a rich source of subjects for the microscope.
"Actually looking at the leaves under the microscope is better than trying to explain it," said George Savitsky, a science teacher. "It just makes it easier."
The foundation uses the garden as example that not all projects need to be big-ticket items to have an effect. The garden, for instance, cost the foundation only $300, to buy various plants and other items. "Some trustees believe we should be further along," said Jane T. Pelland, the foundation's administrative assistant. "But no matter how small the project, kids can benefit."
 
A $350,000 Budget Item
 Other foundations, especially those in wealthy districts, can be major sources of money in their districts' annual budgets. The foundation serving the Beverly Hills Unified School District in California, for example, accounts for $350,000 of the district's annual budget.
"There is a myth that Beverly Hills doesn't need the money," said Linda Kinnee, executive director of the foundation. "This recession is affecting everyone."
That is why the Fort Lee school district in New Jersey is expected to create its own foundation in about two months. Recession-induced budget cuts have resulted in the elimination of foreign language classes in middle schools and counselors in elementary schools. Also scuttled because of the budget cuts was an advanced mathematics program for students.
"Under the circumstances, it has become quite clear to me that there needs to be some auxiliary source of funding to meet the needs of the district," said Alan W. Sugarman, the superintendent of the Fort Lee district, with 2,850 students. Given the way the California foundations helped school districts there cope with the recession and an anti-tax mood among voters, Mr. Sugarman said, he expects his school board to approve the creation of a foundation.
"Hard times," he said, "are here."

HEADLINE: THE THOMAS CONFIRMATION;
Senate's Futile Search for Safe Ground

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
At the end of the bitter fight over Clarence Thomas, Senators sat quietly and listened to dignified speeches. They usually don't. Then, even more unusually, they listened to each other vote, wondering how other senators had decided the issue.
At its simplest political level, tonight's 52-to-48 vote to confirm Judge Thomas as a Supreme Court Justice was a search for safe political ground. But, despite the dignity of the last minutes, it was not a moment that is likely to do much to heal the self-induced doubts about the Senate and its confirmation process or to salve the anger of many Americans. 
 As individuals, a solid majority of senators had announced for Judge Thomas before last weekend's hearings on his former aide's accusation of sexual harassment. When the roll was called, with all their colleagues and a national television audience watching, three of them, all Democrats, admitted by switching their votes that they had found the record of that confrontation clear-cut and convincing. The rest stayed put.
Those switches, and the decisions of most unannouced senators to vote no produced a much lower, closer vote than the 60 or so expected a week ago when the vote was first scheduled. Close votes are sometimes exhilarating, but tonight even the victors showed little joy.
Indeed there were laments on all sides. Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the president pro tempore of the Senate and a classic defender of the institution, claimed it had yielded to "blatant intimidation" by Judge Thomas and the White House. Other senators saw other failings: indifference to women, unfairness to the judge, the Judiciary Committee letting down its senators. And before the end the debate was as raw as it gets, with two Republican Senators challenging Senator Edward M. Kennedy's role as a defender of women, one of them with an apparent reference to Chappaquidick that was later withdrawn.
 
Southerners Look Home
 All day long there were different tones and nuances in the floor debate. Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, who faces re-election in 1992, pressed ahead with his politically risky accusation of perjury against Anita F. Hill, Judge Thomas's accuser. Senator James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, said he was simply not impressed by her explanations of why she continued working with him if she found his conduct as vulgar as she said. Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, denounced the tactics used to discredit Professor Hill by the judge's backers in her own party, but said she stuck by her earlier decision to vote for him, having seen "no compelling reason to overturn that judgment."
But race was never far from the minds of the senators considering the second nomination of a black to be a Supreme Court Justice, and to succeed the first, Thurgood Marshall, the leading civil rights lawyer of his age.
Senator Kassebaum, Senator Byrd and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, rejected Judge Thomas's claim that the hearings were "a high-tech lynching of uppity blacks." But whatever its merits, that phrase had underlined a main reason for Judge Thomas's confirmation, and Southern Democrats dependent on many black voters provided his margin of victory. None them switched their votes.
After the emotion of the hearings, votes loyal to the judge were easier to cast when one national poll after another found far more Americans, men and women alike, saying they believed Judge Thomas and not Professor Hill. The Senators, of course, are not just influenced by constituents. They are like them, too, glued to television sets, wondering about the clash of testimony of two intense, proud black Americans, and in the end finding her story harder to believe.
But those polls don't solve their political problems.
The hearings, which proved so damaging to the Senate's reputation, were conceived as an emergency, institutional defense against what Senator Kennedy called today the "tidal wave of anger among the women of America." Their anger grew out of the disclosure that the Senate had heard of the sexual harassment charges and done hardly anything to measure their truth or gravity.
 
Unabated Fury
 That "tidal wave" remains a political concern even if it represents a minority. Voters who are angry at politicians always have the potential to do them more harm than larger numbers who are satisfied. Moreover, the Democratic leadership knew that their angry feminist critics, usually their allies, are organized, articulate and political.
And that anger is not slaked. Perhaps nothing but the defeat of Judge Thomas would have put an end to it. But the hearings themselves deepened that anger among many women.
Nan Aron, executive director of the Alliance for Justice, one of the groups that fought hardest against the nomination, said after the vote that Judge Thomas won "because the Democrats were wimps -- they let the Republicans destroy Anita Hill."
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, told her colleagues that the "backers and the handlers" of the nominee wanted nothing but "to win at all costs." She said the Senate sent the message to women that if they come forward with sexual harassment complaints "your courage in coming forward will be met with suspicion and scorn, with unproven unsupported charges about you being mentally unbalanced."
Some of those attacks were renewed on the Senate floor today. Senator Specter made his perjury argument. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, assailed the witnesses who testifed on Sunday that Professor Hill had told them of being sexually harassed at work. He said they were not "corroborating witnesses," as most had seen them, but "collaborating witnesses, collaborating with the special interest groups that pounced on Anita Hill and her story in their effort to assassinate the character and integrity of Clarence Thomas."
Many Republicans, seeking the votes of those women outraged at the treatment of Professor Hill, avoided that approach and chose instead to concentrate on praising Judge Thomas.
Senator Kassebaum said she had "no intention of being a party to an intellectual witch hunt against Professor Hill." She made it clear that she found no evidence that the accuser was "mentally unstable, is inclined to wild fantasy, or is part of a decade-long conspiracy to get Clarence Thomas."
The Senate got to this bitter point only a week ago, when its initial arguments for inaction -- that the process had already gone on too long or that new hearings would never prove truth or falsity -- impressed hardly anyone.
But even though the senators thought they were overcoming the specter of white males indifferent to the plight of a black female by holding new hearings, they may have only deepened the initial dilemma while creating another problem, revealing to Americans who ordinarily watch ball games or soap operas that the Senate could be as feeble when it mattered as the Toronto Blue Jays.
Judge Thomas and his White House allies saw to it that the Judiciary Committee did not find an easy way to get off the defensive. The deferential, conciliatory nominee of September was replaced by an intense, angry man who said he didn't care if he got the job or not and who attacked the Senate, its committee and the process it oversees even harder than he attacked Professor Hill.
He scowled and lectured through Saturday, in a manner that probably would have insured his rejection a quarter century ago.
The hearings seemed repetitive and nitpicking. The Senate's television image, so high when it debated the war with Iraq 10 months ago, was shabby.
For every occasion when a Senator seemed to be pressing to understand the truth, there were two or three more when a lawmaker came across as a self-important windbag. When the Senators squabbled over procedure, recessed endlessly, or took 15 minutes to complete 5 minutes of questioning, the American people were seeing the Senate the way it is far more often than they way it was at 6 P.M. tonight.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Louis D. Brandeis; John F. Parker; Hugo L. Black; Abe Fortas; HomerThornberry; Clement F. Haynsworth; G. Harrold Carswell; William H. Rehnquist; Robert H. Bork; Douglas H. Ginsburg. (pg. A20)
 
Chart: "Other Contested Supreme Court Appointments in This Century"
 
Louis D. Brandeis, 1916
 President Woodrow Wilson nominated Brandeis, a renowned legal champion of the redress of economic and political inequities, who had detractors in many segments of the business community. The first Jew to be nominated for the Supreme Court, Brandeis was seen by his foes either as a dangerous radical who would destory institutions or as a dreamer who subordinated the Constitution to preconceived notion. After months of debate, the Judiciary Committee turned up no valid grounds for rejection and he was confirmed by a vote of 47 to 22 in the Senate.
 
John J. Parker, 1930
 President Herbert Hoover nominatet Federal Judge Parker of NOrth Carolina, who had a reputation for antilabor, conservative decisions. A labor-led campaign to reject Parker was based partly on an objection to the highly conservative, antilabor majority already on the Court. Civil rights groups opposed his nomination and brought out statements of racial bias made by the nominee when he ran for governor of North Carolina. He was rejected, 41 to 39, by the Senate, with progressive Northern Republicans joining the opposition to the Republican President's choice.
 
Hugo L. Black, 1937
 A Senator from Alabama, Black was a passionate partisan of the New Deal when President Franklin D. Roosevelt nominated him in 1937. During the confirmation debate there was talk that he might have been a member of the Ku Klux Klan. His supporters denied it; he said nothing. He was confirmed in five days by a vote of 63 to 16, but then a storm broke. Newspapers printed the story that he had once been a member of the Klan. He was denounced as a racist and there were demands for his resignation. The new Justice made a nationwide radio address in which he said that he had belonged to the Klan only briefly and had no racial or religious prejudice.
 
Abe Fortas, 1968
President Lyndon B. Johnson nominated Associated Justice Fortas to fill the seat of retiring Chief Justice Earl Warren. The nomination was reported favorably by the Judiciary Committee and was late September before debate began on the Senate floor. Justice Fortas was criticized for his liberal opinions while a Justice, his continuing practice of advising President Johnson on policy matters, and for what a number of senators viewed as excesses of the Warren Court. When his supporters in the partisan and often bitter debate, failed to end a filibuster, Justice Fortas asked that his name be withdrawn.
 
Homer Thonrberry, 1968
 At the same time that President Johnson nominated Justice Fortas as Chief Justice, he named Judge Thornberry to fill the vacancy that Justice Fortas's promotion would create. Judge Thornberry was an old friend of the President, who had named him a Federal district judge and then appointed him to a Court of Appeals. When his promotion to the Supreme Court was proposed, the question of "cronyism" arose, but the matter became moot when Justice Fortas withdrew. When Richard M. Nixon became President the next year, he appointed Warren E. burger as Chief Justice.
 
Clement F. Haynsworth, 1969
 President Richard M. Nixon nominated Judge Haynsworth, who met the Presiden't specifications as a jurist with a conservative judicial bent. The chief jduge of the Fourth Circuit, he was also a judge of some distinction, and at first the Senate seemed disposed to confirm him. But during the confirmation hearings as he was attacked as antilabor, called a "laundered segregationist" and accused of "ethical insensitivity" because he ruled insome cases in which he had a small stake though stock holdings. He was rejected by the Senate by a vote of 55 to 45.
 
C. Harrold Carswell, 1970
 After Judge Haynsworth was rejected, President Nixon nominated Judge Carswell. Mr. Carswell was a little-known and little-distinguished judge with six months of experience on the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals. During his tenure as a Federal judge, he compiled an almost unequaled record for being reversed by higher courts, and earned a reputation for shallow and dubious rulings. Doubts were also raised about his objectivity in racial matters and his civil rights record. The Senate rejected the nomination 51 to 45.
 
William H. Rehnquist, 1986
 President Ronald Reagan nominated Associated Justice Rehnquist to fill the seat of retiring Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. Opponents questioned his judicial ethics, his candor and integrity, and his record on civil rights, including whether as a young Republican Party worker in Phoenix in the early 1960's he had intimidated minority voters at polling places. The Senate confirmed the nomination to 65 to 33.
 
Robert H. Bork, 1987
 President Reagan nominated Circuit Court Judge Bork in 1987 to replace Justice Lewis F. Powell, who was knows as a "swing vote" on the Court. Judge Bork was acknowledged to be profesisonally qualified, and his judicial philosophy was clear enough even as its merits were hotly debated. His opponents succeeded in framing two questions that proved fatal to his nomination: whether he would "turn back the clock" on civil rights and other pressing social issues, and whether he was "out of the mainstream" of modern legal thought. He was rejected by the Senatae by a vote of 58 to 42.
 
Douglas H. Ginsburg, 1987
 After the Bork nomination failed, President Reagan announced his intention to nominate Circuit Court Judge Ginsburg. Nine days after he was chosen, Judge Ginsburg asked that his name be withdrawn. He acted after several disclosures about his personal and ethical conduct stirred a storm of criticism. He admitted that that he had smoked marijuana. Questions wre also raised about his truthfulness regarding a form h had filled out when nominated to the Federal appeals court, and ethical concerns wre voiced about his action as a Justice Department official in handling a cable television case when he held stock in a cable company.
 
(Sources: "Congressional Quarterly's Guide to the Supreme Court," second edition, "God Save This Honorable Court" by Laurence H. Tribe, "Justices and Presidents" by Henry J. Abraham) (pg. A20)
