SECTION: Section C; Page 16; Column 5; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 440 words

HEADLINE: Review/Cabaret;
Curmudgeonly Reminiscing In Oscar Levant Impression

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Barbed epigrams fly from the stage of Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street), where the pianist and composer Stan Freeman is portraying Oscar Levant in his one-man show, "At Wit's End."
"I am a deeply superficial person," he announces early in the evening. The only difference between the Democrats and Republicans, he asserts a little later, is that "the Democrats allow the poor to be corrupt, too." "Integrity is a lofty attitude assumed by someone who is unemployed," he declares further on. As nasty about others as he is about himself, he recollects taking Elsa Maxwell to a Halloween party and ripping off her mask "to find I had beheaded her." His first embrace with Judy Garland, he speculates, "may well be the greatest moment in pharmaceutical history." 
 The stream of self-deprecating remarks and insults is the glue that holds together a highly entertaining two-act, two-hour portrait of the pianist, composer, actor, television personality and professional neurotic who died in 1972. The show, which plays at Michael's Pub through Nov. 3, was written by Joel Kimmel and directed by Barbara Karp. It presents an imagined 1950's Levant concert performance in which he aphoristically reviews his life and times, directs occasional remarks offstage to his wife, June, and plays the piano. The numbers range from Falla's "Ritual Fire Dance" to Levant songs like "Blame It on My Youth" and "Wacky Dust" to several selections by Levant's hero, George Gershwin.
If the recollections are amusing, they are somewhat helter-skelter. The opening anecdotes recall Levant's days on the radio show "Information Please" and move ahead to the late 50's, when he became seriously addicted to painkillers and was hospitalized several times. His childhood and early Hollywood experiences are covered in the second act.
Mr. Freeman doesn't attempt an exact impersonation of his subject. The character he creates is a debonair sophisticate whose airs suggest an American Robert Morley with the soul of a Woody Allen character run amok. The show's tenderest moments are devoted to Levant's memories of Gershwin, whom he regarded with "undiluted idolatry." In the decades after the composer's death in 1937, Levant became the foremost interpreter of Gershwin's piano music and a crucial keeper of the flame.
The bilious undertone of much of the dialogue is balanced by Mr. Freeman's interpretations of Gershwin preludes, a lushly ornate "Somebody Loves Me," and especially "Rhapsody in Blue," which closes the show. His solo version of the Gershwin classic has a vigor and passion that echo Levant's own memorable interpretation.

HEADLINE: Stranding the Jobless

 BODY:
President Bush vetoed the Democrats' bill to aid the long-term jobless because it wouldn't pay for itself. Yet the Republican proposals he prefers are a sham. They help too few people and depend on gimmicks that waste future revenue.
More than three million of the nation's eight million jobless are collecting unemployment insurance. New claims have mounted slowly but steadily. Mr. Bush has made much of his measures to boost the economy by easing credit. But he ignores the depressing effects of job insecurity. People don't spend when they fear being laid off. 
 The vetoed bill and two Republican bills all offer added benefits to workers who exhaust, or have exhausted, the basic 26-week maximum. The Democrats' $6.5 billion bill offered up to 20 weeks more. The Republicans propose a maximum of 10 more weeks in one bill, for $3.5 billion, or up to 15 more in the other, for $3.9 billion.
All three bills would aid workers whose benefits expire in months to come, if they work in states where the unemployment rate exceeds a specified level. But Democrats and Republicans are far apart on helping idle workers who have already exhausted the basic entitlement. The Democrats would have helped more than a million in 34 states; the Republicans, with a much tighter formula, would help only 200,000 in six states and Puerto Rico.
The other big difference is financing. The Democrats' bill has none; it would add to the deficit and to the Federal debt. That's forbidden by last year's budget pact between Congress and Mr. Bush, except in undefined emergencies.
The Democrats argue that the distress of the long-term unemployed warrants emergency treatment, no less than the emergency aid that went to Iraq's Kurds. Mr. Bush says he wants to help the unemployed but must also protect all taxpayers. Thus he rejects new deficit spending. But he's wrong to think the Republican approach protects taxpayers. It avoids new taxes or more borrowing now, but it robs the future.
Some of the Republican financing comes from student loan delinquencies. Washington already duns delinquents by deducting their debts if they claim tax refunds. Authority for this expires in 1994. The Republicans want the authority renewed now, so that future collections can be counted on the 1992 books. Federal budget accounting may tolerate such trickery, but it's still trickery.
The bulk of the Republicans' revenue scheme rests on a fire sale of unused radio frequencies. Mr. Bush has proposed an auction starting in 1994. To rush it through in the next 12 months is throwing money away. The Congressional Budget Office estimates a quick selloff could yield as much as $2 billion but that a properly managed sale later could yield up to $4.5 billion.
The Democrats are rightly concerned. But even though Communism's collapse has invalidated last year's assumptions, the budget pact still stands, giving Mr. Bush a reason to veto.
Voting to override the veto is expected today. If the President prevails, the wisest, most honest course would be to pay for extended benefits with a higher tax on employers. But given that 1992 is an election year, that's not likely. What is likely is that the losers will be America's jobless.

HEADLINE: Family Leave Makes Economic Sense Too

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Family Leave: Fine, in Modest Doses" (editorial, Sept. 26) falls far short of the kind of support this important legislation deserves. You miss the fundamental truth about family-leave policy, which is that it makes both human sense for today's working families and economic sense for American business. 
 We have to stop talking about "cost" in dollars and cents only and recognize the social costs when we make people choose between caring for very young children or sick relatives and their jobs. Employers must recognize that money spent on family leave is an investment in the stability of their current work force and the nurture of their future work force.
If we look at recent experience with government mandates for unpaid parental leave on the state level, as a recent study by the Families and Work Institute in New York did, there is no evidence to support your gloomy predictions of job loss and wage suppression. There is, however, increasing data on the erosion of America's stature as a leading player in the world marketplace. American companies will not be able to compete in the global economy of the 21st century if they nickel-and-dime young children and their families in the 1990's.
Our businesses and our Government need to join all the other industrialized countries around the world (with the exception of South Africa) and adopt a national family-leave policy. If President Bush can take leadership in nuclear arms reduction, surely he can also reduce the stress on millions of American working families.
 
ANN BOOKMAN
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 1, 1991
 
The writer is research associate in family policy, Lesley College.

HEADLINE: $508.5 Million Loss at Security Pacific

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Like Citicorp, the Security Pacific Corporation yesterday reported a stunning third-quarter loss and said it was suspending its dividend because of large real estate loan problems.
The announcement came on a day when the nation's other large banks -- including Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover -- issued third-quarter earnings indicating that for them the rapid rise in troubled loans appears to be leveling off. 
 Security Pacific, which is about to be merged with the BankAmerica Corporation, reported a loss of $508.5 million, after taking a $1.2 billion provision for future losses on bad loans. That the Los Angeles-based Security Pacific would increase its reserve for bad loans had been anticipated by analysts in light of the merger, but the size of the reserve was larger than expected.
Also in California, Wells Fargo & Company reported a drop in profits to $86 million, about half its earnings in the 1990 third quarter, because of higher problem loans.
"West Coast banks are catching up to the problems that have visited other parts of the country over the last few years," said James J. McDermott Jr. of the bank analysis firm of Keefe Bruyette & Woods. "The industry profile suggests stabilization. But there will be episodic outbreaks of new problems."
 
Improvement for Some
 On the East Coast and in the Midwest, however, banks that last year reported staggering real estate losses appear now to have begun to put these problems behind them. This is a sign, analysts say, that the end of the recession is beginning to be felt at some of the nation's largest banks. Earnings at many of these banks were also helped by strong trading profits.
Despite these positive trends, the industry has yet to rebound fully. Even at strong banks, earnings were tempered by slow loan growth, continued high loan losses and higher premiums paid to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation fund that protects depositors in bank failures.
"The signals are that we are getting fairly close to the end of the recession, and earnings are better than expected," said Ronald I. Mandle, a bank analyst at Sanford Bernstein & Company. "With the end of the recession and the fact that regulators have forced banks to recognize problem loans more quickly, nonperforming loans should be nearing their peak and should begin to decline."
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Security Pacific
 Security Pacific's $508.5 million loss compared with profits of $135.3 million, or $1.05 a share, in the comparable period last year. The bank, California's second largest, announced plans in August to be acquired by BankAmerica, the state's biggest banking company and second largest in the nation, in a $4 billion stock merger. Both companies said yesterday that the merger, scheduled to be completed by the end of the year, would not be affected by this large loss.
Security Pacific also said that "it is anticipated" that the suspended quarterly dividend of 38 cents a share would be restored after the BankAmerica merger when Security Pacific common stock would be converted to BankAmerica stock.
Robert H. Smith, Security Pacific's chief executive, said the large loan-loss reserve "reflects current and anticipated adverse economic conditions." And he said he expects that loan losses will "remain at high levels" through the rest of the year.
Much of Security Pacific's loan problems are a result of bad real estate loans, a particular problem in California.
The $1.2 billion loan-loss provision was $965.6 million more than the loan-loss provision taken in the 1990 third quarter. It brings the total reserve for future bad loans to $2.3 billion. Charge-offs for bad loans in the 1991 third quarter came to $392.6 million, compared with $204.3 million in the 1990 third quarter.
Campbell K. Chaney, a bank analyst at Sutro & Company, suggested that the large loss might cause BankAmerica to change the terms of the merger. But Peter Mangnani, a BankAmerica spokesman, said there was no provision in the merger agreement that would allow for such a change.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Security Pacific's stock rose $1.325 a share, to $32.50, as investors apparently were encouraged by the measures taken by the bank to position itself for the merger.
 
Wells Fargo
 Wells Fargo's earnings of $86 million, or $1.59 a share, were down 47 percent from a 1990 third-quarter profit of $163 million, or $3.03 a share. The drop was attributed to a large increase in the loan-loss reserve and more write-offs at the San Francisco-based bank, California's third largest.
The provisions for anticipated loan losses increased to $350 million in the quarter, compared with $200 million in the 1990 quarter. And more bad loans were written off in the latest quarter: $123 million compared with $46 million in the 1990 quarter.
The total amount of troubled loans in the quarter came to $2.2 billion, compared with $1.2 billion in the 1990 period. This includes foreclosed real estate that is now owned by the bank.
"Earnings at Wells Fargo were lower than I had anticipated," said Mr. Mandle of Sanford Bernstein. "I was looking more for a loan loss of $150 million and a lower rise in nonperforming assets, say to $200 million to $225 million. Most of their problems were real estate-related."
Wells Fargo shares rose $3.875 each on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $71.25.
 
Chemical
 Earnings at the Chemical Banking Corporation were $131.6 million, or $1.22 a share, compared with a loss of $43.7 million in the third quarter last year that was attributed to a large loan-loss provision.
The earnings in the recent quarter were aided by record profits of $34.7 million from Chemical's Texas Commerce Bancshares subsidiary. In addition, third-quarter trading profits at Chemical reached $77 million, a record high.
Total nonperforming assets, which include bad loans and foreclosed real estate, were $3.4 billion, a slight increase from the 1990 third quarter. Chemical's reserve for bad loans decreased to $1.9 billion, from $2.2 billion in the 1990 third quarter, and the latest provision for bad loans decreased to $145 million, from $250 million in the 1990 third quarter.
Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover said in July that they planned to merge to speed their recovery from loan losses. Both have been severely weakened in recent years by bad loans, mostly in real estate at Chemical and to developing nations at Manufacturers.
Chemical's stock gained $1.75 yesterday, to close at $26.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Manufacturers Hanover
 At Manufacturers Hanover, third-quarter earnings were $77 million, the same as in the 1990 third quarter. Trading-account profits reached $81 million, compared with $34 million in the 1990 third quarter.
Total nonperforming loans increased only slightly from the year earlier, to $3.2 billion. At the same time, the reserve for future loan losses decreased slightly, to $1.8 billion, while loan charge-offs, excluding third world debt, totaled $168 million, nearly double the level of the 1990 third quarter and up from $142 million in the second quarter of 1991.
Manufacturers stock rose $1.875 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $29.25.
 
Banc One
 In the Midwest, the Banc One Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, reported record third-quarter earnings of $133.9 million, or 81 cents a share, up 22.8 percent from $109 million, or 68 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter.
An increase in retail loans brought an increase in the bank's net interest margin, the spread between what it pays for funds and what it earns on loans, to 6.13 percent. In the 1990 quarter, the margin was 5.28 percent.
The bank reported a slight increase in its problem loans and provisions for loan losses. Its total nonperforming loans rose to $513 million, from $405 million in the 1990 third quarter, although write-offs rose modestly, from $66.6 million, to $73.5 million in the quarter last year.
The reserve for future bad loans increased by 12 percent from the 1990 third quarter, to $85.5 million, but fell slightly from the amount set aside in the 1991 second quarter.
Banc One shares gained 37.5 cents each, closing at $44.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
First Chicago
 Earnings at the First Chicago Corporation fell 32 percent, to $24.6 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter, from $36.2 million, or 45 cents a share, in the 1990 period.
Earnings were hurt by a $35 million restructuring charge, which included layoffs, and an increase to $40 million in expenses associated with foreclosed real estate. Trading profits at First Chicago, however, rose to $30 million, from $2 million in the 1990 third quarter.
In anticipation of a drop in future loan problems, the bank set aside $105 million in reserves for future bad loans, compared with $155 million set aside in the 1990 third quarter.
First Chicago's shares rose $1 each on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $25.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 17, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the third-quarter earnings of a number of large banks misstated the provision for loan losses at Wells Fargo & Company in the latest quarter and a year ago. It was $200 million in this year's third quarter and $75 million in the 1990 third quarter; a provision of $350 million was taken in the 1991 second quarter.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Continue to Decline

DATELINE: ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields of both tax-exempt and taxable money funds continued to decline in the week ended yesterday, according to IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, reported that total assets of tax-exempt funds rose by $495 million in the last week, to $89.7 billion, a modest increase coming after a $2.9 billion surge of buying the previous week. 
 "The huge inflow of a week ago put some pressure on municipal bond fund yields," he said. "I would expect that if yield declines continue we will see some drying up of the inflow." He also said that "there is some seasonal effect involved in the huge total inflow of the past two weeks."
The maturity of portfolio holdings of the tax-exempt funds rose to an average of 62 days, up from 60 days, he reported, explaining that the fund managers were reaching out for longer maturities to bolster the yields.
The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempt funds dropped from 4.23 percent to 3.93 percent, while the seven-day simple yield declined from 4.14 to 3.86 percent.
In the 30-day period, the compound yield dropped from 4.35 percent to 4.28 percent, and the simple yield dropped from 4.26 percent to 4.19 percent.
The highest-yielding fund among those with assets over $100 million continued to be the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 5 percent, down from 5.22 the previous week.
Among funds investing in New York State securities, Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market continued to head the list with the highest seven-day compound yield of 4.75 percent, down from 4.95 percent.
There was a tie between the Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a yield of 4.22 percent, compared with 4.5 percent last week, and the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Fund, also yielding 4.22 percent. A week ago it yielded 4.39 percent.
The leader in New Jersey funds again was Calvert N.J. Tax Free Reserves, reporting a seven-day compound yield of 4.5 percent, declining from 4.89 percent the previous week.
Assets of the taxable funds rose by only $87 million, to $461.3 billion, with most of the rise coming from individual investors. The funds showed a $220 million outflow of institutional money.
Average maturities of portfolio holdings of the taxable funds moved up by one day, to 63 from 62.
 
Taxable fund Yields
 Among the taxable funds, the average seven-day compound yield dropped to 5.14 percent from 5.21 percent, and the simple yield dropped to 5.02 percent from 5.08 percent.
The 30-day compound yield dropped to 5.25 percent from 5.29 percent and the 30-day simple yield was down to 5.12 percent, from the 5.16 percent yield a week ago.
The taxable fund with the best return continued to be Riverside Capital Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 6.34 percent, up from 6.32 percent, possibly because of capital gains or stretched-out maturities.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.98 percent, from 5 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Lower As Traders Await Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower yesterday in lackluster trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices advanced after settling lower in foreign markets. On the New York Commodity Exchange, bullion for current delivery settled at $358.20 an ounce, up 50 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained 85 cents an ounce, to $357.70. 
 Analysts said trading was extremely light as investors stepped aside ahead of today's release of fresh economic data. The Government is scheduled to report on consumer prices and industrial production for September. Merchandise trade figures for July are also scheduled to be announced.
"It was an extremely quiet day," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank P.L.C. "The market was kind of marking time waiting for the economic numbers."
 
Watching Price Index
 Traders are expected to key in on the Consumer Price Index, which will give an indication as to whether inflation is being held at bay.
"If inflation is tame, the market will anticipate a Fed easing," Mr. Hatcher said. Low inflation enhances the chance that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.
Low interest rates are generally bearish for the dollar because they decrease the value of dollar-denominated securities.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 130.02 yen, from 129.72 yen on Tuesday. Later in London, it fell to 129.95 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 130.10 yen, unchanged from Tuesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.7105, from $1.7115 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7070 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.7005.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.7060 German marks, down from 1.7128; 1.4905 Swiss francs, down from 1.4950; 5.8145 French francs, down from 5.8335; 1,275.75 Italian lire, down from 1,280.25, and 1.1308 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1298.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $356.55 a troy ounce, down from $358.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $356.90 from $358. Hong Kong markets were closed for a holiday.
Silver prices gained. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.098 a troy ounce, up from $4.051 on Tuesday. In London silver rose to a late bid price of $4.09 an ounce from $4.08.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Philip Morris Climbed 20.6% in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies announced a 20.6 percent rise in third-quarter earnings yesterday, based on the strong growth of its cigarette sales abroad and the sound performance of its food products.
The results were marred only by a decline in its Miller Brewing Company. The company spent heavily on marketing a number of its beer brands, including Miller Genuine Draft, Sharp's and Milwaukee's Best. 
 Earnings at the world's largest cigarette company rose in the latest quarter to $1.13 billion, or $1.22 a share, from $937 million, or $1.01 a share, in the third quarter last year. The gains came as Philip Morris increased its presence in the fast-growing world cigarette market and increased its share of the domestic cigarette market, with brands like Marlboro, Benson and Hedges and Virginia Slims and Bucks, a lower-priced brand. The growth came even as the domestic cigarette market is shrinking.
Most analysts described Philip Morris's report as uplifting news for the company, which is attempting to expand its food and tobacco business to new and growing markets overseas.
The earnings came on operating revenues for the third quarter of $13.77 billion, an increase of 7.4 percent over the $12.82 billion reported in the corresponding quarter in 1990. For the first nine months of 1991 operating revenues were $42.76 billion, up 15.7 percent, from $36.95 billion in the period last year.
"Despite a recessionary trend in the U.S. and a general weakening of the economy in certain foreign countries," said Michael A. Miles, Philip Morris's chairman and chief executive, "the company's results for the quarter and year to date reflect the strength and depth of our domestic and international consumer brands."
In the tobacco arena, revenues for Philip Morris USA rose 12 percent, to $2.8 billion from $2.5 billion. With more than 47 percent of Philip Morris's income coming from the domestic tobacco business, analysts looked favorably on an overall increase in its domestic unit sales of eight-tenths of 1 percent. Industrywide, unit sales declined 1.8 percent during the quarter.
Philip Morris USA recently introduced Marlboro Medium cigarettes, as well as lower-priced brands to continue its growth of market share.
"Their ability to grow in a declining category is impressive," said John McMillin, an analyst with Prudential. " They are increasing their presence in value-added brands and they are shifting their emphasis overseas, where there is plenty of room for growth."
Philip Morris's cigarette revenues outside the United States and Canada increased 10.4 percent, to slightly more than $3 billion in the quarter, from $2.7 billion in the third quarter of 1990. Profits abroad rose 20.4 percent, to $501 million, from $416 million the year before. Volume of unit sales increased 11.6 percent in the third quarter.
Analysts also noted a strong performance for the company's Kraft General Foods International, with products like Toblerone chocolate, Kraft mayonnaise and Tang. Revenues rose 12.6 percent, to more than $1.7 billion from $1.5 billion.
Domestically, however, operating revenues were flat, compared with an income increase of 8.4 percent over last year. Analysts attributed slack food sales in North America to consumers' concerns about the economy and their shift to less expensive cheese and meat products and to store brands.
The Miller Brewing Company reported a decline in income of 4.8 percent in the third quarter, to $99 million from $104 million, although revenues increased by 17.7 percent, to $1.1 billion, from less than $964 million in the third quarter of 1990.
Despite the generally good earnings report, the company's stock slipped 50 cents, to $73.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. One analyst called the decline "a mystery."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Coca-Cola Profit Up 15.8% On Strong Overseas Sales

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Bolstered by strong sales overseas, the Coca-Cola Company said yesterday, profits rose 15.8 percent in the third quarter.
Earnings rose to $456.3 million, or 69 cents a share, it said, compared with $394.1 million, or 58 cents a share, a year earlier, while sales increased 13.6 percent, to $3.17 billion, from $2.79 billion a year ago. 
 Robert C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive of Coca-Cola, said that the earnings growth was "particularly rewarding, given the tough economic environments in some key international markets and in the U.S."
Internationally, sales to retail customers increased 8 percent, and sales of flavoring to bottlers increased by 6 percent.
Martin Romm, an analyst at First Boston, said, "Their international business, which really is the driving force behind Coca-Cola's earning performance, continues to be fairly strong."
The international market accounts for 80 percent of Coca-Cola's operating profits, and the company has been investing heavily in building its international distribution system.
Coke's results were in line with expectations, and the company's stock fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $62.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Sales Climb 20% in Germany
 Retail sales climbed 20 percent in Germany, fueled by new business from the eastern region. In France, retail sales grew by 17 percent, and in Italy 10 percent. But in Britain, retail sales declined 8 percent.
George E. Thompson, an analyst with Prudential Securities, said the "great thing" about Coke's far-flung empire was that subpar performance in one country could be counterbalanced by strong performance in another.
In Japan, which produces more operating income for Coke than the United States, flavoring sales to bottlers increased by 17 percent in the quarter. Retail sales were up only 2 percent, which Coke attributed to heavy rains caused by several typhoons.
Mr. Romm of First Boston said that the once-lagging Latin American market was beginning to show strong volume and profit growth for Coca-Cola. Retail sales grew 11 percent in Latin America in the quarter, with flavoring sales to bottlers up 6 percent. Retail sales in Argentina grew by 23 percent.
For the company as a whole, soft drink sales increased by 5 percent during the quarter.
In contrast to the strong international performance, sales were sluggish in the United States, which Coke attributed to the soft economy. Retail sales in the United States increased by less than 1 percent during the quarter. Sales of Coke flavoring to bottlers increased by 1.5 percent.
"In a business that is seemingly immune to a recessionary environment, there has been some impact," said Mr. Thompson, the Prudential analyst. "That gives you an idea of the impact of the recession."
Yesterday, the company took additional steps to expand overseas, announcing that it had formed a joint bottling venture in the Ukraine, called Rosinka, Coca-Cola Bottling. Mr. Goizueta, Coke's chairman, said the Ukraine represented a market of 50 million new consumers.
The announcement of such international ventures is "going to be a continuing event," Mr. Thompson of Prudential said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
McGraw-Hill Profits Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter earnings dropped 18.2 percent because of the soft advertising market.
The New York-based publishing conglomerate said earnings in the three months ended Sept. 30 were $55.1 million, or $1.13 a share, down from $67.4 million, or $1.38 a share, for the period a year earlier. Revenue totaled $489.5 million, down from $502.8 million a year earlier. 
 Joseph L. Dionne, the chairman of McGraw-Hill, said in a statement that "the economic recovery remains invisible to many of our customers and spending restraints are still the norm for U.S. business."
McGraw-Hill's trade magazines and broadcasting operations were hurt by lower ad volume, while the domestic and overseas textbook divisions suffered from reduced financing for schools.
Only McGraw-Hill's financial news services unit and Standard & Poor's Ratings Group reported gains in operating profits.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Georgia-Pacific Posts Loss, Citing Depressed Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, citing a downturn in the market for pulp and paper and building products, reported a net loss yesterday of $27 million for the third quarter.
In the comparable period last year the company, the nation's largest paper producer, earned $95 million, or $1.11 a share. 
 Like others in the paper industry, Georgia-Pacific is suffering from sagging prices for a number of products. Also, analysts attribute the company's problems, in part, to its acquisition of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation last year. Great Northern had a siginificnt share of its business in many of the products that have been affected by the recession.
 
Several Depressed Markets
 "Business conditions continue to reflect depressed markets in both pulp and paper and building products," said T. Marshall Hahn Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive.
Analysts said the Atlanta-based company was affected by price weakness in a number of areas. For exmple, prices for linerboard, the material used for making boxed and packaging materials, have declined 18 percent from the corresponding period last year. And market pulp prices have tumbled by about 30 percent from the 1990 period.
Georgia-Pacific's sales declined to $2.97 billion in the third quarter, compared with sales of $3.43 billion in the comparable period last year.
The company reported operating profits of $72 million in its pulp and paper division, compared with operating earnings of $279 million in the period in 1990. For the building products division, Georgia-Pacific said its operating profits increased to $130 million, compared with $111 million in the third quarter last year.
"The hope for the company is that linerboard appeared to have bottomed," said Sherman Chao, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. "Also, there are announcements for price increases for uncoated free sheet," the material used for copier- and computer-printer paper.
 
Future Problems Seen
 Still, Mr. Chao said, the fourth quarter was likely to be worse than the third. That forecast was endorsed by Mr. Hahn, who said he was "not overly optimistic" about the prospects for that business for the rest of the year.
Georgia-Pacific's stock rose $1.25 yesterday to close at $56.375 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the stock action was related to a general upward movement in the market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Profit Off at 2 Baby Bells; United Telecom Net Up

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
A stagnant economy took its toll on third-quarter earnings reported yesterday by three telephone companies, setting a pattern for the industry that is in line with Wall Street expectations.
The Pacific Telesis Group and Ameritech, the first two "Baby Bells" to report, had slight declines in net income from normal operations. 
 United Telecommunications Inc., which owns U S Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance company, reported a modest gain. Declines in local telephone operations partly offset relatively strong growth in long-distance operating income. But United Telecom's revenue growth looked weak compared with the previous quarter, and the company warned that its fourth-quarter operating earnings would be about the same as its third-quarter results.
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
Ameritech
 Ameritech said its net income from operations declined 1.7 percent, to $305.8 million in the third quarter, from $311.2 million a year ago. Including a special gain of $73.6 million from the sale of the company's interest in the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand in an initial public offering, Ameritech's net jumped 21.9 percent from last year's comparable period, to $379.4 million, or $1.43 a share.
Ameritech's revenue edged up 1.5 percent, to $2.71 billion in the quarter, from $2.67 billion a year earlier. The Chicago-based company said that return on equity climbed to 18.7 percent, from 16.2 percent a year ago.
Customer telephone lines in service edged up 1.7 percent from last year's third quarter, to nearly 16.5 million. But the number of mobile phone customers grew more rapidly, to 424,000, up 50 percent from last year's period.
The company's shares slipped 12.5 cents to close at $60.625 today on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Pacific Telesis
 Pacific Telesis said its net income for the third quarter fell 3.5 percent, to $275 million, or 70 cents a share, from $285 million, or 72 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings were down even though revenue edged up 1.2 percent, to $2.50 billion from $2.47 billion.
"Telesis earnings are reflecting the continuing weakness in the economy and the restructuring taking place in our industry," said Sam Ginn, chairman and chief executive of the San Francisco-based company.
Pacific Bell, the Telesis subsidiary that provides basic service in California, earned $263 million, a 6 percent decline from the comparable three months in 1990, although revenue grew 1.6 percent, to $2.24 billion.
The figures for the company's cellular subsidiary were positive, although modest by historic standards. Net income was up $1 million, or 4.8 percent, compared with $22 million a year earlier, despite a 31.6 percent increase in the number of subscribers to 512,000. Cellular revenue rose to $151 million, from $122 million in last year's period.
The company's shares were down 37.5 cents to close at $41 in today's trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
United Telecom
 United Telecom's net income rose 7.9 percent, to $96.8 million, or 44 cents a share, from $89.7 million, or 41 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1990. Revenue rose 5.2 percent, to $2.21 billion from $2.10 billion.
U S Sprint was the bright spot, said William T. Esrey, chairman and chief executive of the Kansas City-based company. The long-distance unit's operating income climbed 67 percent, to $90 million, from $54 million a year ago.
Analysts were less impressed than might have been expected, however, saying that Sprint had achieved the gains through strict cost controls that had hampered its ability to compete for new customers with A.T.& T. and MCI, the two larger companies in the long-distance market.
Mr. Esrey said that Sprint would be increasing its marketing outlays in the current quarter, which would probably put a halt to the company's string of gains in operating earnings gains.
United Telecom's local phone companies, which serve 3,000 communities in 17 states, earned $159 million in the quarter, down 5.9 percent from $169 million a year ago. Revenues for the units rose 4.4 percent, to $709 million from $679 million.
The company's stock declined 12.5 cents, to $23, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Shake-Up Of Licensees In British TV

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The biggest shake-up in the 36-year history of British commercial television occurred today, when a Government-appointed commission announced that four leading companies had lost their licenses in the country's first auction of television franchises.
Three American companies -- Disney, NBC and Home Box Office -- were members of some of the 40 groups bidding for what is called here the national breakfast franchise and 15 regional franchises, whose advertising revenues last year totaled 1.67 billion, or about $3.22 billion. The breakfast slot is one of the most coveted franchises, presenting morning news and interviews. 
 The auction was a result of legislation passed last year that was aimed at exposing the overmanned, clubby world of commercial television to the rigors of the marketplace.
The winning bids for the 16 Independent Television franchises totaled 231.9 million at anticipated 1993 prices. That is about $396.8 million at current exchange rates.
The licenses, which begin in 1993, are for 10 years but are expected to be rolled over when they expire. But starting in 1994, hostile takeovers of television companies will be permitted.
The winning bids ranged from a low of 1,000, or about $1,712, for the small Channel Island franchise, to a high of 43.2 million, or about $73.9 million, for London weekday television. The latter went to a group led by Carlton Communications P.L.C., one of Britain's leading independent television producers and a big provider of services to the film industry.
The losers included some of the biggest names in British television: TVS Entertainment, owner of the American production company MTM, which had the franchise for south and southeast England; Thames Television, a subsidiary of Thorn EMI, which is one of Britain's largest program producers and which had the London weekday franchise, and TV-am P.L.C., whose light breakfast news and interview show is watched by about 70 percent of morning viewers.
Along with the national breakfast slot, the franchises for weekday London and south and southeastern England are among the most coveted franchises in the industry.
The fourth loser was TSW Television Southwest, the holder of the southwestern England franchise.
The Walt Disney Company was a member of the group that won a three-way battle for the national breakfast broadcast, while NBC was part of a losing group. Home Box Office, a Time Warner Inc. unit, was in the losing TVS group.
Advertisers had been among those lobbying the Conservative Government for changes in the television industry. They had been upset by what they saw as excessive increases in charges for commercial time, which had risen in the 1980's at an average annual rate that was 2.5 times faster than inflation, said Paul Styles, head of media consulting at KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock, the accounting firm.
 
Upheaval in the Industry
 The industry has already gone through upheaval. Companies have dismissed thousands of employees as they frantically tried to slash costs so they might have the financial strength to prevail in the auction. Many of the winners now plan to rely heavily on programs bought from independent producers.
Besides saving money, there is another reason that independent producers can expect more business: the new broadcasting law also requires the commercial television stations and the British Broadcasting Corporation to buy at least 25 percent of their programming from independent producers.
The growth of satellite and cable television is also expected to put pressure on the commercial television stations, predicted John Perriss, chairman of Zenith Media Worldwide, a media-buying company owned by Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the advertising giant.
British Sky Broadcasting, the service whose main owner is Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, "is now in about 12 percent of Britain's 22 million homes, and I believe in five years it could easily be in a third," he said. "It will take revenue from the commercial franchises."
 
Four Free Channels
 Britons now can choose from four free channels. Channels 1 and 2 belong to the Government-supported BBC and carry no advertising. Channel 3 consists of the 16 commercial franchises, which carry advertising. So does Channel 4, whose charter, like Channel 2's, is to carry programs that might not appeal to a mass audience. Channel 3 has about a 45 percent share of the television audience, compared with 38 percent for the BBC's Channel 1.
There are also plans to create a fifth commercial channel that will be able to reach most of Britain. It is expected to be sold in a similar auction.
Today's auction will have a significant impact on what programs Britons watch -- or at least where they watch them. There was speculation today that Thames would sell some of its popular series programs now shown on the Independent Television network -- like "The Bill," a police drama -- to the BBC or British Sky Broadcasting. And many bidders had promised to increase the time devoted to regional public-service issues and local news.
Insuring that programming quality did not suffer was a reason the Government commission did not award eight of the franchises to the highest bidders. For instance, TVS bid 59.8 million, or about $102.3 million, but the commission chose a group that bid 36.5 million, or about $62.5 million, maintaining that TVS would not have been able to maintain its proposed service.
Besides the size of the bid, the law also required the commission to take into account the quality of each bidder's proposed programming and the viability of its business plan. The commission used both criteria to reject contestants. Several losers said they would mount court challenges.
"Clearly, the concern about sustaining high-quality programming is very much at mind in the commission," said David W. Byles, media director in the London office of J. Walter Thompson, the ad agency.
The auction comes at a time when the commercial television industry is reeling from Britain's recession. Advertising revenues were flat last year and are expected to fall by 5 percent or more in 1991.
 
Plenty of Complaints
 As could be expected, there were plenty of complaints today about the auction system. Executives of losers like Thames, which has been broadcasting for 23 years, and TV-am complained that the system did not take into account their records as broadcasters. Some consultants and advertising executives complained that the auction did not shake up the system enough. And The Evening Standard, a London newspaper, called the outcome "The Great TV Auction Farce" in its front-page headline.

HEADLINE: MAN IN THE NEWS: William Pelham Barr;
Attorney General Choice With Low-Key Style

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
William P. Barr, President Bush's nominee as Attorney General, is a bagpipe-player, China scholar and one-time employee at the Central Intelligence Agency who got his law degree in night school and has never prosecuted a criminal case in court.
He has served as Acting Attorney General since Dick Thornburgh left two months ago to run for the Senate in Pennsylvania, and his affable, unpretentious style at the Department of Justice has been an antidote to the aloof and sometimes imperious approach of Mr. Thornburgh. 
 Mr. Barr's most difficult test so far came just three days into his tenure as the department's top official, when Cuban inmates at the Talladega Federal Correctional Institution in Alabama seized 10 hostages in an effort to avoid being returned to Havana.
 
Trial by Fire
 The incident thrust Mr. Barr into a tense drama in which he was forced to make a difficult choice between equally dangerous alternatives. He decided early that the Government could not agree to the inmates' demands for freedom, but he became increasingly fearful that the lives of the hostages were at risk.
It was Mr. Barr who ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Hostage Rescue Team to storm the cell block where the hostages were held in a pre-dawn assault, armed with high-powered weapons. The hostages were rescued unharmed and no shots were fired.
Mr. Barr, who is 41 years old, has a solid conservative track record, working mainly behind the scenes to advance the Administration's main law-enforcement programs, including its crime bill and its proposals to attack savings and loan fraud.
Less clear are his views on other matters in which the department plays a role, including civil rights and abortion. But Mr. Barr agreed with the department's decision to file a motion in Federal court in Wichita, Kan., last August that was widely perceived as siding with an anti-abortion group. The group was fighting an order by a Federal District Judge restricting demonstrations at abortion clinics in the city.
Department officials insist that the motion was not an effort to take a stand on behalf of the demonstrators but a restatement of the department's legal position that the Federal courts lack jurisdiction in such cases.
Mr. Barr has also assumed a role in a long-running dispute with a House Judiciary subcommittee over a 1989 legal opinion that concluded that United States law allows F.B.I. agents to arrest people charged with crimes in this country and who have fled overseas, without obtaining the permission of the country involved.
 
An Early Showdown
 The efforts by the panel, the Judiciary Subcommittee on Economic and Commercial Law, to obtain the opinion, which was written by Mr. Barr, nearly provoked a showdown on the Constitution. The two sides eventually agreed to negotiate a compromise that would provide limited access.
William Pelham Barr was reared in New York City, the son of an educator who was once dean of the Columbia University engineering school. He is married and lives in suburban Virginia with his wife, Christine, a school librarian, and their three children.
After graduating in 1973 from Columbia University with a master's degree in Chinese studies, Mr. Barr worked at the C.I.A. and completed George Washington University law school at night. He entered private practice in 1978, mainly in civil law and Federal administrative matters.
Mr. Barr landed on the fast track when he took a job in 1982 as a lawyer for the Domestic Policy Council in the Ronald Reagan White House. It was there that he met allies who have helped him since then, including C. Boyden Gray, who was counsel to Mr. Bush when he was Vice President.
After Mr. Bush's election as President, Mr. Barr joined the department as Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Office of Legal Counsel, which provides advice to the White House, other executive branch departments and the Attorney General.
Not long after Mr. Barr took over as the department's No. 2 official, he said he hoped to apply the law with fairness and integrity, but he added a cautionary note. "Apart from that, my main goal is to survive," he said. "There are mine fields every day, and I just hope I can get through the day without stepping on one."

HEADLINE: MITTERRAND JOINS KOHL IN PROPOSING A EUROPEAN ARMY

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Hoping to influence NATO and European Community summit meetings in the next two months, France and Germany called today for creation of a corps-strength Western European army as a step toward giving the region an independent defense capability.
The two Governments said they would strengthen an existing 5,000-member French-German brigade and indicated that units from other countries in the European Community could eventually join the force. Officials here in Paris said the expanded French-German force could have 30,000 troops. 
 In a letter to other European leaders, President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl also proposed that the Western European Union, a moribund military group comprising nine of the 12 European Community members, become the pillar of a joint European security and defense policy.
 
Britain Challenges Proposal
 The French-German initiative was immediately challenged by Britain as a potential threat to NATO.
Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, speaking from Harare, Zimbabwe, where he is attending a Commonwealth conference that opened today, warned that it would be "useless and dangerous" to duplicate what the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization is already doing.
Britain has maintained that the 42-year-old alliance should remain the region's principal military organization, and has frequently cautioned that any weakening of NATO could lead the United States to reduce its commitment to Western Europe's defense.
The initial American reaction to today's proposal was that Washington was not alarmed by the general notion of a European security arrangement with a distinctly European character. An American official said, however, that any European defense structure should be compatible with NATO.
A French spokesman insisted today that, under the new plan, the Western European Union would complement NATO. "It will not become a rival of the alliance," he said. "But the identity of a European security system is being created. It's a fact. It exists."
A German spokesman in Bonn, also seeking to reassure the alliance, emphasized that the creation of a European army was "a long-term proposal" and recalled that the United States has often urged its European partners to assume greater responsibility for their defense.
Some military experts said the difficulties of forming a European army would become apparent as France and Germany try to expand their joint force, not least because of their armies' different equipment, training and command structures.
But the experts said the Mitterrand-Kohl letter suggested that Germany was moving closer to the position of France, which is not a member of NATO's integrated military command and which has long favored a more independent European defense stance.
 
Anticipates Summits
 European officials said the French-German move was timed to anticipate debates on European security expected at a NATO summit meeting in Rome on Nov. 7 and 8 and another of European Community leaders in Maastricht, the Netherlands, on Dec. 8 and 9.
The NATO meeting is expected to define the alliance's strategy for the post-cold-war era, including plans to cut back American troops in Europe, to eliminate short-range nuclear weapons from the region, to create a rapid-reaction force and to establish new relations with members of what was once the Soviet bloc.
The community meeting has the much broader mandate of leading Western Europe toward greater economic and political union, a concept that includes establishing the rules for a common foreign and defense policy.
European officials said today's French-German initiative was intended to break the deadlock in the community's debate on political union and to send a signal to NATO that Western Europe is ready to assume new defense responsibilities both inside and beyond the region.
They said the plan was also a response to a joint British-Italian proposal made two weeks ago that called for the creation of a European rapid-reaction force, but that emphasized any regional military group should remain subservient to NATO.
While Britain indicated today that the French-German idea could hurt NATO, Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni de Michelis, said during a visit to Paris that he saw "no contradiction" between the two plans. Mr. Mitterrand is to visit Rome for further talks on Thursday.
The French-German proposal, presented in the form of language to be included in a community treaty on political union, also went further than the British-Italian proposal by specifying key areas in which the community's members should work to adopt a common foreign policy.
These included relations with the Soviet Union, Central and Eastern Europe, the United States and Canada, the Mediterranean and the Middle East as well as issues like disarmament and arms control, nuclear nonproliferation and United Nations peacekeeping activities.
The French and German statement did not address one of the crucial questions dividing the community -- whether the community should define its position on specific foreign policy questions by majority vote or, as at present, through consensus. Britain, for one, is unwilling to give up its right of veto.
European officials said that, while the 12 community members were still far from agreement on the substance of their political union, today's initiative demonstrated that France and Germany, the traditional motors of European integration, were again working together.
In recent weeks, Paris has expressed fear that Bonn's growing influence over Eastern Europe was weakening its commitment to their special relationship, one that gave France political leadership and Germany economic domination within the community.
Germany has also recently found itself squeezed between its loyalty to Washington and to Paris. Just two weeks before joining today's initiative, for example, Germany endorsed an American plan to strengthen NATO's ties with the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. "We see Germany going in both directions," a Western diplomat said.
For France, which first advocated political union as a way of anchoring a powerful united Germany to the European Community, the action today is a boost to its faltering prestige within Europe, and gives it hope of working with Germany through the community meeting in the Netherlands.

HEADLINE: JOBLESS BILL VETO SURVIVES IN SENATE BY NARROW MARGIN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Senate today narrowly failed to override President Bush's veto of a $6.4 billion bill to provide extended unemployment benefits to millions of jobless workers, and Democrats warned that the veto would become an issue in next year's elections.
The vote was 65 in favor of an override and 35 against, two votes short of the two-thirds necessary to overcome the President's rejection and the same tally by which the Senate passed the bill two weeks ago. 
 As before, all 57 Democratic senators favored the bill today, joined by eight Republicans. But they were not enough to prevail over the 23d veto that Mr. Bush has cast in his Presidency. The vote today marked then 12th attempt by Congress to override a Bush veto, and the 12th failure.
 
Democrats and Domestic Issue
 Democrats, laying the groundwork for a campaign against Mr. Bush next year that will emphasize domestic issues, have called the benefits bill a test of compassion for Americans buffeted by the recession, and they plan to cite White House opposition as a evidence that Mr. Bush does not care about economic hardships.
While conceding that Mr. Bush has dominated foreign policy issues, Democrats say he is vulnerable on economic policy, and he has already adopted a defensive posture when discussing the economy and domestic concerns.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York was one of the Republicans voting to override the President's veto. "We have too many middle-class New Yorkers who have always worked and would be working now, but for the fact of economic dislocation and job loss due to no fault of their own," he said in an interview tonight. "We should give them the benefit of the doubt, give them additional time to find jobs and relocate in a different job market.
"I always attempt to support the Administration, the President, but here we are talking about a situation where American workers need help."
 
The Opposing Republicans
 The Republican Senators who voted to override President Bush's veto, besides Mr. D'Amato, were John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, William S. Cohen of Maine, James M. Jeffords of Vermont, Robert W. Kasten Jr. of Wisconsin, Mark O. Hatfield and Bob Packwood of Oregon and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania.
Senators D'Amato, Kasten, Packwood and Specter are up for re-election next year.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chief author of the bill to extend unemployment benefits, said: "The members of this body have an obligation to the working men and women of this country, those who are out of work in the third-longest recession since World War II. These are mothers and fathers who have a long-term commitment to the labor force."
"If the President is right, that the economy is going to surge and come out of this recession, then these benefits will not be paid," said Mr. Bentsen, the chairman of the Finance Committee. "These unemployed will be working at jobs and paying taxes and not drawing these benefits." On the other hand, he said, if the economy remains stalled, "these benefits put bread on the table and will help pay the mortgage, and they will help decent Americans hang in there until they can find jobs."
The bill would have provided from seven to 20 weeks of extra unemployment insurance benefits to jobless workers who have exhausted the basic 26 weeks of benefits. The number of extra weeks of benefits available under the bill depended on the severity of unemployment in a given state. Thus, for example, the bill would have given 20 additional weeks of jobless benefits to workers in Michigan and West Virginia, 13 additional weeks of benefits to those in New York and California, and seven additional weeks to jobless workers in New Jersey and Texas.
 
Many Reasons for Opposition
 The Administration dislikes the bill for many reasons, not least because it defies the Administration's confident predictions that the nation is recovering from the recession.
In vetoing the bill on Friday of last week, Mr. Bush said, "The Administration is deeply concerned about the needs of the unemployed and their families." But he complained that the measure would "destroy the integrity of the bipartisan budget agreement" reached in October of last year.
Mr. Bush said the bill "would significantly increase the Federal deficit," because Democrats had not found a way to pay for it, as required under the budget agreement.
The number of unemployed workers reached 8.4 million in September of this year, up from 7.1 million in Sept. 1990. The civilian unemployment rate, 6.7 percent last month, was a full percentage point higher than in Sept. 1990.
More than three million Americans used up their regular unemployment insurance benefits in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. The Government estimates that 3.4 million additional workers will exhaust their regular benefits in the coming year.
The bill vetoed by Mr. Bush was originally passed on Oct. 1 by votes of 65 to 35 in the Senate and 300 to 118 in the House of Representatives.
Democrats like Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the majority whip, said it was absurd for the President to cavil at the cost of the bill because there was already plenty of money in the Federal Unemployment Trust Fund, derived from taxes levied on employers.
"These benefits are already paid for," Mr. Bonior declared. "They have been paid for by insurance premiums taken out of the paychecks each month and put into a trust fund, set aside exactly for this purpose."
Mr. Bonior suggested that Mr. Bush and many other Republicans were "so dazzled by emergencies in Kurdistan or Turkey or the Soviet Union or Bangladesh that they are blind to the emegrencies of our own people right here at home."
In a preview of themes sure to be used by Democratic candidates for President and Congress, Mr. Bonior said of the benefits bill: "This is the issue that divides the Democrats from the Republicans. This is the issue that cuts at who we are and who they are."
Democrats, who control both houses of Congress, said today they would revise their proposal, pass it once again and send it to Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: Nonprofit Groups in Line For New Wall St. Home

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Wall Street, the profit center of New York City, would become a nonprofit center in the near future under a plan announced yesterday by the Dinkins administration.
Twenty floors in a 34-story office tower at 120 Wall Street, owned by Larry A. Silverstein, would become the Association Center, available for use as headquarters by national and international nonprofit organizations. The exodus of such organizations from New York is a source of worry at City Hall. 
 "There are more than 18,000 not-for-profit organizations in the City of New York and they account for more than 10 percent of all employment in this town," Mayor David N. Dinkins said. "This industry helps drive our economy, and, I am proud to say, no other city has set up this kind of facility to foster it."
What the organizations would receive from the plan are lower occupancy costs, with one year's free rent, among other concessions.
What Mr. Silverstein would receive is a higher occupancy rate for a 62-year-old building that overlooks the East River and is more than one-third empty. Some 225,000 square feet of space is available.
The center would eventually occupy 400,000 square feet in the 615,000-square-foot tower. Depending on tenants' needs, it might include conference rooms, classrooms, printing and mail services and a day-care center.
To reduce or eliminate real-estate taxes, the building would be divided into condominium units, and the city's Industrial Development Agency would take nominal title to the floors that make up the Association Center. That property would thus be tax-exempt. Mr. Silverstein would lease the space from the city and sublease it in turn.
Tenants might be liable for some payments in lieu of taxes, but the amount has not yet been determined. They would also benefit from the use of Industrial Development Agency bonds to finance basic office construction work, for which there would be an allowance of $35 a square foot. With the exemption of taxes, rents would be less than $20 a square foot in the first year of the lease, Mr. Silverstein said, a figure that "covers fully the operational costs of the building."
Tenants would pay their shares of increased operating costs over the life of the lease, as well as a share of the costs of common services.
As to how he could afford the year's free rent, Mr. Silverstein said through a spokeswoman, "It was one element among many in the negotiating process." She did not elaborate.
Rents for secondary office space in the eastern financial district have been about $22 a square foot, according to the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage.
The Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, said 120 Wall Street was chosen from 13 buildings because Mr. Silverstein's plan was the most responsive to a city request for proposals.
This is the second time in a decade that the city has tried to create an Association Center. The first was to have been a new building financed by the State Dormitory Authority. That effort foundered in 1982, when the authority was dragged down by the collapse of the Lombard-Wall financial concern, with which it had invested most of its portfolio.
 
Prospective Tenants Lost
 A number of prospective tenants for that center have left the city. According to the city's Economic Development Corporation, they include the Young Men's Christian Association, which went to Chicago; the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which moved to Baltimore; the American Cancer Society, which has gone to Atlanta, and the Presbyterian Church, which has gone to Louisville, Ky.
"Other large cities have been trying to steal our not-for-profit glitter," Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said yesterday as she addressed a meeting of the New York Society of Association Executives in the Drake Hotel. "Not any more, with this Association Center. I'm pleased to announce that the Association Center is up, airborne and, folks, I think it's going to fly."
The president of the executives' group, Joel A. Dolci, chose a different metaphor. "We've been thrown a life raft by the city," he said. "And we will be quick to reach for it."
The executive vice president and general manager of the Magazine Publishers of America, P. Robert Farley, stood up just after the announcement and said: "If anyone had bet me $1,000 three months ago that we'd be looking at a picture of the building, I'd have taken the bet. I have a date with the developer and agent for tomorrow afternoon to look at the building."
Mr. Farley said later that his group's lease at 575 Lexington Avenue would expire "in a couple of years" and that the group was looking for 12,000 to 16,000 square feet of space.

HEADLINE: Commissioner Of Labor Quits Post in Albany

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The State Labor Commissioner, Thomas F. Hartnett, is resigning to work as an arbitrator for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Mr. Hartnett and other Cuomo administration officials announced today.
Mr. Hartnett, who has been commissioner since 1987, plans to leave at the end of next week. His successor has yet to be chosen, but the officials said that John F. Hudacs, the State General Services Commissioner, is under consideration. 
 "He is clearly a contender for the job," one official said. "But this is not a done deal." The official said a decision is expected in a week or so.
 
Mediating Disciplinary Cases
 In his new job, Mr. Hartnett will serve as a mediator on disciplinary cases involving Transit Authority employees. The cases are heard by a three-member panel, with one member appointed by the Transit Authority, one by the Transport Workers Union and one a neutral member approved by both sides. Mr. Hartnett will be the neutral member.
The 46-year-old Commissioner said he would be paid about $75,000 a year in his new job. His state salary was nearly $92,000, but Mr. Hartnett said he would also be lobbying and negotiating labor contracts as a private consultant. State law prohibits public employees from lobbying or appearing before their former agencies for two years.
As labor commissioner, Mr. Hartnett has overseen the gradual conversion of the state's unemployment offices into community centers where labor-related services are provided on issues ranging from health and safety to literacy.
 
Backed Child Labor Bill
 He lobbied for a child labor bill that became law this year. It placed restrictions on the number of hours children can work while in school.
He also backed legislation in 1989 that raised unemployment insurance payment levels and he represented Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in several recent labor disputes, including those at The New York Post and The New York Daily News.

HEADLINE: New York Urged to Improve Tourist Services

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Warning that the New York City tourist industry is being threatened by competition from other American cities as well as by the erosion of the city as a gateway from Europe, a study by the Urban Research Center of New York University has suggested a variety of improvements.
They include a direct rail service from New York to Newark International Airport and the adoption of a year-round tourist policy rather than one based on attracting political conventions and other high-profile events with short impact. The study also suggests that hotels and retailers sponsor shopping trips for tourists and that arts institutions sponsor cultural weekends. 
 The report, "Tourism in New York City: Threats and Opportunities," is scheduled for release at a conference on tourism this afternoon at N.Y.U. It was written by the director of the research center, Prof. Mitchell L. Moss, and Georgia Manganaris-Decavalales.
 
Diversity Helps and Hurts
 In the report and in an interview, Professor Moss said New York remained a strong tourist city. But its very diversity is a source of strength and weakness. "It enhances the appeal of New York," the report said. "But it also requires greater effort and skill to consume the activities that New York has to offer."
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, deputy mayor for finance and economic development, who has not seen the report, said the Dinkins administration was "working closely with all the agencies involved in encouraging tourism and is supportive of a much more aggressive marketing program for the city, in the boroughs as well as Manhattan."
"But we always welcome creative approaches and new ideas," she added.
A spokesman for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Steven E. Trombetti, endorsed the recommendation for cultural and shopping weekends. He said 25 million people visited the city last year, adding that despite a weak economy this year, "we're predicting an increase of maybe 3 or 4 percent."
 
Attracting Foreign Tourists
 The report emphasizes foreign tourism, which it says is growing at a much faster annual rate than the domestic segment. Noting that about half of all foreign travel to the city originates in Europe, the report cites the need to attract visitors from Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe, especially because airline deregulation is eroding New York's pre-eminence as a gateway.
The city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey should focus on the role of foreign carriers, the report says. To attract international travelers, the study proposes rail service linking the Amtrak Northeast Corridor Line with Newark International Airport.
A spokesman for the Port Authority, Mark Marchese, said the suggestion was "highly questionable."
"Only 14.1 percent of Newark Airport patrons come from New York," he said. "And a lot of them are using buses."
The authors of the report said too little attention was given to information needed by foreign tourists, including information at subway stations and bus stops.

HEADLINE: Ticonderoga Journal;
A Mayor Who Protests That His Pay Is Too High

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TICONDEROGA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Just a few months into his term as Mayor here, Michael Diskin is in a major feud with Village Council members over his salary. But this is no garden-variety pay dispute. He says the council is giving him too much money.
"I feel the people are paying too much for what they are getting," said Mr. Diskin, who receives an annual salary of $10,500 for a 30-hour week. A few weeks ago he introduced a measure to the Village Board that would cut the job to a $3,500, 10-hour-a-week position. 
 The Council, which upgraded the salary in 1988, balked. It not only refused to cut the salary, but it also passed a resolution effectively ordering him to be at the Village Hall from 9 to noon and 1 to 4 every weekday, even if he felt that he had nothing to do.
"So maybe Mike doesn't want to sit around in an office 30 hours a week," a Council member, Paul Salstead, said. "I really don't blame the man. But he ran to be in the office, and he should be there."
Many residents in this Adirondack village in the area bridging Lake George and Lake Champlain say Mr. Diskin is a local hero or, as one admirer put it, perhaps even a potential tourist attraction, somewhat akin to a five-legged cow: come and see the bureaucrat who tells the world that he is underworked and overpaid.
But others here are skeptical of his pronouncement. They describe it as either a case of mayoral disgruntlement that the job is taking too much time from his real livelihood, a metal-salvage shop he runs out of his front yard on Champlain Avenue, or a clever political ploy.
Mr. Diskin does appear to have the best of both worlds right now. Railing against the Council's fiscal irresponsibility for refusing to cut his pay, the Mayor continues to collect the full salary on what he calls a point of principle. As long as the council forces him to be at the Village Hall for 30 hours a week, making him a hostage of sorts, he says he certainly should be paid for it.
Paradoxically one of the things that Council members say should keep Mr. Diskin occupied is a study that the village is conducting on dissolving itself and merging services into the surrounding Township of Ticonderoga. If there is a merger, of course, there would be no more Mayor and no more Council, and no one would be paid anything. Mr. Diskin said he was still weighing the matter, but might well come to the conclusion that his services as mayor are not needed at all.
For the moment, though, the controversy over how much to pay the 43-year-old Mr. Diskin continues and he comes to work -- grudgingly -- even though he frequently complains of boredom. He seemed genuinely grateful to have a visitor at his office the other day; he was so far ahead on his work, he said, that he had just finished writing a proclamation thanking a local doctor even though it would not be issued for another month and a half.
"This requirement to just sit there and wait for something to happen kind of goes against my grain," Mr. Diskin said. "I don't like to be idle."
Many Ticonderogans agree that the controversy has also provided a refreshing diversion from the usual subjects of conversation in this village of 2,700, which has an economy largely dependent on nearby mills and annual attractions that include the International Festival of Paper and Pencil.
The pay dispute is apparently not a partisan issue. The Mayor is a Republican, as is virtually everyone in the drama. But it has stirred many people to take sides.
Dale (Freshy) Wallace, owner of Freshy's Donuts, described the dispute as comical, but added that he thought the Mayor had a point. "I mean, if Mike says he can do it for less, I think I'd take Mike's word for it," Mr. Wallace said.
On the other hand, as Candy Geiser, a waitress at Bob's TV Bar and Restaurant put it, many people wondered "whether there was some kind of catch" when the Mayor started campaigning to reduce his salary. But if there was, she said, "I haven't been able to figure it out."
Council members say that with a $1.6 million budget and 21 employees to oversee, there is plenty of work for the Mayor to do.
Hazel Flack, the previous mayor who lost to Mr. Diskin in her race for re-election in March and who supported the salary increase, said there were many good reasons to have a full-time mayor.
"I think it saved us from a lot of lawsuits, frankly," Mrs. Flack said. "I had people call me up all the time really furious about something and I could say, 'Come right down and let's talk about it.' "
Mrs. Flack, who is running for town supervisor, dismisses Mr. Diskin's plea for a lower salary as a stunt that he may use if he ever campaigns against her again.
But the Mayor says that with all those other full-time employees on the payroll, his main task is to make sure that they are doing their jobs, and that certainly does not require 30 hours a week, he said.
"There's no trick here," he said, leaning back in his office chair and smiling broadly. "I'm really not a politician. I know it sounds like a cliche, but I've just got to be me, and I say what I think. And I think it's an injustice to spend all that money on a mayor."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Michael Diskin of Ticonderoga, N.Y., left, wants the Village Council to cut his salary and the number of hours a week he works. He spoke with Jane Borho, a candidate for the Council. (Nancie Battaglia for The New York Times)
