HEADLINE: The Sputtering California Miracle

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16

 BODY:
California, a big engine of growth during the 1980's, is turning out to be an economic caboose in 1991, as it suffers from consistently high unemployment, a weakening real estate market and troubles in key industries like aerospace,
While many other parts of the country appear to be pulling out of the recession, economists here said California might not yet have hit bottom. Even after it does, they said, myriad problems are likely to dampen the strength of its recovery. 
 "It's arguable that the U.S. economy is in the early stages of a modest economic recovery, but California is still locked in a recession," said Mark Green, an economist at Wells Fargo & Company in San Francisco. "The recovery in California, once it gets going, may not be as strong as on the national level."
California's troubles are already rocking the state's big banks. With fewer businesses being formed or expanding, developers can no longer find tenants to fill office buildings and shopping centers. That is adding up to large and growing losses on real estate loans and investments.
The Los Angeles-based Security Pacific Corporation, the state's second-largest bank, posted a $508.5 million loss for the third quarter on Tuesday, and the company said it expected loan losses to remain high in the fourth quarter, largely because of problems in California.
"The California economy appears to be lagging a very slow national economic recovery, and the timing and the strength of the recovery in California is uncertain," said Robert H. Smith, Security Pacific's chairman.
But its very size makes the state's economy an issue far beyond California's borders. If California were a country, its economy would be the world's eighth largest, ranking just behind Britain and ahead of China and Canada. As measured by personal income, California accounts for 13.3 percent of the national economy. By that yardstick, the state is more than a third larger than No. 2 New York and is more than twice as large as all of New England.
As a result, the lingering California recession is clearly putting a crimp in the national economy's sputtering attempts at revival.
Being the laggard is a sharp role reversal for California. The state has typically not suffered as much as the rest of the country in downturns. The only other time the state has fared worse than the nation as a whole since World War II was in 1970, when deep cuts in military spending led to widespread unemployment in the aerospace industry.
California's economy boomed during most of the last decade, spurred by high rates of home and commercial real estate construction, the growth of Pacific Rim trade, big new Pentagon contracts for aerospace and weapons companies and a rapid growth in population. These strengths helped keep it strong through much of last year as the rest of the country slipped into recession.
But early this year, the downturn finally arrived here -- and with a vengeance. By some key measures, the state has been hit harder by the recession than the nation as a whole. The unemployment rate jumped to 7.7 percent last month from 7.3 percent in August, while the national rate declined to 6.7 percent in September from 6.8 percent in August. Unemployment for both California and the nation peaked in June, with the state rate standing at 8.2 percent and the national rate at 7 percent.
 
Picture Becomes Gloomier
 This month California officials said the state had lost many more jobs in the recession than previously estimated. They said employment declined by 240,000 jobs from mid-1990 to mid-1991 rather than by 35,000, as previously announced.
And the Ccommission on State Finance cut its estimate of personal income growth for 1991 to 2.5 percent from 4.5 percent, a level it said was "the weakest in recent history." Officials said the economic problems helped push state tax receipts for the three months ended September to 3.7 percent below projections, raising the possibility of another fiscal crisis just months after officials increased taxes and slashed spending to close a budget gap. The Wall Street firm of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company recently projected that the state is in danger of losing its triple-A bond rating.
"Clearly, California is in a much steeper recession than we imagined back in March or April," said Kathleen Brown, the State Treasurer.
California continues to enjoy many strengths, and most economists expect it to bounce back eventually and outperform most of the rest of the country over the next decade.
Despite some recent signs that migration into the state is slackening, population growth remains robust, creating considerable demand for new housing, services and consumer products. A steady flow of new immigrants has provided the state with wave after wave of entrepreneurs as well as skilled and unskilled laborers. The state will remain a primary gateway not just to the Pacific Rim, but to Mexico, with which the United States is negotiating a free trade agreement. Few states can match the technological resources found in Silicon Valley and in California's computer, aerospace and biotechnology companies.
But this time around, California is being battered simultaneously on a number of fronts, and the problems keep getting worse instead of better.
"We had hoped that if the U.S. economy were pulling out of recession by May, California would be showing signs of growth by now," said David G. Hensley, head of the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles. "There are no signs to support that. To the contrary, new signs of weakness have emerged."
Real estate, perhaps the clearest gauge of the state's economic health, remains moribund. The pace of new-home construction is depressed. Existing-home sales rallied earlier this year but have eased despite falling prices and low mortgage rates.
New offices buildings that were started during the boom are now opening, at the same time that banks, law firms and other service businesses are retrenching, sending commercial real estate vacancy rates to distressing levels in many cities. In downtown Los Angeles, for example, the office vacancy rate stood at 22.6 percent as of June 30, up from 15.7 percent a year earlier, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial real estate firm.
 
The Battered Banks
 All of this has meant big problems for the state's banks.
Security Pacific, which is in the process of merging with the San Francisco-based BankAmerica Corporation, is just one of the California financial institutions battered by the problems in commercial real estate. The merger, which the two banks said is still on track, is intended to make the banks stronger and more dominant throughout the West. But it will do little to help the California economy, at least initially. In fact, analysts expect the merged companies to cut thousands of jobs in California as they close branches and combine back-office operations.
Other banks are also suffering. Wells Fargo said on Tuesday that it had added $350 million to its provision for anticipated loan losses, most of them real estate-related and that it had written off another $123 million in bad loans. As a result, Wells Fargo said its earnings for the period were down 47 percent from last year's third quarter, to $163 million.
The First Interstate Bancorp, based in Los Angeles, is expected to post a $200 million loss, largely because of commercial real estate problems in California, when it releases its third-quarter results later this month. The bank said last month that it would have to lay off 1,500 people last month.
 
Military and Farm Losses
 California has already lost tens of thousands of jobs in the aerospace and military field because of declining military spending. And just when some analysts thought the worst was past, a new round of cuts is in the works. President Bush's recent cancellation of several nuclear weapons programs led the Rockwell International Corporation to lay off 400 workers last week, and the Northrop Corporation would have to eliminate thousands of jobs if Congress, as many analysts expect, cancels the B-2 Stealth bomber program.
Other sectors of the economy are at risk, as well. Farmers in California, the nation's largest agricultural producers, remain endangered by a drought now heading into its sixth year, though there was just enough rain this year to postpone a crisis.
The state has brought some of its problems on itself. High labor rates and land costs, combined with strict environmental controls, are pushing some companies to relocate some of their operations outside the state. The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, for example, has decided that it will not build its next commercial jetliner at its huge plant in Long Beach.
"Short term, it's a very bleak picture for our state," Ms. Brown said. "In the long run, our growing population will really fuel our strengths in the decades to come. But to be truly competitive, we need an attitude check about how we regard business and industry in our state, and we need to be more thoughtful about retaining jobs and growing new jobs."

An article in Business Day yesterday about the California economy misstated Wells Fargo & Company's earnings and provision for loan losses in the third quarter. Earnings totaled $86 million, down 47 percent from $163 million, and the provision was $200 million, not $350 million.

HEADLINE: Weld Denting Massachusetts' Liberal Framework

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
In nine months in office, Gov. William F. Weld has begun a profound transformation of Massachusetts, a state long regarded as a bastion of liberalism, the only state to vote for George S. McGovern for President.
After years of fiscal chaos here, Mr. Weld, the state's first Republican Governor in 16 years, has managed to win passage of a a budget with no new taxes. His budget for the fiscal year 1992, which started in July, even cut spending by 6 percent, making Massachusetts the only state to reduce spending from the previous year. 
 To his supporters, Mr. Weld is a conservative savior. To his critics, the 46-year-old Mr. Weld, a descendant of a founder of Harvard College in 1636, is a callous patrician who has cut benefits to the poor and reduced state aid to education in a single-minded quest to make government smaller.
But the real Mr. Weld is more complex, a politician who defies labels, a blend of libertarian and liberal. To some of his closest friends, he is seen as a new-age political leader.
"Bill Weld is totally locked into the concerns of the baby boomers," said Charles Manning, a Republican consultant who serves as an adviser to the Governor. "Anyone who tries to characterize him as conservative or liberal is missing the picture."
Mr. Weld jokingly refers to himself as a "filthy supply-sider," an apostle of Ronald Reagan's economics. But he is also pushing, for example, for a bill that would require tough standards for packaging materials, a measure backed by environmental groups and opposed by businesses.
On crime, Governor Weld likes to describe himself as "to the right of Attila the Hun," and he is working to restore the death penalty and end parole for prisoners. But he recently introduced a package of bills to liberalize the state's stringent abortion laws, including a proposal to lower the age until which a teen-ager requires parental consent to 16 from 18.
 
Starts Pilot Condom Program
 Mr. Weld has also said he would oppose any effort to repeal the state's homosexual-rights law. And under his direction, state health officials started a pilot program in 10 communities that makes condoms available in schools and community agencies to teen-agers.
But at the same time he has won praise from national conservative groups, like the Reason Foundation in California, for initiating a plan to contract with businesses to perform what are normally state functions and to sell state agencies to private enterprise. As a first step, in an executive action last month, he hired a Florida concern to provide medical services to the state's 9,300 prison inmates. He calculates that the change will eliminate 400 employees from the state payroll and save about $10 million annually. Mr. Weld hopes eventually to sell the Massachusetts Turnpike to a private owner who would operate it for the tolls. This would require legislative approval.
"I'm not opposed to all government," the tall, red-haired Mr. Weld said in a recent interview in his office. He said he recognized the need for government to preserve public security, foster economic development and "make sure that the safety net is there for people who cannot help themselves."
But he believes that Massachusetts residents became spoiled by what he calls "the Cadillac style" of government services provided by his Democratic predecessors. Massachusetts, for instance, is second only to New York in the amount it spends on welfare, $765 a person a year as against the national average of $423, according to the United States Census Bureau. New York spends an average of $824.
Given a state economy that is in its worst slump since the Great Depression, with 10 percent of the work force having lost jobs over the past three years, Mr. Weld asserts that the Cadillac must be traded in for a Chevrolet.
When Mr. Weld took office last January, he at first clashed openly with the leaders of the Democratic-controlled Legislature who opposed his drastic budget cuts. But Mr. Weld's insistence that the only way to balance the budget was through cuts rather than new taxes prevailed, and he has now forged a good working relationship with the Legislature.
Mr. Weld's first budget reduced state spending to $12.9 billion, from $13.7 billion in the fiscal year 1991. He cut 3,962 workers from the state payroll of 72,000, cut $400 million out of the state's $2.4 billion Medicaid program, and reduced the amount of financing the state provides to cities and towns for education, police and other services, by 11 percent, according to state budget figures.
 
Cuts Aid of Last Resort
 Last week, Mr. Weld proudly signed a new law that will end weekly payments averaging $330 to one-third of the 38,000 residents who had been on General Relief, the state's welfare program of last resort.
But advocates for the poor and for public education have been growing increasingly critical of Mr. Weld. Bernard Cardinal Law, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston who has also assailed the Governor for his abortion stance, told worshipers at a recent church service, "There's a mean-spiritedness abroad in our land."
James Braude, the executive director of the Tax Equity Alliance for Massachusetts, a public interest group, accused Mr. Weld of deception in pretending that his cuts had not hurt people. Mr. Braude pointed to the Governor's elimination of state aid to low-income families to help them pay their fuel bills. The legislation cut all assistance to 7,000 families and reduced benefits to more than 30,000 other people.
Mark Roosevelt, a Democratic State Representative and chairman of the House Committee on Education, asserted that the reason that Mr. Weld has been able to carry out his cutbacks is that he is "an incredibly cold and aloof person."
Because of the cut in state aid, the city of Holyoke has reduced its school budget 25 percent this year, laying off 221 teachers, or 36 percent of the total teaching staff. The result is that some schools have classes with up to 40 students.
"There is no teaching going on; it is just caretaking," said Mr. Roosevelt, who lives in Boston. "I don't know what Weld's tax cuts are going to do to prepare our children for the future."
But many other politicians believe that Mr. Weld has given Massachusetts voters, angered by years of rising taxes and fiscal gridlock in the State House, precisely what they asked for in last November's election. "He is giving people confidence in the Commonwealth again," said Lucile P. Hicks, a Republican State Senator.
 
'A Working Government'
 Peter Lucas, a spokesman for State Representative Charles Flaherty, a Democrat who is Speaker of the House, said Mr. Weld "has re-established a working government," after several years in which Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a Democrat, and the leaders of the Legislature came close to paralysis. "The atmosphere is much better," Mr. Lucas said. "You can sense it."
Mr. Weld has stumbled a few times. He tried, unsuccessfully, to get a major pay raise for his new Cabinet officers, when other state employees have had their wages frozen for two years, raising charges that he was too upper class.
But Mr. Weld, who is the son of a wealthy investment banker, has developed a relaxed -- some say nonchalant -- style that has kept him from becoming obsessed with criticism.
"Bill is easy going and doesn't sit there and let steam come out of his ears," said John Moffitt, the chief secretary of his Cabinet. In part this is because Mr. Weld knows that "criticism comes with the territory," Mr. Moffitt said, adding that it is also because "he is very secure and has a good family life."
Mr. Weld and his wife, Susan, have five children, all of whom attend private schools.
 
Making Fun of Himself
 Mr. Weld does not mind poking fun at himself, and on the conference table in his office he keeps a stuffed armadillo. "They are extremely slow and dumb animals, and I'm just fond of them," he said.
On the wall behind his desk, where Governor Dukakis had a portrait of Sam Adams, the hero of the Revolution, Mr. Weld has installed a portrait of James Michael Curley, the longtime Congressman, Governor of Massachusetts and Boston Mayor, who last held office in 1950, and who was sent to jail on corruption charges.
It seems a strange selection. Mr. Curley was the archetype of the Democratic Irish Catholic politician who made a career out of campaigning against Yankee bluebloods like Mr. Weld. Moreover, Mr. Weld was a United States Attorney in Boston and later, an Assistant United States Attorney General in charge of the criminal division.
Why then pick the Curley painting? "He was a man of the people and I'm intrigued by the guy," Mr. Weld replied, deadpan, relishing the mischief in his choice.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Thursday about Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts misstated the frequency of payments being denied to some welfare recipients under a law signed by the Governor. They are monthly, not weekly.

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 798 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
2 Key Statistics Are Due to Shift

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the American economy in a recovery, a recession or a no man's land? The answer is not easy to come by because economic statistics lag behind current events and because data on past growth or contraction are complex, crude and continually being revised.
For instance, the first estimate by the Commerce Department of real gross national product -- total output adjusted for inflation -- for the second quarter had the economy growing at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent. Hats went off to hail the recovery. The second estimate moved that figure down to one-tenth of 1 percent, and some economists, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, said the recession was over but the recovery had not yet begun. 
 Then department's third revision put the growth rate of real G.N.P. down further, to minus five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, provoking worries that the economy was still in recession.
But that is not the end of the changing picture. Two new sets of data, to be released in late November, will indicate that the recovery did begin in the second quarter after all.
The first is an updated version of the price index used to correct G.N.P. for inflation, shifting the base year of the index to 1987 from 1982. Periodic updates of the "G.N.P. deflator" are necessary as inflation or deflation affects different goods differently over the years, and the mix of goods that make up total national output changes. A price deflator based on outdated weights for different goods and services would distort the calculation.
Using the new 1987-base G.N.P. deflator, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis finds in a preliminary study that instead of falling at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, as measured in constant 1982 dollars, real G.N.P. rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, when measured in 1987 dollars.
When the department releases its first estimate of the just-completed third quarter on Oct. 29, real G.N.P. will still be measured on the old 1982 price base. The new figures for real G.N.P. on the 1987 price base will not be released until Nov. 26.
In addition to shifting from 1982 to 1987 dollars, the department's second change will be to emphasize gross domestic product, rather than gross national product, as the primary measure of the national economy. G.D.P. is already used by almost all countries as the main indicator of growth.
G.D.P. covers the goods and services "produced by labor and property located in the United States," while G.N.P. measures the market value of goods and services produced by property and labor "supplied by United States residents," whether the production is here or abroad.
Thus, G.D.P. measures the value of goods and services produced within the United States, while G.N.P. includes the profits or other income received by Americans overseas. Production by, say, Toyota or Siemens in plants in the United States is included in America's G.D.P., but I.B.M.'s or General Motors' earnings brought back from Japan or Germany do not count in United States G.D.P. although they do count in G.N.P.
G.D.P. is considered by the Commerce Department the better measure of what is happening within the American economy, since income flows to businesses or residents of this country from abroad are influenced mainly by economic developments in the rest of the world. No measure gives all one wants to know; the Commerce Department will continue to report on both G.D.P. and G.N.P.
Though new official data for G.D.P. will not be introduced until late November, preliminary estimates by the Commerce Department show that real G.D.P., measured in constant 1982 dollars, rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in the second quarter of 1991, even more than the revised figures for G.N.P. in 1987 dollars now indicate.
The evidence is that the recovery is in motion, but slow motion. An Experimental Index of Coincident Indicators, developed by the leading mapper of the business cycle, the National Burerau of Economic Research, points to continuing but slowing economic growth. This slowdown in the rise of the so-called X.C.I., the bureau says, reflects the modest growth in industrial production and the net declines in real personal income and employee-hours of work during July and August. The figures released yesterday by the Government on industrial production, capacity use, trade and inflation confirm this picture of a weakening recovery.
The economy is shaping up as the key election issue. This week President Bush narrowly defeated Democrats' efforts to override his veto of the bill to extend unemployment benefits, but called a meeting of Republican leaders to discuss tax cuts and other measures to spur the economy.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in U.S. Trading After Some Gains Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower against most leading currencies in domestic trading yesterday after posting some gains overseas.
Gold prices rose, with gold for current delivery gaining $1.80 an ounce to close at $360 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Later, the Republic National Bank of New York quoted an after-hours bid of $360 an ounce, up $2.30 from Wednesday. 
 Analysts said the dollar's mixed showing reflected confusion about the prospects for interest rates as a result of a new report that showed inflation in the United States was unexpectedly strong in September.
The Government said consumer prices jumped four-tenths of 1 percent last month in the biggest inflation spurt since January. That was about twice the increase many economists were expecting.
The report initially sent the dollar higher on European markets and in early American dealings, as it appeared to dim chances that the Federal Reserve would move promptly to encourage lower interest rates.
The Fed generally tries to encourage economic growth with lower rates but has hesitated to drive rates lower when inflation appears to be accelerating.
The inflation report was one of several Government reports released yesterday, however, and the others indicated that the economy remained sluggish. Industrial production rose a lackluster one-tenth of a percent in September, while the United States merchandise trade deficit widened dramatically, to $6.8 billion, as overseas demand for American products dropped.
Kevin Lawrie, the head of strategic trading in the foreign exchange division at the Bank of Boston, called the reports "an avalanche of news" that did not warrant a big move up in the dollar.
While the inflation report could ward off an immediate cut in rates, he said, most traders still expected a decline in interest rates by the end of the year.
The dollar finished at 129.45 yen in New York, compared with 130.10 yen late on Wednesday. That was lower than its close earlier in the day of 129.53 yen in Tokyo, which was down from 130.02 yen on Wednesday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 129.75 yen.
The dollar also finished lower in New York against the British pound. The pound rose to $1.7175 in New York, from $1.7070 late on Wednesday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.7090, from $1.7105 late on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Wednesday, included: 1.6965 German marks, down from 1.7060; 1.4815 Swiss francs, down from 1.4905; 5.7760 French francs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BankAmerica Net Higher Than Expected

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation today reported third-quarter earnings above what Wall Street analysts had expected, despite the recession. The bank also said its merger with the Security Pacific Corporation was proceeding according to plan in spite of that bank's higher- than-expected losses for the quarter.
For the quarter, BankAmerica said it earned $285 million, or $1.20 a share, up 1 percent from $283 million, or $1.26 a share, in the period a year ago. The 5 percent decrease in per share figures primarily reflects a 3 percent gain in the number of common shares outstanding, to 221.7 million. 
 Analysts had estimated that the bank would earn about $1.12 a share. BankAmerica shares closed today at $42.75, down $1.625, on the New York Stock Exchange after closing up $2.125 yesterday.
"BankAmerica achieved solid results in the third quarter, despite the continued weak economy and in a period of intense activity and change for the corporation," Richard M. Rosenberg, BankAmerica's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. "Growth in net interest income, coupled with effective management of expenses, helped keep the corporation's financial performance on track."
The bank decreased its provision for loan losses, a key benchmark for loan performance, to $210 million from $260 million in the period a year ago. But the provision was substantially above the $175 million taken in the second quarter of this year, and above most analysts' estimates as well.
"The loan-loss provision was relatively high," said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in San Francisco. The higher-than-expected provision "is clearly a function of the recession; that will probably continue to be a drain," he said. But the bank's fundamentals and financial results remain strong, particularly relative to other large banks at this time, he said.
Frank Newman, BankAmerica's chief financial officer, said at a news conference that the provision reflected some increase in bad loans, but also some internal reclassification of loans that was not disclosed. He said the bank had not seen any improvement in commercial and consumer loan performance that would indicate a recovery in the economy. "In some sectors we see status quo -- no further deterioration -- but we don't see much improvement either," he said.
Security Pacific took a $1.21 billion loan-loss provision earlier this week, rather than the $1 billion provision it had been expected to take. Mr. Newman reiterated that this would not affect the merger proceedings and would help bring Security Pacific's classification of the bank's loan portfolio in accord with BankAmerica's own policy. "Nothing about that provision at all changed our assessment of the transaction," Mr. Newman said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Gannett Profit Declines 25.1%

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Gannett Company, publisher of 87 daily newspapers including USA Today, said yesterday that its net income dropped 25.1 percent in the third quarter.
The Arlington, Va., company said it earned $59.5 million, or 42 cents a share, in the quarter, down from $79.4 million, or 50 cents, a year earlier. 
 Gannett, which also operates 10 television stations, 15 radio stations and owns the nation's largest outdoor advertising business, said the recession affected advertising spending disproportionately, hitting all its units.
Newspaper advertising revenues fell 3 percent in the quarter, while circulation revenues rose 6 percent, the company said. Broadcasting revenue fell 12 percent.
Over all, Gannett said, its third-quarter revenues totaled $819.7 million, down 1.2 percent from $829.9 million a year earlier.
Gannett's shares lost 75 cents yesterday to close at $39.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Weakens With Increase of Only 0.1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Industrial production weakened in the third quarter, the Government said today, and analysts called it a sign of fading momentum in manufacturing, which had been leading the nation out of recession.
"There is a real question as to whether the solid recovery on the industrial side of the economy will persist as we move into the fourth quarter," said Allen Sinai, an economist with the the Boston Company. 
 The Federal Reserve said output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose an anemic one-tenth of 1 percent in September after showing no change at all from a month earlier.
The Fed attributed the September output gain entirely to a 7.7 percent gain in motor vehicle production. Excluding automobile and truck output, production actually fell two-tenths of 1 percent.
Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, suggested the growth in the automotive component would not continue. "Due to slackening car sales, Detroit already is cutting back production of 1992 models," he said.
President Bush cited the report as one of several recent economic trends that look good, saying industrial production "has risen for five straight months."
In an accompanying report on capacity utilization, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities slipped one-tenth of a percentage point, to 79.7 percent.
After falling for six months through March, industrial production rebounded from the recession, including a 9 percent gain in May. It remained at 8 percent in June before slowing to 6 percent in July.
At the same time, the housing sector and consumer spending remained sluggish, leading many analysts to suggest the industrial sector was in the unusual role of leading the economic recovery. But the flat performance in August showed output was weaker than first thought.
Production at factories manufacturing both durable and nondurable goods advanced five-tenths of 1 percent in September after remaining flat in August and rising eight-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Durable goods output gained eight-tenths of 1 percent after falling one-tenth of 1 percent a month earlier. These are usually expensive goods ranging from cars to computers that are expected to last more than three years.
Production of nondurable goods like chemicals and clothing were flat, however, following a two-tenths of 1 percent advance in the previous month.
Mining output lost another nine-tenths of 1 percent after plummeting 1.2 percent in August. Utility production plunged 2.5 percent after a four-tenths of 1 percent gain.
The Fed said its industrial production index in September stood at 108.1 percent of its 1987 base of 100.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Times Co. Says Its Income Dropped 79% in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter fell 79 percent, to $1.9 million, or 3 cents a share, from $9.2 million, or 12 cents a share, for the third quarter of 1990.
Revenue for the quarter dropped 6.5 percent, to $393.4 million from $420.7 million. 
 The company said the principal reason for the drop was a continuing decline in advertising linage at The New York Times because of the national recession and New York City's weak economy.
Profit for the newspaper group, consisting of The New York Times, 32 regional papers and a 50 percent interest in The International Herald Tribune, fell to $10.1 million on revenues of $289.8 million from $19.6 million on revenues of $320.6 million.
Advertising linage at The New York Times in the third quarter declined 16.4 percent from the period in 1990.
 
Market Share Gained
 The advertising categories hurt most were help wanted, down 47 percent, and real estate, down 24 percent. But the company said it had gained market share in both categories and remained the market leader.
The company said that daily and Sunday circulation reached record highs in the quarter.
For the six months ended Sept. 30, The Times reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations an average daily circulation of 1,114,800, a gain of 6,400, and Sunday circulation of 1,700,800, an increase of 13,800.
Circulation at the company's 32 regional newspapers was also up slightly, while advertising linage for the group declined 5.1 percent in the quarter from the 1990 quarter.
The company's magazine group reported an improvement in operating performance for the quarter with a loss of $900,000 on revenues of $85.3 million, compared with a loss of $2.3 million on revenues of $81.1 million a year ago.
Lower costs associated with the July 1989 acquisition of McCall's magazine were given as the principal reason for the improved results.
 
Broadcast Operations
 The company's broadcast operations had an operating profit for the quarter of $2.9 million on revenues of $18.2 million, compared with profits of $3.3 million on revenues of $19.1 million for the quarter in 1990.
After-tax earnings in the forest products group were $1.5 million, compared with $2.4 million for the quarter last year. The decline was attributed to higher discounts on newsprint and an unfavorable Canadian currency exchange rate.
In August, the company and the Kimberly-Clark Corporation agreed in principle to give their shares in the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company to the company's employees.
Net interest expense rose to $7.7 million for the quarter, compared with $4.8 million last year at this time. The increase came principally because interest on a new plant in Edison, N.J., which was completed in 1990, is now being added to current interest expenses. Previously it was added to the cost of building the plant.
The company said the highly automated color printing plant in Edison would not begin operating until current labor negotiations with several unions were resolved. Depreciation of the building began in 1989, but depreciation of the equipment will not begin until the plant goes into operation.
In American Stock Exchange trading yesterday, the share price of The New York Times class A common stock was unchanged at $20. The earnings were released after the market closed.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened In August

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
After shrinking sharply in the first half of 1991, the merchandise trade deficit swelled in August as foreigners unexpectedly slowed their buying of American goods.
The deficit widened by $1 billion, to $6.8 billion, its highest level in seven months. It had dropped as low as $3.8 billion in June. 
 Trade deficits typically widen in economic recoveries as Americans buy more imported goods. Economists had been expecting imports to climb in August, but they also anticipated exports would remain steady. The combination would have been a healthy sign for the United States recovery.
Instead, exports fell by about $1 billion, to $34.2 billion, and imports, at $40.9 billion, were basically flat. Exports had been hovering around a $35 billion since April.
 
Sense of Lost Momentum
 The drop in exports, along with a small rise recorded for industrial production in September, reinforced the worrisome sense that the economic recovery lost momentum after midsummer.
"It strengthens the case for lower interest rates," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services.
But while economists expect the trade deficit to widen further in coming months, they also expect the August pattern of declining exports and stagnant imports to change. "It's always very dangerous to overreact to one month's numbers," Mr. Hale said, referring to the bumpy nature of monthly trade data.
In particular, exports, which have been one of the economy's few bright spots, should resume their growth, several forecasters said.
 
'I Don't See Anything Wrong'
 "I don't see anything wrong with exports," said David Rolley, an international economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
Even with the August drop, exports are up 5 percent from a year earlier. And the details of the export report, Mr. Rolley said, were less discouraging. Capital goods exports, nearly 40 percent of United States exports, edged down to $13.3 billion because of slower aircraft deliveries. But they were still substantially higher than last winter.
Similarly, industrial materials exports, which encompass everything from perfume essences to paper, barely fell, slipping $60 million. And food shipments, which were supposed to decline with good harvests overseas, have remained within the range of $2.8 billion to $3.1 billion as they have been since January.
Auto exports did drop but the decline mostly reflected a slowdown in shipments of parts and subassemblies to plants in Canada and Mexico. Their decline, Mr. Rolley said, mostly reflects the cautious production plans of Detroit carmakers.
A pickup in growth abroad should help United States exports in coming months. Even though Germany and Japan are beginning to wheeze, Mr. Rolley said, the Britain and Canada are coming out of their recessions. And not only do American companies sell more to the latter two countries than the former, but the economic rebounds in Britain and Canada are also apt to be stronger than the slowdowns in Germany and Japan.
 
Imports Likely to Grow
 Imports are likely to grow faster than exports, Mr. Hale said, as the United States economy expands and business stops cutting inventories. Indeed, although they did not rise in August, imports are already $2 billion higher than they were in June.
Machinery and equipment imports fell by $500 million in August. But capital goods imports have been fluctuating along a flat trend all year, reflecting, most likely, flat capital equipment spending by American businesses.
What is noteworthy is that imports of industrial materials actually rose in August, as did imports of foreign cars, by a total together of nearly $900 million. And imports of other consumer goods, not including food -- which dipped from a very strong July level -- were still 7 percent higher than in June.
"What you're seeing is an import revival as the inventory cycle comes to an end," Mr. Rolley said. "Business has been meeting consumer demand out of inventories, so you didn't need to import much. That game's over."
Inventories, which were shrinking at roughly the rate of half a percentage point a month last winter and spring, basically held steady in July and August. Economists say the common explanation both for higher imports and September's five-tenths of a percent rise in factory production is that businesses have stopped depleting inventories.
This year's merchandise trade deficit, which has averaged $64 billion at an annual rate in the first eight months of 1991, is down sharply from last year's $102 billion.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Balance of Trade" shows U.S. imports and exports and trade deficit from 9/90 to 8/91 (Source: Commerce Dept.) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Are Up Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday, as investors dumped large amounts of Treasury securities after an unexpectedly bad inflation report was released by the Government.
In fact, the selloff began minutes before consumer price data were released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics at 8:30 A.M., Eastern daylight time. That led some traders to voice suspicions that the contents of the report had been leaked. 
 The report showed the Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of a percent in September, and four-tenths of a percent when energy and food prices are excluded.
The rise was about twice as large as most Wall Street economists had anticipated.
 
Sell Order Begin to Surface
 Traders said that at 8:28 sell orders began to appear at the Chicago Board of Trade, where Treasury bond futures are traded. The selling quickly spilled over into the cash market.
As a result of the selling, traders said that bond prices had fallen about 10/32 before the number was released.
"I can't prove it, but I think some guys had the number," one government bond trader said. "I think there should be an investigation."
Patrick Jackman, chief economist for the Consumer Price Index at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the sudden move in prices came to his attention early in the day.
"We did some extensive checking," Mr. Jackman said. "We don't know why the bond market reacted as if it had prior information. To the extent that we can determine, it wasn't because it was released early."
Mr. Jackman said that while release of the consumer price statistics is embargoed until 8:30 A.M., major news organizations, primarily television and radio stations, receive the report early.
"At least three times in the past couple of years news organizations have inadvertently released the information a couple of minutes early," he said.
Mr. Jackman said that based on his review the consumer price data released yesterday were not put on the air before the embargo was lifted.
Mr. Jackman said the policy of providing the information early to news organizations would be reviewed.
Bloated dealer inventories had much to do with the market's virulent reaction to the inflation report, analysts said. The numbers also appeared to erase the widely held notion that the Federal Reserve Board was on the verge of easing monetary policy.
"A Fed ease had been completely built in to the market's mind," one government bond trader said. "Now it appears there will be no ease for a month or so. With huge amounts of supply coming over the next few weeks, it is time to wake up and smell the coffee."
Between now and the middle of November dealers will be asked to place bids on around $50 billion worth of Treasury securities at a variety of debt sales, including the quarterly refunding auctions.
Samuel Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago, said: "The inflation report wasn't as bad as it appeared, and the market's reaction was overblown. But when investors are fully invested, they are vulnerable to adverse numbers."
Aside from the inflation report, market participants also reacted negatively to a report from the Federal Reserve Board that showed that all three aggregates of the nation's money supply rose much more sharply during the week ended Oct. 7 than analysts had anticipated.
The selloff in the secondary market for Treasury securities was most pronounced among long-term notes and bonds.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 1/4, down nearly 1 1/2 points, or just under $15 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.01 percent. Late Wednesday the benchmark bond was offered at a price to yield 7.87 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 1/8, down 29/32, to yield 7.56 percent. And prices of the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes fell by 7/32, to 100 9/32, to yield 5.96 percent.
Bids at an auction of one-year Treasury bills produced an average yield of 5.42 percent, down from an average rate of 5.26 percent at the last one-year bill sale on Sept. 19.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.05 percent, up 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 9 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.08 percent.
In its money report, the Fed said that all three monetary aggregates rose during the week ended Oct. 7.
M-2, the aggregate most closely monitored by the Fed, rose by $4.5 billion, a much bigger increase than expected.
But analysts said that even with the increase, M-2 growth since the fourth quarter of 1990 remains below the 2.5 percent increase that is the low end of the Fed's target growth range for the year.
"The rise suggests that M-2 growth will be flat to up slightly" in October, said Wayne Smith, an economist at Reid Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn., "But I don't see this signalling any improvement."

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. Loses $1.8 Billion; Other Phone Results Mixed

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
A.T.& T. and MCI, the nation's top long-distance companies, yesterday reported slow third-quarter revenue growth, with a huge loss at A.T.& T. because of one-time charges and an earnings gain at MCI. Three of the regional Bell operating companies reported mixed results, with profits off at Nynex and up at BellSouth and Southwestern Bell.
Analysts said A.T.& T.'s performance was surprisingly strong, despite the reported net loss of $1.8 billion. The loss was entirely attributable to previously reported one-time charges, mostly related to its acquistion of the NCR Corporation. MCI apparently gained a small amount of market share in the quarter, analysts said, but at the expense of smaller competitors.
The weak economy was apparent in both the volume of calling and the rate of new line installation reported by the three "Baby Bells." "From a telephone industry perspective, the recession is still with us," said Joel Gross, who follows the companies for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
A.T.& T.
 One-time charges resulting from the takeover of NCR reduced net income for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in the quarterby nearly $2.65 billion, producing a net loss of $1.8 billion, compared with combined profits for the two companies of $803 million, or 62 cents a share, a year ago. Combined revenues rose 1.2 percent, to more than $11.04 billion, from $10.91 billion in the third quarter of 1990.
Nearly all of A.T.& T.'s operating profits for the quarter came from the telephone business. The company's third-quarter net profits from what it owned before acquiring NCR rose 13.5 percent, to $808 million, from $712 million a year ago. About a fourth of that improvement was attributable to a one-time gain on the sale of Sun Microsystems stock. The rest came from strong operating revenues, including improved product and service margins.
By contrast, NCR's operating earnings were just $40 million on revenues of $1.38 billion, compared with $91 million on sales of $1.53 billion a year ago. A.T.& T. attributed the decline to "general softness" in computer markets and the negative impact of a stronger dollar.
"The good news in all these numbers is the continuing strength of A.T.& T.'s long-distance business and the strong actions we're taking for future earnings growth," said Robert E. Allen, A.T.& T.'s chairman and chief executive.
Phone service sales rose 5.1 percent, to $5.24 billion, on volume growth of 6.5 percent. The company said that "800" numbers, WATS services and international and residential calling led the growth. Product and systems sales declined 5.5 percent, to $3.81 billion, from 1990's third quarter, mostly because of a 17.3 percent decline in computer sales to $818 million.
Analysts believe A.T.& T., which is estimated to have between 63 and 65 percent of the long-distance market, has maintained that share.
A.T.& T.'s write-off will include the severance costs for 14,000 employees to be laid off by the beginning of 1994.
A.T.& T. shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $39, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
MCI
 The MCI Communications Corporation earned $133 million, or 51 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $176 million in the 1990 period, when the company took a one-time charge of $550 million for modernization of its network.
The Washington-based long-distance company's revenues were $2.15 billion, up 7.5 percent from $2 billion a year ago. The revenue gains came on a 12.4 percent increase in calling volume in the last year.
Excluding the impact of last year's special charge, MCI's third-quarter operating earnings in 1990 would have been $334 million, nearly 22 percent higher than the $274 million reported yesterday for the recently completed quarter. That gap highlights how heavily MCI has been spending on programs to build market share, particularly a promotion gives 20 percent discounts to customers who create a personal circle of telephone contacts, all using MCI. Marketing and operations expenses for the recent quarter were $645 million, up 21 percent from a year ago.
MCI's shares lost $3, to $27.125, in over-the-counter trading. The trading reflected, in addition to earnings, a report that I.B.M. was exploring the potential private sale of its $400 million in MCI preferred stock. I.B.M. said last night that the possible sale does not represent a loss of confidence in MCI.
 
Nynex
 The Nynex Corporation said that it earned $291.8 million, or $1.44 a share, in the quarter, down 1.7 percent from $296.7 million, or $1.50 a share, last year. Revenues for the White Plains, N.Y.-based parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone fell 3.5 percent, to $3.27 billion, from $3.39 billion a year ago.
Nynex's operating income actually rose 3.3 percent, to $600.2 million, from $580.9 million a year ago, but that increase did not compensate for a $24 million rise in taxes and interest expenses. Operating expenses were $2.67 billion, down nearly 5 percent from $2.81 billion a year ago.
Nynex is currently in the midst of a program to reduce both its hourly and managerial work forces. A one-time charge for the cost of the program will be estimated and taken against earnings in the current quarter, the company said yesterday.
Nynex's shares rose 12.5 cents, closing at $75.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
BellSouth
 The BellSouth Corporation, based in Atlanta, said net income fell 12.5 percent, to $352.4 million, or 73 cents a share, from $402.9 million, or 84 cents a share, a year ago. But the current quarter included $42.9 million in one-time charges for an early-retirement program and another $11.4 million charge stemming from accounting changes in the company's cellular telephone operations. Without the one-time charges, earnings were essentially unchanged from a year ago.
Revenues rose 2.3 percent, to $3.63 billion, from $3.55 billion a year ago. The number of access lines rose 2.9 percent, to 513,000, in the the last year.
BellSouth said that continuing rate reductions, a weak economy, competition and the costs of its rapidly expanding investment in cellular and paging services affected its earnings.
On the Big Board, BellSouth stock fell 37.5 cents, to $46.875.
 
Southwestern Bell
 The Southwestern Bell Corporation said that net income for the quarter rose 12.2 percent, to $363.1 million, or $1.21 a share, from $323.6 million, or $1.08 a share, a year ago.
The strong income gain came despite an increase of just more than 2 percent in revenues, to $2.42 billion, from $2.37 billion in the 1990 period.
"Strengthened performance by our cellular and Yellow Pages subsidiaries contributed substantially to our growth," said Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the St. Louis-based company's chairman and chief executive.
Analysts said the figures represented a mildly pleasant surprise.
Southwestern Bell stock rose 37.5 cents, to $56.375, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Dow Slips 8.72, Ending 5-Day Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
After scaling new peaks on Wednesday, stocks finished down yesterday, as falling bond prices and disappointing earnings halted the market's five-day rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 8.72 from Wednesday's record to 3,053, and the New York Stock Exchange composite was off by 0.25 to close at 215.80. 
 Blue-chip stocks were also weakened by the bond market, which collapsed on a stronger-than-expected consumer price number.
Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company, noted that the market's 115-point rise over the previous five sessions may have gotten a bit too much for the market in the face of inflation and a weak bond market.
"The economic data proved an excuse for some buyers to take a respite from the market," he said. Mr. Seagle said, however, that the Dow could reach the 3,150 and 3,200 levels before the end of the year, and even 3,400 by year's end, as a result of the Fed's easing of credit conditions.
 
Big Board Volume Heavy
 Volume on the Big Board was heavy at 206 million shares, but was down from 225.4 million shares traded on Wednesday. Losers outpaced gainers 846 to 776.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slipped 0.88, to 391.92, while the American Stock Exchange composite was off 0.80, to 381.11.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index was off 4.67 from Wednesday's high, to 536.27.
The stock market was under pressure from bonds most of yesterday, as the Dow took initial losses and recovered some by its close. Traders said the market's strong momentum going into yesterday might have limited the day's losses, as trading was choppy, and the Dow fluctuated within a 20-point range.
A surprisingly strong consumer price report raised concern that the Fed might delay easing rates, as weakness in technology and consumer product stocks also undermined the market. Some analysts called yesterday's market pullback "a healthy correction."
Technology stocks came under pressure after Digital Equipment's earnings came in at the low end of analysts' estimates. The stock fell by 3, to 57 1/4, while Microsoft fell 1 1/2 to close at 89 1/4 and Intel fell 1 3/4, to 43 5/8.
Traders said major airline issues traded down, as County NatWest USA downgraded the group to underperform from hold. UAL fell 1 3/8, to 134 5/8; AMR dropped by 1 1/8, to 64 1/2, and Delta Air Lines fell 1 1/2, to 68 1/2.
Analysts at Piper, Jaffray and Paine Webber repeated their buy recommendations on St. Jude Medical. The stock fell 2 7/8, to 49 7/8, after reporting earnings that were below Street expectations. The analysts called the selloff in the stock an overreaction. Edward Mutsch, analyst at Paine Webber, noted that the company returns 40 percent of every sales dollar to the bottom line, compared with about 5 cents at most other American companies.
AST Research, a manufacturer of personal computer systems, fell 4, to 28, after the company's first-quarter earnings dipped below some analysts' estimates, and it said it was cutting prices on its premium executive notebook line by 30 percent.
Citicorp and Wells Fargo shares were mixed, as George M. Salem, analyst at Prudential Securities, cut his earnings forecast on both banks. He was a little harder on Wells Fargo, which dropped 1 3/8, because he says the California commercial and residential real estate prices are in for a major downturn. Citicorp, which he did not reduce badly, led the active list and was up 1/4, to 12.

HEADLINE: Slack Credit Demand Seen

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Bankers told President Bush today that slack demand and not excess regulation was responsible for the slowdown in bank lending.
The message delivered to President Bush by a dozen banking executives at a White House meeting came a week after the Administration issued proposals intended to prod banks into making more loans. 
 The package would provide a new way for banks to appeal unfavorable examinations and ease other rules.
After today's meeting, bankers said they told President Bush that they welcomed the initiative but cautioned that it would not get at the root causes of the slow growth in bank lending that some analysts believe is holding back the economic recovery.
"Bankers are quite willing to extend credit, are eager to extend credit, to anyone that is halfway creditworthy," said John Medlin, chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C. "There is simply not the demand coming forward."
And Hugh McColl, chairman of the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said, "We told him we felt loan demand was very slack, that people were nervous."
Nevertheless, the bankers said Mr. Bush's proposals could contribute to easing the credit squeeze. Alan Tubbs, president of the American Bankers Association, said, "We felt his initiatives were certainly headed in the right direction."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
In a disturbing inflation report, consumer prices climbed 0.4 percent in September, the biggest increase since January, the Government reported. Prices for food and energy, which have been restraining the inflation rate for much of 1991, were two of the main factors pushing the index up. [Page A1.] Americans who receive Social Security benefits will get a 3.7 percent increase. [A10.]
The U.S. trade deficit swelled in August, after shrinking sharply in the first half of 1991. [D1.] 
 A free trade agreement would not lead many U.S. manufacturers to move operations to Mexico, the Administration said. [D2.]
The Business Roundtable has been meeting with Administration officials to bypass the S.E.C. in trying to prevent new rules for corporate shareholder battles. [D1.]
Industrial production weakened, the Government said, and analysts saw a sign of fading momentum in manufacturing. [D5.]
Michael R. Milken has admitted committing at least one additional crime, a Government document disclosed. [D6.]
A capital gains tax would reduce unemployment by creating jobs, Bush and Republican Congressional leaders argued. [A18.]
 
COMPANIES
BankAmerica reported earnings above expectations. It said it earned $285 million, up 1 percent. [D1.]
Citicorp is burdened by a mountain of bad loans, this time loans made on John Reed's watch, and there is some question whether the bank has recognized all its problems. News Analysis. [D1.]
A.T.& T. and MCI reported slow revenue growth, with a huge loss at A.T.& T. because of one-time charges. [D1.]
Digital Equipment said profits rose 9.2 percent, and Apple Computer reported an 18 percent decline even as sales grew. [D3.]
Fujisankei Communications said it would become the first top Japanese company to establish its own Hollywood production company and directly manage moviemaking. [D4.]
The New York Times Company's income fell 79 percent, to $1.9 million, or 3 cents a share, it reported. [D15.]
The Time Inc. Magazine Co. informed about 25 news employees at six magazines that they would be laid off. [D15.]
Lasmo, the British oil company, began a $2 billion hostile takeover offer for Ultramar. [D3.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Underscoring strained U.S.-Japanese relations, the Treasury's Mulford delivered a slashing attack on Japan's financial regulation. He charged the Finance Ministry with permitting a host of anticompetitive practices in the financial markets. [D1.]
Ukrainian officials said they would not join with other republics in a proposed economic pact intended to create a free market. [A1.]
 
MARKETS

HEADLINE: Biggest Increase For Price Index In Eight Months

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
In an inflation report that many investors and analysts found disturbing, the Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in September, the biggest increase since January.
Prices for food and energy, which have been restraining the inflation rate for much of 1991, were two of the main factors pushing it up last month. 
 The broadly based increase was higher than generally expected and contributed to a big selloff in the bond market, raising interest rates. The rationale was that the Federal Reserve would be less inclined in the face of fresh evidence of inflationary pressure to take further steps to ease interest rates as a stimulus to the economy.
 
3.7% Rise in Benefits
 The report on the Consumer Price Index also means that nearly 50 million recipients of Social Security and other Federal benefits tied to inflation will get increases of 3.7 percent in January. This is the smallest adjustment in five years. It is the amount by which prices in the third quarter exceeded those a year earlier. [Page A10.]
But while the inflation figures captured much of the attention, a sizable proportion of economists found other indicators published today, particularly industrial output, of equal if not greater importance. Industrial production rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the Federal Reserve reported, and what was initially reported as a three-tenths of 1 percent advance for August was revised to zero. Although industrial production covers only about one-third of the economy, it is an important indicator because it reflects the part of the economy most sensitive to the business cycle.
"The recovery to date has been modest, and now it looks even more modest than we thought," said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. "We have very little momentum going into the fourth quarter."
Mr. Gramley, a former research chief and board member at the Fed, said that while there was no danger the economy would slip back into recession, the usual forces to sustain recovery were missing. He also said the data would seem to increase, not reduce, the chances for additional Fed rate-cutting.
"I'm a little puzzled about what it is they're waiting for," he said.
At a briefing for reporters, Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, said that the Fed "may well have to consider further action" if neither the economy nor the nation's money supply perk up.
Figures on international trade published today for August showed the American deficit rising for the second straight month, to $6.8 billion, with exports down 3 percent. Exports, which have been relatively robust of late, are counted upon to help sustain the recovery, which most economists believe began during late spring or early summer.
In still another report, the Labor Department said that initial claims for state unemployment insurance fell 13,000 in the first week of October, to 423,000, but continued to rise a bit on the four-week moving average that many analysts use to smooth out gyrations. That average rose to a seasonally adjusted 432,500 from 427,000.
Michael W. Keran, chief economist at the Prudential Insurance Company, joined Mr. Gramley in minimizing the significance of the inflation figures and contending that the Federal Reserve will pay more attention to the weak production results.
 
No Change in Outlook
 "We don't think this represents a major change in our outlook about inflation," he said. In any event, Mr. Keran added, the Fed's long-run strategy may be to bring down inflation, "but its short-run strategy is to not have recession."
On the other hand, Paul W. Boltz and Norman Robertson, chief economists for T. Rowe Price Associates and the Mellon Bank, respectively, found the inflation data worrisome.
"This is an alert," Mr. Boltz said, that modest inflation is unlikely to continue into the new year. Noting the turnaround in food and energy prices, he said, "They stopped helping -- and there it was." He also argued today that the recovery "is on increasingly firm footing."
Mr. Robertson said he was disturbed by both the inflation and output data, which reflect what he called a weak and hesitant economy and inflation so stubborn that it flares up in a protracted period of recession and sub-par growth.
The report on consumer inflation came as such a surprise today in part because it followed a favorable reading last week on producer prices, which rose only one-tenth of a percent in September.
 
Rise Without Food and Energy
 Even without food and energy, the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the fourth straight advance of this size. A leading contributor was a five-tenths of 1 percent jump in housing, which makes up 41 percent of the index and showed no price change in August.
Both renters' costs and homeowners' costs rose five-tenths of 1 percent, more than offsetting a three-tenths of 1 percent decline for maintenance and repairs. The price of household fuels and utilities turned up, rising six-tenths of 1 percent over all, with fuel oil up 1.7 percent, natural gas up 1.4 percent electricity up seven-tenths of 1 percent. Household furnishings and operations rose two-tenths of 1 percent following a small decline in August.
Food prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent, but this followed two months of larger declines. Fresh fruits jumped 3.1 percent, dairy products advanced six-tenths of 1 percent and pork and fish prices also moved up. Prices for beef, poultry and eggs, however, fell.
 
Surge in Motor Fuels
 In transportation, a two-tenths of 1 percent advance was mainly attributable to a nine-tenths of 1 percent surge in motor fuels. A drop in automobile finance charges held the costs of new cars to three-tenths of 1 percent and used-car prices fell. Public transportation dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting a 1.4 percent cut in airline fares.
Clothing fell four-tenths of 1 percent following two large increases, the result of earlier-than-usual introductions of fall and winter wear.
The cost of medical care continued to bound ahead, rising seven-tenths of 1 percent to a level 8.4 percent above that of September 1990.
In the entertainment and other goods and services categories, prices of sporting goods, fees for participant sports, tuitions and other school fees and tobacco products all moved up by more than 1 percent last month.
Viewed another way, services in the C.P.I. rose five-tenths of 1 percent, compared with three-tenths of 1 percent in August, while commodities rose two-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month.
For the third quarter, prices rose at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, up from 3 percent in the second quarter and 2.4 percent in the first, a combined rate less than half the 6.6 percent pace during the first nine months of 1990.
The the index covering all urban consumers now stands at 137.2. This means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-84 now costs $13.72.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1601 words

HEADLINE: Portrait of Texas Killer: Impatient and Troubled

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELTON, Tex., Oct. 17

 BODY:
At 5:30 Wednesday morning, the last day of his troubled life, George J. Hennard walked into a convenience store here and bought a sausage and biscuit sandwich, orange juice, a candy bar, a newspaper and a pack of Old Fashioned Dunkers doughnuts.
He had been buying breakfast at the store six mornings a week for months, but Wednesday there was something different about the darkly handsome son of a former Army doctor. 
 "George never smiled when he came in here," a clerk at the store, Mary Mead, said today. "He just seemed like he had the world on his shoulders. He was a loner. He never talked. But yesterday he seemed almost calm, even a little friendly, for the only time I can remember. Usually, I was scared of him."
Seven hours later, Mr. Hennard smashed his light-blue pickup truck through a plate glass window at Luby's cafeteria in nearby Killeen and methodically shot to death 22 people. Then, wounded by police officers who had moved in, he put an automatic pistol to his head and killed himself.
 
Search for a Motive
 As investigators tried to piece together a motive for the slayings, former co-workers and acquaintances today described Mr. Hennard, a 35-year-old merchant seaman who lost his job after marijuana was found in his room on a ship, in similar words: "loner," "combative," "rude," "impatient," "troubled."
Tim Snyder of Killeen said he and Mr. Hennard, whom he called "Big George," were "drinking buddies."
"He wasn't particular about what he drank," Mr. Snyder said. "When he was drunk, that's when he'd talk crazy. But he's a nice guy when he's sober."
An autopsy will determine if Mr. Hennard had used drugs or alcohol before the shooting.
Today, as investigators continued to sift through details of Mr. Hennard's life and the bloody debris at the cafeteria, a fuller portrait of the killer began to emerge.
But it is only a portrait, not an explanation for the worst mass shooting in the United States. The chances that such an event could be explained may have died along with Mr. Hennard and the 22 people he killed in 10 minutes on a sunny afternoon in Texas.
Francis L. Giacomozzi, the police chief of Killeen, a town of 63,500 people that borders the nation's largest military base, Fort Hood, said investigators were pursuing the prospect that Mr. Hennard might have been driven by an intense hostility toward women.
"That is one avenue we are pursuing," Chief Giacomozzi told reporters this morning in Killeen. "A greater percentage of women were killed or injured." Fourteen of the 22 people killed, many at close range, were women, as were many of the 23 people wounded. Several people who survived said Mr. Hennard passed over men to shoot women.
 
Two Remain Critical
 Two of the wounded, Lou Carabello, 42 years old, and Kriemhild Davis, 62, were listed in critical condition today at Darnall Army Community Hospital at Fort Hood. Mr. Hennard's father, a former Army colonel, was the hospital's commanding officer in 1978 and 1979, Army records show.
A 19-year-old dishwasher, Mark Matthews, who had been missing since the shooting, was found unharmed at 7 A.M. today, sleeping on a conveyor belt inside an idled dishwasher in the restaurant's kitchen. "He said he never felt safe enough to get out of there," said Luby's chief executive, Ralph (Pete) Erben.
Mr. Hennard's father, Georges, was born in Switzerland, where he received his medical degree, and speaks French, German and Spanish as well as English, the Army said. His mother, Jeanne, once sold antiques. The Hennards and their four children moved a a dozen times from base to base by the time George J. was 18 years old.
Born in Pennsylvania, Mr. Hennard graduated from Las Cruces High School in New Mexico in 1974 while his family was living on the White Sands Missile base there. Mr. Hennard had transferred to Las Cruces from Bangor Area High School in Five Points, Pa.
The Hennards moved to Fort Hood later in 1974. In 1980, the family purchased a large red brick house with six white columns in front and a swimming pool in an expansive backyard in Belton, several miles of east of Killeen.
A few years later, Mr. Hennard's parents divorced. Dr. Hennard moved away from the area, and now lives in Houston. Mrs. Hennard moved to Henderson, Nev., where she works as a manicurist at Miss Faye Nail Salon.
Her son also apparently lived at least part time in Henderson. A neighbor of Mr. Hennard there, Beverly White, said today: "He didn't seem out of line or out of the ordinary at all to me. I certainly wasn't afraid of him."
Mrs. Hennard also kept the house in Belton and Mr. Hennard frequently lived there for extended periods.
"Whenever he was home, he was in the yard working," said George Rakowitz, the Hennards' postman. "He was always in the yard, raking leaves, cleaning things up. He was a workaholic. He was always doing something."
And when he worked in the yard or when he washed his shiny blue pickup truck, he often went shirtless, showing off his muscles and a tattoo, according to a neighbor, Jana Jernigan.
A police spokesman in Belton said Mr. Hennard appeared to have been unemployed at the time of the shooting. But for most of his adult life, Mr. Hennard earned his living on the high seas in the Merchant Marine.
Isaiah (Ike) R. Williams, a port agent for the national maritime union in Wilmington, Calif., said Mr. Hennard first shipped out from the port on the John Lykes on Nov. 9, 1981.
As an able bodied seaman, Mr. Hennard worked on deck, steering the ship while on watch or standing guard when in port, Mr. Williams said. He particularly liked to sail on vessels bound for the Far East, the agent said.
"He was very loud," Mr. Williams said. "And he appeared to be combative at times. He would come in with a very cold look and be very argumentative, loud, boisterous, sometimes cursing and swearing."
 
Trouble on the Job
 Mr. Williams said Mr. Hennard did not last long on any ship and worked for a lot of people over the years.
On May 11, 1989, Mr. Hennard was taken off a ship in Oakland, Calif., after authorities found drugs in his room. Mr. Hennard's seaman's papers were confiscated by the Coast Guard. A few months later, he entered a drug treatment program in Houston.
In 1990, Mr. Hennard called Mr. Williams, saying he needed a letter of recommendation so he could regain his papers and return to sea.
"I don't recall having given him one," Mr. Williams said.
Mr. Hennard's lawyer, David McCormack said his client learned in mid-February that his attempt to be reinstated had been denied.
"He desperately wanted to get his license back and go back to sea," said Mr. McCormack.
On Feb. 21, Mike's Gun House in Henderson, Nev., sold a Glock 17 pistol to a member of the Hennard family, said a spokesman for Glock Inc. in Marietta, Ga.
The shop, owned by Michael O'Donoghue, on March 29 also sold the Ruger semiautomatic that Mr. Hennard used along with the Glock in the shooting, The Associated Press reported. The news service reported that a Las Vegas undersheriff, Eric Cooper, said that Mr. Hennard signed for both guns and listed himself as unemployed on both registrations.
 
Signs of Trouble
 There have been more recent signs of trouble. Four months ago, Miss Jernigan, 19, and her married sister, Jill Fritz, 23, received a five-page letter from Mr. Hennard, whom Miss Jernigan described as a "weird, good looking guy" in the big red house up the street.
Apparently, Mr. Hennard had been admiring the two sisters when stayed at his mother's house in Belton. He did not know their names and addressed them as "Stacee" and "Robin." He also sent the letter to a neighbor's house by mistake.
In the letter, he complained about women being "vipers" but praised the sisters' high virtue.
"It is very ironic about Belton, Texas. I found the best and worst in women there," the letter said. "I will no matter what, prevail over the female vipers in those two rinky-dink towns in Texas. I will prevail in the bitter end."
About a week after the letter arrived, Miss Jernigan and her mother, Jane Bugg, were taking a walk on a Sunday evening when they heard Mr. Hennard screaming at a women in the street.
"He was screaming obscenities, some words I never heard before," Miss Jernigan said. "He was screaming he couldn't believe she had gone to Killeen the night before and danced with all those G.I.'s."
She said the woman tried to walk away but each time Mr. Hennard grabbed her by the wrist and dragged her back. Several times, she said, he raised his hand as if to strike the woman, but he did not.
The red brick house, where Mr. Hennard spent so much time, was put up for sale several weeks ago by Jeanne Hennard, and Mr. Hennard was reportedly reluctant to see it sold.
Two months ago, he walked into the convenience store in Belton to buy breakfast. Mrs. Mead, the clerk, recalled that he leaned over the counter and told her: "I want you to tell everybody, if they don't quit messing around my house something awful is going to happen."
Mrs. Mead's daughter-in-law, Nancy, who owns the store with her husband, said Mr. Hennard "made us all nervous whenever he came in."
She said a couple of months ago, a young woman was writing a check at the counter in the store when Mr. Hennard walked in. He pushed the woman aside and put a soda he was purchasing onto the counter.
"He didn't apologize or say excuse me or nothing," she remembered. "He just pushed her out of the way, paid his bill and left. He acted like he hated everybody."
