HEADLINE: The Thomas Confirmation;
Hill's Case Is Divisive To Women

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Rebecca Moody, a 59-year-old retired secretary, watched the Anita F. Hill-Clarence Thomas drama on television and came away thinking "it's unbelievable that a woman couldn't stop something like that at its inception."
Tammie Lee, a 33-year-old worker at the House of Ruth, the shelter for battered women here, said: "I was harassed, and I nipped it in the bud; I stopped it right then and there. One guy said, 'I see you don't take any guff.' " 
 Theresa Lowry, 52, an elementary school teacher, asked: "Wouldn't you haul off and poke a guy in the mouth if he spoke in that manner?"
In the blue-collar corners of this city, the women who keep house or bag groceries, nurse patients or work in construction have little sympathy with Professor Hill.
They are angered by sexual harassment, which many say they have experienced. But that anger does not translate into support for the soft-spoken law professor who accused the Supreme Court nominee of intimidating her with graphic discussions of pornographic films a decade ago.
 
Matter of Disrespect
 In part, it is a matter of disbelief. But perhaps in greater measure, it is a matter of disrespect. The feelings of these women provide some clue to the reasons why, although nearly 40 percent of American women said in recent polls that they had been sexually harassed, only about 25 percent of women said they believed Professor Hill's versions of the events more than Judge Thomas's.
Interviews with about 20 women in Baltimore in a variety of occupations showed sharp divisions, with lawyers, human services professionals and politicians showing strong sympathy for Professor Hill. At a retreat Thursday for all the women in the State Legislature, all but one believed her version of the events, said State Senator Paula Hollinger of Baltimore.
But white and black women from the low-rent neighborhoods of this city look at Professor Hill as cowboys might look at a dude adrift in Dodge City, their incredulity spiced with contempt. The workplace they know is an untamed frontier where bad men roam and smart women learn how to take care of themselves or leave.
 
'Women Against Women'
 Roberta Gayle, a radio talk-show host on WCBN here, calls the phenomenon WAW, or "women against women." Yet women here are not stuck in some pre-feminist time warp. About 46.5 percent of the work force in the Baltimore area is composed of women, slightly higher than the national average.
Forty-four members of the Maryland State Legislature, not quite one in four, are women. Gov. William Donald Schaefer made national headlines in February when he commuted the sentences of eight battered women convicted and imprisoned for attacking or killing the men who beat them.
But that does not mean Maryland is an oasis of enlightenment. Women in state government say that examples abound of demeaning conversations with men.
At the House of Ruth, which 14 years ago was founded as one of the country's first shelters for women beaten by their husbands or live-in partners, the executive director Carole Alexander was still shaking with anger over the hearings and the Senate's 52-to-48 vote confirming Judge Thomas as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
"The potential for backlash here is very great," Ms. Alexander said. "For men inclined to minimize this problem, it'll enhance their minimization."
She said women who believe they can take care of such situations, when Professor Hill could not, will continue in this belief. She said this was mistake.
"If we minimize the issue of sexual harassment and say it's not a problem," she said, "we're sending a very very bad message to the community."
Her colleague, Judy Wolfer, 33, a lawyer who defends battered women on trial for attacking their partners, said: "If you have a case where the battered woman fights back, the last person you want on your jury is a formerly battered woman. She'll say: "I got myself out of it. Why didn't she?' "
Valerie Gebre-Amlak, who, like Ms. Lee, works at the center and sees its clients regularly, had far less sympathy for Professor Hill. "I might have stayed on one job, if I needed the money," she said. "I sure wouldn't have followed him to another job. I honestly think something happenned."
None of these women said that sexual harassment did not exist, and many said they believed Judge Thomas had said or done something to Professor Hill. Her story, in fact, made them talk about their own.
 
View From Another Era
 "There was a guy who was pinching my bottom at work years ago," said Honey Ashel, 48, who does volunteer work in Pikesville, a suburb just northwest of the Baltimore City line. "I waited, and eventually he started pinching someone else's bottom because he liked their's better."
Senator Hollinger said: "I know an elderly woman, 82 years old, who, after these hearings, told a friend for the first time about something. When she was 12 and just beginning to develop, a pair of men who lived in her building started chasing her one day. They chased her around the yard, grabbing at her breasts. She didn't tell anyone about it for 70 years, not until this week."
But only rarely did the personal experiences provoke feelings of empathy for Professor Hill.
"A lot of women do handle this sort of thing themselves," said Nancy Gregor, 43, a lawyer with the firm of Kramon & Graham. " But when you're younger, for some women it may be more difficult. You have to develop in some fashion a feeling of power. As you move on in life, you have some more resources to handle it."
Darby Carrington, 30, an unemployed construction engineer, said: "What he was supposed to have said to her, I've had said to me, jokingly, and I've had said seriously by people trying to get a reaction. You have to make sure you get across that you're a professional. If someone isn't willing to accept that, you make sure you're not in a room alone with him."
But some women like Ruth Ennis, the director of human resource services for PHH Fleet America, a subsidiary of the business services firm PHH Corporation, said that their work made Professor Hill's lack of reaction to what she said was harassment believeable.
"A number of things are hauntingly true in her testimony," said Ms. Ennis, who used to investigate sex harassment complaints in Jefferson County, Ky. "She was afraid of losing a career track, a person who would be a valuable resource to her networking. This is not her fault, but it shows the mark of an insecure person."
She added, "If what Professor Hill said was true, the man was not seeking a date, he was seeking to intimidate and control her. Sexual harassment is not an act of lust or a compliment or an attempt to get a date. It's an action of control. One should first and foremost say, 'No!' in a loud clear voice and mean it.

HEADLINE: Social Security Benefits to Go Up 3.7%

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The 40 million Americans who receive Social Security benefits will get a 3.7 percent increase starting in January, the Government announced today. That is the smallest cost-of-living adjustment in five years.
The increase, while smaller than those allowed from 1988 through this year, is larger than the increases from 1984 through 1987. 
 Under Federal law, the increase, intended to help beneficiaries keep up with rising living costs, is automatic. It is determined by increases in the Consumer Price Index.
For retired workers, the new cost-of-living adjustment will increase the average Social Security check by $22 a month, to $629 from $607. For an elderly couple, both receiving benefits, the average monthly Social Security check will rise by $38, to $1,067 from $1,029.
 
Others to Get Increase
 The same 3.7 percent increase will raise payments to nearly 10 million people receiving benefits under other Federal programs. Among those who will receive the cost-of-living adjustment are 4.6 million aged, blind and disabled people enrolled in the Supplemental Security Income program; 2.2 million people who receive Civil Service retirement pay; 1.7 million people who get military retirement pay, and more than a million veterans who receive pensions based on financial need.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that these automatic increases will cost the Government at least $13.5 billion next year. Ten billion dollars of that amount is for Social Security. As a rule of thumb, each percentage point in the cost-of-living adjustment increases Federal spending for Social Security benefits by $2.7 billion a year, Social Security officials said.
The American Association of Retired Persons, which has 33 million members, said the cost-of-living adjustment was relatively small because overall inflation was comparatively low in the last 12 months.
"While low inflation is good news for most Americans, a 3.7 percent increase does not offset health-care costs that are rising at double or more the rate of overall inflation," said Horace B. Deets, executive director of the association. "Twenty-two dollars may not be enough for even one month's medicine, much less needed medical treatment." Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, generally does not pay the costs of drugs for people outside a hospital.
 
Rise in Medicare Premiums
 The monthly premium for Part B of Medicare, which covers doctors' services, will increase in January as a result of the comprehensive budget law approved last year by Congress and President Bush. The monthly premium, now $29.90, will rise to $31.80.
Conservative members of Congress have often proposed reducing the cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security and other benefit programs. But organizations representing the elderly have adamantly opposed such cuts, saying they would lead directly to an increase in poverty among the elderly, many of whom are heavily dependent on Social Security as a source of income.
In addition, spokesmen for the elderly note that many Social Security beneficiaries are children, disabled workers and nonelderly survivors of deceased workers. Of the 40.4 million Social Security recipients, 6.6 million are under 62 years old and four million are in the 62-to-64 age range.
Benefit programs that offer assistance to all people who meet certain eligibility criteria, account for more than 40 percent of all Federal spending. They account for $574 billion of $1.3 trillion in total outlays in the last 12 months, the budget office says.
Many such benefit programs grow steadily from year to year, largely insulated from the fierce debates in Congress over annual appropriations for the armed forces and domestic "discretionary" programs like highways, education and science.
The annual cost-of-living adjustment reflects the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index from the third-quarter of one year to the corresponding period of the next year.
Gwendolyn S. King, the Commissioner of Social Security, said the cost-of-living adjustment assured more than 40 million people that their "benefit checks will continue to allow them to pay for needed goods and services."
The maximum earnings subject to the Social Security payroll tax will rise next year to $55,500, from $53,400. Philip A. Gambino, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration, said this change would cause a tax increase for nine million people who earn more than $53,400 a year.
Eileen P. Sweeney, a lawyer at the National Senior Citizens Law Center, which represents many elderly poor people, said the automatic cost-of-living adjustment was "one of the best things Congress ever did for people who are elderly or disabled."
Social Security was created in 1935 and did not have an automatic cost-of-living adjustment until Congress established that mechanism in 1972. Before then Congress periodically legislated increases in benefits.
Although now seen as a factor driving up the cost of Social Security, the cost-of-living adjustment was originally adopted to control the growth of the program. The first automatic increases took effect in 1975.
P. Royal Shipp, senior specialist on social legislation at the Congressional Research Service, said indexing was "sought largely by conservatives as a means of curbing even larger ad hoc benefit increases" approved by Congress in previous years.

HEADLINE: Renewed Republican Call For Tax Cut Is Led by Bush

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
President Bush and Republican Congressional leaders argued today that the way to reduce unemployment was through a capital gains tax cut that would create more jobs, while Democrats renewed their effort to pass legislation extending unemployment benefits for the long-term jobless.
Politics dominated both arguments in the aftermath of Wednesday's Senate vote to sustain Mr. Bush's veto of a $6.5 billion Democratic bill to provide up to 20 weeks of additional benefits for people out of work for at least half a year. 
 Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip in the House, said Republicans "would go to the country very hard this fall and refuse to adjourn" until Congress acted on proposals for economic growth.
Mr. Gingrich said those proposals, which would go beyond the capital gains cut and include a smaller unemployment plan than the Democrats want, would be outlined next week and produced in legislative form as early as next week.
But House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, renewing the assertion that Democrats have consistently made since July, complained that Mr. Bush supported deficit spending to help foreigners but not jobless Americans. He called the Administration's jobless proposal "totally inadequate."
Mr. Bush renewed his calls for a capital gains tax cut in a televised address to the Associated Press Managing Editors' Association, which was meeting in Detroit. He said that "a capital gains tax cut will set off an explosion of small business formation" and "give our economy a much needed boost."
"It would raise real estate prices and cut the overall cost of the savings and loan cleanup," he said. "It would help people of imagination and drive."
The Bush view that a capital gains tax cut would stir a sluggish economy is disputed by many economists, and Republican enthusiasm for the issue has waxed and waned in recent months.
But Senate Republicans keep trying to raise the issue. That has led the Democrats to go to considerable lengths to keep any tax bill from coming up in the Senate, thus preventing the Republicans from seeking to amend it to cut capital gains taxes.
Mr. Bush also maintained that the economic "trends look good," although he acknowledged that "a lot of people are still hurting."
He said, "The unemployment rate in September fell to 6.7 percent, down three-tenths of a percent in three months and the lowest rate in nearly five years." In fact, the rate is not the lowest in five years; for all of 1990 it averaged 5.4 percent.
A White House spokesman said later the President meant "nearly five months."
Congressional Republicans and Mr. Foley agreed on one thing: that if the economy is recovering, it is doing so feebly. Mr. Foley called it "a recovery that either has not occurred or is the most technical and vapid and inactive recovery that we have seen in this century."
After meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House, Senator Phil Gramm, the Texan who heads the Senate Republican campaign committee, said of the economy, "We should recognize that if it did turn the corner, it didn't leave any skid marks."
Mr. Gramm maintained that what the country should do to bring recovery was to enact a growth package starting with cutting capital gains taxes, broadening the reach of Individual Retirement Accounts so they could be used to pay college tuition, make down payments on first homes, pay catastrophic medical charges and raise the limit on earnings by Social Security recipients. He also said that it was important to frame the plan in a way that would not increase the deficit.
Mr. Foley's focus was on the unemployed. He said Mr. Bush had been wrong to veto the extended benefits bill, and, reflecting the views of most House Democrats, insisted that any package ultimately adopted should be paid for by increasing the deficit. This would be permitted under last year's budget act with the declaration of an emergency.
His insistence on the emergency provision suggested there was not movement toward a compromise that would get checks to the jobless. He wants any extended benefits to be paid out of an $8 billion Federal trust fund created to pay the extended benefits to people who have been out of work for more than the 26 weeks that are covered in most states.
Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Committee on Ways and Means, is planning to introduce another bill to help the unemployed in the next few days. It would pay extended benefits of up to 13 weeks in states with average unemployment of 7 percent or more and 7 weeks in all others. It would cover about one million people.

HEADLINE: Oklahoma School Plan Survives Vote

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
An Oklahoma referendum to repeal a $574 million education improvement plan produced the state's largest turnout ever for a special election, but after months of nasty debate, the result of Tuesday's vote surprised many: the referendum was defeated.
The plan, which voters retained by a tally of 428,204 to 361,293, was seen by education analysts as a national litmus test of states' resolve to finance education improvements in a weak economy. Although the plan survived the referendum, it created a maelstrom of debate. A month before the vote, the offices of the Oklahoma Taxpayers Union, one of two statewide citizens' groups opposed to the education plan, was firebombed. 
 "Oklahoma was a crucial vote because it is a conservative state," said Chris Pipho, director of state relations for the Education Commission of the States, an education research and policy organization in Denver. "People are seeing a need to make changes in education and if it means more money, so be it."
 
Second Attempt
 The Oklahoma referendum also marked the second time in as many years that a state education package already approved by legislators was placed on the ballot by citizens attempting to repeal it because of cost. Last November, Nebraska voters similarly rejected a referendum that would have rescinded $416 million in new taxes for education. As in Nebraska, opponents of the Oklahoma plan groused that the cost was too high for too few changes.
Approved in April 1990 by the Oklahoma Legislature, the plan calls for new curriculums, tougher teacher accreditation standards, smaller classes and a recruitment center for minority teachers. Also, higher minimum teacher salaries were mandated, with $15,060 minimum for a first-year teacher and $24,060 in the fifth year. The plan is scheduled to be phased in over five years.
To finance these improvements, the Legislature approved increases in the state sales tax, to 4.5 percent from 4 percent; in corporate taxes, to 6 percent from 5 percent, and in personal income taxes by a range of 1 percent to 16 percent, with the wealthy bearing the heaviest increases.
 
'Very Reassuring'
 "It's very reassuring that the voters of Oklahoma are ready to recommit to education," said Terry Almon, executive director of Growth Oklahoma, a citizen's group that spent about $1 million to support the education plan through television, radio and print advertising. "Now we can try to move Oklahoma to match its football standing."
In defeat, opponents of the plan continued to maintain that it was too expensive and did little to advance educational improvements.
"This is faulty education reform," said Dan Brown, chairman of the Oklahoma Taxpyers Union. "We're putting more money into a system of education that is broken."
Stanley M. Ward, a lawyer who is chairman and a founder of Stop Taxing our People said: "We don't want any of these cram-down-your-throat, tax-and-spend bromides. We are trying things that have been tried previously without any basic success."
Indeed, opponents to the Oklahoma plan received a boost before this week's vote from the recent distribution of President Bush's national report card, which showed that for all the money spent in the 1980's on education improvements, some of them similar to those in the Oklahoma plan, students today are performing at 1970 levels.
Mr. Brown and other opponents of the plan said they were defeated because they were outspent by an estimated 15 to 1 by supportors in statewide advertising campaigns. "They had the organization and the money," he said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, in a Shift, Is Paying His Own Way to South Africa

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Reversing his earlier position that he would not contribute to the cost of his trip to South Africa next month, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he had donated $5,000 to pay his own way.
But because money for the trip is being raised by a nonprofit city-controlled entity, the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, Mr. Dinkins will be able to claim a tax deduction, as will the city commissioners, business people and news organizations paying to join him on the trip Nov. 10. 
 "Of course it's deductible," the Mayor said. "But you've still got to pay the $5,000." That would be 40 times the size of Mr. Dinkins's $125 donation to charity last year; his salary is $123,500, and he has since made other donations.
 
City Pays for Bodyguards
 Even so, Mr. Dinkins's check would not cover the entire cost of the trip for himself and his wife, Joyce. Mayoral aides have said it will cost perhaps $4,500 per person. He is still raising money from private contributors to pay the way of an undetermined number of aides and advance team members. As always on mayoral trips, the city will pay for his police bodyguards, more than a dozen, officials said.
The weeklong trip is aimed at forging economic and cultural ties with the South African black majority.
The Mayor again declined yesterday to name the contributors or say how much had been raised, saying the effort was still under way. He said the full list would be made public eventually, and that questions about possible conflicts of interest involving donors who might have business with the city were legitimate.
But he also complained that fundraising for the trip had drawn far more criticism and scrutiny than past efforts by the Assistance Corporation to raise corporate and private donations for the ticker-tape parade for Persian Gulf veterans and a meeting of big city mayors last year. For example, he noted, The New York Times Company contributed $75,000 toward a "living memorial" to help aid veterans of the gulf war and the families of those who died.
Mr. Dinkins suggested some of the criticism had a racial cast.
"I'm just simply contrasting it with the other," he said. "And I suggest that it's because not enough people appreciate the significance of a trip to South Africa, the only place where we have legalized slavery in the world."
Later, asked if he meant that the public was not sufficiently aroused by the injustices of apartheid, he said, "Come on, what public -- the press." When pressed why he thought that was so, he said: "I wish I knew. I wish I knew."

HEADLINE: THE WATER MAIN BREAK;
After 87 Years of Change, Some Water Mains Remain

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
When work crews laid a 20-inch cast-iron water main into 42d Street between Park and Lexington Avenues in 1904, New York was a very different place. Horse-drawn carriages shuttled the well-to-do around town. The city's first subway line was about to open.
Then everything changed. Except the pipe.
Steam pipes, telegraph wires, sewers, telephone wires and electrical and television cables elbowed their way under the street and around the water main. 
 Another subway line, the IRT No. 7, was built along 42d Street beneath the first line that had run from City Hall to East 42d Street and then across town to Times Square. The East Side line was expanded, heading north beneath Lexington Avenue.
 
Confluence of Factors
 Today, high-rise office buildings line both sides of 42d Street, with deep foundations to support them. Heavy trucks and buses rumble almost incessantly on the street. Below, the ground trembles every few minutes as modern subway trains thunder by.
The city's engineers do not yet know why the 87-year-old pipe burst early yesterday morning, disrupting traffic and mass transit throughout midtown and the East Side, but they recognize the confluence of factors that made the water-main break possible.
Age, congestion, vibrations from subways and street traffic, corrosive soil conditions, the material used to make the pipe, the presence of high-rise structures with deep excavations -- all contribute to the stress that can cause a water-main break and create turmoil in a densely populated city.
During the 1980's about 540 water mains broke each year, city officials said. Most are small and cause little damage. Even the larger ones -- when they occur on quiet streets away from business districts -- are seldom noted, except by those directly inconvenienced.
 
6,000 Miles of Main
 But when a large main breaks in a major intersection in Manhattan or downtown Brooklyn, as happened every year or two over the last decade, the impact can be extraordinary.
The city replaced about 10 percent of its 6,000 miles of water mains during the 1980's and is to replace another 10 to 15 percent of the mains during the next 10 years, said Edward C. Scheader, a deputy director of water supply and waste-water collection.
Even so, Mr. Scheader said, the city will not be able to replace all of the most vulnerable mains, which includes small mains, those built before 1930, those with a history of breaking and those that have persistent problems with low pressure.
Money is one reason why the city cannot eliminate the risk of ruptures: It will cost about $850 million to replace mains over the next 10 years, he said.
But even if money were not an impediment, Mr. Scheader and other engineers said, the city is still limited in the amount of repair work that it can do. Streets have to be torn apart to replace water mains. If too many streets were disrupted, they said, travel in New York would be brought to a halt, with profound economic consequences.
 
Cooper Union Study
 "I don't know if it's possible to do more during the next 10 years without creating chaos on the streets," Mr. Scheader said.
But some experts contend that the city must accelerate its pace in replacing water mains or endure a different kind of chaos: an increase in large, disruptive pipe ruptures.
A study released two months ago by the infrastructure institute at Cooper Union estimated that by the year 2030, more than 1,600 water mains would break each year -- three times the current rate.
That prediction was based on several assumptions, all of which were challenged by city water engineers. The study estimated that water mains should last about 100 years. It also calculated that the city's current replacement cycle is 150 years, said Samuel I. Schwartz, an engineering professor at Cooper Union who directed the study.
"We're going to see more of these unless we have more preventive maintenance and we accelerate the replacement cycle," Mr. Schwartz, who was a deputy transportation commissioner in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, said yesterday.
When parts of Madison Avenue, the Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Avenue in midtown were rebuilt in recent years, the water mains were also replaced, Mr. Schwartz said. But the water mains under Fifth Avenue, built around the turn of the century, have not been replaced. "We can expect to see water main breaks along Fifth Avenue," he said.
 
200 or 600 Miles
 "Our problem is that we have kind of backed ourselves into a corner," Mr. Schwartz said, in part because the city's public works were allowed to languish during the 1960's and 1970's. He said it would require a major increase in the city's replacement effort to catch up for the lost time.
But city officials said they had begun to do precisely that. The Cooper Union study estimated that 200 miles of water mains were replaced during the 1980's, based on city documents, said Clark Wieman, who was research director for the report.
Mr. Scheader said the city actually replaced 600 miles of pipes during the decade. He also disputed the study's assumption that water mains can last for 100 years.
"It makes the assumption that age by itself is the major contributor to the problem," he said. "I don't honestly believe that that is true."
Small pipes break much more often than the larger, stronger pipes, Mr. Scheader said. Location can also be critical, he said.
"The big ones don't break all that often," Mr. Scheader said, "but when they do, we all know about it."

HEADLINE: Foreboding in Connecticut As State Employees Depart

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 17

 BODY:
About 1 percent of the state's public employees turned off the lights and walked out the door today, laid off from jobs to which they may never return. It was the single largest exodus since Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced the first of more than 3,700 layoffs in late September, and by far the most departures in one day since the state's budget troubles began several years ago.
By the close of business on Friday, at least 545 people who had jobs when the week began will be facing unemployment, out of a work force of about 45,000. Most are secretaries, clerks and typists, including the entire four-member secretarial pool at the University of Connecticut School of Nursing, which formally disbanded as of 4 P.M. 
 "There's no one to tell them where the disks or the files are," said one of the four former nursing secretaries, Diana Moore. "I don't know what they'll do."
State administrators and union leaders who are tracking the layoffs said that most residents would not feel the effect of the cutbacks quite yet. Rather they described a government structure being gnawed at from the inside and weakened in ways that will only be felt over time.
 
'Delays Will Become Longer'
 State lawmakers who are seeking repeal of the income tax and even further reduction in the size of Connecticut's government expressed sorrow today at the human cost inflicted by the cuts, but guarded joy at the evidence that government could make do with less. They also chose to outline a major plank of their proposed repeal bill that will be considered at a special legislative session next month: a package of proposals to squeeze more money out of state workers by extending the work week from 35 to 40 hours, while eliminating the arbitration rules that have given some union members generous pay raises.
"We weren't all that good to begin with," said the state's chief court administrator, Judge Aaron Ment, describing the cuts in clerical staff and probation officers that his department has faced. "We already had long delays in some areas of the state -- those delays will become longer."
The Senate minority leader, M. Adela Eads, a Republican from Kent, also conceded that layoffs will likely be needed if the income tax is repealed next month, but said the number would depend on the unions' willingness to grant concessions.
For people on their way out the door today, or those left to hold the pieces together, such talk has made Connecticut's pared-down government a deeply troubled place where few jobs or benefits seem completely secure and where long-term planning consists of trying to hold one's position through at least the next round of layoffs.
At the Department of Correction, which administers a still-expanding prison system, 140 prison guard posts are being eliminated in various detention centers as a result of layoffs. A spokesman for the department, Bill Wheeler, conceded that the average Connecticut resident will never know those guards are not there, but he said that every guard will know it and know that he or she is perhaps a bit less safe as a result.
At the Department of Mental Health's three largest hospitals, staff workers who normally oversee two wards of mentally ill residents will supervise three wards, a 50 percent increase in their caseloads. Another 90 patients will be released to community programs because of insufficient staffing levels.
Some of the effects of the layoffs are almost unmeasurable.
At the Judicial Department, for example, where about 10 percent of the state's probation officers have either received pink slips or have already left their jobs, Judge Ment said that many of the gaps in probation officer ranks have been filed by supervisors transferred back into the field. That means the caseloads are still being more or less maintained, but with the supervisors gone, the immediate gauge of how well or poorly the systems works is also gone.
 
Is Tenure Safe?
 What could be one of the single most wrenching effects of the cuts is still to be addressed. At the state's public colleges and universities 335 professors have been selected by the Weicker administration for dismissal. But actually issuing a pink slip to a tenured professor also means publicly declaring that the hallowed rules of tenure can no longer be trusted as a job guarantee in Connecticut.
The technical and community college system has already made that declaration, known as financial exigency, and the state university system has begun the process. The University of Connecticut, the flagship of the system, has vowed to resist as long as possible. Officials said that a declaration of exigency would cripple the university's ability to attract new professors or keep good ones.
"Once you have done that, you send out a signal that is very very difficult to alter," said the University's president, Harry J. Hartley.
Union leaders said today that discussions were still under way with the Weicker administration on a package of concessions that could rescind the layoffs.
But for people like Ms. Moore at the nursing school, it may be too late. Under state rules she was considered a "durational" worker who only worked 34 hours a week instead of 35 and so was not entitled to all the benefits. If her job is resumed, someone else who is fully vested into the state employee system will get the first crack at the job she held for the last two years.

HEADLINE: D'Amato's Rating Falls to Low in Poll

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 17

 BODY:
A statewide poll released today shows that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's job-performance rating has dropped to its lowest level ever, despite the Senator's efforts to advertise the Senate Ethics Committee's decision to clear him of charges of improper conduct.
The poll by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, taken from Oct. 7 to 10, also showed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo with his lowest rating ever and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan with his lowest rating since early 1984.
 
Recession's Impact Cited
 The results led the Institute's director, Lee M. Miringoff, to speculate that anti-incumbent sentiment is being fueled by the recession and by disillusionment with government. 
 Mr. Miringoff said that Mr. D'Amato's ratings were particularly notable because they suggested that the court of public opinion had not been favorably influenced by the verdict of the Senate Ethics Committee in August. The committee found that Mr. D'Amato, who was charged with improperly exerting his influence on behalf of friends and relatives, had not violated Senate rules or Federal laws.
The two-term Republican Senator, who faces re-election next year, spread the word of the committee's findings with a mailing sent to 3 million New Yorkers at a cost to taxpayers of more than $400,000.
But the Marist poll showed that only 34 percent of those questioned rated Mr. D'Amato's job performance as excellent or good. That was down from 42 percent last March. The poll of 624 voters has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Abrams Leads the Challengers
 The poll showed that Attorney General Robert Abrams, one of the four Democrats vying to challenge Mr. D'Amato, would run ahead of Mr. D'Amato by 45 percent to 41 percent if the election were held now.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman was in a dead heat with Mr. D'Amato, with each at 40 percent. Geraldine Ferraro, the former Vice Presidential nominee, trailed the incumbent, 46 percent to 38 percent, and Representative Bob Mrazek of Long Island trailed 41 percent to 19 percent.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. D'Amato, said he was encouraged that he had outpolled three of his four challengers. "It's clear that the obituaries on Senator D'Amato are premature," she said.
Mr. Cuomo's job performance was rated as excellent or good by 45 percent of those polled, down from 48 percent in March. Fifty-four percent of those surveyed said they had a favorable impression of him and 56 percent said he generally has been a good governor since first elected in 1983.
But 72 percent of those questioned said the state was headed in the wrong direction, an increase from 59 percent a year ago, and 86 percent said they believed the state was in a recession.
Mr. Moynihan, a Democrat, was rated excellent or good by 48 percent, down from 60 percent in March.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Mystery (but No Spies) From a Young le Carre

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Pre-empted last week by the Senate hearings starring Judge Clarence Thomas, Prof. Anita F. Hill and a mixed roster of bit players, the premiere of the 21st season of "Masterpiece Theater" on Channel 13 is instead taking place tonight at 9, with a repeat at midnight. The chosen production is "A Murder of Quality," a two-part version of a 1962 John le Carre novel, his second published work, adapted for television by the author himself. The second hour will be broadcast, as originally scheduled, on Sunday at 9 P.M.
"A Murder of Quality," a rare le Carre novel not about spies, is a mystery story, and a slight one at that. In a foreword to a published edition, the author calls the work a "flawed thriller," albeit one that is "redeemed by ferocious and quite funny social comment." The writer has never been especially enthusiastic about British institutions, most notably the boarding schools ("I found them monstrous and still do"). The fictional one in this story is called Carne, but it could be easily mistaken for Sherborne, once attended by Mr. le Carre. In fact, the filming was done on location at Sherborne. 
 The detective turns out to be a reluctant George Smiley, now being played by Denholm Elliott instead of Alec Guinness. On sabbatical from the Circus, the headquarters of British intelligence, Smiley is called by a former colleague who has received a letter from a woman claiming that her husband is going to kill her. The gloomy agent finds this little reason for him to interrupt his listening to Mahler on the phonograph, but then it turns out that the woman has indeed been found dead. Smiley sets out for Carne to assist the local police in their confrontations with smug headmasters and traditions.
No more of the plot need be revealed here, although it might be noted that Mr. le Carre, conceding youthful fury when he wrote the novel, does not apologize for what he now describes as "a spray-gun, frontal assault, not just on the British private educational establishment, but on our whole class structure -- religious, social, economic." The author's coup de grace: "Carne was the Circus made School. Both were rotten through and through."
Chronic Anglophiles can be assured that Mr. le Carre's fury is generally conveyed with ingrained British understatement and good manners. A top-notch cast makes sure of that. Mr. Elliott is perfect as the gray, piercingly intelligent Smiley; and his co-stars are sparkling. There's Glenda Jackson, as Smiley's rather dotty but thoroughly efficient former colleague, and there are Joss Ackland, Ronald Pickup and David Threlfall as the more prominent oddities on the school's staff. Lurching in and out of the story as Mad Janie is the wonderfully gifted Billie Whitelaw.
"A Murder of Quality" is a small piece seething with enormous anger. It gets a prestigious series off to another season with customary style.
 
'Brooklyn Bridge'
 CBS
 Tonight at 8:30
A good new series is being made better with the addition of Carol Kane in the role of Aunt Sylvia, a Greenwich Village habitue who enters reading Allen Ginsberg's "Howl." The Silver boys are delighted with their aunt's offbeat ways. Sylvia's mother is not impressed, especially when she hears that her daughter has decided to leave her nice but dull husband. You can imagine what the neighborhood will think of that. Ms. Kane gets a rare chance to be quite touching, and makes it shine.
 
The World Series
 CBS
 Beginning tomorrow at 8 P.M.
It's going to be baseball vs. the stunts. CBS, already reeling from poor ratings for the playoffs, will no doubt be looking at its billion-dollar investment in baseball-broadcast rights with something approaching classic panic. Meanwhile, the competition has geared up for counterprogramming, which this Sunday puts its bets squarely on the past.
 
'I Still Dream of Jeannie'
 NBC
 Sunday at 9 P.M.
Barbara Eden does a reprise of a role that she first played in 1965 when, popping out of a bottle, the remarkably well-preserved genie was a mere 2,000 years old. This time Jeannie is looking for a new master. The original was Larry Hagman who, having since snared stardom in "Dallas," was obviously not about to touch this labored project.
 
'Dynasty: The Reunion'
 ABC
 Sunday at 9 P.M.
A two-parter that will conclude on Tuesday. The network is keeping this one under wraps so as not to give away the story lines, but it has been reported, breathlessly of course, that one long scene will feature a violent mano-a-mano between Alexis (Joan Collins) and Krystle (Linda Evans). What more could any fan ask for, unless it be the return of the once-dismissed Al Corley as Steven, the oft-sexually confused Carrington son? He now lives happily in Washington with his male lover. Blake (John Forsythe) will presumably be released from prison. And all's well in the loopy world of television entertainment.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
A Couple Try to Buy What They Can't Make

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
Any chronic theatergoer is sooner or later asked, "What is the worst play you've ever seen?" There is no answer, of course, but if pressed to the wall, I might be tempted to start such a discussion with "The Wayward Stork," a short-lived farce of 25 years ago in which the late, great comedian Bob Cummings, his hair all but aflame with red dye, played a husband caught up in a botched effort at artificial insemination. There were, if memory serves, many jokes about chicken basters. Loved that Bob.
"The Baby Dance," the new play at the Lucille Lortel Theater, is nothing if not a "Wayward Stork" for the 1990's. Though the quality of the writing is a couple of rungs above rock bottom and though the tone is lugubrious rather than antic, it takes the same sad situation, that of an infertile couple eager to have children, and exploits and trivializes it to equally numbing effect. Reflecting its own time, "The Baby Dance" is much more pretentious than "The Wayward Stork," and, instead of being cooked up by a Broadway schlockmeister, it has been nurtured by three nonprofit theater companies that list themselves in a wayward honor roll in the Playbill: the Pasadena Playhouse, the Long Wharf Theater and the Williamstown Theater Festival. 
 No doubt reflecting this parentage, the play's plot, about an affluent Los Angeles couple buying the impending baby of a poor Louisiana couple, touches on such matters as class conflict, racism, abortion, birth control and the ethics of surrogate parenthood, among other aspects of the present-day baby market, legal and not. But the author, Jane Anderson, has nothing to say about these issues; she just milks them for cheap melodrama in the apparent hope that she'll bring forth a commercial entertainment, an "Other People's Baby."
Ms. Anderson condescends to all her characters except the unborn. The baby-makers, a redneck couple living in a rural Louisiana trailer court, wear tattoos, eat both Cool Whip and Miracle Whip, own a Princess phone and use a Crisco can as a flower vase. Yet they have primitive parental instincts and animal sexual passions beyond the ken of sterile rich folk. The California couple -- damningly employed at the lowest end of the film-industry food chain (he's in business affairs, she's in development) -- are defined by such brand names as Honda, Evian and Williams-Sonoma. The husband in this couple, a Jewish man who will only buy a baby commensurate with his own economic and intellectual status, is presented so mean-spiritedly that the characterization comes across as anti-Semitic. For added measure, a stereotyped baby-bartering lawyer wanders in for Act II; he may be one of those two-bit slick operators that Senator Orrin Hatch warned the nation about during the Judiciary Committee hearings last weekend.
Under these circumstances, the actors deserve sympathy, especially in Act I, when, in keeping with the Louisiana weather noted in the Playbill ("Highs are in the 90's and the humidity is 100 percent"), they are all drenched in sweat. It is also in that act that Linda Purl is asked to end a scene with the center-stage declaration, "I got to get my tubes tied!"
At least she and Richard Lineback bring some fierce passion to the white-trash couple, who might otherwise seem to have stepped out of "The Beverly Hillbillies." As the wealthy husband and wife, Stephanie Zimbalist and Joel Polis are to the mannered born. In keeping with the soapy text, Jenny Sullivan's direction is stagy in the extreme, with far more pregnant pauses than even this play's subject demands.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

A New Sunday Gospel Brunch
Tatou, the restaurant and nightclub at 151 East 50th Street in Manhattan, has begun a Sunday gospel brunch. The $19.50 brunch and show is put on by Lola Bell, who held rollicking gospel brunches at the Manhattan restaurant Lola, at 30 West 22d Street. Miss Bell is no longer associated with Lola, although gospel brunches continue there. Tatou reservations: (212) 753-1144.
 
Turnips and Cabbage for the Prudent
 The frugality bug has bitten in the most unexpected place. At the sumptuous Quilted Giraffe, in the A.T. & T. arcade at Madison Avenue near 56th Street, a signature dish is beggar's purses, a tongue-in-cheek appetizer of crepes holding sevruga caviar, tied in bundles and garnished with gold leaf (a $50 supplement to the $75 dinner menu; $45 at lunch). A new tidbit on the menu is called recession purses, the same crepes filled with turnips and cabbage, and no gold leaf. They come with strips of marinated sirloin of beef, and no supplement. Telephone: (212) 593-1221.
 
The Changing Scene
 OPEN: Armando Orsini, a veteran of the restaurant scene in Manhattan, whose last establishment, Orsini, on East 63d Street, closed two years ago, is back in business. His new venture, called Orsinini, at 227 East 50th Street, has only 18 tables and serves a blend of classic and contemporary Italian cuisine. Telephone: (212) 750-5315 . . . Four Winds, a Japanese restaurant at 135 East 62d Street in Manhattan, (212) 486-1664.
NEW HOURS: Le Madri, at 168 West 18th Street in Manhattan, (212) 727-8022, has begun Saturday and Sunday brunch from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. The restaurant's new Sunday dinner hours are 5 to 10:30 P.M. for the regular menu, 10:30 to 11:30 P.M. for pizza. . . . Starting Sunday, Union Square Cafe, 21 East 16th Street in Manhattan, (212) 243-4020, opens for Sunday dinner from 5 to 9:30 P.M.

HEADLINE: Promising Courtship in the Pacific

 BODY:
Tokyo and Moscow are moving ever so gingerly to settle their longstanding territorial dispute, and that should suit Washington just fine. The territory at issue, inhospitable islands in the Kurile chain north of Japan, were seized by the Soviets at the end of World War II. Their return would do much to thaw Japanese-Soviet relations, still frozen in cold war antagonism.
Deft diplomacy by both sides has removed some stumbling blocks. Japan has astutely offered the Soviets $2.5 billion in aid and credits, even though Moscow has not finally agreed to return the islands. That unlinks the issues of territory and aid, and spares Moscow the embarrassment of appearing to conduct a fire sale of the Soviet Union's assets. 
 Soviet leaders have also taken steps to speed negotiations. They have announced a troop cutback on the islands and agreed to a joint committee to discuss reversion.
Significantly, the Soviet delegation will be headed by a Deputy Foreign Minister of the Russian Federation; the islands are now part of Russian territory. The leader of Russia's parliament, in a visit to Tokyo, pointed the way to a settlement by saying that it "should not be based on who won or lost World War II," but on international law. That implies eventual return of the islands to their rightful owner, the Japanese, who settled the islands three centuries ago.
The collapse of the coup against Mikhail Gorbachev and Moscow's acceptance of the Baltics' independence undermined hard-line resistance to redrawing Soviet borders. Still, some advisers to the Russian president, Boris Yeltsin, fear that reversion could trigger the disintegration of the Russian Federation. But an even greater threat to Russian stability would be economic collapse -- which Japanese aid might avert.
Some in Washington worry that a Japanese-Soviet rapprochement would devalue the U.S.-Japan security treaty. But a prosperous and peaceful Soviet Union would help stabilize a region where the interests of Russia, China, Japan and the U.S. converge. It would reduce the need for a defense buildup by Japan, which alarms its neighbors. And it would allow the U.S. to maintain a more modest presence in the Pacific.
A deal on the Kuriles clearly deserves Washington's encouragement.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Push for a Break On Real Estate

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With the economy pulling out of recession at an agonizingly slow pace, real estate interests hope to find fresh support for a campaign to undo what they consider a singularly mischievous provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. And they seem to have picked up an important ally in the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency created to take over failed savings and loans and sell off their assets.
While passage of any tax-related legislation this year seems increasingly unlikely, there is a certain logic to the argument that making investment in rental real estate more attractive would spur overall economic activity while helping the agency dispose of its $12 billion inventory of rental properties, about 25 percent of the total portfolio. 
 The sweeping 1986 law, introducing the notion of "active" and "passive" investments as part of a drive against tax shelters, generally made rental real estate automatically passive no matter how much time or energy somebody devoted to it and prohibited investors from using passive losses to offset other types of income.
Those now seeking to put passive rental activity back onto equal footing want to limit this provision to people in the real estate business, an unintended 1986 target, and would still require the so-called material participation test.
The R.T.C. would enjoy more demand for its properties, many of which tend to generate losses and have relatively values as tax deductions. The revenue loss to the Treasury of this legislation, with some 340 Congressional co-sponsors, is estimated at $3 billion over five years.Meanwhile, Senator John B. Breaux, a Democrat from Louisiana, home of much R.T.C. property, has introduced a bill offering purchasers of all commercial property held by the agency a tax credit of up to 80 percent of the purchase price, to be claimed over five years. This measure, the subject of a Senate Finance subcommittee hearing next Tuesday, is opposed by the people who support change in the passive-loss rules. They say the tax credit would skew the market.
 
Deduction for Food

In the tradition of legislators seeking to spur demand for home-state products -- not to mention the sales point of seeking to solve two problems at once -- Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and three other Midwest Democrats have introduced a bill that would effectively double the charitable deduction for individuals who buy surplus food and donate it to charity for use in famine and disaster relief or in economically depressed areas.
"Nothing frustrates a farmer more than to have grain wasting away in a bin because prices are too low to sell it while he watches television news stories about the growing numbers of hungry people around the world," Senator Daschle said.
In analyzing the bill, the Joint Committee on Taxation finds that it would both shrink surpluses of eligible commodities (cutting Federal subsidy payments) and raise their market-clearing price. Lower subsidies save the Government money, but the analysts note that consumers not receiving donations would pay more for some commodities, and that the bill might result in costly duplication of existing food-distribution channels.
At a hearing on Wednedsay, the Bush Administration opposed the bill on the ground that some of the extra food donations would come at the expense of other contributions and that the augmented deduction would lose revenue for the Treasury. "This legislation," said Bruce L. Gardner, Assistant Secretary for Economics at the Agriculture Department, "implicitly contains a judgment that food aid is socially twice as valuable as other charitable donations."
 
Footnotes
 The Florida Tax and Budget Reform Commission recommends ending the sales-tax exemption for professional and other personal services, but the state seems unlikely to repeat its short-lived 1987 levy that applied to services used in Florida but performed elsewhere.
Median salaries for chief tax executives at $1 billion-plus companies ranged from $75,000 to $164,000 in 1990, according to a survey by D. E. Foster & Partners, a search firm.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Reports a Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 18

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said today that it lost $37 million in the third quarter of 1991 and expects to lose more money in the fourth quarter as its markets continue to shrink.
The construction-equipment maker's loss compared with earnings of $54 million, or 54 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Revenue fell 15.7 percent, to $2.36 billion from $2.80 billion. 
 "Almost all the markets we serve in the United States have not recovered from the recession," said Len Kuchan, Caterpillar's treasurer. "And in the rest of the world, markets have weakened, with the exception of the Middle East and Latin America.
"It's clear 1991 is not a year we can be very happy with. Our prospects for 1992 heavily depend on economic activity in the United States."
Caterpillar last suffered annual losses in 1982-84.
It has warned investors for months to expect a loss because of deteriorating economic conditions around the globe.
"The marketplace will improve; it always does," Mr. Kuchan said. "It's just a question of when."
Caterpillar's share price rose $1.125 today on the New York Stock Exchange to $48.625.

HEADLINE: U S West's Net Off 11%; Bell Atlantic Posts Gain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Continuing the mixed profit results reported by the nation's telephone companies for the third quarter, U S West Inc. said yesterday that its earnings had dropped 11 percent from a year earlier, while another regional Bell company, the Bell Atlantic Corporation, reported a profit increase of nearly 7 percent as the sale of an investment helped to override the weak economy. 
 Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
U S West
 U S West, based in Englewood, Colo., said its earnings fell to $269.3 million, or 66 cents a share, from $302.6 million, or 77 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 5.6 percent, to $2.62 billion, from $2.48 billion a year earlier.
The company said the 1991 quarter included a $17 million accounting charge to pay for a Washington State incentive regulation plan.
Richard D. McCormick, U S West's president and chief executive, attributed the earnings decline primarily to the impact of interstate telephone rate reductions and expanding international investments.
U S West owns U S West Communications and companies involved in data, marketing and financial services.
The company's shares were unchanged yesterday at $35 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Bell Atlantic

Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said profits rose to $382.7 million, or 98 cents a share, from $358.4 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was nearly flat at $3.1 billion.
The company said earnings were bolstered by the sale of a significant portion of its investment in the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand. The stock sale increased quarterly earnings by 19 cents a share, but there were costs of 3 cents a share.
Bell Atlantic's telephone subsidiaries reported small volume gains, reflecting the economy, the company said.
The average number of access lines for the quarter totaled 17.7 million, a 1.6 percent increase from the 1990 quarter. The number of cellular subscribers was about 295,000 at the end of the quarter, up about 58,000 for the last year.
Bell Atlantic is the parent of Bell of Pennsylvania, New Jersey Bell, Diamond State Telephone of Delaware and the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone companies of Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and the District of Columbia.
Bell Atlantic stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $45.125, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices at Highest Level Since the Persian Gulf War

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The price of oil soared yesterday to its highest level since the Persian Gulf war, wrapping up a week when traders decided that just about every bit of news or rumor was a good reason to buy.
Crude oil for delivery in November settled at $24.14 a barrel, up 21 cents, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had not closed that high since Jan. 22, in the early days of the gulf war, when the price was $24.18. 
 Trading focused on stormy weather in the North Sea, which forced one platform closing and delayed oil shipments. Given the tone of a market that has pushed up the per-barrel price by more than $2 over the last month, that was enough to prompt more buying.
"The way this market is acting, it's kind of a run-up with blinders on," said Victor Yu, vice president of futures at the Nikkhah Energy Group of Refco Inc. in New York. "It only looks at things that are bullish, not at things that are bearish."
An oil analyst, Peter Beutel of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., agreed that the market was nervously jumping at anything, even more than it did during certain points of the Iran-Iraq war.
"There were times a couple of years ago when we had a tanker hit every day by a missile, and it didn't do a darn thing," Mr. Beutel said. "Now, we have tankers being delayed and it sends the market scurrying."
Analysts are reluctant to speculate on how high prices could go, saying there is concern among many market participants that oil could become overbought and that a selloff would follow. But some experts who have been forecasting a selloff for some time were wrong again this week.
Crude declined only on Wednesday, when it fell 19 cents a barrel. For the week, oil for next-month delivery rose $1.05 a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Petroleum products have also been strong, at times leading the market higher.
Home heating oil for delivery in November settled at 69.81 cents a gallon, up 0.41 cent for the day and 2.27 cents for the week. Unleaded gasoline for delivery in November settled at 65.73 cents a gallon, up 1.30 cents for the day and 3.38 cents for the week.
Natural gas prices were mostly lower yesterday. But contracts for delivery in November settled at $2.025 for 1,000 cubic feet, up 1.1 cents for the day and 7 cents for the week.
In London, North Sea Brent blend crude oil for delivery in December settled at $22.59 a barrel, up 17 cents for the day, at the International Petroleum Exchange. For the week, Brent for next-month delivery rose 55 cents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Steep Decline On Weak Economic Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against most currencies yesterday as traders took profits after another bearish report on the United States economy.
Gold prices advanced. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery gained $2.20, to $362.20 an ounce. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $2.30, to a late bid of $360. 
 Analysts said the dollar sold off in Europe and continued to lose ground when trading shifted to the United States.
"The dollar finished at new lows for the week against key European currencies," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA. He said investors were bent on selling as hopes for an economic recovery continued to dim.
The Government reported yesterday that housing starts fell 2.2 percent in September, breaking a string of five advances and raising fresh doubts about the viability of a recovery in the housing sector.
Analysts said the dollar was also depressed by a news service report quoting an unidentified Federal Reserve official as saying the central bank is more concerned about the choppy economy than inflation. The report said the Fed viewed Thursday's report of an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in consumer prices in September as a blip that would not stop officials from lowering interest rates.
Lower interest rates are generally bearish for the dollar because they lessen the value of dollar-denominated securities.
Another factor depressing the dollar was the University of Michigan's latest survey of consumer sentiment, which showed a further erosion of confidence in the economy.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.85 Japanese yen, from 129.53 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it fell to 129.70 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.65 yen, up from 129.45 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7245, from $1.7090 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7270 to buy a pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7175.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6865 German marks, down from 1.6965; 1.4750 Swiss francs, down from 1.4815; 5.7480 French francs, down from 5.7760; 1,261.25 Italian lire, down from 1,267.00, and 1.1268 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1284.

HEADLINE: Panel Endorses F.D.I.C. Choice

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Senate Banking Committee voted 21 to 0 today to approve William Taylor as the new chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
His nomination is expected to be confirmed quickly by the full Senate next week.
Mr. Taylor is currently the director of banking supervision at the Federal Reserve. 
 One of his first tasks in his new job will be to decide whether the F.D.I.C. should raise the premium that banks pay to the insurance fund that protects banking deposits. Mr. Taylor has taken no public position on the premium level, which was increased to 23 cents for each $100 in deposits in July.
Even though some banks are complaining that the new level is onerous, many bankers attending an annual conference in San Francisco last week said a rise to 30 cents appeared inevitable.
The chances of an increase were heightened Wednesday when L. William Seidman, on his last day as chairman of the F.D.I.C., sent a letter to Senator Donald W. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the Banking Committee, warning that prolonged economic weakness could raise the cost of strengthening the bank fund.
Mr. Riegle responded by calling on the F.D.I.C. to consider higher premiums in order to limit future taxpayer costs.

HEADLINE: Bonds Rise as Inflation View Is Reassessed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rebounded yesterday after Thursday's sharp selloff, and interest rates moved lower.
Traders and analysts said a reassessment of Thursday's consumer price report, coupled with the release yesterday of figures showing September housing starts were weaker than expected, had much to do with the turnaround in prices. 
 The housing report said starts fell by 2.2 percent in September. Most analysts had expected starts to be unchanged or slightly higher.
 
Some Worries About Inflation

On Thursday, the Government said that consumer prices rose by four-tenths of a percent during September. The increase was about twice what had been anticipated, and, in response, long-term bond yields moved above 8 percent.
"The selloff has taken some of the complacency out of the market," one trader of government bonds said. "But I couldn't get too excited about that inflation number, because I don't think inflation is a problem. In my view, the economy is losing steam. If that's right, there isn't much chance that inflation is going to take off."
The sense that the economy was losing momentum as it entered the fourth quarter was reinforced yesterday by the release of the University of Michigan's survey of consumer sentiment in early October. The survey showed a marked decline in confidence from September.
The survey and the weak housing-starts figure "reawakened hopes that the Fed will ease credit in the near future," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "The economic data suggest that the economy is losing momentum, and that the consumer price report was an aberration."
Yesterday's increases in bond prices erased about half of Thursday's decline.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 31/32, up 29/ 32, to yield 7.95 percent, compared with 8.01 percent late Thursday.
 
Higher Than a Week Ago

Despite the improvement, bond yields were higher than a week ago, when they stood at 7.88 percent.
Among Treasury notes, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 18/32, up 14/32, to yield 7.49 percent. The 7 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 19/32, up 11/32, to yield 6.85 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 13/32, up 5/32, to yield 5.89 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.01 percent, down 4 basis points, or four one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 7 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.03 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 24.15, to a High of 3,077.15

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
For the second time this week, the Dow Jones industrial average reached a record high. It closed yesterday at 3,077.15, up 24.15 for the day and 93.47 for the week.
After a one-day pause, the momentum from previous sessions sparked by an improving outlook on corporate earnings and by a strong bond market again moved blue-chip stocks to higher levels. On Wednesday, the Dow had reached its previous high of 3,061.72. 
 "The key to this market is that many investors are concentrating on 12-month new highs in stocks," said William Raftery, a technical analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "This is a nice rally, but under the surface it still lacks some strong fundamentals. Sometime within the next two weeks, the market should shake out, and we will see if this rally is substantial. The key could come from the bond market."
Blue-chip stocks began their rally in the morning, as bond prices rose on a lower-than-expected report on September housing starts, which fell 2.2 percent. That raised expectations of another move by the Federal Reserve to invigorate the economy by lowering interest rates.
 
Volume Heavy Again

Volume was again heavy, at 205.3 million shares, down just slightly from 206 million shares on Thursday. Gainers outpaced losers by 900 to 723.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.58, to 392.50, while the New York Stock Exchange index rose by 0.35, to 216.15. Trading on the American Stock Exchange moved the composite up 1.38, to 382.49.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite was up 2.63, to 538.90, and the Russell 2,000, a more precise measure of the small issues, was up 0.57, to 183.41, breaking its previous high, reached Wednesday, of 182.84.
Mr. Raftery noted that many of stocks listing new highs were preferred stocks and thus reactive to interest rates. A weak bond market could erase a good many from that list and give a different picture of the strength of the market.
 
Marvel Entertainment Gains 3 5/8

In yesterday's market, the shares of the comic-book publisher Marvel Entertainment jumped 3 5/8, to 39 7/8, as the company reported surprisingly strong third-quarter earnings. Traders said Lauren Fine, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, raised Marvel's 1991 and 1992 earnings estimates, noting the profits would include money that Marvel would make from the Spiderman movie.
Schlumberger, the big oil service company, fell 1 1/2 to 68 7/8, on higher earnings. Philip J. Kehl, an analyst at Dean Witter, said he thought the earnings were good and could only speculate that some investors might have been expecting more.
Owens-Corning fell 8 1/8, to 24 3/4, after the company said it would increase 1992 reserves -- to cover an estimated 20,000 asbestos liability cases -- to $96 million, from $24 million in 1991. The company also reported third-quarter earnings that came in on the low side of analysts' estimates.
 
United Technologies Up 3 3/4

Reporting stronger-than-expected third-quarter results, United Technologies stock jumped 3 3/4, to 47 1/8. Analysts at Smith Barney and Dean Witter raised their ratings as a result.
Caterpillar reported a larger-than-expected third-quarter loss and predicted a loss in the fourth quarter. The stock, however, rose 1 1/8 to close at 48 5/8, indicating the loss was not surprising, the analysts said.
Eli Lilly was down 3 3/4, to 73 3/4, as analysts at Paine Webber and Smith Barney cut their ratings on the company. Traders said concern about earnings derived from the sale of Prozac, a drug for depression, and a $4.25 million lawsuit settlement may have been among the factors.

HEADLINE: Firm Cuts Its Rating On Citicorp

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The rating on short-term securities of Citicorp and its subsidiary Citibank was reduced yesterday by Thomson Bankwatch, a rating firm that specializes in bank securities.
The rating cut did not prompt any immediate increase in the interest rates that Citicorp and Citibank must pay for short-term borrowings, traders and investors said, but it was another blemish on the reputation of the nation's largest banking company. 
 Earlier in the week, after Citicorp announced an $885 million loss for the third quarter and suspended its common stock dividend, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reduced its ratings for short- and long-term Citicorp issues. Moody's Investors Service, which had reduced its ratings earlier in the year, left its ratings unchanged.
 
Rating Dropped to a C
 Nancy Newcombe, Citicorp's chief funding officer, was not at the New York office yesterday and unavailable to comment on the company's market reception. On Wednesday afternoon, when the loss was announced, she said that there had been no discernible market reaction to the announcement.
Thomson, whose bank ratings are closely watched by corporate treasurers and bankers who invest cash in bank certificiats of deposit, lowered its rating on Citicorp to C, the fifth highest of nine ratings, from B/ C the fourth highest. Companies with a C rating, according to Thomson's definition, are "inherently a sound credit, with no serious deficiencies." The C-rated companies "may have recently have experienced a period of difficulty, but those pressures should not be long-term in nature."
The ratings measure the probability of repayment, as well as the risk of adverse news that could depress prices of securities and make them harder to sell over the next two years.
Thomson also lowered its Citcorp numerical rating to 1 from 2. The numerical ratings, which range from 1 through 4, measure only the likelihood that debts will be repaid on time.
 
Rating Termed Justified

Because of its size and well-developed network of contacts with investors, Citicorp has long carried short-term debt ratings that were higher than some other banks that had larger cushions of capital and reserves to absorb future losses. With the latest reduction, Thomson's ratings for Citicorp are the same as those it has for other large New York banking companies, including Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical.
Gregory Root, president of Thomson, said the lower rating was justified for Citicorp because "they still face earnings pressure and have capital needs that must be addressed." Although he expects that Citicorp's financial health and earnings will improve as it reduces costs, he said, "That process is going to take some time."
Among the 199 American banking companies rated by Thomson, only 7 have the highest rating of A, followed by 20 with A/B, 38 with B, 29 with B/ C, 35 with C, 29 with C/D, 23 with D, 7 with D/E and 11 with E.
The subdued response to Citicorp's earnings announcement contrasts sharply with the turmoil a year ago, when it paid interest rates above 12 percent at some auctions of preferred stock amid unconfirmed rumors that it was having trouble borrowing in short-term markets. Since that episode, Citicorp has redeemed all $925 million of the auction-rate preferred stock.
 
Longer-Term Impact
 In the long-term bond market, the reaction to Citicorp's third-quarter loss was more noticeable. Yields on issues due in 5 to 10 years increased 15- to 20-hundredths of a percentage point, as prices fell a full point, or $10 per $1,000 bond, while most other bank issues were unchanged to slightly higher. One actively traded Citicorp issue, the 9 3/4 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1999, dropped 1 1/8 points since the earnings announcement, and the bid bid yesterday was 98 5/8, to yield about 10 percent.
Similar securities of other banking companies ranged from a low of about 8.20 percent for the top-rated J. P. Morgan & Company, to 8.95 percent for First Fidelity, a medium-grade regional banking company in Newark whose quality is improving, to 9.45 percent for Chemical and 9.85 percent for Chase Manhattan.
"Citicorp paper is like Teflon -- bad news just seems to slide right off," said Andrew Tarica, head of corporate bond trading at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Since the earnings announcement, he noted, there has been very little selling of Citicorp paper, but he warned that the paucity of bids for Citicorp issues could mean that larger price declines could result if more sellers emerged.
 
Cutting Out 'Hot' Money
 Like many other banking companies whose losses on commercial real estate loans have led to lower ratings, Citicorp has been adjusting its financial structure to reduce its reliance on "hot" money borrowed from investors who would be likely to withdraw their funds at signs of trouble.
Despite the recent changes, Citicorp relies heavily on the continued good will of investors around the world. At midyear, it had borrowed about $4.75 billion from other banks in the Federal funds market, down from $8.89 billion at the end of 1989, and its commercial paper sales were down to $1.46 billion from $7.12 billion. Other short-term borrowings, like deposits purchased in the Eurodollar market, were down to $13.07 billion from $18.93 billion.
Citicorp was able to reduce the borrowings by cutting its total size to $217.35 billion from $230.64 billion, and by increasing its consumer deposits to $95.02 billion from $87.29 billion.
One Federal funds broker, who asked not to be identifed because he does business with Citibank, said that there was no unusual borrowing by Citibank. After news of the Thomson rating reduction is spread, he said, some smaller banks around the country might reduce the amounts they are willing to sell to Citibank, "but the changes are not significant."
 
Rates Not Publicized

By reducing their short-term borrowings, and increasing the staff needed to raise funds from institutions around the world, Citicorp and other large banks are generally able to keep the interest rates they pay for borrowed funds from being widely publicized.
"You rarely hear from them," said James McDonald, a portfolio manager at T. Rowe Price Associates, a Baltimore-based mutual fund company. He noted that the interest rate offered on 30-day commercial paper by the Corporate Asset Funding Corporation, a special purpose company created by Citicorp to issue commercial paper and finance loans of Citicorp's business customers, was offered yesterday at about 5.20 percent, not much different from the 5.15 percent rate offered by the highest-quality industrial companies.
