HEADLINE: Minnesota Cancels Plan to Play Lottery on Nintendo

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Minnesota, under fire by its own legislators, has dropped its plan to use Nintendo video games in the home as a way to play the state lottery.
With the revenue growth of state lotteries tapering off, the Nintendo plan had created a great deal of interest in other states as an innovative use of the most widely available and easy-to-use computers in homes. But Minnesota legislators criticized the use of a children's toy to allow adults to gamble, and some also expressed concern about what they say is the already-high level of gambling in Minnesota. 
 George R. Andersen, director of the state lottery, said earlier this week that he had decided to drop plans to test the Nintendo lottery in 10,000 Minnesota households next June. The plan, which would have linked Nintendo video-game systems to a central lottery computer, included safeguards aimed at preventing children from playing the lottery.
The test would have been one of the first wide-scale instances in the United States of Nintendo computer equipment's being used for something other than playing video games.
"But it rubbed me and the rest of my colleagues the wrong way," said Roger D. Moe, a Democrat from Erskine and the State Senate's majority leader. "It was taking a children's game, using it for gambling in the home, and giving the whole thing the state's seal of approval."
Senator Moe said the Legislature received numerous letters of criticism after Minnesota's plan was given nationwide publicity last month. "I got a letter from some former Minnesotans sailing off the East Coast who heard about it on the radio," Senator Moe said. "They said it wasn't the right thing to do."
Mr. Andersen, the lottery director, was asked yesterday if legislators had put pressure on him to cancel the program. He laughed, and said, "We had a lot of frank, open discussions."
The Control Data Corporation, which is based in Minneapolis and provides equipment for the lottery, had developed the Nintendo idea. A company spokeswoman said yesterday that Control Data had received several inquiries from other state lotteries but that it was unclear what impact the Minnesota decision would have elsewhere. The company had hoped to market the plan in other states, but that seems less likely now with the cancellation of Minnesota's test.
Nintendo, the Japanese video-game company, is the world's largest maker of home computers. There are more than 30 million Nintendo systems in the United States; nearly a third of the nation's households have one. In Japan, people trade stocks and do their banking on Nintendo machines. But American companies have had little success in efforts to get consumers to use home computers for services like banking at home or reading the news.
 
A Step Too Far

Senator Moe said he had no criticism of Mr. Andersen because of the situation. "George did exactly what we wanted him to do, and that was to be creative," Senator Moe said. "But this went one step beyond what we could stomach."
Senator Moe had been circulating a letter among his 66 Senate colleagues urging that Mr. Andersen drop the plan. The Senator said he was certain a substantial majority, if not all, of his colleagues would have signed the letter.
The state lottery says Minnesota has one of the highest levels of gambling in the nation, principally because of the popularity of "pull tab" instant-winner games that raise money for local charities. Begun in the mid-1980's, the games have mushroomed into a $1.3 billion business in a state with a population of 4.3 million.
Also, there are 13 full-scale casinos on Minnesota Indian reservations, where blackjack and other games bring in $450 million. The two-year-old lottery brings in only $320 million.
 
A Senator's Concerns

"I'm fairly uneasy about all this gambling," Senator Moe said. "We should rein this in." He noted that the state had banned offtrack betting on horse races, and he said the Nintendo plan had parallels to offtrack betting.
Mr. Andersen, the lottery director, said of the legislators' reaction, "It was basically a call for a 'time out' on gambling, and I can't really quarrel with that."
Under the Nintendo plan, players would have deposited up to $200 in a special account to be used for wagering, with winnings credited to the account. Players would have been given an 11-character password to keep out children and unauthorized players. The lottery numbers would have been selected on their television set using a Nintendo control deck and then transmitted through a telephone modem to the central lottery computer.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fell by 2.2% in September

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments fell 2.2 percent in September, the Commerce Department said today, ending a mini-boom of five consecutive monthly increases and adding further evidence that the economy is struggling.
The September decline left housing starts at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.03 million units, somewhat less than Wall Street economists had expected. In August, housing starts rose seven-tenths of 1 percent. 
 "What this illustrates is the recovery in general and the housing recovery in particular is far more anemic this time around," said Wayne Ayers, chief economist at the Bank of Boston.
The weak housing numbers helped revive market hopes for lower interest rates, prompting rallies in stock and bond prices. In the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average reached its second record high of the week, gaining 24.15 points yesterday to close at 3,077.15. [Page 38.]
So far this year, housing starts are 19.5 percent below the comparable period last year, when they fell 13.3 percent from 1989. Economists nonetheless expect housing starts to improve gradually in the months ahead.
"I think the mortgage rate decline we have seen in the past six weeks may be reflected in the October numbers," said Ram Bhagavatula of Citicorp Global Finance.
Home building was one of the few bright spots last spring as the economy struggled out of a recession that began in mid-1990.
Lower interest rates meant more affordable monthly payments for buyers, although fears about jobs and accumulated debts from the 1980's have constrained consumers from taking on new long-term financial commitments.
The housing report was another in a long series of mixed economic reports. It came a day after the Government reported a one-tenth of 1 percent rise in industrial production in September.
There were some positive elements in the housing report. Building permit applications, an indicator of future building plans, rose 2.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted 979,000-unit annual rate, after a 5.2 percent drop in August.
 
Pickup at the Low End

"If you look at levels of the last three or four months, there is a little bit of strength showing the beginnings of a pickup in lower-priced" housing, said Allan Leslie, an economist at the Discount Corporation.
But even if starts improve, some economists doubt that they will rise back to the levels of some previous recoveries, notably the comparative boom years of the 1970's.
Among the housing report's details, construction of single-family homes fell in September by 2 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 868,000 units. It followed an eight-tenths of 1 percent rise in August.
New apartment building construction fell by 2.9 percent in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 165,000 units after being unchanged in August at a 170,000-unit rate.
Regionally, housing starts fell 3.5 percent last month in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 111,000 units a year.
Starts fell 4.5 percent in the Midwest, to a 235,000-unit rate. In the South, starts rose 1.6 percent in September, to a 433,000-unit rate, while in the West they fell 5.6 percent, to a 254,000-unit rate.
The number of houses actually started in September fell to 87,800 before seasonal adjustment, compared with 95,200 in August and 93,100 in September 1990.
Permits for building of single-family homes rose 1.4 percent, to a 780,000-unit rate in September. Permits for apartments rose by 8.2 percent, to a 199,000-unit rate.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Creditors Approve Carter Hawley Bailout

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Creditors of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. approved a $280 million bailout by the Zell-Chilmark Fund, it was announced today.
Zell-Chilmark, which is led by Samuel Zell, the Chicago investor whose dealings in troubled real estate and distressed companies have made him one of America's wealthiest men, specializes in bailing out troubled companies. It is now poised to take over Carter Hawley, the parent of the Broadway, Broadway Southwest, Emporium and Weinstock's stores, and the biggest department store operator in the West. 
 Chicago-based Zell-Chilmark said about 80 percent of Carter Hawley's creditors had accepted its offer to pay them 47 cents on the dollar for the retailer's debt to them.
The close of the tender offer for that debt on Thursday set the stage for Zell-Chilmark's eventual takeover and the company's emergence from bankruptcy proceedings within the next six months.
As Carter Hawley's largest creditor, Zell-Chilmark will negotiate with it to trade the debt for a controlling ownership stake.
"I don't know what we will end up with, but it will be significantly more than a majority of the company," Zell said.
The fund has also promised to lend Carter Hawley $50 million to help dress up aging stores.
"We feel terrific about this," said the retailer's chairman, Philip M. Hawley. "This is the most constructive thing that's happened to this company in a long time."
Mr. Hawley said the modernization program, intended to win customers back from specialty stores, will begin after the Christmas season.
Carter Hawley filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in February. Hammered by the recession and debt from a restructuring in the late 1980's, it had been struggling to pay suppliers.

HEADLINE: Israel and Soviets Restore Full Relations

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 18

 BODY:
A quarter-century of diplomatic estrangement ended today when the Soviet Union and Israel restored full relations and expressed hope that their renewed ties would help the cause of peace in the Middle East.
On many practical levels, little will change just because ambassadors will again be exchanged after a 24-year lapse. 
 The two countries established consular ties in 1987, and the political climate has steadily improved to a point where Soviet Jews are largely free to emigrate here after years of severe restrictions. Nearly 350,000, including many from the now-independent Baltic republics, have flocked to Israel in the last two years, making them the country's largest Jewish group by country of origin.
But today's action carried great symbolic importance. For Israel, a young nation still craving world recognition, it means that it has finally regained approval from a superpower, albeit a diminished one. For the Soviet Union, it erases a diplomatic anomaly that helped shove it to the political sidelines in this region.
"This brings us to a more open dialogue so that they will hear Israeli positions face-to-face," said Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel. "We will also hear their positions. We need not agree on everything."
 
A 'Historic Mistake'
 His Soviet counterpart, Boris D. Pankin, making only the second trip to this country by a Soviet Foreign Minister, suggested agreement with Mr. Levy that the long rupture in relations had been a "historic mistake."
"In the past, the Soviet Union tended to sort of side with the Palestinians and the Arab states, while the United States sided with Israel," Mr. Pankin told a news conference. "This did not bring any tangible fruit."
"The new approach now," he said, "is certainly not to have any proteges and support their positions no matter what they say and no matter how legitimate they may be."
That remark was certainly welcome to Israel, which had chafed for years over Moscow's policy of favoring -- and arming -- Arab nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization at every turn. The Soviet Union was one of the first countries to formally recognize the nascent Israeli state in 1948, partly to gain a diplomatic foothold in the Middle East and partly to counter British dominance in the region. But relations soured in the late 1950's, when Moscow became the principal arms supplier to Egypt and Syria during their short-lived United Arab Republic. The Soviet Union severed all ties at the time of the 1967 Middle East War, which to Moscow's dismay was won by Israel on all fronts in six days.
The rupture in relations led to virulent anti-Zionist campaigns in the Soviet Union, which prompted hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews to seek to emigrate.
 
A Question of Support
 It was not clear if the new relationship would actually translate into Soviet decisions to line up behind Israel on at least some disputes with its Arab neighbors.
On one point there was no question: Diplomatic ties went hand in hand with a signal from Israel's leaders that they would ask the Cabinet on Sunday to accept a joint United States-Soviet invitation to attend the opening of a Middle East peace conference in Madrid on Oct. 30. The Soviet side was unwilling to act unless Israel seemed likely to stay in the peace process, and, similarly, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had said repeatedly that without formal Soviet recognition, Israel would stay home.
In a statement issued by both Foreign Ministers, the two sides said that their resumption of ties "fully serves the interests of a comprehensive settlement in the Middle East, the establishment of a lasting peace and stability in this region and a further development of international cooperation."
Mr. Levy suggested that for starters Israel would ask the Soviet Union to put pressure in the peace process on Syria, now Moscow's chief Arab ally. He also said that Israel and the Soviet Union had set up a committee on economic cooperation and other matters that would meet soon in both countries' capitals.
Despite the sense of occasion, there was also an air of anticlimax, partly because the Soviet Union, despite its co-sponsorship of the Middle East peace conference, has clearly forfeited to the United States the power to shape the regional agenda. Some Israeli officials have gone so far in recent days as to say that it is debatable who is doing whom the bigger favor by restoring relations.
 
Playing Second Fiddle
 Moscow's shrunken status was clear over the last two days as Mr. Pankin's trip overlapped with that of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Not too long ago, their convergence in this ancient city would have carried enormous significance and sense of drama. But there was little of that today, for clearly Mr. Pankin was playing second fiddle to his American colleague.
Moreover, Moscow, which had led its Warsaw Pact allies to break relations with Israel 24 years ago, is now the last of that bloc to restore them in the wake of Communism's collapse.
Although the Soviet Union became a strident enemy of Israel after 1967, it started off as an enthusiastic supporter, having been the third country, after the United States and Guatemala, to recognize the new state after the British mandate ended on May 14, 1948.
Many Israeli pioneers, fired with Socialist fervor in the early days, saw a kindred spirit in the Soviet Union that seemed worth emulating. But the goodwill faded and then disappeared after 1967. Bitterness still lingers, raising questions about how long it will take the two sides to turn cordial relations into truly friendly ones.
"The circumstances in which they announced the severance of ties were very humiliating," said Reuven Mershav, a former Foreign Ministry director-general. "Their behavior was insulting."
"Walls like this don't come down in a day," Mr. Mershav said, "but there is no question that what the Soviets did signals a lot."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Soviet Union and Israel ended 24 years of estrangement by restoring diplomatic relations yesterday. The Soviet Foreign Minister, Boris D. Pankin, left, celebrated with Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE RESIST REPATRIATION PLAN

BYLINE: By BARBARA BASLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Vietnamese refugees who fear they may be forcibly returned to Vietnam from Hong Kong have been staging demonstrations inside the largest of this British colony's detention camps and have been making plans for armed resistance should Britain and Hanoi conclude an agreement on the repatriations.
Officials here had confidently expected an agreement on the mandatory return of tens of thousands of Vietnamese to be signed in Hanoi this week. 
 But late today a British Foreign Office spokesman in the colony said: "We have indicated we are ready to sign, and they have indicated they are not. We don't know for certain at this stage what's causing the delay."
 
Tension in the Camps
 Inside the gritty camps, which house 59,000 Vietnamese refugees, the suspense and tension over their fate has grown "almost unbearable," said a relief worker who requested anonymity.
"The people inside are afraid they will go to sleep one night, and without warning, the guards will come to take them away," the worker said. "Even the sensible people are so afraid they can't think very straight anymore."
For three years, the Hong Kong authorities have insisted they had a right to deport Vietnamese who have been classified as nonrefugees through a screening process monitored by United Nations officials. But the process has been criticized by human rights groups as being unfair and inaccurate.
In 1989, the British authorities carried out the first forced return of Vietnamese from Hong Kong, using riot police to herd 51 refugees, most of them women and children, onto an airplane in what they hoped would be a secret nighttime operation. But news of the action was reported and photographed, and it led to an international outcry that so embarrassed Hanoi it refused to accept any more refugees who were forced to return.
Hong Kong officials said the delay over the new agreement has been because the Vietnamese were trying to work out the logistical problems of reintegrating the thousands of returnees.
One Western diplomat said, however, there could also be internal political problems in Hanoi, with some officials there opposed to the agreement because of the American opposition.
The United States led the protest over the 1989 incident, arguing that it was wrong forcibly to return people to a repressive government that might persecute them for their original flight. Hanoi is currently sensitive to American opinion because it wants to establish diplomatic and economic ties with the United States.
United States Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon said today that America's position "has been clear for a long time. We are opposed to the forced repatriation of people from Hong Kong to Vietnam, particularly given the current circumstances in that country."
 
U.S. Response Critical
 But it is uncertain how strongly Washington would protest a new British-Vietnamese deal on forced repatriation, and officials in Hong Kong have said the American response will be critical to the accord.
Whatever the cause, the delay has only added to the wrenching tensions in the Hong Kong camps.
In Whitehead Detention Center, the largest and most volatile camp, thousands of refugees have been staging peaceful demonstrations for the past two weeks, and some of their leaders said some have begun to plan hunger strikes, armed resistance and even suicide if guards come to take them away.
Whitehead, which houses 25,000 people, is populated largely by Vietnamese who have been through the screening process and were told they do not qualify as genuine refugees fleeing persecution.
Reporters are not allowed inside the detention camps, but they can sometimes get close enough to see the demonstrations at Whitehead, where as many as 15,000 Vietnamese march in circles behind high mesh fences looped with barbed wire. The protesters carry homemade banners and signs that read "Freeworld Save Us,' and "Dead Better than Red."
"So far the demonstrations have been peaceful and orderly, but everyone is very, very anxious, and some extremists are pushing for more violent actions," said David Liu, a spokesman for Refugee Concern Hong Kong, an umbrella organization of relief groups that work inside the camps.

HEADLINE: Thomas Hearings as Testimony to the Power of Race in American Politics

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 17

 BODY:
It was billed as a watershed drama about sexual harassment, but in the end, as has been the case so often in the past, the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court turned on something else -- race.
The particulars were new -- a black conservative defended by Southern white Senators. But in its imagery, in the emotions it engendered and in the way both blacks and whites reacted, the fight over Judge Thomas's nomination was a stark evocation of the eerie continuity and the startling power of race in American life and politics. 
 "When you put all the hot buttons out in front of you, clearly race is the one that's white hot," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic political consultant.
 
Flux in Race Relations
 The furor, particularly the emotion-packed Senate hearings last weekend, reflected much of the flux in the nation's race relations. Not only was the Thomas nomination salvaged by white Southerners, who were clearly concerned with the power of the black vote, but it also presented television audiences -- perhaps for the first time -- with a view of cadres of conservative black professionals very different from the general stereotypes of blacks.
But beneath the surface, the emotions engendered were so familiar as to be almost primal.
For blacks, there was a solid show of support for an embattled black man, even one assailed as an enemy of civil rights, that reinforced the degree to which blacks have behaved as a unified political force.
For whites, there was a melodrama in which a black man was seen as either a long-suffering figure assaulted on all sides or Willie Horton in a suit and tie -- a division that mirrors the traditional racial iconography of the South.
For the nation, there was the reminder that racial politics remain the most emotionally charged divide, one that is so powerful that a black conservative critical of the civil rights agenda could raise the specter of racism and the Democrats questioning him were all but silenced.
There was also the reminder that more than three decades after the beginning of the civil rights revolution in the South, the racial dilemmas that once haunted the South now play the same role nationally.
"The role that blacks play today is the role they have always played in the South," said Joel Williamson, a humanities professor at the University of North Carolina who is the author of "The Crucible of Race: Black-White Relations in the South Since Emancipation" (Oxford University Press, 1984). "If you just look at the black and white bodies and their mutual proximity to one another, there's been a revolution. But if you look at ideas, opinions and notions, if you push it out toward the subconscious, very little has changed."
In some ways, the Thomas nomination, the hearings and the vote helped destroy the idea of a monolithic black community. Instead, Judge Thomas's conservative views and the savvy black professionals who testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee, provided a rare view of the philosophical and economic diversity among blacks.
But most striking may have been the way that many black Americans vigorously supported Judge Thomas, who characterized the hearings as a "high-tech lynching," a comparison that was later derided by members of Congressional Black Caucus.
Roger Wilkins, a longtime civil rights figure who teaches at George Mason University, attributed part of the support to the degree to which most blacks were unaware of the specifics of what he termed Judge Thomas's "hideous record of attacking civil rights remedies and civil rights leaders."
But he also saw a deep-rooted and instinctive reaction of blacks who saw a common interest in defending one of their own.
"Blacks have been terribly deprived throughout our history and we've been deprived among other things of symbols of pride occupying high places," he said. "So that when a black is presented for such a position there is an instinctive reaction to support that person."
That was the clear view on Auburn Avenue here, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born, and where the Southern Christian Leadership Conference he headed and the civil rights center named for him stand.
Here, in one of the spiritual meccas of the civil rights movement, there was overwhelming support for Judge Thomas, more often in spite of his philosophy than because of it.
"How can a black man be a conservative?" asked Marquette DeCuir, shaking his head in disgust as he and a small group of men discussed the Thomas affair near the shoeshine stand at the Fashion Dry Cleaners.
But, that said, he voiced his wholehearted support of Judge Thomas, to the unanimous assent of the other men on hand. "Of course, I'm going to support a black man," he said. "I don't care who he is."
In their recent book, "Chain Reaction: The Impact of Race, Rights and Taxes on American Politics," (W. W. Norton, 1991) Thomas Byrne Edsall and Mary D. Edsall argue that racial issues, explicit and subterranean, have torn apart the old Democratic coalition and driven whites toward the Republican Party. It is a process that mimics the traditional politics of the South.
Professor Williamson says much of the racial psychology of the South is also being played out on a national level. Much like the world depicted in Ralph Ellison's classic novel, "Invisible Man," he said, whites had never been able to see blacks as people but rather as stereotypes. He said throughout history Southerners had seen blacks as either devils or angels -- either beloved field hands and docile country folk or as rapacious animals.
In the Thomas hearings, before a transfixed nation, Judge Thomas was transformed into both, with a power clearly exacerbated by race, he said.
But Professor Williamson said integration, however limited and often painful, was also producing a quiet transformation. "The one bright element is this business of physical integration," he said. "We're getting better generation by generation, but I think we have several hundred years to go."
Whatever the case, few people expect race to recede as a national issue.
"I think it will continue to heat up," Professor Wilkins said. "When we're in uncertain economic times, white people become insecure and frightened, and they look around for scapegoats. The racial advances we've had usually have come in times of economic expansion, when people feel good about themselves. I don't think the American people are going to feel very optimistic for some time to come."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Bars Project in Way Of Skyline View

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of motorists and bus drivers move down the ramp to the Lincoln Tunnel each day, taking in a sweeping view of the Hudson River and the Manhattan skyline before they plunge into the tube that takes them from New Jersey to Manhattan.
New Jersey environmental officials have decided that the view is worth preserving, and they announced yesterday that a developer could not block it by building two high-rise office buildings on the Hudson River waterfront in Weehawken. 
 The decision, which the developer says it will appeal, was a victory for state and local environmental groups that have fought to have the project either scaled down or rejected.
Ruth Elsasser, president of the Weehawken Environment Committee, said: "This is a one-of-a-kind view of the Hudson River. It is a magnificent, beautiful resource."
 
Project Developed by Hartz
 The proposed buildings were to be part of Lincoln Harbor, a commercial and residential complex being developed by Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus on 93 acres of Hudson riverfront. The project consists of retail and restaurant space, a 322-room hotel, 300 units of housing, a 250-slip marina and two other completed office buildings.
The buildings at issue were designed to be "mirror images" of two 160-foot buildings that went up earlier. The Weehawken Planning Board had approved Hartz Mountain's plans, but the developer also needed a permit from the state Department of Environmental Protection and Energy.
John Weingart, Assistant Commissioner in the department, said, "When balancing the competing equities, the department concluded that the view enjoyed by millions when approaching the Hudson River is an important asset to the waterfront region and New Jersey as a whole."
Mr. Weingart said that the decision to deny the permit was reached only after Hartz Mountain had been given an opportunity to revise its plans so that the buildings would not obstruct the view that officials say is enjoyed by nearly 400,000 commuters a day. He said environmental officials suggested that the buildings be redesigned 85 feet tall instead of the original 160 feet.
The developer's lawyer, Daniel E. Horgan, called the suggested changes "economically impractical."
"Nobody would invest his mother's money in the scheme the department has come up with," Mr. Horgan said.

HEADLINE: Suggestion on Housing for the Homeless in Brooklyn Draws Anger

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In the first round of what promises to be a long debate, a Federal agency has recommended that Andrew Cuomo's HELP for the Homeless group be chosen to build housing for hundreds of homeless people on the site of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, angering some local groups who have other ideas.
As word of the recommendation seeped out yesterday, the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden -- already irate at the Dinkins administration's recent plan for scattering up to two dozen new shelters for homeless single people around the city -- denounced it as "inhumane dumping." 
 Mr. Cuomo, the Governor's son, heads a special mayoral commission due to make sweeping recommendations on the city's homeless policy by next winter. His role in the Brooklyn Navy Yard site injected him into a long-simmering dispute between Hasidic and Hispanic groups in Brooklyn, each in search of land to gain more housing for their own communities.
"This was the promised land that we were continually told by the city will be the answer to the housing crisis in Williamsburg, and to relieve the tension between the Latinos and the Hasidic community," said Isaac Abraham of the Federation of Tenants Councils of Williamsburg. "We have lost the battle for good."
But Mr. Cuomo said yesterday that his proposal would be only part of a comprehensive plan for the site, which stretches over more than 30 acres from Fort Greene to Williamsburg along the East River. He said he would defer on the design and specifics to state and city officials who are crafting a joint proposal for a mix of permanent housing, economic development, homeless housing and open space there.
Mr. Cuomo's proposal was recommended by the Department of Health and Human Services under a Federal law that requires the Government to give special consideration to housing for the homeless when disposing of surplus Federal land. The final decision rests with the Navy, and city officials said they expected any disposition would be months away.
In effect, Mr. Cuomo now has his foot in the door, with first priority to develop whatever part of the site is used for homeless people, and in a position to help broker a compromise among all the various groups that have an interest in using it.
"I believe the most intelligent approach is to forge a coalition that goes to the Federal Government hand in hand with one comprehensive plan, rather than leaving it to the Federal Government to forge such a plan," he said in a telephone interview yesterday.
Mr. Cuomo said his plan involved only transitional housing for less than 1,000 homeless families and singles, but he would not be more specific, saying the outline would be subsumed in a broader plan.
Deputy Mayor Barbara J. Fife said the city and state would submit their joint plan to the General Services Administration, which acts as go-between for the Navy, on Monday.
Depending on what sorts of projects are settled on, she said, the city might need fewer of the 35 potential sites it suggested last week for building new transitional shelters, with special services to meet the mental and health needs of single homeless people. She said the city had not earlier included the Navy Yard in its plan because control of the site was not certain.

HEADLINE: Weiser Journal;
For Small-Town Doctor, A Big Banner Welcome

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEISER, Idaho, Oct. 16

 BODY:
On the menu at this weekend's Weiser Wolverine homecoming feast is a tub of potato salad, piles of hot barbecue beef sandwiches and a mountainous cake, which is inscribed, "Welcome, Dr. Barr."
If that doesn't make Dr. Deland Barr of Wellington, Kan., feel at home in Weiser -- "call us Weezerites, that's what we are," says the town grocer, Tom Anderson -- there is more. Much more. 
 Across the town's main drag, the central route for the homecoming parade, is another big banner welcoming to town the 40-year-old doctor, his wife, Sally, and their six children. At halftime in the big game, Dr. Barr will be introduced. And in a grand, final ceremony on Saturday, Dr. Barr is to sign his name to a contract binding him to this farm town of 4,700 people in western Idaho for at least two years.
The rhythms of small-town America remain as ageless as the cottonwoods now aflame with color here, but its problems change with the years. Weiser, like many rural communities, has a doctor shortage. Two of the town's three physicians want to retire, and the third, Dr. Byron Drake, who is 38, says he will not stay unless he has at least one partner. Dr. Barr will be his partner.
Without doctors, the 27-bed hospital would close. Without the hospital, said Mayor J. K. Jones, the nursing home might close, too. And then Weiser itself might well roll up and die.
As Mr. Anderson put it, "You start forcing people to leave your town to go for a basic service, and everything else might leave as well."
With 2,000 counties around the country underserved by doctors -- there is a shortage of nearly 35,000 family practitioners, primarily in rural areas, according to the American Academy of Family Physicians -- the odds of Weiser's finding a new doctor were bleak. Idaho, with only 1,400 practicing doctors for its one million people, has the lowest ratio of doctors to patients of any state.
More than ever before, medical students are shunning rural areas. Beginning their careers with an average college debt of $53,000, young doctors say it is nearly impossible to survive economically in small towns. The typical doctor now makes about $150,000, according to the American Medical Association.
What could Weiser offer? Well, its people grow onions as big as softballs and as sweet as apples, and they raise a hybrid corn that is marketed as microwave popcorn. Hell's Canyon, the deepest gorge in North America, starts just a holler to the west, and the great alpine peaks of the Sawtooth Range are within a day's drive to the east.
You can buy a house for $25,000. Most people leave their doors unlocked and their car keys in the ignition. (Note to potential burglars: don't get any ideas; Weiserites are well-armed, especially now that it's hunting season.)
But you can't eat the scenery, and even sweet onions get old after a while. Cash, the citizens of Weiser decided, was the only sure-fire way to bring a new doctor to town.
For the last three years the townspeople have held bake sales, car washes, raffles, card games, and sold tables full of pies on Cabin Fever night at the high school. They raised $55,000 in the doctor recruitment drive, but still had no doctor in sight.
The big break came this year when a Dallas medical recruitment firm, Merritt, Hawkins and Associates, chose Weiser from among more than 50 communities that applied after the firm said it would waive the $20,000 fee it charges for finding doctors.
Weiser was chosen because of its strong community spirit and because it is a textbook example of the crisis in rural health, said James Merritt, the firm's president.
After a nationwide search, the firm found Dr. Barr in Kansas. He and his wife said they always wanted to live in the mountains. Colorado, they said, "was too touristy." Weiser seemed perfect. On a visit last summer, they were impressed with the town.
The problem was money. After much discussion, a deal was struck in which the town agreed to subsidize part of Dr. Barr's salary in the first two years of his contract. The aim is to have him earn from $85,000 to $110,000, said Phil Lowe, the administrator of the Weiser Memorial Hospital and head of the recruitment drive. After a few years, Dr. Barr's practice should be self-sustaining.
But some sticking points remain. The life of a country doctor is anything but idyllic. Dr. Barr said he would like to have some time to enjoy the country around Weiser, but with on-call responsibilities at any hour, the job can be a seven-day affair.
"I enjoy small-town medicine because it allows me to do things I wouldn't normally be allowed to do, but that's also a drawback," he said.
If, as expected, Dr. Barr can work out the final details of his contract by Saturday morning, Weiser can rest easy for at least two years. But Weiserites have no such plans.
"After he signs, we're just going to love him and love him and show him how much we care about him," Mr. Lowe said. "He will never feel unwanted."

HEADLINE: Urban Memo;
An Underground Burp Makes Midtown Quake

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
There is a breakdown at a telephone switching station. Half the long-distance phone circuits into and out of New York City are cut off. Airports are thrown into chaos because the air traffic controllers who guide takeoffs and landings at local airports are disconnected.
There is a lovers' quarrel. A homeless woman raging at her companion sets fire to a shack under the West Side Highway. Traffic is tied up for miles and for hours as officials assess the damage to the elevated roadway. 
 There is an electrical-transformer fire in lower Manhattan. Wall Street trading floors go dark, hundreds of workers are trapped in elevators and thousands are forced to walk down endless shadowy flights of stairs.
The vulnerability of the city was demonstrated once again on Thursday when a water main burst at Lexington Avenue and East 42d Street, flooding the subway station below, buckling the pavement above and creating a Rube Goldbergian chain reaction that clogged highways leading into the city and snarled traffic on feeder roads as far away as Yonkers.
 
19th-Century Infrastructure
 New Yorkers see their city as big, complicated and invincible. And it is, so long as everything functions the way it is supposed to. Not everything does. There were 592 broken water mains in the 12 months that ended June 30.
But the water mains are not the only problem. Some urban planners say that high-tech marvels that have been superimposed over a low-to-medium-tech infrastructure -- essentially the layering of late 20th century over the 19th century city -- could make disruptions more frequent and more annoying. "The more sophisticated the city, the more fragile it is," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Planning Institute.
New York City's population is roughly the same as that of Belgium or the Netherlands, but its 7.3 million people are jammed into far less space. The density alone magnifies the disruptions to the underground labyrinth, the largest on this continent. Density also plays a role that small European countries do not have to think twice about. New York's infrastructure converges at what amounts to an epicenter: Manhattan. Snaking under the 24 square miles of Manhattan are 11 million miles of telephone wire, 19,000 miles of electrical cable, 6,000 miles of water mains, 4,000 miles of gas lines, 100 miles of cable television wiring and 105 miles of steam pipes -- all crammed into passages barely big enough to crawl through.
 
Problems Upon Problems
 It is a system, if that word can be used to describe such a labyrinthine maze, that urban planners still marvel at. The drawback is that much of it, once pioneering and imitated, is by now ancient.
"One of the problems of coming first is you have the oldest infrastructure," said George Sternlieb, former director of the Urban Institute at Rutgers University.
Indeed, more than half the city's water mains were installed before 1940 and are made of brittle, breakable cast iron. The one that ruptured on Thursday was far from the first. Three years ago, a main laid in 1898 ruptured, flooding Columbus Circle above and below ground and disrupting subway service for two days. And a main that burst on Fifth Avenue at 19th Street in 1989 took more than a year to repair.
 
A Recipe for Disaster
 Some problems arise when the increasingly sophisticated parts of the infrastructure do not mesh. This is what Tony Hiss, the urban historian and author of "The Experience of Place," means when he talks about the tensions between "the water delivery system" and "the people delivery system."
Twice as many cars enter Manhattan every day as did immediately after World War II, causing vibrations that can often rupture water pipes, although officials indicated that was not a factor on Thursday. "You're putting much more stress on the system because of the way we've reconfigured transportation -- without thinking about the way it would affect the rest of the the infrastructure," Mr. Hiss said.
Some experts see contrasts between the old mechanical systems and the new software-driven communications networks. Mr. Moss maintains that the water mains are the most sensitive component of the infrastructure, because they can more easily wreak havoc on the other components. But other components, while more efficient than the ones that handled the same tasks in the past, are still vulnerable, which can mean more havoc than ever.
The new fiber optic phone cables are a prime example, Mr. Moss said. "Since they carry more messages than the copper they replaced," he said, "a break is far more significant than a break in a copper cable. A small problem produces an international catastrophe for communications. The reason is the phone systems are now software-driven and they're all connected to each other. They're so highly interconnected that problems occurring in a small fiber can have consequences for the entire Northeast."

HEADLINE: Year After Tax Leap, New Jersey Faces Budget Gap

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
 New Jersey, which last year had the biggest tax increase in state history, faces its second budget crisis in a row next year.
Barring a dramatic turnaround in the state's economy, revenues will fall at least $500 million short in the fiscal year that will begin on July 1. State Treasurer Douglas Berman says the short-term outlook for such a turnaround is "gloomy" based on reports this month on the economic health of the nation and the region. 
 Mr. Berman's prediction has implications for this year's budget of $14.6 billion as well as for the budget next year when the state will not be able to count on more than $500 million in one-time revenues that it used this year.
"The economic news is more uncertain" than had been expected when the present budget was drawn up, Mr. Berman said in an interview. "We assumed the economy would lag but would start to grow. I am not so sanguine any more."
 
Delay Expected in Early '92
 Despite such pessimistic forecasts, echoed by other Democratic leaders, Republicans have said that if they win control of the Legislature in November, they will make good on a pledge included in their party platform this summer: to roll back a one-cent increase in the sales tax that was approved by the Democratic-controlled Legislature last year at Mr. Florio's urging. If they succeeded, it would cost the state another $550 million in revenue -- and the Republicans say they are prepared to reduce the size of the government to deal with that.
Mr. Berman said that while overall revenue was on target so far, his concern was that money might not come in nearly so fast as expected in the first half of 1992.
Sales-tax revenue for the first two months of this fiscal year -- the most recent figures available -- showed an increase over last year of only two-tenths of 1 percent, from $689.2 million to $692.2 million this year.
But income-tax collections in the first quarter of the fiscal year increased by 22 percent, from $534.9 million to $653.5 million, over the same quarter a year ago, mainly because of rate increases imposed on higher-income taxpayers.
 
A Democrat's Concern
 Senator Laurence Weiss, the Middlesex Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee, said in an interview that his biggest concern was flat sales-tax revenues despite the one-cent increase.
"It will take 18 months or more" for retail sales to increase substantially, he said. "Retail sales will stay flat, so sales taxes will stay flat. It's nobody's fault."
The Republican Assembly Leader, Chuck Haytaian, who would become Assembly Speaker if the Republicans take over that house in next month's elections, maintains that his party is committed to reducing the sales tax, even if it means further sharp cuts in spending on top of those imposed by the Florio administration, including the elimination of some 5,000 state jobs through attrition, early retirements and layoffs. The sales tax was increased from six cents to seven and extended to items not previously taxed, like paper products and alcoholic beverages. That accounted for about $1.5 billion of the record $2.8 billion tax increase.
 
'Major Downsizing'
 "We will not approve the budget next year if the Governor has a revenue source based on the sales tax increase," Mr. Haytaian said. "We will not pass the budget."
Mr. Haytaian was not specific about which jobs or services he would cut to make up the $550 million that would be lost if the sales tax is rolled back, but he said a "major downsizing" of state government would be necessary.
Senator Gerald Stockman, a Trenton Democrat who is a ranking member of the Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee, said of the Republicans' vow: "It's snake oil for him to be talking about this around the state."

HEADLINE: A Valuable Government Document! Free!

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Whenever Donald W. Kellerman, a specialist in retirement planning for Dean Witter Reynolds, meets with new clients he recommends that they obtain a free Government document describing the benefits on which two-thirds of retirees rely for at least half their income: Social Security.
"I always hold up one of these forms and tell them to send it in," said Mr. Kellerman, referring to the application for a Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement. The Social Security Administration began offering the statement in 1988. This, along with information about one's company pension, is the starting point, he said, for anybody planning for retirement. 
 Yet, this mine of information is relatively unexploited. Less than 5 percent of the 133 million people with Social Security accounts request the statement in a given year, far fewer than could profitably use it.
Even savvy financial people, in fact, often assume that the Pebes (rhymes with webs) merely confirms that their employer has been paying into the account on their behalf and that they will ultimately qualify for benefits on retirement.
 
A Valuable Financial Planning Aid
 But the statement provides far more, making it an extremely valuable financial planning aid that can help determine, among other things, how long a person will need to work and what other financial provision he or she will need for retirement.
When I recently received my own statement, I learned that if I worked for the next 13 years and retired at 65 my monthly retirement benefit would be about $1,230, and that if I worked until my so-called full retirement age of 65 years, 4 months, the benefit would rise to $1,260. A gradual increase in the full-retirement age begins to take effect in the year 2000 until the age at which one can collect full benefits reaches 67 in 2027.
The statement also informed me that if I retired at 70, my estimated benefit would be $1,740 a month. These estimates are all figured on the basis of a presumed 1 percent annual increase in the average national wage between now and age 62, but they do not allow for inflation. Social Security benefits are automatically raised each year, based on increases in the Consumer Price Index. (The rise for 1992, announced this week, is to be 3.7 percent.)
In addition to these figures, of which I previously had only a vague notion, the Pebes told me I would get $1,055 a month if I were disabled now, and detailed the amounts my wife and children would get if I should die.
The statement thus represents a major advance from the days when Social Security officials typically did manual calculations on request for those approaching retirement, and account holders knew virtually nothing about the other benefits.
"I'm really proud we were able to do this," said Dorcas R. Hardy, a former Commissioner in whose tenure the Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statement was adopted. "It was a massive computer undertaking."
Besides describing and estimating benefits, the Pebes also provides a year-by-year record back to 1937 of a worker's earnings that were subject to Social Security taxes and the amount of taxes (formerly called contributions) the worker paid. Among other things, this allows one to see the relation between taxes and benefits, a link seldom established in public discussion.
You can see, for example, how long it will take after retirement to get back the amount paid in. Most retirees will get back far more money than they paid in Social Security taxes even if it is assumed that they would have saved the money and invested it in Treasury bills. People with average earnings (about $20,000) will get all their taxes back in two years -- five and a half years if allowance is made for interest. High earners, those earning more than $50,000, break even in seven years if interest is figured, and three years if not; low-income people, earning about $10,000 a year, in four years with interest, one without.
Lower-income workers pay a higher proportion of their income in Social Security taxes than do the wealthy, but their retirement benefits are proportionately higher.
"The $50,000-a-year guy doesn't get five times the benefits of the $10,000 guy," said Philip Gambino, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration.
A check of one's own record establishes two things. First, it shows that one's employer has not absconded with the withheld taxes and, second, whether one has worked long enough to qualify for benefits, which are based on a combination of longevity in the work force and of earnings.
The minimum requirement is 40 credits, a credit this year being $540 of wages subject to Social Security taxes or self-employment income. Four credits, previously called quarters, can be earned in a year.
"The sooner people can review what we are recording, the sooner we can catch any errors," said Gwendolyn S. King, the present Commissioner. Some 2 to 3 percent of people checking their records allege errors.
If your Pebes does not accurately reflect your work and earnings history, report this to Social Security by calling the 800 number provided on the statement. You must have W-2 statements, pay stubs or other proof.
 
How to Get a Benefit Statement
 Obtaining your Pebes is quite simple. First, telephone Social Security at (800) 772-1213 (a new number this fall) and give your name and address. This will bring a short form on which you supply your date of birth, Social Security number, the retirement age you desire (the minimum is 62, at which the benefit is 80 percent of the benefit at 65), your present salary and your projected earnings until retirement. It takes about a month for the statement to arrive. You may apply for statements repeatedly if, say, you want to compare benefits at different retirement ages.
The earnings and benefit statements have attracted such praise among those who know about them that, beginning in 1999, the law obliges the Social Security Administration to start mailing them out automatically each year.
Beginning in 1995, statements are to be automatically mailed to those reaching age 60 for whom a current address can be found.
"I think it's a really great tool," Ms. King said. "People need to start doing some serious planning. We need to make sure they have a realistic view."

HEADLINE: Ex-Klan Chief Has Even Odds in Governor's Race

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18

 BODY:
As the Louisiana governor's race drew near a close today, the politics of this state seemed at first glance to be as murky and meandering as the waters of a delta bayou.
But one factor seems most likely to dictate the outcome: David Duke, a former neo-Nazi and grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, has become a major contender in Saturday's open primary by running a campaign that has used code words and symbols like "the rising welfare underclass" to blame blacks for unemployment, crime, government bureaucracy and almost anything else he can identify as a threat to what he calls "our treasured Christian life style." 
 Recent public opinion polls indicate the vote Saturday is essentially a three-way heat with Mr. Duke, a State Representative; former Gov. Edwin Edwards, and the incumbent Governor, Buddy Roemer, running close.
Regardless of the outcome, this election will be a major test of how racial identities and biases are shaping political loyalties in a major Southern state on the eve of a Presidential election year. The two top vote-getters will probably meet in a runoff on Nov. 16, since no one of the three candidates seems likely to receive a majority of the vote on this round.
Mr. Edwards, a populist Democrat, is counting on the historic loyalty to his party of black voters, who usually make up 27 percent of the electorate. Mr. Roemer, who switched to the Republican Party last March, is trying to show that a moderate conservative can draw black votes from the Democrats. And Mr. Duke is openly appealing to whites as the only candidate who would truly protect their interests.
So far, Mr. Duke has avoided explicit attacks on blacks, and he found a new vehicle for making his point without overt racism in the controversy over the confirmation of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
At a campaign rally in the Cajun country of east Louisiana earlier this week Mr. Duke said: "When I saw Clarence Thomas during some of those hearings, my heart went out to him. The forces that tried to destroy his character are the same forces that tried to destroy mine."
Mr. Duke then focused his attack on the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which opposed the Thomas nomination and noted that both Mr. Roemer and Mr. Edwards are "members in good standing." Mr. Duke said: "The N.A.A.C.P. is a far-left organization. The N.A.A.C.P. stands for gun control. I believe in the right of law-abiding citizens to bear arms. I believe in the rights to be judged on your merits and not your race."
Looking blow-dried and freshly scrubbed, the 41-year-old Mr. Duke campaigns in blue jeans and T-shirts or in big-shouldered suits. On his lapel he wears a pin shaped like a fish, an ancient symbol for Christ. He speaks with fervor and sincerity, and there is none of the anger common to the segregationist politicians who were the heroes of his youth.
 
Letting Alone His Past
 No one, not even his opponents in this campaign, has made a major issue of his past associations with the Klan and neo-Nazi groups.
This is a marked contrast to last year's election, when Mr. Duke unsuccessfully tried to unseat Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat. When Mr. Duke showed surprising strength in opinion polls, he was the target of television commercials showing him raising his arm in a Nazi salute at a cross burning several years earlier.
Mr. Duke took 44 percent of the total vote, including about 58 percent of the white vote in that race.
"Voters here know about Duke, and they have made up their minds about his past," said Susan Howell, director of the Survey Research Center at the University of New Orleans. "The other candidates are afraid to attack Duke because they worry about a backlash."
A survey made public by the center earlier this month analyzed the responses of 745 voters to identify those who favored Mr. Duke even if they would not admit it. The researchers found that some 24 percent of the voters surveyed favored Mr. Duke, as against 28 percent for Mr. Edwards and 30 percent for Mr. Roemer. The sampling error in the survey was plus or minus four percentage points.
Several factors have combined to spare Mr. Duke the criticism he faced in 1990.
Various polls suggest that the two constituencies most likely to oppose Mr. Duke have been divided in the three-way race. Black voters have gravitated to Mr. Edwards, while affluent, highly educated whites are loyal to Mr. Roemer.
Also, both Mr. Roemer and Mr. Edwards must consider the possibility that they will be vying for Mr. Duke's constituents if they eliminate him in the first round of voting and face each other in the second. Harsh attacks on him now would prove counterproductive later, aides to both Mr. Edwards and Mr. Roemer said.
Finally, from the start of the campaign Mr. Duke has identified his enemies as outlandish liberals and as nefarious people from out of state. In a half-hour television campaign advertisement that he is broadcasting repeatedly, Mr. Duke pre-empts his potential critics: "They never accuse me of any violence toward minorities. They accuse me only of thought crime; of being politically incorrect; of saying out loud what many say privately."
Mr. Duke reportedly became active with the Klan when he was 16 years old and quit only in 1980. During the 1970's he worked with the National Socialist White People's Party and openly espoused Nazism. From 1980 to 1990 he was president of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, a group he founded and used as a launching platform for his political career. He remains active in the group.
Addressing all-white crowds, Mr. Duke has frequently stated that "this election is about our way of life surviving in Louisiana and across the United States," identifying the principal threat as the "uncontrolled demographic growth of the welfare class."
In Louisiana many people of all races have found their way of life threatened by an economic depression that started with the oil price bust of 1982. Nearly a decade later, in a campaign debate, Mr. Roemer tried to put as bright a face on the current situation as he could by saying, "We've stabilized our free fall."
Mr. Duke's appeal under these circumstances was evident at a rally in the small town of Kaplan in eastern Louisiana this week. "The young voters see Duke as a gladiator," said Kim Verret, a restaurant owner.
At the rally Mr. Duke hammered at his standard themes: testing tenants of public housing for drugs, obliging welfare recipients to work and giving cash payments to welfare mothers who accept implants of long-term contraceptives. The crowd cheered him at every turn.
"You can't fault the other candidates for not attacking Duke," said Lance Hill, executive director of the Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism, a group that has criticized Mr. Duke. "The other candidates are just trying to win elections. Duke is trying to win hearts and minds with the idea of building a racialist political movement, and so every election provides him a platform whether he wins or loses."

HEADLINE: Most Oil Fires Are Out in Kuwait, But Its Environment Is Devastated

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Less than eight months after most of its oil wells were set ablaze by withdrawing Iraqi troops, causing one of the world's great environmental and economic catastrophes, Kuwait has put out most of the fires. Oil-industry officials in the region said this week that all the blazes would be extinguished sometime in November.
More than 700 wells were sabotaged. Yet the speed with which they have been brought under control, and the $1 billion cost so far, have surprised many industry experts. Back in February, most of these experts had predicted that it would take two years and several billion dollars to restore the country's once-thriving oil industry. 
 "As of today, we have only 87 oil wells on fire," a senior Kuwaiti oil executive said in a telephone interview, "and they are being put out at the rate of two to three a day."
Kuwait's Oil Minister, Hamoud Abdullah al-Raqba, told Parliament earlier this week that 28 teams of oilfield firefighting specialists will complete their work well ahead of a Dec. 23 conference of heads of state of the Gulf Cooperation Council, an alliance of Saudi Arabia and five smaller countries on the Arabian peninsula.
Kuwaiti and Saudi officials said they expected Kuwait's oil exports to increase to 550,000 barrels a day by year's end and 1.3 million barrels a day by December 1992. Before it was invaded by Iraq in August 1990, Kuwait pumped two million barrels daily.
Kuwaiti officials estimate the total cost of the Iraqi sabotage to be at least $22 billion, including oil gone to waste and damage to the pipelines, pumps and wellheads in the oilfields.
"The recovery has been much faster than what most people expected and it comes at a time when the world oil markets can use more oil to dampen the rise in oil prices," said Pierre Terzian, editor of Petrostrategies, a Paris-based oil-industry newsletter.
Kuwait's re-emergence on the world market comes at an opportune time for its Government. Oil prices have risen steeply over the last three weeks as companies and consumers around the world begin to stock up for winter. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, led by Saudi Arabia, is pumping all the oil its 13 members can produce but failing to satisfy world demand. This week, prices reached $24 a barrel in the United States, up from less than $22 a barrel only three weeks ago.
The world's oil-supply situation has been aggravated by a steady fall in Soviet production amid the country's political chaos of the last two years. Soviet output has fallen to a little more than 10 million barrels a day this year, down from a high of 12.5 million barrels a day only three years ago.
 
Iraq Mired in Export Dispute
 Another reason why oil prices are rising, experts say, is uncertainty over the resumption of exports by Iraq.
An authorization by the United Nations to allow Iraq to begin exporting oil in order to generate $1.6 billion in income to be used to buy essential food, has yet to take effect as Iraq argues with the United Nations over the terms of lifting the economic and military embargo that has been imposed on the country since its invasion of Kuwait.
"Right now the market is uncertain about what's ahead with regard to Iraqi exports, Soviet exports and what kind of winter we will have," said Gary Ross, president of Petroleum Industry Research Associates, which is based in New York. "Under these circumstances the prices will only climb up."
Despite the accomplishments of the firefighters in Kuwait, officials in the Persian Gulf region said the country still suffers from enormous environmental problems. Among the most serious of these are the vast lakes of oil that have formed in the desert around leaking wells where the fire has been put out but the oil continued to flow.
A senior executive of the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation said there were about 200 such lakes, some of which are more than a mile wide and several feet deep. Altogether, these lakes contain 30 million to 60 million barrels of oil, Kuwaiti experts estimate. The oil is evaporating, leaving behind a thick residue of fuel oil and gas oil, these experts say.
This residue is slowly seeping into the ground, poisoning the desert. There is no precedent for this calamity, so environmental experts can only guess at the extent of the damage to underground water supplies and the soil itself, as well as the hazards to human health.
Another problem is the smoke that continues to pour from the oil wells that are still burning.
Yet Abdelrahman al-Awadi, a former Kuwaiti Cabinet minister who is overseeing the environmental aspects of the oil disaster, said this week that the quality of the air in the country has improved to the point that pollution levels are half of what is considered very hazardous to humans.

HEADLINE: Experts Explore Rise in Mass Murder

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The killing of 22 people at a Texas cafeteria Wednesday is only the latest incident showing a rapid increase in mass murder in the past decade, both in frequency and in the number of victims murdered in individual attacks.
In the view of experts, mass murder is a peculiarly American phenomenon that has grown out of the proliferation of guns in this country, the disintegration of traditional American society and, more recently, the decline in the standard of living in recent years as millions of relatively high-paying jobs have been lost. 
 Of the 10 largest mass murders in American history, in fact, 8 have occured since 1980, according to a widely recognized expert, Dr. James A. Fox of Northeastern University here.
And while mass murderers are part of a larger picture of increasing violence in American society, they also represent a distinctly identifiable subset of murderers, a group whose menacing characteristics are sometimes recognized by neighbors and friends after the crimes occur, but whose explosions into murder cannot be anticipated.
 
Possible Link to Hearings
 In the case of the shootings in Killeen, Tex., several experts said they were intrigued by the possibility that the murders might have been triggered by the killer's reaction to the televised Senate hearings last weekend into Prof. Anita F. Hill's accusations of sexual harrassment against Judge Clarence Thomas. The murderer, George J. Hennard, evidently harbored a strong dislike for women.
Dr. Fox, defines mass murder as the killing of four or more people, said there were now an average of two mass murders a month in this country. Most are in Texas, California and Florida, heavily populated states with a large influx of migrants searching for new jobs or families after disappointments or frustrations elsewhere.
It is this kind of unhappy, angry people, almost always middle-aged white men in their 30's or 40's, who are most likely to become mass murderers, said Dr. Fox, the dean of the College of Criminal Justice at Northeastern and a co-author of "Mass Murder," (Plenum Publishing, 1985) widely considered the most authoritative study of this type of crime.
Typically mass murderers are men with no previous criminal record or history of mental illness, said Dr. Marvin E. Wolfgang, professor of criminology and law at the University of Pennsylvania, and their killings "are not really planned."
 
'Inability to Predict'
 Like Mr. Hennard, they may be rude to their neighbors and have occasional outbursts that frighten people, but that is true of thousands of people around the country and offers no clue that they will become mass murderers, added Dr. Fox.
"What is really striking is our complete inability to predict this kind of violence," said Deborah Denno, a criminologist and an associate professor of law at Fordham University.
What seems to happen with men who become mass murderers, Dr. Fox said, is that after a prolonged period of being lonely, frustrated and filled with rage, "There is some precipitating event, often a catastrophe in their lives," which drives them over the edge. It may be getting divorced or losing their jobs, Dr. Fox said.
In Mr. Hennard's case, one factor might have been that he was disconsolate about having been stripped of his license as a merchant seaman after being found with marijuana.
But, neighbors say, Mr. Hennard also exhibited a hatred for at least some women, which showed up in a letter he wrote to two women referring to "those mostly white treacherous female vipers" who "tried to destroy me and my family."
In Dr. Fox's view, "It's possible the Senate hearings stirred up his anger at women.
Neil Semelser, a professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley, agreed. "The Thomas hearings could have been a precipitating factor," he said. "It could have been the last straw for him."
Park Dietz, a consulting psychiatrist and criminologist in Newport Beach, Calif., who has studied mass killers, saw a different connection to the media. Dr. Dietz said he believed that "mass murderers acquire their fantasies from media accounts" of other mass murder cases. Hence he asserts that the "way to turn this thing off is by greatly reducing media coverage."
But any broad conclusion about mass murder is dangerous, because such murders occur rarely and the killers usually die in the incident, said James Q. Wilson, a professor of management and public policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. Consequently, "Medical and social science have not caught up with mass murder," he said.
But there is no question among the specialists that mass murders have become bloodier. "A lot can be traced to the increase in firepower, with more and faster automatic and semiautomatic weapons," said Dr. Fox. "It's hard to kill 22 people with a knife."
Homicide rates in America have long been the highest in the world. In 1988, for example, there were 8.4 murders in the United States for every 100,000 residents, according to the Department of Justice. But figures compiled by Interpol show there were only 4.2 per 100,000 in Germany, 1.97 in Great Britain and 1.2 in Japan, which has the strictest gun control laws in the world.
 
Societal Changes Cited
 Jack Levin, a professor of sociology at Northeastern and co-author of "Mass Murder," said the growth of mass killings reflected a breakdown in American society and the economy. "A lot more middle-aged males feel life has passed them by," Mr. Levin said. "They have lost their jobs or been divorced. The support systems that used to be there are disintegrating, like the family and the church."
This is especially true, Mr. Levin said, for some of the millions of people who have picked up in mid-life and moved. "They get there and if they lose their job there, they really have no one to turn to," he said.
All the images of violence on television have also contributed to the prevelance of mass murders, he said, "by desensitizing us to violence."
Mr. Levin also said he believed that mass murderers have been encouraged by "the growing culture of hate in the United States."
He said the lyrics of some songs, the increasingly violent nature of pornography and the rising incidence of racially motivated crimes show that "hatred has become hip." Mass murderers are spurred by this, he said, because they themselves are filled with hatred and their killings are a way to avenge themselves on people or groups they feel have hurt them.
The killing of five schoolchildren and the wounding of 30 others, many of them Southeast Asian refugees, in Stockton, California in 1989 was an example of this kind of hate crime, he said.
"For mass murderers, the more people they kill, the sweeter the revenge," Mr. Levin said.
