PUB-DATE: October 19, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1958 words

HEADLINE: Arabs And Israelis Invited to Begin Peace Talks Oct. 30 With Bush and
Gorbachev

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union issued invitations today to Israel, its Arab neighbors and the Palestinians for a Middle East peace conference to convene on Oct. 30 in Madrid.
 Although the parties to the negotiations have yet to formally accept, Washington and Moscow were so confident that the conference would take place that they announced that President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would be present to begin the first phase of the peace effort, in which the sponsors and the principal parties will sit down together. 
This mostly ceremonial phase is intended to lead in several days to direct talks between Israel and Syria, Israel and Lebanon, and Israel and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation.
 
Goal: A Lasting Accord
 Egypt, its other neighbor, signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979.
 Mr. Bush said in a statement from the White House that the goal of the conference will be "nothing less than a just, lasting and comprehensive settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict."
 Today's announcement of the time and place for the conference was made by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Boris D. Pankin of the Soviet Union at a joint news conference here. [Excerpts, page 5.]
 Mr. Pankin came to Israel not only to issue the invitations, but also to re-establish full diplomatic relations with this country, bringing to an end a quarter-century of estrangement that was often marked by bitter hostility. An ambassador is to be named later.
 
A Mark of Success
 The announcements were the climax of a week of intense diplomacy by Mr. Baker in the region. Ever since the end of the Persian Gulf war in February, the United States has been promoting this conference -- the first such broad-based approach since a Mideast conference in Geneva in December 1973.
 This conference, in addition to pursuing the broad objective of achieving peace between Israel and its neighbors, will try to work out the final disposition of the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians.
 American officials, while saying that they expected the conference to begin as scheduled and that all those invited have given positive signals in that direction, stressed that there are issues still outstanding that could derail the talks -- including which Palestinians will take part and how the second phase of direct, one-on-one negotiations will be conducted.
 The parties have until 6 P.M. Eastern time on Wednesday to officially respond to the invitations, which were conveyed today by the American and Soviet envoys to the Governments of Israel, Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Lebanon, and by the American and Soviet Consuls in Jerusalem to Faisal al-Husseini, a Palestinian leader in the occupied territories. The European Community will also be represented, and the United Nations and the Gulf Coordination Council will be asked to send observers.
"We have witnessed new beginnings in other parts of the world," said Mr. Baker, who made eight trips to the Mideast since the end of the gulf war to arrange the conference. "The negotiating process we are seeking to launch with this invitation holds the hope of a new era in the Middle East. This invitation offers the peoples in the region a pathway to ending an era of confrontation and it offers a basis for a new future."
 He continued: "The road to peace will not be simple. To the contrary, it will be extremely difficult with many problems, many hitches and probably many interruptions along the way. Old suspicions will not disappear quickly. The gaps are real and the gaps will not be easily overcome." Last-Minute Accommodations
 The decision to issue the invitations today came after Mr. Baker met with Palestinians in East Jerusalem and was told that they are prepared to send representatives to the conference who will satisfy Israel's insistence that they not be formal members of the Palestine Liberation Organization or residents of Israeli-absorbed East Jerusalem. When Mr. Baker communicated that to Prime Minster Yitzhak Shamir, the Israeli leader indicated that he would recommend to his Cabinet that it approve Israel's participation when it meets on Sunday.
 "Israel will participate in the peace conference when and if it takes place," Mr. Shamir said tonight. "Without negotiations it can never attain peace. This is the first time that we have an opportunity to negotiate as we have wanted to -- direct negotiations, without a mediator, face-to-face, without preconditions -- with our Arab neighbors. I don't know what the results will be. In any case, I think I will recommend to the Government to choose this way because I don't see a better alternative."
 None of the principals is completely pleased with all aspects of the conference, but Washington decided to issue the invitations now in hopes that no one will dare stay away, even if the terms are not 100 percent satisfactory.
 
A Chance Not to Be Missed
 "We just thought if we don't make it happen in October, it very likely won't happen, this being the Middle East," a senior American official said.
 According to the invitations, the conference will be opened by Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev. The opening session is expected to last three days and will involve speeches by the two Presidents, Mr. Baker and Mr. Pankin, the six Mideast participants and the representative of the European Community. Observers from the Saudi-led Gulf Cooperation Council and the United Nations will also be present, but will not address the session.
 The ceremonial opening session, in which the participants will be represented by foreign ministers, is not supposed to involve any substantive negotiations. It is intended solely to pave the way for two parallel tracks of negotiations.
 One track will be the direct talks for the purpose of effecting "real peace" between adversaries, the invitation says. Israel wanted the invitation to say "peace treaties," not just "real peace," but the Syrians rejected that wording and notion. These direct negotiations, the invitation says, should follow "immediately" after the last day of the opening session.
 
Meeting Places as Symbols
 There is a serious dispute between Israel and Syria over where the direct talks will be held. Syria prefers them to be held in the same city as the opening session, because then it can argue that they are still taking place under the umbrella of the superpowers and the United Nations observer.
 The Israelis insist that these talks be held in a separate city, to underscore their one-on-one nature. The Israelis suggested that talks with Syria, for instance, could be held one day in Tiberias, in northern Israel, and one day on the Syrian side of the border.
 
Madrid Offered for Talks
 The Americans and Soviets are inclined to have the first one-on-one talks in Madrid for purely logistical purposes and so as not to lose momentum.
 Another potentially serious and unresolved problem relates to the Palestinian representatives. Early this morning, the Central Council of the Palestine Liberation Organization, meeting in Tunis, announced that it had approved Palestinian participation in the talks. Hours later, Mr. Baker met with a group of nine Palestinians from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, with whom he has been negotiating, for the purpose of receiving from them the names of the Palestinians who will represent them in the joint delegation with Jordan.
 While the Palestinians chafed at the conditions imposed by the Israelis, they ultimately accepted them and presented Mr. Baker with the names of seven Palestinians who fit the criteria. Mr. Baker left the meeting and told reporters that he had the names of Palestinian representatives and that his experts said they fit the guidelines. He went into talks with Mr. Shamir on that basis.
 But American officials said that this afternoon the Palestinians informed Mr. Baker that the names he was given were only examples of the sort of Palestinians who might be involved, and not necessarily those who will be involved.
The problem, the officials said, is not that the P.L.O. in Tunis is trying to force unacceptable names onto the list, but that the representatives of the West Bank and Gaza cannot decide among themselves who should be on the delegation.
 Mr. Baker said that he had not shown Mr. Shamir any names, but the Israelis say they know who is being suggested and can live with those names that they have seen so far.
 What the Israelis are more worried about is how high a profile the P.L.O. will assume in directing the Palestinian delegation that comes to Madrid. After receiving his formal invitation, Mr. Husseini said: "We are happy that there is going to be a peace conference. Madrid is a historic city and it is close to us. It is also convenient because it has an office of the P.L.O. there."
 According to the invitation, the talks between the Israeli and Palestinian-Jordanian delegations will initially be about interim self-rule for the Palestinians in the occupied territories. Over Israel's objections, the United States and Soviet Union have committed themselves in the invitation to trying to see that those negotiations are wrapped up in one year. In the third year of self-rule, a condition that is to last five years in total, talks are to begin about the final status of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
 A third outstanding issue has to do with negotiations between all the principal parties to the conference and the six Arab gulf states -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman and the United Arab Emirates. Those talks are supposed to be about regional problems like water rights, arms control and economic development, and were intended to underscore to the Israelis that if they do cede land for peace, they can really have reconciliation with the larger Arab and Muslim worlds.
 But Syria is refusing to attend that broad-based conference and is calling on all other Arabs not to attend until Israel first agrees to give up the Golan Heights, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The Israelis have complained bitterly to Mr. Baker about that but have not used it as an excuse to stay away.
 "The Syrian position is completely negative and does not promise success," Mr. Shamir said. "But still we decided to go to these negotiations. If the negotiations with the Syrians do not succeed, everyone will know whose fault it was."
 The United States accompanied its invitations to Syria, Jordan, Israel, Lebanon and the Palestinians with letters of assurance about the terms and conditions of the conference and basic American policies.
 A key line in the letters to the Arabs is that the United States and the Soviet Union promise to be the "driving forces" behind the negotiations, which means that while they will not be in the room when the one-on-one talks take place, but will be on the sidelines ready to offer ideas and initiatives of their own as "honest brokers." Arab officials expect the two-way negotiations to quickly stall and want the Americans to come in with compromise proposals.
 In that regard, Mr. Baker signaled at his news conference today that the United States stands by its earlier proposal that Israel suspend its settlement-building in the West Bank and Gaza Strip in exchange for the Arabs' suspending their economic boycott of Israel.
 For the first time, he said that "some consideration might be given" to adding into that package deal the Palestinians' formally suspending their nearly four-year-long uprising in the occupied territories. That might make it more attractive for Israel, which rejected the earlier American proposal.

PUB-DATE: October 20, 1991

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2975 words

HEADLINE: What Became of The Democrats?

BYLINE: By David Oshinsky; David Oshinsky, a professor of history at Rutgers University, is completing a book on race, criminality and punishment in the American South.

 BODY:

CHAIN REACTION
The Impact of Race, Rights, and Taxes
on American Politics.
By Thomas Byrne Edsall with Mary D. Edsall.
339 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton. $22.95.  
 Less than three decades ago, President Lyndon B. Johnson defeated his Republican opponent, Senator Barry Goldwater, so convincingly that some pundits mourned the loss of two-party politics in the United States. Since that time, of course, an astonishing reversal has occurred. Republicans have won five out of the six Presidential elections. In two of them, the Democratic candidate received almost no electoral votes. In the most recent one, in 1988, he squandered an apparently insurmountable lead of 17 percentage points in the public opinion polls. As 1992 approaches, the list of Democratic Presidential contenders is pitifully thin, and the party itself is in trouble. Another Republican victory seems assured.
Who is responsible for this turnabout? In "Chain Reaction," a remarkably candid and insightful account of the Democrats' steady decline, Thomas B. Edsall, a political reporter for The Washington Post, with his wife, Mary D. Edsall, focuses on two major groups. The first includes members of the party's reform wing, the well-educated, often intolerant George McGovern activists, who gained control of the Presidential nominating process in the early 1970's -- and powerfully influence it today. Far more liberal than the traditional Democratic voter on virtually every issue, these people, according to the Edsalls, have alienated core Democratic constituencies (including the culturally conservative white working class); squelched a desperately needed debate on the issues of black poverty, joblessness, family structure and welfare dependency (by labeling opposing views as racist); and repeatedly forced their national candidates into the suicidal position of defending minority rights against majority values. Scorning political compromise, dead certain of their mission, they seem impervious to the lessons of defeat.
The Edsalls' second group includes the present Democratic members of Congress. They are found to be devoid of creative proposals and unwilling to act boldly, clinging to power by milking a corrupt system of campaign finance that further diminishes the prospect of independent thought. As a result, their control of the legislative branch adds little to a party in clear need of fresh faces, new directions and original ideas.
Historically speaking, the "new" Democratic Party was conceived at the national convention of 1972. Before that, say the Edsalls, "Democratic presidential delegates were only slightly more liberal than the public at large . . . while Republican delegates were considerably more conservative than the electorate. Delegates to the 1972 Democratic convention, however, were significantly farther to the political left of the electorate . . . than the GOP delegates that year were to the right."
The Edsalls maintain that these Democratic delegates were deeply committed to a "rights revolution" that went far beyond anything the party had advocated before. Besides proposing a major redistribution of political power and cultural authority in the United States, they embraced the causes of numerous "outcast groups," such as homosexuals, drug addicts and the urban poor. Indeed, "at a time when crime was rising at an unprecedented rate," the Edsalls write, "the Democratic platform devoted more attention to the restoration of constitutional rights to released convicts than to efforts to combat street violence."
The Democrats took a terrible beating that year. Their Presidential candidate, Senator McGovern, lost by nearly 18 million votes. But the memory of his debacle was quickly erased by Jimmy Carter's improbable victory in 1976. The Edsalls argue persuasively that Democratic leaders misread the significance of that win. Instead of viewing it in pragmatic terms, as a natural reaction to the Watergate scandals, they saw it in ideological terms, as a ringing endorsement of their new social agenda.
This interpretation was disastrous, for it allowed the party leaders to ignore the burdens of their divisive agenda upon the core of their constituency -- working-class and middle-class whites. They seemed oblivious to the fact that prescriptions for racial equality such as affirmative action involved zero-sum solutions in which one group gained at the expense of another. And they did not foresee that their emphasis on the rights of the excluded would leave them vulnerable to charges of being "soft" on everything from crime to drugs to "deviant" sexual behavior.
Then -- in 1978 -- the economy began to collapse. Unemployment, inflation, runaway interest rates, industrial stagnation -- all came together at once to pose big problems for the Democratic Party, which relied on sustained growth as a way of providing special benefits to the poor. A backlash was inevitable. For the first time in decades, the Edsalls say, traditional Democrats questioned the party's ability to protect their jobs, their homes, their futures. And they fumed at the favoritism shown to "special interests" at a time when nearly everyone's standard of living was falling. "Fairness" became a paramount issue. By 1980, the Edsalls write, many white voters mistrusted the Democratic Party's capacity "to administer improvements in medical care, education, and other domestic programs . . . without distributing benefits most heavily to blacks and to the very poor."
Ronald Reagan and the Republicans played brilliantly upon these themes. Their aim, the Edsalls contend, was to "break the underlying class basis" of the Democratic coalition by persuading white voters that the party of Franklin D. Roosevelt no longer represented their basic interests. Time and again Mr. Reagan laid out competing visions of the United States: one of hard work and equal opportunity (Republican); the other of welfare dependency and special breaks for undeserving minorities (Democratic). After years of defensiveness on the race issue, a Republican Presidential candidate captured the moral high ground by portraying himself as a cultural populist, preaching an egalitarian sermon against the purveyors of "reverse discrimination" and other such evils.
Or so it appeared. In reality, the Edsalls explain, Republican strategists had put a new spin on an old technique: the politics of resentment. Already light-years ahead of the cash-starved Democrats in terms of campaign technology -- polling, fund raising and advertising -- they carefully reinforced the growing conviction among white working-class voters that their real enemies were no longer big business and the very rich, but rather big government and the very poor. Republican candidates hammered at the Federal courts and the Federal bureaucracy for threatening jobs (affirmative action), neighborhoods (open housing) and the local control of schools (busing).
At the same time, they attacked Federal spending selectively by differentiating between popular, race-neutral programs such as Social Security and vulnerable, race-freighted programs like Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Their objective, quite simply, was to shift the voter's attention from what the Government once gave to what it now took away.
The strategy worked well. With Mr. Reagan as the link, the Edsalls say, "Working-class whites and corporate CEO's . . . found common ideological ground in their shared hostility to expanding government intervention; these former antagonists joined forces across traditional class lines to form the core of a center-right majority that survived past election day to become a driving force in support of conservative policy retrenchment."
It was, however, a coalition of remarkably unequal members. When Mr. Reagan declared in 1983 that he wanted the United States to remain "above all . . . a country where someone can always get rich," that someone was invariably a Donald Trump or a T. Boone Pickens, not an assembly line worker from Akron or Detroit. As it turned out, the President's "just folks" persona masked a huge bias in favor of those at the very top. Indeed, the Edsalls point out that the policies of the Reagan Administration regarding taxes, wages, unions, banking and antitrust produced one of the most dramatic redistributions of wealth in our nation's history.
"In terms of income alone," they write, "those at the high end of the distribution experienced huge gains during the decade of the 1980s, as the top one percent saw average family income grow by 75 percent, from $313,206 in 1980 to $548,970 in 1990 (both figures in 1990 dollars); while all those families falling in the bottom 90 percent saw average income grow by just 7 percent, from $27,451 to $29,334." Not surprisingly, the lower one went on the income scale, the worse things became. Families in the bottom 10 percent saw their average income decline during the 1980's, from $4,791 to $4,295.
In theory, at least, this coddling of the mega-rich should have created serious problems for the Republican Party. But such was not the case. The Democrats could not capitalize on the issue because the average voter had lost faith in their ability to manage the economy. Throughout most of the 1980's, opinion polls showed a growing public confidence in the Republican Party's handling of economic issues -- a dramatic shift from earlier days. For the majority of Americans, the modest gains made under Ronald Reagan seemed a lot better than the painful losses suffered under Jimmy Carter. At least most families, the Edsalls say, were inching ahead.
In addition, the Democrats appeared more vulnerable than ever on the key issues of race, taxes and values. Their Presidential candidate in 1984, Walter Mondale of Minnesota, was a political moderate. In order to win the nomination, however, he embraced much of his party's social agenda. As a result, he struck many voters as both an opportunist and a pawn of liberal special-interest groups. At best, Mr. Mondale seemed oddly unaware of how much his support for obviously unpopular issues like affirmative action and a Federal tax hike would cost him at the polls. And part of the reason for this, the Edsalls suggest, is that he and his advisers relied "almost entirely on the distorted information gained from campaigning among liberal primary and party activist constituencies." By catering to these groups, the Edsalls believe, Mr. Mondale assured himself of an easy victory at the Democratic National Convention and a humiliating defeat in the November election.
Still, in the 1988 Presidential campaign there was reason for the Democrats to hope. George Bush, the Republican candidate, had none of Mr. Reagan's charisma. He was way behind in the early public opinion polls, and bogged down by nagging questions about Republican corruption and the Iran-contra scandal. The Bush game plan, as mapped out by his campaign strategist, Lee Atwater, was to take the offensive, portraying the Democratic candidate, Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, as an elite Eastern liberal, lacking in good sense and contemptuous of American values. As Atwater put it: "I'm going to scrape the bark off that little bastard."
He did just that. The Edsalls describe the process perfectly: "Facing off against Dukakis, who was a committed reform Democrat, a liberal lawyer, a card-carrying member of the American Civil Liberties Union, a Harvard Law School graduate, an early civil rights activist, a governor who had vetoed a bill mandating the Pledge of Allegiance, and a Greek ethnic with a Jewish wife, the Bush campaign used the American flag, Willie Horton, the ACLU, the death penalty, the Pledge of Allegiance, and a dramatic emphasis on no new taxes ('read my lips') to drive a wedge right into the heart of the Democrats' 17-point advantage."
The most emotional of these issues, by far, involved Willie Horton, a black prisoner from Massachusetts who was featured in numerous Republican television commercials and speeches throughout the Presidential campaign. Convicted of first-degree murder in the early 1970's, Mr. Horton shortly thereafter had received the first of 10 weekend furloughs under a state program supported by the sitting Republican Governor. But even at the start, the program -- and its safeguards -- raised concerns. In 1976 the state legislature passed a bill that would have ended the furloughs of first-degree murderers. Governor Dukakis, as the Edsalls point out, vetoed it. A strong advocate of prisoners' rights, he contended that the bill would "cut the heart out of efforts at inmate rehabilitation."
A decade later, during Mr. Dukakis's second term in office, Mr. Horton took his 10th weekend furlough and did not return. He was captured eight months later in Maryland, after raping a woman and beating her fiance. He was tried there, found guilty and sentenced to life in prison. The presiding judge refused to return him to Massachusetts. "I'm not prepared to take the chance that Mr. Horton might again be furloughed or otherwise released," he said. "This man should never draw a breath of free air again."
In Boston, meanwhile, the Dukakis administration grimly circled the wagons. The Governor himself, the Edsalls say, did not contact -- much less apologize to -- Mr. Horton's victims. His aides defended the furlough program while refusing newspaper requests to examine the records of Mr. Horton and other furloughed prisoners. "Don't forget that Mr. Horton had nine previous successful furloughs," an obtuse state official told the press.
Atwater could hardly believe his good luck. The Willie Horton incident had everything he needed: a black rapist, a white victim and a bleeding-heart Democrat to blame. The timing, too, was perfect, for it played against a background of skyrocketing crime rates in the cities. The Edsalls correctly view the Willie Horton advertisements as racist trash, exploiting the worst emotions of an angry and frightened electorate. But the Willie Horton case was another matter. At the very least, it raised serious concerns about "the consequences of an aggressively expansive liberalism, a liberalism running up against public opinion, against 'traditional' values, and, to a certain degree, against common sense."
"Chain Reaction" should be read by anyone with an interest in American politics, but it should be required reading for Democratic leaders who dream of someday winning another national election. The Edsalls have brilliantly illuminated the party's mistakes and its problems.
It is unfair, perhaps, to ask them for more. Nevertheless, one does wonder what they have to offer in the way of concrete solutions. The Democrats must begin an honest (and long overdue) debate on the causes of poverty, crime and dislocation among the black underclass. But we never learn where the Edsalls stand on these matters, or what they personally would add to that debate.
The same thing can be said about their concerns for the alienated white voter. It is certainly true that the activist liberal agenda has badly split the Democratic Party. It is also true that Democratic leaders have not done enough to address the anger felt by many whites over the alleged favoritism shown to disadvantaged minorities. But once again, the question arises: what, exactly, would the Edsalls have the Democrats do? If programs like affirmative action cause more trouble than they are worth, then what, if anything, should be substituted in their place?
Until some answers are found, the Democrats will have trouble rebuilding their old majority coalition. In the United States today, race -- not class -- dominates the domestic political agenda. And the price for the once-proud Democratic Party, as the Edsalls so superbly demonstrate, has been division, desertion and defeat.
 
 
 
SOLUTIONS ARE NOT IN SIGHT
 The Democratic Party is in trouble. Thomas Byrne Edsall, a national political writer for The Washington Post, once thought the problem lay in the steep downward slide of the United States economy in the late 1970's, and the blame that many voters placed on the Carter Administration. That was his first book, "The New Politics of Inequality."
Now, in his second book, "Chain Reaction: The Impact of Race, Rights, and Taxes on American Politics," Mr. Edsall and his wife, Mary D. Edsall, a short-story writer, have described a vastly more complex web of causes.
"All the current Democratic candidates are struggling to come up with solutions," Mr. Edsall said in a recent telephone interview. But he shied away abruptly when asked which candidate seemed closest to the answers.
Mr. Edsall is not optimistic that any candidate will succeed before Nov. 3, 1992, Election Day. On the key issue of race, for instance, he said that the Democrats have avoided a genuine debate. Civil rights policies have been set by the courts, "without a political consensus," he explained, "and it is going to be painful and difficult to meet the civil rights agenda in political terms because there is not anything like a consensus.
"Congress is now debating in very arcane terms the civil rights bill of 1991, arguing whether it will be a 'quota bill.' But Congress should open a full debate on the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and how the courts and the regulatory agencies have met the terms of that act. How equitable are the civil rights laws? The serious question is the question of fairness."
What makes the Democrats' problem even more difficult, Mr. Edsall added, is an accelerating demographic change of major proportions. "For the first time," he said, "the majority of voters will live in the [traditionally Republican] suburbs, which have become isolated politically from the urban areas." -- BARTH HEALEY

HEADLINE: Near Paris, Disney's Next Park

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING; ALAN RIDING is chief of the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
THE magic wand has not yet been waved, and cranes, earth-movers, 10,000 workers and a host of unfinished buildings and attractions testify to how much has still to be done. Yet, rising out of the French countryside like a strange lost city, Euro Disneyland has already taken on the shape of things to come.
And everything is on schedule to implant that most American of dreamworlds into the European psyche when the fun officially begins at 9:01 A.M. next April 12. For the moment, though, promotion is the order of the day. So last weekend, the Walt Disney Company overcame its penchant for secrecy and invited the press for a sneak preview. Mickey Mouse and his accomplices were of course on hand, Sleeping Beauty's Castle was unveiled and 3,000 employees, many in costume and all trained to smile, bombarded visitors with "Howdy," "Bonjour" and "Buenos dias." 
 A good many employees and guests took along their children.As the brass band t led Disney characters through a storm of balloons and confetti along Main Street, U.S.A., little faces lighted up, prefiguring the excitement that awaits the millions of girls and boys who will visit Euro Disney in the coming years.
The real purpose of the occasion, though, was to show how much has been built. Just four years after the Walt Disney Company won France's approval for construction of Euro Disney on a 5,000-acre plot at Marne-la-Vallee, 20 miles east of Paris, it can boast that 90 percent of the $4.4 billion initial project is finished. To give an idea of the scale, Euro Disney ranks second to the Channel tunnel as Europe's largest construction project ever.
By next April, the resort and theme park, both improved and adapted versions of those existing in California, Florida and Tokyo, will be ready to receive what company executives project will be 11 million visitors in the first 12 months of operation. By then, Euro Disney will be just a 40-minute ride away from Paris on the R.E.R. suburban rail system. In 1994, France's high-speed T.G.V. trains will also carry visitors directly to the park from all over Western Europe.
Although other sites were studied, the logic of choosing the Paris area for Euro Disney proved overwhelming, not least because, with 26 million tourists a year, the French capital is already Europe's most visited city. Paris's strategic location -- within easy reach of Germany and, once the Channel tunnel opens in 1993, Britain -- made the area still more appealing. Even concern about the weather in northern Europe was eased by evidence that Tokyo's similar climate had not discouraged visitors to its Disneyland.
The more interesting question was whether the French, ever proud of their ancient culture and often disdainful of the American way of having fun, might turn up their noses at Euro Disney. So, to appease intellectual watchdogs, the company promised to emphasize the European roots of many of the fairy tales made popular by Hollywood. But now it seems less worried. After all, to the dismay of local gourmets, the French have embraced American-style fast food. And if things go to plan, the French will account for half the visitors.
The main attraction is, of course, the Magic Kingdom theme park. And since it is a world that no one wants to change, Euro Disneyland is modeled after Disney parks elsewhere, divided into five "lands," packed with 29 attractions and peopled by the likes of Mickey and Minnie, Donald Duck and Daisy, Pluto and Goofy and a host of familiar fantasies. The main departure is the substitution of a Discoveryland, inspired by Jules Verne and Leonardo da Vinci, for the futuristic Tomorrowland. Admission prices are expected to be comparable to other Disney theme parks.
As elsewhere, it is the accompanying resort that makes the entire venture economically feasible. In this case, six hotels with a total of 5,200 rooms are already well advanced, each designed to mirror a different aspect of America. They also range in price to suit every pocket, with small seasonal variations. Indeed, for large families, it might well prove economical to visit Paris from Euro Disney.
The cheapest hotels -- $95 to $130 for rooms with one double and two single beds -- are the Cheyenne, which represents a Far West frontier town, and the Santa Fe, evoking the sun-parched world of New Mexico. The Sequoia Lodge with its echoes of American national forests and the Newport Bay Club with its late 19th-century grandeur are considered middle-priced -- between $130 and $190, also with capacity for four people. All four have about 1,000 rooms each. Finally, the modernistic Hotel New York, with 539 rooms and 36 suites, and the rococo Disneyland Hotel, with 479 rooms and 21 suites, are in the luxury class, charging between $190 and $340 for rooms that can accommodate four people.
Next to an artificial lake that serves as the center of the resort stands Festival Disney, an area of shops, restaurants and discotheques that also includes a theater with room for 1,000 where Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, starring American trick riders, will be put on twice daily. Some distance away, an 18-hole golf course is near completion, with plans to add another 9 holes in 1993. And for those looking to save money, Camp Davy Crockett will offer room for campers as well as mobile homes for rent, with shops and sporting facilities conveniently nearby.
If the Euro Disney Resort offers images and tastes of America, the theme park goes a step further by representing the magical world of Disney that has so shaped the imagination of generations of former children.
Main Street, U.S.A., representing a turn-of-the-century American town, is the first "land." It houses the railroad station for the steam engine that will carry visitors around the roughly circular park as well as a tribute to the Statue of Liberty. And it is here that a brass band will parade regularly with the Disney family. Going clockwise, Frontierland comes next, recreating the old American West, with a steamboat ride around the old river and the Big Thunder Mountain roller coaster and a visit to Phantom Manor for those who enjoy frights.
Adventureland brings alive the world of Caribbean pirates and Arabian nights, with Captain Hook's galleon moored beside a mystery island and the Swiss Family Robinson's tree house standing on another islet. Here, as elsewhere, figures will come to life and speak through what is known as the audio-animatronics process. Fantasyland already has Sleeping Beauty's Castle as its turreted centerpiece, but it will evoke other fairy tales, such as Snow White, Peter Pan, Pinocchio and Alice in Wonderland.
The new Discoveryland looks to the future and, in a special nod to Europe, it includes tributes not only to Leonardo and Verne but also to H. G. Wells, all ofwhom looked to the future in the past. In Le Visionarium, visitors will voyage through time and, on a 360-degree Circle-Vision screen, view the splendors of Europe. A 3-D film, "Captain EO" -- starring Michael Jackson, directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by George Lucas -- will provide the thrills in the Cinemagique. And there will be chances to float in an airship, to pilot a spaceship, to visit an orbital station and to drive a racing car.
For Euro Disneyland, though, the real future lies just six months away. And by then, synthetic "skins" must be wrapped around fantasy mountains, modern roofs must be placed on "ancient" edifices, high-tech attractions must be installed in many buildings, water must fill the numerous lakes and muddy work areas must be covered by cement or lawns. The whole park will now be closed to all outsiders until April 12 so work can rush ahead and the eventual "cast" of 12,000 employees can be hired and trained.
When its doors do open, Euro Disney must also be ready to feed the hungry masses. In this, of course, it has ample experience, but the word is that, aware of local sensibilities, more effort is going into the quality of food in France than in the American parks. The fare, though, will be much the same. The resort hotels will each have one or more restaurants, with American themes emphasized at the Festival Disney entertainment center where there will be a steak house, a diner, a seafood restaurant and a delicatessen. The theme park itself will have some 30 places to eat, variously offering waiter, buffet and counter service and menus ranging from fast food a la hamburger and enchilada to exotic delights at the Explorer's Club and French cuisine at the Auberge de Cendrillon.
As with other Disney parks, the entry fee to Euro Disneyland will give access to all attractions. The fee itself, though, has not yet been set. So-called "commemorative passports" for a one-day visit are being sold at 200 francs ($35) for adults and 150 francs ($26) for children under the age of 10. The company also began taking hotel reservations last March.
But Disney executives hinted they may charge somewhat more for regular admission. They also plan to vary the park's operating hours with the seasons, although they are confident that enough attractions are indoors for cold or wet weather not to discourage visitors.
Indeed, they are so confident of success that they are looking far beyond April 12. For the record, they say they will continue to add to Euro Disney through the year 2017. Already in 1995, Disney plans to open a second theme park, Disney-MGM Studios/Europe, which like the original park in Orlando will evoke the world of cinema and be linked to new movie and television production facilities. After that, an Epcot center is being contemplated and perhaps more hotels. And why not? When it comes to making money out of magic, the Walt Disney Company seems to have a way of turning dreams into reality.
Reservations and information are available from Walt Disney World Central Reservations, Box 10,100, Lake Buena Vista, Fla. 32830-0100; (407) 934-7639; or Euro Disney S.C.A., Central Reservations Office, Box 105 F77777, Marne-la-Vallee, Cedex 4, France; 49.41.49.10 (for English speakers).

Scuba Diving in Belize
Q. I am interested in obtaining information about Belize, with special emphasis on scuba diving. -- Nina Garfinkel, New York, N.Y. 
 A. To some extent, your choice of a way to scuba dive in Belize depends on your own enthusiasm and how much discomfort you are willing to tolerate, or how many amenities you desire. In Belize, an independent Commonwealth nation once known as British Honduras, both packages that offer live-aboard-a-ship arrangements and others based at resorts are offered. One source for either kind of package is See and Sea Travel Service, 50 Francisco Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94133; (415) 434-3400 or (800) 348-9778. For those who wish to stay aboard a ship, the 110-foot Belize Aggressor, which holds 18 people, departs from Belize City every Saturday, and returns the following Saturday. The price, not including air fare, is $1,395 a person. If you prefer to stay at a scuba resort, See and Sea represents three, from 20 to 60 miles offshore, at rates from $1,950 to $1,999 a person. These rates also apply from Saturday to Saturday and do not include air fare. Similar packages are offered by Tropical Adventures, 111 Second North, Seattle, Wash. 98109; telephone (206) 441-3483 or (800) 247-3483.
Another source of information and reservations, but only for single travelers from 25 to 55, is Gallivanting, the Club for Adventure, at 515 East 79th Street, Suite 20F, New York, N.Y. 10021; telephone (212) 988-0617 or (800) 933-9699. Representatives of the Belize Aggressor may also be contacted directly at Post Office Box 9182, Treasure Island, Fla. 33740; telephone (800) 654-3483 or (813) 367-1952. More information, and the names of additional operators, is available from the Belize Tourist Board, 415 Seventh Avenue, 18th floor, New York, N.Y. 10001; telephone (212) 268-8798 or (800) 624-0686.
 
Indians and Amish
 Q. Are there any areas of New York State where Native American and Quaker or Amish working communities (not just museums) can be visited? -- Elizabeth Cuesta, Marlboro, N.Y.
A. A spokeswoman for the Division of Tourism of the New York State Department of Economic Development had no information on working Indian communities that could be visited, but did point out that Salamanca, N.Y., in the western part of the state about 10 miles northwest of Olean, was partly inhabited by Senecas. The town rests on Indian land, the 22,000-acre Allegany Indian Reservation, and is leased from tribe.
A little-known community of about 5,000 Amish is also in western New York State, around Cherry Creek, about an hour and a half's drive south from Buffalo and only 18 miles from Lake Erie. A map for self-guided tours is available at a local restaurant, the Grainery, and either motorcoach tours with a guide or tours with a guide in your own car can be arranged. The three-hour tour with the guide in your car is $45, and lunch or dinner must be taken in the Grainery, which is in a 100-year-old barn. Bus tour rates, for groups, are set by the individual companies; information and reservations from the restaurant: (716) 287-3500.
The Amish in the area are mostly farmers, but there are also shops selling such items as leather belts, wallets, wooden toys and other handmade craft objects. Quilts, pillows and similar household goods are generally sold directly from individual homes.
 
Seeing Flowers in 1992
 Q. Where and when will the next International Flower Expo take place? -- Janice Kelly, Westport, Conn.
A. Two International Horticultural Expositions, as they are formally known, have been sanctioned by the Bureau of International Expositions for next year, according to Michael Italiaander of Expo Garden Tours of New York. One, Floriade, will be held in Zoetermeer, the Netherlands, from April 10 to Oct. 11. The other, Ameriflora, the first such international exposition to be held in the United States, is scheduled for April 20 to Oct. 12 in Columbus, Ohio. At both, numerous countries mount flower exhibits reflecting their native and cultural heritages.
In the Ohio city that bears his name, Columbus will be honored in an exposition with 88 acres of gardens, exhibits, restaurants and performance spaces. Organizers say they are spending $93 million to remake Franklin Park, two miles east of downtown Columbus, for the event. Formal gardens will be created to equal those on several royal European estates. A 3,500-seat amphitheater will be used for jazz, country music and symphonic performances.
More information on the Zoetermeer exposition is available from the Netherlands Tourist Board, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; telephone (212) 370-7360. For information on the Columbus event, contact the Greater Columbus Convention and Visitors Bureau, 10 West Broad Street, Columbus, Ohio 43215, or telephone (800) 282-5393. Expo Garden Tours, 145 Fourth Avenue, Suite 4A, New York, N.Y. 10003, (212) 677-6704, offers travel packages to both expositions. The 14-day one to the Netherlands is $2,650 a person, including hotels, most meals and entrance fees, but not air fare. The similar, seven-day, package for the Columbus exposition is $1,495.
 
Renting a House in Brittany
 Q. We are planning a family trip to France for June and July and would like to rent a house in St.-Servan or St.-Malo on Brittany's northern seacoast. How can we find rental information for this area? -- Ellen J. Kennedy, Edina, Minn.
A. There are several sources for house rentals in Brittany, as well as elsewhere in France, according to the French Government Tourist Office. Among them, RAVE (Rent a Vacation Everywhere) offers rentals in Brittany from about $650 a week to $2,195, depending on the size of the house and the season. (The $2,195 house sleeps 12.) For more information, contact RAVE, 328 Main Street East, Suite 526, Rochester, N.Y. 14604; telephone (716) 454-6440. On the West Coast, Chez Vous has rural cottages as low as $420 a week. Chez Vous is at 220 Redwood Highway, Suite 129, Mill Valley, Calif. 94941; telephone (415) 331-2535. July and August are high season, so the rates then are at the more expensive end of the scale. But since this part of the coast is at the end of the Gulf Stream, the area is relatively mild and green year round. And Mont St.-Michel, the medieval fortress and religious shrine, is only about 20 miles away. The agencies mentioned, and others, also rent houses, from modest cottage to great chateaus, throughout France, as well as apartments in Paris and bed-and-breakfast accommodations in private houses around the country. Information is also available from the French Government Tourist Office, 610 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 757-1125.

HEADLINE: Homeownership -- a Receding Dream

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
YOUNG couples struggling to pay the rent and still save enough for a down payment on a house fell further behind their homeowning parents last year, according to a new study of home costs and ownership rates.
The problem among the young lingered despite the hopes of economists, home builders and uncounted rent-paying nonowners that the recession, lower interest rates and falling prices would make homeownership easier for them. 
 As a result, the population is growing more and more skewed toward homeowners who are white, middle-aged and middle-class, and a renter population that is more and more minority and lower middle class or poor.
This analysis comes from the latest home tenure statistics of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, which was released Wednesday. It saw two distinct trends in America:
"Rapid growth in the number of high-income households has fueled a strong homeowner tradeup and renovation and repair market, while slow income growth at the low end of the distribution has expanded the number of households unable to afford even minimally adequate housing."
The problem, unsurprisingly, can be summed up as one of cost versus income. In the 20 years from 1970 to 1990, the median price of a starter home for a typical married couple between 25 and 29 years old rose by 21 percent in constant dollars, while the income of this typical couple declined by 7 percent, from $28,500 to $26,700, also in constant dollars.
At the same time, the incomes of couples 10 or more years older than this age group stayed even or rose, and this group took advantage of their improving finances to increase their share of homeownership.
So the proportion of all households headed by people aged 25 to 34 years of age who own their own home has dropped, from 51.4 percent in 1973 to 44.3 percent in 1990, while the proportion of people 45 to 64 years old who began climbing the homeownership ladder in the 60's and 70's rose from 75.9 to 78.1 percent, according to the Harvard study.
There is some evidence that couples who were in their early 20's five or so years ago are falling behind those who are that age today, since houses were more expensive, and interest rates higher, in the mid-80's. But the authors of the report cautioned that several more sample years will be needed before it can be shown that people who entered the housing market in the middle of the last decade will remain behind those who came into the market after them.
THE recent period of moderating home prices and a decline in interest rates to their lowest levels in a decade has helped some new households to step on the ladder of homeownership, a ladder that will let them trade up to better and larger homes as they age and their incomes rise.
Real estate brokers and sales people in the New York City region report a buying spurt this summer that was dominated by young, first-time buyers who had decided that prices and mortgage interest rates were unlikely to fall much more.
But according to both the authors of the Harvard study and real estate brokers, lower home prices and interest rates alone are little help to renters who cannot accumulate the 20 percent down payment most mortgages require.
"The challenge today is to help young people come up with the down payment they need," said Dorcas Helfant, president-elect of the National Association of Realtors, the real estate brokers who have a personal interest in seeing more people being able to afford to buy a house. "That's the only way they will be able to take advantage of lower home prices and lower interest rates."
But today's renters will have a harder time saving to buy a house, according to the Harvard study, because declining apartment construction for moderate-income families will mean higher rents, and so less saving.
The trend has implications for generations beyond the present, said Denise DiPasquale, a professor of economics at Harvard University and one of the report's principal authors.
"Homeownership is an important source of wealth accumulation over one's lifetime," she said. "So part of the issue here is that, to the extent that home equity is part of the legacy that can be passed on from generation to generation, increasingly the inability of young renter housheholds to cross the threshold of homeownership will affect not only their own lives, but the lives of their children."
The fact that housing costs have outpaced the ability of many people to pay for them is underscored by the Census Bureau's 1990 Census of Housing, which found the highest homeownership rates in states with the lowest prices, and lower ownership rates where housing is most costly.
So West Virginia ranks first in home ownership in the country, at 74.1 percent of all households, but 47th in median house price, $47,900. Hawaii, conversely, ranks next to last in homeownership rate, at 53.9 percent, and first in median home price, at $245,300.
In last place for homewnership is New York state, at 52.2 percent. But that figure is misleading, pulled down by the 32 percent rate in New York City, where rent regulations and high housing costs make it cheaper for many households to rent than to own. In New Jersey, 64.9 percent of all households own their home; in Connecicut, 65.6 percent.
The national homeownership rate stands at 64.1 percent after having peaked in 1985 at 65.6 percent. But the fairly stable national rate masks the generation gap that is at work.
The rate of homeownership in households headed by someone under 25 years of age has declined steadily since 1973, from 23.4 percent to 15.3 percent in 1990, said the Harvard study, whose figures are based on the Census Bureau's Current Population Survey series.
Each five-year age group between 25 and 45 also shows declines in home ownership, from 44 percent to 36 percent for those 25 to 29, from 73 percent to 70 percent for those aged 40 to 44.
Not until the study reaches those 45 to 54 does it find a group that stayed even, at 76 percent homeownership, and only those above 55 years of age today have been able to increase their group's ownership rate, from 75.7 percent in 1973 to 80.4 percent, the highest rate of any age group.
Why?
"After World War II, we made homeowning much more available to people at a younger age than before, with the V.A. and the F.H.A. and other programs," said William Apgar, associate director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies and another author of the Harvard report. "They were able to start earlier and own their homes longer, and that's where the equity buildup comes from. Now that process is reversing."
EVEN when selected to account for the group most likely to own -- married couples with children -- the figures show younger couples falling behind in homeownership. In 1973, 39 percent of couples under 25 with children owned their own homes; in 1990, the proportion had fallen to 23.6 percent.
The only families with children who improved their homeownership rates were those over 35 today, people who most likely bought their first homes before the price inflation of the late 1970's.
The decline in homeownership has been particularly severe for black families, who started the decade of the 1980's behind the white majority and ended it even worse off. In 1980, 43.8 percent of black households and 68.8 percent of white households owned their homes. By 1990, both rates had slipped, to 42.4 for blacks and 67.5 for whites, but the decline among younger families was sharper.
Thus, white families headed by people under 35 years of age saw their ownership rate drop by 12 percent, from 48 to 42.2 percent, while for blacks, the rate fell 21 percent, from 23.1 to 18.2.
With all this dispiriting news about young familes failing to own their homes, some have wondered if there is not an element of voluntary nonownership at work -- if young couples, in the spirit of the times, are not spending more money on video cameras, cars, vacations and clothes, and indirectly choosing not to save for a home of their own.
Some analysts point to the amount of student debt being carried over from college and graduate school by young couples, noting that banks qualify borrowers for mortgages not only by their income but also by how much they owe.
Carl Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College and an analyst with the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, noted also that homeownership is no longer seen by many as the sure-fire investment it once was. Prices have been on a roller coaster -- up in the early 80's, down at the end of the decade, now perhaps starting up again, he pointed out.
Some economists, meanwhile, forecast that fewer household formations in coming years will mean less price appreciation for those who buy.
"The investment advantages of homeownership have certainly been reduced by the degree of uncertainty raised by these factors, and that has created a lot of background noise that buyers have to take into account," said Mr. Case.
A New York Times poll conducted in June confirmed popular lore that an overwhelming majority of Americans regard homeownership as a sound move. In the poll, 84 percent of 1,600 respondents agreed with the statement, "Buying a home is the best long-term investment in the United States."
Mr. Apgar, at Harvard, agrees that voluntary nonownership is an interesting question, but not at today's ownership rates.
"Some people say that those who want to become owners have already bought their homes," he commented in an interview. "That's O.K. if you have ownership rates of 80 or 90 percent, or if you say that single people don't really want to own a home. But that doesn't cover the married people with children who we know really do want to own and who can't afford it. So you can say people really don't want it, but you also have to look at what people can simply afford."
BEARING in mind that the housing market and incomes vary widely by area, the Harvard study broke the country into four broad regions. It found that in the Northeast, the hardest place for renters to buy, to buy a median-priced starter home for $94,230 means having to have accumulated a 20 percent down payment and meet closing costs of $20,452. To do so requires a minimum annual income of $33,260 .
In the South, by contrast, a starter home sells for $60,111 and closing costs come to $13,046. That, plus a 20 percent down payment, means such a home is within reach of someone with an income of $20,101.
Lowering the down payment requirement -- the solution offered by many housing advocates and by most subsidized mortgage programs run by states -- can also work against affordability. Since lowering the down payment increases the amount that must be borrowed, it also raises the amount of income needed to qualify for the loan, according to the report's analysis.
So, for example, with a 5 percent down payment, the income needed to buy a starter home in the Northeast rises to $39,686, from the $33,260 needed with a 20 percent down payment. In addition, low-down-payment loans usually require the buyer to purchase mortgage insurance, an added cost.
Nor are renters likely to find it any easier to save the down payments needed to qualify for an affordable loan, said Dr. DiPasquale. This is because rents, particularly those paid by moderate-income families, have not moderated with the price of housing in recent years. And they are likely to start rising in the future, since the creation of new rental apartment projects has dropped sharply since the 1986 tax reform act eliminated most of the tax shelters available to those who invested in them.
"A LOT of people point to high vacancy rates as proof that rates won't rise, but much of that vacancy rate is concentrated at the high end of the market," Dr. DiPasquale said. "We are definitely seeing a loss of the rental stock that traditionally serves low- and moderate-income households, those who pay a contract rent of $250 a month or less. That tightening in the market indicates that their rental burdens are high and are going to continue to be high."
Rents that take a high portion of income keep savings low, Dr. DiPasquale noted, "so one of the big points we are making is that, increasingly, the rental market is becoming the market for low- and moderate-income households."
When Ms. Helfant of the National Association of Realtors see studies that show her group's brokers selling to a smaller and smaller share of American households, she begins to think about politics.
"Those of us who are in the real estate business have to make sure we stay active politically, and make sure our legislators understand these homebuying issues," she said in an interview.
She is working to build support right now, for example, for a measure introducted by Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, that would let the parents or grandparents of first-time home buyers lend portions of their Independent Retirement Accounts as a down payment. Currently, the law does not allow such a use of the tax-deferred accounts without a tax penalty for early withdrawal.
"You can invest your I.R.A. in real estate, in a shopping center or an office building, by buying into a mutual fund," she said of the current law, "but God forbid you help your children buy a home of their own."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Communications Landmarks;
New Technology, Old Architecture

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
IF owners and brokers could be entirely believed, you would think every office building in the United States had some "state-of-the-art" feature or other. But the relentless attention to modern amenities ignores the question of what happens to high-technology buildings when the state of the art has advanced by several decades.
Three such structures in lower Manhattan -- richly colored, dramatically detailed, sharply faceted mesas that have dominated their surroundings for six decades -- were given landmark status this month as early exemplars of American Art Deco by Ralph Walker, of Voorhees, Gmelin & Walker. 
 Even more significantly from an economic standpoint, all three remain communication centers, even as they are being adapted to suit modern technology.
The three whose exteriors and first-floor public interiors were designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission are:
*The Barclay-Vesey Building, also known as the New York Telephone Company Building, 140 West Street, between Barclay and Vesey Streets. This was completed in 1927 and is still owned by New York Telephone.
*The Long Distance Building of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, 32 Avenue of the Americas, between Lispenard and Walker Streets. Called the "Tower of Speech," the building in its present form was finished in 1932. It is still owned by A.T.&T.
*The Western Union Building, 60 Hudson Street, between Worth and Thomas Streets. It was finished in 1930.
"One million telegrams will be transmitted to and from it daily," an early promotional brochure declared. "The heart of the nation will throb here." Certainly, the heart of the Western Union Telegraph Company throbbed there. Telegraph and cable lines converged in its basement, as did pneumatic tubes that ran as far as 42d Street. Although there were only 24 stories, the structure had 950,000 square feet -- almost as much as the Chrysler Building. On the ground floor was a large auditorium, with a balcony. On the mezzanine was a gymnasium.
Western Union Telegraph sold the building in 1948 and took a 25-year lease, with a 25-year option. In 1973, headquarters moved to Upper Saddle River, N.J., but the company owned the leasehold until 1980, when it was sold to Robert Carmel, Joseph Comras and Stanley Stahl, who purchased the fee in 1985.
Now a multiple-tenant property known as 60 Hudson Street, the building is managed by the Williams Real Estate Company, which stresses its continuing advantages as a communications hub. "We have all the major telecommunications carriers," said Audrey Novoa, managing director of Williams.
These include MCI Telecommunications Corporation, which has a switching center for the New York metropolitan area, and US Sprint Communications Company, which also has a switching center through which calls in the New York area are routed.
THE building was put up to exploit an underground duct system laid out through New York City, said Kenneth E. Pliska, of Highland Associates, which serves as a kind of resident engineering and architectural firm to 60 Hudson Street.
"With cable penetration via duct and conduit into a large cable vault in the basement, and vertical runs that allow for interconnection -- that was the key for people to come into the building," he said. "A lot of these ducts are now used for fiber optics."
"The fact that the big guys came in really drew smaller people," Mr. Pliska said. "The attraction is interconnection." Underscoring that point, the ceilings seem to be filled with horizontal forests of conduits.
"For some high-level tie-ins, it's nice to be located next to your competitors," explained Jim Farris, director of contract and real property administration at Sprint headquarters in Kansas City. "There are economies of scale that are created by proximity. It's the difference between running cable two floors versus running cable two miles. It also helps from the standpoint of interconnecting with the local telephone company."
Among other tenants are American Airlines; Associated Press; Cable & Wireless Communications; Locate, formerly known as Local Area Telecommunications; Metropolitan Fiber Systems; Micronet; Nycom Information Service; RCI Long Distance; Teleport Communications Group and Williams Telecommunications Group.
Such concentration raises a question of vulnerability, which the management said it has addressed. "The owners have provided a great deal of security: a 24-hour staff, closed-circuit TV, card-access locks," Mr. Pliska said. "At times of great concern, such as when the war was going on, extra security staff was brought on to protect the building."
Besides telecommunications companies, 60 Hudson Street is also a major government hub, thanks to its location near the civic center. Agencies with offices there include the New York State Insurance Department and the New York City Human Resources Administration, Buildings Department, Correction Department and Employment Department. Together, they have about 530,000 square feet.
A spokesman for the buildings agency, Vahe Tiryakian, said that the building's architecture actually lifted employees' morale -- particularly the vaulted, through-block lobby, with golden, patterned brick walls that seem to glow from within.
"I always feel so special walking into that lobby," he said. "I marvel at it. There's a meaningfulness that never wears out. I'm not saying we stand around and gawk at it, but we don't take it for granted."
(Some of the other great spaces in the building have not fared as well as the lobby, which is meticulously maintained. The auditorium is now a Federal Express distribution center but its proscenium arch and balcony are intact, complete with starkly geometric Deco motifs. The gymnasium is empty but still has its wooden floor.)
As to the recent landmark designation, which is still subject to review by the City Council, Mr. Pliska said, "What the ownership has been trying to do is establish a master plan with Landmarks, similar to the one at the Empire State Building."
A master plan might include guidelines for the replacement of windows by ventilating louvers and for the installation of microwave and air-conditioning equipment on setbacks.
Five blocks north, the A.T.&T. building on the Avenue of the Americas is no longer the largest long distance center in the world. But the company uses it for administrative, technical, sales, legal and regulatory offices.
"WE did support the building becoming a landmark," said Laura Abbott, a spokeswoman for A.T.&T. "We believe this is an important building with a rich history. And we are pleased that the city has named it a landmark."
The Barclay-Vesey Building, notable for its ground-floor arcade and its lobby, was designed as headquarters of the New York Telephone Company and served as such until 1972, when the executive offices were moved to 1095 Avenue of the Americas, at 42d Street.
Over the years, the building had been filled with more and more equipment, to keep pace with the development of lower Manhattan.
More recently, however, "a change in technology has dramatically changed the way we use floor space," said Charles Clos, general manager for real estate at New York Telephone. "The new digital switching systems have caused our need for space to diminish precipitously, because the new devices are one-fifth the size of the old devices."
At 140 West Street, he said, the company was "going to take advantage of that transition and put people back in that building." In the next two or three years, much of New York Telephone's engineering department will be moved there. The company, which has itself described the tower as a landmark, did not oppose the designation.
"It's a wonderful opportunity," Mr. Clos said. "I get the space for free. It's a good location for our people. And it fills the building back up. We're going to keep the character of the building -- its facades and entrance foyer -- as it is today, in class and quality, so it continues to be a landmark building."

LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: Candidates Seek to Turn Voter Anger To Advantage

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THIS is the year of the "fed up" candidate in New Jersey's legislative races.
With the recession maintaining its hold on the economy and many voters still upset over Gov. Jim Florio's quick enactment of a $2.8 billion tax program after his election two years ago, many candidates -- including some incumbents -- are trying to appeal to voters by adopting an angry, anti-government posture. 
 There was a time when only challengers ran on slogans like "Clean up the mess in Trenton" and "Stop the waste of taxpayers money." But this year those sentiments are finding their way into the campaign literature of some incumbents who voted for recent state budgets and were in Trenton when the "mess" presumably was created.
The recent redistricting that created many new legislative districts offers another opportunity for incumbents to campaign as newcomers since their names are not familiar to thousands of voters in their new districts. In addition, a few Democrats who voted for the Governor's tax package and also for the subsequent repeal of the sales tax on heavy trucks and paper products are campaigning as tax cutters because of their repeal votes and are ignoring their support of the much larger tax package.
Since no Republicans voted for the Governor's taxes, many Democrats, including the Senate President, John A. Lynch of New Brunswick, have also dropped their party's label from campaign material. And, much to the Governor's dismay, several Democrats are frankly running, or at least inching, away from him. Senator James T. Phillips, Democrat of Old Bridge, campaigns with a life-sized cutout of the Governor, which he dramatically shoves away from himself while challenging his Republican opponent to "push aside Governor Florio as an issue" in the campaign.
But Republicans aren't about to push the Governor aside since they believe Mr. Florio's unpopular tax program is the key to their hopes of taking control of the 40-member State Senate and 80-member General Assembly in the Nov. 5 elections.
Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New Providence, the New Jersey Republican Party chairman, said Democrats were trying to raise "obfuscation" to the level of high art in order to avoid a voter backlash in November.
A recent poll by The Star Ledger in Newark and the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers may have helped to encourage that strategy. The poll said 75 percent of the electorate did not know how their local representatives voted on the tax package. Eight hundred people took part in the telephone poll, which had a sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
To counter this, Mr. Franks said, the Republican campaign strategy is simple, but it must be carried off effectively if the party is to reach its goals. "We have to help the public learn a simple rule of thumb," he said. "Only Democrats voted for the Florio taxes, and every Republican voted against them."
 
Vote Against All Incumbents
 Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and a frequent Republican consultant in statewide elections, said some grass-roots, anti-tax groups formed after the Governor's tax program had been approved are telling their supporters to vote against all incumbents.
"But that won't be easy since many people don't know who their senators and assemblymen are and, if they did, they may have new representatives because of the redistricting," he said. "They don't put asterisks on the ballot next to names of incumbents the way newspapers do when listing the names of candidates."
But they do list the candidates by party, and it will be easy to tell Democrats from Republicans when the time comes to pull the lever in the voting booth, he said.
Richard Roper, executive director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University, said: "This is the era of the fed-up constituency, there's no doubt about that. People feel that their government and government officials aren't serving their interests well. And a candidate who wants to use voter anger to his advantage will have to buy into that view and articulate it well."
 
Disenchantment Across All Levels
 Incumbents who want to run on the record of the last two years have a tough task, he said. "The public is not willing to be convinced that the responses to recent financial problems were the right responses," he said. Mr. Roper added that public disenchantment with the parties in power in the current difficult economic climate cut across all levels of government -- local, state and Federal. "And if people could," he said, "they would like to bring down the leadership at each level, Democrat or Republican."
"What they want is more efficient and effective government, to see government operate in a way that is not wasteful," he said. "They don't want higher taxes and they want to know how the money that is available is being spent."
Cliff Zukin, another professor of political science at Rutgers and former director of the Star Ledger-Eagleton poll, said candidates who campaign as being angry and anti-government would receive only marginal benefit unless their names appeared on the ballot with a slogan identifying them as "fed up."
"People these days don't trust any politician," he said. "Including those who run as fed up."
But aside from the debate over how best to channel voter anger in the closing weeks of the campaign, Republicans appear to have history on their side. Mr. Zukin said a look at State Assembly races in off-years, two years after a gubernatorial election, showed that the party in power lost about half of the Assembly seats it had picked up when the party's candidate for governor was winning.
 
Byrne Gave His Party a Majority
 When former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, a Democrat, won his first term in 1973 in a landslide, he carried in 26 new Assembly members, giving the party a 66-to-14 majority over the Republicans. Two years later, the Democrats lost 17 Assembly seats. In Mr. Byrne's second run in 1977, when his approval rating had dipped in opinion surveys to 35 percent because of enactment of the income tax, he still won re-election by 14 points and Democrats picked up five Assembly seats. But in the off-year election in 1979 the Democrats lost 10 seats to Republicans, although they still retained control of the Assembly by 44 to 36.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean -- who in 1981 defeated Mr. Florio by the slimmest margin in state history, 1,776 votes -- managed to pick up only one Assembly seat, which the Democrats took back two years later. But in 1985, riding the crest of an economic boom and high voter-approval ratings, Mr. Kean won re-election by a wide margin and the Republicans picked up 15 new Assembly seats, enough to give the Republican Party control of the house for the first time since 1971 by a margin of 50 to 30. Two years later, with Mr. Kean's popularity intact, the party still lost eight Assembly seats, but held onto control by a 42-to-38 margin. They lost another seat the next year through the resignation of a Republican lawmaker and the victory of a Democrat in a special election.
In his 1989 victory, Mr. Florio pulled in five new Democratic Assemblymen, enough to give control back to his party. Republicans got one seat back last year through the resignation of a Democratic Assemblyman, who moved up to the Senate, and the victory by a Republican in the special Assembly race. Democrats now hold a 43-to-39 majority in the Assembly and a 23-to-17 edge in the Senate.
 
Independents With Angry Slogans
 Mr. Zukin said past history would indicate that Republicans should pick up a couple of Assembly seats in this off-year election, when about 500,000 fewer voters usually go to the polls than in gubernatorial years.
And if angry-sounding slogans might be a plus, then independent candidates, who do not have party labels to identify them and who can run under any banner, might attract more votes this year. Voters in some districts will see a number of challenging slogans when they enter the booth, including, "No Party Deals"; "Truth in Government"; "Non Lawyer"; "I Represent You"; "Accountable Independent"; "Sound Fiscal Policies"; "Coalition of One"; "The People's Voice"; "Citizen Not Politician"; "Reduce Insurance Rates"; "Middle Class Alternative"; "Unbossed, Unbiased, Unbought"; "Taxpayers' Only Choice," and a perennial, "Politicians Are Crooks."
But Neil J. O'Connell of Jackson Township, a Democrat running for the Senate in the newly created 30th District, probably tried to cover the field in his appeal for support. His campaign slogan: "We Are ALL Fed Up!"
