HEADLINE: Forum to Air Sexual Bias in Courts

BYLINE: By Tessa Melvin

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
TERMING the issue of sexual harassment "just the tip of the iceberg," Justice Samuel G. Fredman of State Supreme Court has announced that the Westchester court system will consider that subject and related matters at a public forum this week.
After nearly a year of planning, the Committee to Promote General Fairness in the Courts has scheduled the forum for Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. in the Ceremonial Courtroom of the Courthouse, at 111 Grove Street in White Plains. 
 Calling the timing "exquisite," Justice Fredman said the discussion should appeal not only to the legal community but also to Westchester residents, many of whom spent last week debating issues raised during the Washinton hearings on the nomination of Judge Clarence Thomas to the United States Supreme Court.
 Justice Fredman said that the county's court system provided numerous examples of sexual harassment. "I know from being there," he said. "Women aren't satisfied by the court, and they feel an undercurrent of unfairness by male judges."
 
New Ways to Handle Complaints
 "We hear of lawyers mistreating women opponents and using foul language," said Justice Fredman, who serves on the bench in the Ninth Judicial District in White Plains. "But I am not sure today if every judge in our court system is conscious of harassment. Most men don't know what they are doing, and most don't know what women are complaining about."
The forum will consider a new method for hearing and resolving complaints of sexual discrimination in the county court system, and the committee will announce plans for a hearing day in December.
The 29-member committee, made up of 13 judges plus an array of lawyers, academicians and laymen from the five-county judicial district, has been meeting regularly since August last year. It is working with the cooperation of the Ninth Judicial District's grievance committee and the bar associations of the five counties.
The program will include an original skit, "Court Time," by four students at Brown University. The performers have subtitled the play "An Awareness Act Performance About Gender Fairness in the Courts." The revue is a "sometimes tongue-in-cheek, always satiricial work," which has been performed on numerous college campuses, according to the committee.
 
Taking the Show on the Road
 "It's too good for college campuses," said Justice Fredman, the public relations chairman of the group, whoadded that the committee planned to tape the performance "so we can take this show on the road." The committee is planning forums on sexual harassment in the other four counties of the Ninth Judicial District in the next two months.
"This is something whose time has come," Justice Fredman said. "Women feel they don't get the best lawyers" in matrimonial cases, he said, giving an example, "certainly not in comparison with their husbands, who usually have far stronger economic backing."
Female lawyers also have reason to be concerned, Judge Fredman said. "I don't feel they think they get a fair deal from male judges, of which there are a plethora. There are certainly cases of judges who call them girlie or little girl."
The impetus for forming the committee, he said, came from "an active women's bar association," led by Justice Sondra M. Miller, the only woman on the Ninth Judicial bench. "Sondra is the mother superior of this group," Judge Fredman said.
The event is free and will include a question-and-answer session.

HEADLINE: Why E.D.S. Loves a Recession

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
When the Electronic Data Systems Corporation acquired the Enron Corporation's extensive computing staff and equipment in 1989, it essentially guaranteed that it could handle these operations better. It also promised Enron a savings of $200 million over the 10-year life of the contract. The daring pledge underscored E.D.S.'s cocksureness about its ability to squeeze computing costs.
But its confidence was well placed. The Houston-based natural gas company thinks it is on its way to saving at least that much, equal to 20 percent of its computing expenses, by 1999. "We're out of the how-to-do-it part of the computing business," said Jack I. Tompkins, the Enron senior vice president who bargained with E.D.S. on the deal. "We consider E.D.S. the technology experts." 
 By capitalizing on corporate America's drive to downsize, save money and improve efficiencies, E.D.S. has been climbing like a rocket. Despite the departure of its legendary founder, H. Ross Perot, after a squabble with its corporate parent, General Motors, the company's sales have increased sevenfold since 1984, when it was taken over. To be sure, much of this revenue is provided by G.M. itself, but E.D.S.'s sales are expected by the company and some analysts to more than triple, to $25 billion, by the end of the decade.
This growth is expected despite the fact that the number of companies in the business is increasing. The key is an explosion in demand. One recent survey showed that 40 percent of all corporations are seriously considering hiring computer services companies to manage all or part of their data processing operations. Overall, worldwide spending on computer services, which range from a narrow task like managing automated teller accounts for banks to taking full control of a company's entire computing operations and staff, are expected to hit $1.3 trillion in 1995, according to researchers.
 
'Plenty of Business>
 "There's plenty of business for any company that can do a fine job at this point," said Mr. Perot, who as head of the three-year-old Perot Systems Corporation is one of the new competitors.
E.D.S and the other biggest computer service companies have gained leverage in demanding price breaks when buying computers for their customers. In fact, with pressure on their profit margins, the big computer makers have started to look at the computer services business with envy. In May, the International Business Machines Corporation, for one, entered the business, and it is expected to give E.D.S. a stiff challenge.
"Customers have had so much hardware jammed down their throats for so long that they are now going outside for help," said Stephen T. McClellan, a data processing analyst at Merrill Lynch in New York. "The service companies are squarely positioned between the computer hardware companies and the end users. That is starting to change the landscape of the industry."
Bolstered by the urgency of some customers to raise money to ride out the recession, the computer services business did more managing of existing systems and offering advice and purchasing equipment under "outsourcing" contracts with corporations. Now, E.D.S. and a few of its well-heeled competitors have the cash to buy outright the computing operations of large companies as well as hire the employees of those operations.
To help sustain healthy growth, E.D.S. has also been prospecting for business abroad. Last summer, Lester M. Alberthal Jr., the scholarly looking chairman and chief executive at E.D.S. since late 1986, flexed E.D.S.'s financial muscle in Europe, where it has been a laggard. In the company's first hostile takeover battle, he put up more than $250 million and came away with control of a British-based computer services firm, SD-Scicon P.L.C.
Turning over a corporate computing department to a service company, however well known, is not easy. Traditionalists argue that, for one thing, no team of outside experts can know the details of their businesses as intimately as their own staffs.
Sometimes they are correct. E.D.S. manages computer systems for several savings institutions in Texas controlled by the Resolution Trust Corporation. A few months ago, having misinterpreted data from those sources, it sent inaccurate reports to credit agencies that 1,800 homeowners were delinquent in their mortgage payments. E.D.S. eventually caught the error.
 
'The Angel of Death'
 And for reasons that sometimes have as much to do with office politics as economics, many executives in charge of management information system departments resist yielding control of their empires to outsiders. "An M.I.S. director would rather see the angel of death at the door than someone from E.D.S.," said Darwin Deason, head of Affiliated Computer Systems, a three-year-old systems integrator in Dallas.
Still, aversion to outsourcing is gradually breaking down. "We are moving away from the end of the scale that says 'build everything yourself,' " conceded Bill T. Houghton, president of the information systems subsidiary at the Chevron Corporation in San Ramon, Calif. "If we aren't cost-effective in some area, we try to improve it. If we can't, then using outside suppliers is an alternative."
Some senior computing executives in big corporations acknowledge that they have allowed the service companies to get a foot inside their camp as wholesalers of personal computers and packaged software and suppliers of nationwide and global telecommunication networks. Those deals can often lead to bigger contracts.
In a recession, signing up a computer services company to manage all aspects of information systems "moves the risk and capital investments onto someone else's shoulders," said Robert S. Sullivan, dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh.
Like Enron, Continental Bank and Eastman Kodak have turned all of their computing problems and all of their computing employees over to service companies in the last few years and signed long-term contracts with those companies to operate their information systems.
Financially weakened companies like Cummins Engine, Greyhound Lines and the Southland Corporation have also gone to service companies to cut their computing costs.
In the biggest deal yet, the General Daynamics Corporation, which has been forced to scale back its arms business since the collapse of Communism, agreed to pay the Computer Sciences Corporation of El Segundo, Calif., about $3 billion over the next 10 years to manage all of its computing operations. In turn Computer Sciences agreed to pay $200 million for all of General Dynamics's computer equipment and will hire all of its computing employees. E.D.S. may soon sign an even-bigger deal with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
In this atmosphere, E.D.S. has flourished. Its 1990 revenues rose to $6.1 billion from less than $800 million when G.M. bought it for $2.55 billion in cash and stock in 1984. The company earned $496.9 million last year, a 14 percent increase over 1989, and profits were up another 12 percent in the first half of 1991, to $139.8 million.
G.M., which accounted for more than 80 percent of E.D.S. revenues in the first years after the marriage, should account for less than half this year. Analysts expect that orders booked by G.M. for manufacturing software, car-order systems for dealers, health-care administration and other services will be fairly flat as the auto maker struggles with weak car sales in the next few years.
But orders from a growing list of 7,200 other customers in 28 countries should rise at annual rates of nearly 20 percent, analysts said. The company posted an 11 percent sales increase for the first half of the year and will approach $7 billion in revenues for the year. The Yankee Group, a research firm in Boston, projects that revenues for E.D.S. will reach $13.3 billion in 1995, with more than $10 billion coming from customers other than G.M.
Today, E.D.S. accounts for 4.9 percent of the sales of General Motors, up from 3.5 percent just six years ago. Along with E.D.S.'s healthy rise in earnings, that provides at least a small measure of help for a company whose core business has stagnated.
Mr. Alberthal, who is 47, wants his executives reaching toward a yearly sales target of $25 billion, which some analysts think is possible by the end of the decade.
E.D.S., which was founded in 1962, already has lower costs and the best profit margins in the industry compared with a handful of other systems integrators like I.B.M., Andersen Consulting and Computer Sciences.
This advantage stems in part from its position as one of the nation's largest buyers of computers, software and telecommunications services for the insurers, credit unions and health plans that are its non-G.M. customers. And because it is one of the world's largest private operators of data processing centers, capable of handling six billion computer instructions a second, E.D.S. uses dozens of mainframes at 110 sites in the United States, Europe and Asia.
E.D.S. by itself has put pressure on profit margins at I.B.M. It is Big Blue's biggest customer for mainframes, buying more than 50 a year, and it can command bargain prices in small computers as well. If E.D.S. thinks I.B.M.'s price for an order of thousands of personal computers is too steep, it will simply turn to Dell, Compaq, Apple, Digital Equipment and dozens of other suppliers.
To counter inroads made by E.D.S. and other systems companies, I.B.M. in May formed the Integrated Systems Solutions Corporation, even though some rivals contend that the step violated a 1956 consent decree by the computer giant to stay out of the services business. The Justice Department is investigating, but it could be years before action is taken.
I.B.M. is ignoring the fuss. "It is our focus and catalyst for I.B.M. to become a more services-oriented rather than a product-oriented company," said Dennie Welsh, president of the subsidiary.
I.B.M. executives are telling Wall Street that computer services will eventually become a significant profit producer in a company that currently derives 70 percent of its sales from the slowing hardware business.
E.D.S. has other challenges. Its payroll has ballooned to more than 60,000 employees, and a bureaucracy that customers said had slowed the company's response time and made it rigid in its problem solving. In response, Mr. Alberthal last year organized the company into 38 different business units, each dealing with a different industry. The idea was to speed decisions and push them closer to customers.
Earlier, Mr. Alberthal had softened the rigid edges of the military-style culture created by Mr. Perot by, among other things, easing dress codes that banned facial hair and striped shirts.
Flush with more than $700 million in cash, little debt and a yearly revenue stream of more than $3 billion from G.M., Mr. Alberthal is chasing growth in different ways to extend E.D.S.'s vital dominance in economies of scale in computing power, telecommunications networks and other technology.
 
Extending the Reach
 An example of its new reach was a $40 million investment last year in ASK Computer Systems Inc., which gave E.D.S. a 20 percent stake in the company and distribution rights to software programs used by manufacturers. It also signed a deal last July with Consilium Inc. to market management software used in military and aerospace plants.
E.D.S. has a stake in Hitachi's National Advanced Systems and can sell mainframes assembled by National as an alternative to I.B.M. models. And it is hawking a recently developed system for transmitting engineering documents between Macintosh computers.
As for how it all works, executives at Enron, whose former staff of 550 computing specialists are now employees of E.D.S., have some insight.
"It's almost three years and were satisfied," said Mr. Tompkins. "I don't think we've lost control of anything."
Therein is a question. "I would not want anyone to think that by outsourcing your information system that it's suddenly a life of ease," Mr. Tompkins said. " You can delegate, but you can't abrogate."
 
 
PEROT IS BACK IN BUSINESS, STILL THINKING BIG
 On June 1, 1988, H. Ross Perot charged back into the computer services industry, the business he had created nearly 30 years ago. His no-compete contract with the General Motors Corporation expired that day, 18 months after the auto giant bought back his G.M. stock for $750 million.
Analysts say his Perot Systems Corporation, based in Herndon, Va., should exceed $150 million in sales this year. The outspoken Mr. Perot has boasted that annual revenues will reach $1 billion by the year 2000. "I'm working with the best and brightest people I've ever known," he said.
Mr. Perot founded Electronic Data Systems in 1962 when his supervisors at I.B.M. in Dallas rebuffed his urgings to add programming and consulting services for companies buying big I.B.M. mainframes.
Perot Systems pales in size next to E.D.S., but Mr. Perot does not seem to mind. He has taken some hits -- Epic Healthcare Group Inc. in Dallas did not renew a $3 million contract last year. But he has also on occasion defeated E.D.S. and other established giants in bidding wars. NCNB and First American Bancshares are two clients in the financial services business. And Kelsey-Hayes, a maker of auto parts, chose Perot over E.D.S. last spring.
Mr. Perot, who is 61 years old, bankrolled the company with $20 million from his personal fortune, which is estimated at $3 billion. He said he spends about one-third of his time on Perot Systems business. He also has land development operations and is popular on the lecture circuit.
More than half of his top 50 employees followed him from E.D.S., but these days he has nothing but praise for the industry leader, and even for G.M., at least when speaking with reporters. "They're doing a great job, and I'm proud of them," he said.
 
 
 
OUTSOURCING TO THE HILT
 Some companies are not content simply to hire an outsider to provide computer services. Instead, they sell all of their computer operations and transfer the employees that operate them.
The rapid growth of E.D.S. and its biggest competitors raises the intriguing question of how much of the nation's computing capicity will one day end up in the hands of a few computer services giants.
The biggest deal so far was put together last month, when the Computer Sciences Corporation of El Segundo, Calif., agreed to pay $200 million for the computing operations of General Dynamics, a hobbled military supplier. General Dynamics will transfer 2,600 employees to Computer Sciences and pay about $300 million annually for 10 years to Computer Sciences for managing the operations.
But E.D.S. is close to an even-bigger deal with McDonnell Douglas. The two have signed a letter of intentunder which E.D.S. would acquire the contractor's systems-integration unit, with revenues of $398 million last year. But E.D.S.'s head, Lester M. Alberthal Jr., does not rule out buying McDonnell's entire computing operations, which would expand the deal enormously.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Lightening Up on Latin America

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Two big investors in the stock markets of Latin America, which have been shown the best rises among all of the world's exchanges this year, are raising the yellow caution flag. They are taking their profits on some of their holdings and paying more attention to the downside risk.
The two are Antoine W. van Agtmael, president of the Emerging Market Investors Fund in Washington, D.C., and Mark Mobius, president of the Templeton Emerging Markets Fund, based in Hong Kong. 
 "As prices run up, the upside potential is less and the downside risk is greater, and that is a reason to be cautious," Mr. van Agtmael said in an interview after a conference on emerging markets and country funds run by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York last week.
Mr. Mobius agreed. "It is getting more difficult to find bargains at this time," he said at the conference. "It is a good idea to lighten up in these countries."
Mr. van Agtmael had 43 percent of his fund in Latin American stocks in August, but he is now cutting his exposure to 37 percent. In his major Latin holdings, Mexico is being reduced to 15 percent from 17 percent; Argentina to 6 percent from 9 percent; Chile to 7 percent from 8, and Brazil is holding at 8 percent.
This adjustment is a recognition of two factors. One is that the markets have moved so far that corrections are possible. And, the second concern is that there are fewer bargains available as more and more investors join the herd and move to Latin America.
"The screaming bargains are no longer there," said Mr. Mobius.
Because of this, Mr. van Agtmael is venturing out of some of the most popular stocks in Mexico and is beginning to look for second- and third-tier stocks that he feels not many other foreign investors have heard of yet.
He emphasizes that he is not making a dramatic turnaround. He still contends that Latin American stocks are at the beginning of a decade of growth. In Mexico, Argentina and Chile, he notes, he will still be overweight, which means the percentage of his portfolio in those nations is larger than would be dictated by the size of the stock markets.
And even though Mr. van Agtmael acknowledges that "I really can't figure out Brazil," he is not pulling out of that market. What leaves him uncertain is the question of how committed the Government is to its economic restructuring.
Despite this faith in Latin America in the long run, Mr. van Agtmael still suggests moving some money into what he calls the Fallen Angels: Taiwan, South Korea, Indonesia and Turkey, whose markets have been among the worst performers recently. "They," he said, "are due for a bounce."
 
Strike in Milan
 When Erich Stock, the manager of the Italy Fund and director for equities for Shearson Lehman Global Asset Management in London, opened his presentation at the Smith Barney conference last week, he had to make an apology. "I am going to talk about the only market that does not exist," he said.
The Italian stock market in Milan was closed by a strike of floor brokers. In the fifth largest economy in the West, there was no trading for four days because of a lingering dispute over the jobs that will be lost as Italy moves to consolidate and revamp its splintered brokerage industry so it will have the capital and technical resources to compete in a unified Europe.
The strike ended on Thursday but it showed, once again, that this market has the air of a banana republic. It is still small with very few liquid stocks. It is only beginning to move to deal with insider trading, the rights of minority shareholders and the lack of openness and disclosure in a market where about one-third of the trades still take place off the floor of the stock exchange.
The strike seemed to center on two issues. One involved the move to continuous trading via computer screens and the formation of a new unified structure for brokerage firms, which will eliminate the need for the floor brokers who were on strike.
The second item of contention involved the slow progress of legislation to bring the practices of the Milan stock market more in line with the rest of Europe. One proposal would restrict large stock tender offers at premium prices among majority investors in a company unless similar prices are offered to minority shareholders. Deals that ignore the minority shareholders are common now.
In an interview from his office in Milan, Enrico Tagliabue, the head of the association of floor brokers, said the strike was stopped because the Government had said it would give full backing to a provision of the law that could make available some jobs for the laid-off brokers in the new brokerage firms.
Mr. Stock said the strike for jobs was futile. He said the brokerage industry was overstaffed and already struggling because of the drop of the volume in the market.
But he said the strike might have the beneficial effect of focusing attention on the need for change. A number of laws, including one approved to restrict insider trading and the one languishing on tender offers, are needed to bring the market into the modern era.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Happy Birthday To a Big Bull Market

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
How does an annual return of 53 percent strike you? That is, as it happens, the increase in the Russell 2,000 index of small stocks in the first year of its bull market, which began on Oct. 17, 1990.
By contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average gained only 30 percent from its low of last October through its record close of 3,077.15 on Friday. Not a bad move, but hardly in the same league. 
 The big rally in small caps is just one part of the schizophrenic financial markets of 1991. It is hard to remember a time when the beginning of "A Tale of Two Cities" was more applicable.
For some companies, the financing front is as bleak as it can be. The credit crunch is real for those too small or too highly leveraged to have access to the financial markets. "The diminished availability of private capital is pushing prices down" for venture capital investors, says Richard E. Kroon, who runs Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette's Sprout Group. The banks that once would have provided loans to many such companies are no longer interested in hearing from them.
But for other companies, things could not be better. The friendly stock market means that many companies can raise equity capital on terms that would have been unthinkable a year ago. Interest rates are down sharply for those that can borrow, and that group is not as small as many think.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company was among the first to sense that banks were eagerly looking for "safe" borrowers. Its pending recapitalizations of RJR Nabisco and Owens-Illinois depend on paying off high-rate bonds with proceeds from equity offerings that contractually were supposed to pay down bank loans.
"The banks are begging to stay in" the group that lends money to RJR Nabisco, said Daniel J. Donaghue of Duff & Phelps Credit Rating, and are quite happy to give up their right to be paid first. The result is likely to be that the company gets capital at a much lower cost, and the banks get to make loans they now consider to be safe. Mr. Donaghue says RJR Nabisco may even be able to get back into the commercial paper market.
The most important difference between now and a year ago reflects a huge change in sentiment. Now the market is usually willing to assume that bad news relates to a specific company, not to an entire industry. Citicorp shares are near their lows of a year ago, but the average New York bank stock has nearly doubled and went up more last week, even after Citicorp's big loss was reported.
It is that optimism that helped keep stock prices high this summer and fall, even when the evidence of economic recovery was slim. And it is that optimism that is helping companies like Owens-Illinois move from the unloved group to the one with easy access to capital.
A year ago, pessimism was high, and so were the profits to be had by betting against it. Today, it is optimism that is rising.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1755 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 13-18

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
For Better or Worse, Citicorp's Star Is Hitched to the Economy 

Citicorp is the national economy in microcosm. Badly hurt by the recession, especially in real estate, the nation's largest banking company reported a loss last week of $885 million in the third quarter. Its chairman, John S. Reed, said he expected losses on business and commercial real estate loans to rise for a few more quarters as a consequence of the slumping economy. In the first three quarters of the year, Citicorp charged off as a loss $3.97 billion of loans. Its holdings of badly delinquent loans is now $9.64 billion. Much of that comes from its aggressive push into consumer and mortgage lending, especially in the West where the recession lingers. All this makes some analysts question whether the worst really is behind the nation's biggest bank. "We clearly have picked up more, or at least our fair share, of problems," Mr. Reed said. Vigorous growth in the economy would do wonders.
 
America in the Jalopy Age
 
Showroom traffic is way up as Detroit dazzles consumers with loads of new models. But too few browsers are becoming buyers. Sales for early October, when the new-model year began, were down 10.1 percent compared with a year earlier, in the early days of the recession. Analysts attribute sales resistance even among the most car-conscious consumers to nervousness about the economy. The result is that America's fleet of cars is more ancient than ever -- a rust-eaten 7.6 years, according to Charles Brady, an analyst at Mabon Securities Corporation in New York. When, the auto makers wonder, will all those jalopies ever be replaced?

Getting Stubborn on Prices
 
With the economy growing at barely single-digit rates, prices should be tumbling. How else could shopkeepers move those goods? But prices are not. Last week, the Commerce Department reported, the Consumer Price Index jumped 0.4 percent in September after increasing 0.2 percent in August. If you exclude volatile food and energy prices from the index, "you get an annualized inflation rate of 4.6 percent, which appears high," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. That makes some wonder if the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates or simply stand pat. "Right now the Fed wants the economy to expand," said Mr. Kahan.

That Curious Warehouse Watch
 
Number-crunching economists often pose questions to themselves, such as: "At today's sales rates, how long will it take to clear the economy of all its inventoried goods?" The answer to that, they reason, indicates when factory orders will pick up as the nation's stores restock. Right now, according to the Commerce Department, it would take 1.49 months to clean the nation's warehouses of their goods. That is the lowest rate in a year and suggests the economy is picking up. "The recovery is likely to witness stable growth rather than a double-dip," said Jerry Jasinowski, of the National Association of Manufacturers. But at the rate at which those inventories are being cleared, stable growth will also be slow growth.

A Widening Trade Gap
 
Americans sure love their imported goods. The nation's trade deficit with the rest of the world surged by 13.6 percent during August to $6.76 billion, according to the Commerce Department. That happens, the theory says, when the economy is poised for recovery. Not this time. The deficit grew in August because exports slipped 3 percent to $34.16 billion as growth abroad stalled. Before the figures were released, the consensus among economists was that August's deficit would narrow to $5.35 billion. They were off by $1.41 billion.

What Are the Factories Up To?
 
The nation's economic puzzle is composed of pieces not necessarily taken from the same box. Consider factory orders and capacity utilization. According to the Federal Reserve, factory orders were up 0.1 percent in September as inventories were slowly being used up. That was expected. But factory capacity utilization actually dropped in September to 79.7 percent from 79.8 percent in August and 80 percent in July. Factories working less were producing more?
 
Bad News in Housing
 
Since March, housing starts have been picking up. But according to the Commerce Department, they dropped 2.2 percent in September. On its own, that is bad enough. But housing starts are also an indicator of the economy's future course. Buy a house and pretty soon you must fill it. Then you must make the payments. The payments part is what people are worrying about.

No Boost for the Jobless
 
President Bush may style himself the kinder, gentler President, but he wields his veto power with alacrity. Since he has been in office, he has killed 23 bills. Congress attempted to overturn 12 and failed each time. Last week, the survivor was Mr. Bush's veto of a bill extending unemployment benefits for people who have already exhausted their coverage. Extending benefits to the estimated 3.4 million unemployed whose benefits have lapsed "would significantly increase the Federal deficit," Mr. Bush said. Maybe so. But those words sounded far from gentle.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Milken's Plea for Lenience
 
Last week, Arthur Liman, the principal defense attorney for Michael Milken, the jailed junk-bond financier, asked the court to reduce Mr. Milken's 10-year sentence. In a 31-page memorandum to the court, Mr. Liman cited Mr. Milken's 29 meetings with the government and hundreds of hours of debriefings, as evidence of his client's desire to cooperate. Mr. Liman also drew the court's attention to Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted swindler. Mr. Milken's crimes were not as bad as Mr. Boesky's, according to Mr. Liman, yet Mr. Milken's sentence was harsher. Since the court has heard all this before, sympathy is not expected.

The Good and the Bad at Big Blue
 
While the International Business Machines Corporation has been developing its strategy for the future through linkages with dozens of other smaller computer makers, its day-to-day business has been suffering. Last week, Big Blue reported its earnings fell 84.5 percent in the third quarter to $173 million. Its revenue also fell, to $14.43 billion from $15.28 billion. Investors moaned, analysts saw glimmers of hope. Big Blue also said it had trimmed sales, administrative and research expenses. And last week it announced it was selling its $400 million stake in the MCI Communications Corporation. Ultimately, Wall Street could not make up its mind about I.B.M. The stock fell $2.125 then rose $3 to $104.25 and finished the week at $100.25.
 
USAir Losses Ease a Bit
 
USAir, one of the nation's ailing carriers, reported a loss last week of $81.4 million for the third quarter. That was good news. Analysts had expected worse. USAir lost $120.3 million the quarter before. The airline also said it was planning to trim expenses by $400 million.

Chasing That Cellular Profit
 
So far, no cellular telephone company has figured out a way to make money. But they are good at dreaming big. Last week, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. unveiled its visions of the future. It said it had developed hardware and software to link its cellular systems around the country into a seamless web of talk. The network will be called Cellular One. Sixty million potential subscribers live in the area it covers. But to make it truly national, McCaw will try to convince other companies to join its network. "What follows next is persuading partners, not acquiring them.It's politics, not finance," said Craig McCaw, the company's chairman. It had better be. McCaw still has $5 billion in debt from previous acquisitions.

TRW Allows a Free Peek
 
TRW Inc. mostly makes satellites and car parts. But it also has a division that produces credit reports -- and makes enemies, among state attorneys general, in Congress and at consumer groups. So, TRW said it would make its reports available without charge to the people in its files.
 
CBS Misses the Ballpark
 
Pity poor CBS. It bought the rights to air major league baseball to add a little punch to its ratings. But CBS lost out to the Senate confirmation hearings of Judge Clarence Thomas. Last Sunday, according to David Poltrack, senior vice president for research at CBS, 27 million homes tuned into the Judge Thomas saga, compared with just 9.2 million homes at the ballgame. The ratings show that a program that is part politics, part National Enquirer, may have a future on TV.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Unify? Count the Ukraine Out
 
Immediately after the Soviet republics declared their independence from Moscow's central control, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed a new treaty to create a new union. Russia's President, Boris N. Yelt sin and most of the other leaders of the republics were enthusiastic. But last week the Ukraine had a change of heart. It refused to sign the treaty. The new economic union was too encumbering, its Parliament said, especially the proposal to set up a single central bank and currency. What worries the Ukraine most is the idea of falling under the sway of neighboring Russia once again. "The republics agreed to the treaty thinking they could get raw materials from Russia on better conditions than they now do," said Vladimir Kvint, a lecturer at Babson College in Boston. "But Russia wants to impose political conditions on them now. That makes the whole treaty a question mark."
 
Ford Faces Facts at Jaguar

The Ford Motor Company bought Britain's Jaguar in 1986 for $2.7 billion. It might be sorry it did. The luxury automaker is in a slump. Sales have fallen from 45,000 cars last year to well below 30,000 this year. Jaguar has even had to scrap some new models and stop development on others. Last week, union representatives were summoned by Ford to talk about layoffs. Rumors are that 1,400 workers will have to go. So far this year 2,500 Jaguar workers have been dismissed.
 
Honda Latest Concept
 
Most concept cars never get built. They are sketches in metal and plastic to sharpen designers' skills and drum up excitement for the brand. Last week, Honda unveiled a prototype two-seater dubbed the EP-X (efficient, personal, experimental). The car seats the passenger behind the driver -- talk about stiff necks. But it does have an advantage: an estimated 100 miles a gallon. In the tradition, chances are slim the EP-X will ever be built.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
The Satisfying Silliness Of the Paintball Wars

BYLINE: By Mary Billard

 BODY:
On a recent rainy Sunday, Christopher Siedman was running through the woods in a strange half crouch, climbing over low stone walls and hiding from enemy fire. Decked out in camouflage pants, he and two friends were holding black metal guns. They thought they were closing in on their objective, a heavily guarded compound at the other end of a wooded field. But in fact, they were going around in circles in a swamp, thick brush blocking their passage.
Just then, the quiet was pierced by unmistakable Rambo-like screams of skirmish. 
 "We gotta get out of here," Mr. Siedman yelled, sounding like a warrior. Then, like the banker he really is, he howled: "We are all zero assets if we get stuck here."
Paintball war is hell.
Mr. Siedman, an analyst at a large Wall Street rating agency, was recently at a camp called Survival: New York, in Newburgh, N.Y., with friends from the Federal Reserve Bank and other Wall Street offices. Like many other people who work 9-to-5, they have discovered the thrill of paintball war, a game in which teams fire gelatin shells filled with paint at one another. The sport picked up momentum when the stock market crashed in October 1987, grew more popular during the recession and won even more players after the Persian Gulf War, said Jerry Braun, co-owner of Survival: New York.
The players obviously revel in being able to let off steam. "It's a bunch of nerds -- accountants and bankers -- screaming their heads off," said Mr. Siedman. "It's great."
Golf and tennis are the traditional ways for co-workers to bond, but the adrenaline released in paintball war is so intense that it transcends those placid playing fields.
The appeal could be attributed to the men's movement -- the poet Robert Bly's theory that the modern male has become alienated from his masculine nature and needs to reconnect with that "wild man" within his soul.
Paintball does indeed fulfill the call of the child, if not the wild. It is a game where grown-ups run around playing a very competitive game of tag.
"It was a thrill to wake up at 5 A.M. to run around outside all day long, like when you were a kid at camp," said Russ Paparo, a commodities trader playing in Newburgh recently. Added Joe Haley Jr., a data sales executive at the White Plains office of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company: "I loved diving and rolling around on the group. How often do you get to do that?"
And that's not to mention all the dressing up: For roughly $40 at the Newburgh field, a combatant gets a full-day session, complete with ammunition, a gun, goggles and a frightening face mask.
No one needs a management consultant to tell the player firing a gun at a co-worker that it provides a cathartic release, and it is perhaps for that reason that many companies actually sponsor paintball war sessions for employees. "It was a great release," said Laura Sayegh, director of sales administration at HBO Video, who joined co-workers at a company-sponsored session. "Our senior vice president of sales was a decoy. It was his idea."
David Reitz, manager of equipment development at Pepsico Inc., was not with a company-sponsored group recently, but "the boss got hit quite a few times," he said.
The game is straightforward -- simply an armed version of capture the flag. A team, with anywhere from 10 to 30 players, guards its flag at one side of the field while trying to grab the other side's flag and take it back to its home base.
But things are not so simple that people don't prepare. The night before the battle, one of Mr. Siedman's playmates trained by reading "The Art of War," by Sun Tzu, the bible of corporate raiders in the 1980's; another watched the grisly Vietnam War movie, "Platoon."
The game is becoming so popular that soon amateurs will be able to start cribbing chesslike strategies from professional tournaments. Pro paintball is scheduled to run on the Sportschannel in November and on the ESPN cable network early next year.
But even weekend warriors know that attitude is key. The language seems to come straight from a lifetime of John Wayne movies buried deep within their psyches. "Take the ridge," one player screamed in Newburgh, his voice hoarse. "Good D," said another, meaning good defense. "Shoot to kill," yelled yet another.
Strategies develop during the session. "We found hunkering down better than being too aggressive; if you are aggressive you get knocked out early," said Pepsico's Mr. Reitz.
Daniel Rappaport, a commodities trader and member of the board of the New York Mercantile Exchange, hid with teammates in the bushes, then rushed the opponent's flag to a barrage of fire. When the smoke cleared, six enemy guards were dead. "They all fired at the first guy," said Mr. Rappaport. The strategy had worked.
But not everyone can learn to work together. On a recent A.T.& T. Computer Systems outing, the team from the sales side could never agree on a master plan, Mr. Haley said. "The judge would count down, the whistle would blow, no one would agree what to do and everyone would run in their own direction," he said.
Still, like an old soldier, he came out with a good story. "We were all pumped up and talking about it in the office," said Mr. Reitz.
"We still talk about it," said Ms. Sayegh from HBO Video. "It's very competitive, but no one gets left out. Everybody played. It's great for team spirit."
Despite all the thrills, however, nothing is perfect. "There was no hand-to-hand," said Mr. Rappaport, sounding a bit wistful.

HEADLINE: Short-Term Leases Lure the Once-Burned Auto Buyer

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
When Richard and Terrie Hursey went out to buy a family car last fall, their dealer worked out a financing plan that allowed them to meet their $300-a-month budget. They bought a 1989 used Ford Taurus, financing the $11,992 purchase over five years, for a monthly payment of $293.22. He says he was led to believe that he could trade up after about a year.
But the Livermore, Calif., couple was distressed to learn last month while shopping for something larger that their car is worth thousands of dollars less than what they owe on their loan. "We've got a funny feeling we're stuck with the car," said Mr. Hursey. "I just feel we got the shaft." 
 Faced with legions of drivers like the Hurseys who suffer "finance remorse," auto makers are pitching a solution: short-term, two- to four-year, leasing. They're hoping leases will not only relieve the remorse, but also put an end to some of their own problems, like broad rebates and other profit-bleeding incentives.
A growing number of car shoppers find the logic compelling. Because leases allow buyers to pay for only that portion of the car's value that will be used up during the contract, leases generally require lower monthly payments than loans. For instance, if an auto maker determines that a $15,000 car will be worth $7,000 after three years, payments on a three-year lease would be based on only $8,000. At lease-end, leaseholders may have to pay a fee for any wear and tear -- things like dents -- not taken into consideration in the predetermined trade-in value. But if all goes well, drivers can simply turn in their keys for a new car.
The shorter terms also mean customers can trade more often. "To me, it sounds like the greatest way to go," said Mr. Hursey, who has learned a good deal about leasing since he bought his car.
To be sure, lease programs are risky for car companies, which place a potentially costly bet every time they commit to trade-in values on their vehicles. And their betting record is hardly encouraging: lessors, which include the finance arms of auto makers as well as the banks, lost an average $1,300 on the sale of each car returned in 1990, according to Randall McCathren, executive vice president of Bank Lease Consultants in Nashville, Tenn., which advises the auto and banking industries.
But lessors say they have learned from past mistakes and are now confidently putting much of their marketing muscle behind lease programs. Their new emphasis is causing a fundamental shift in the way auto makers and consumers do business. "The whole strategy of the industry has changed," said Cedric Rashad, an automotive leasing consultant based in Atlanta.
Indeed, advertisements today are keyed increasingly to such items as Audi's "three-year test drive." The car companies' lease programs, with names like Smart Lease at General Motors, Red Carpet at Ford and Gold Key at Chrysler, have grown dramatically in recent years. In the process, they have won market share for leasing business from the banks. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, for example, has doubled its leasing volume to about 20 percent of all sales in less than two years. CNW Marketing/Research in Bandon, Ore., estimates that about 20 percent of all cars delivered to retail customers in the United States (excluding fleet sales) are leased.
Many predict leases could eventually reach about 50 percent of the business. At that point, some estimate, resistance will set in. After all, in the words of Buick general manager Edward H. Mertz, "Americans grew up owning things." Anticipating that, Chrysler, for one, introduced a program this month called Gold Key Plus that offers all the features of a lease, but gives customers the title to their vehicle during the lease, creating the illusion of ownership.
Auto makers like leasing for a litany of reasons. For one, customer loyalty. More than 80 percent of consumers who sign leases with a manufacturer's finance arm return to the same dealership for another vehicle, compared with about one-third for buyers, according to CNW.
The lower monthly payments of leasing also help distract shoppers from sticker prices, which now average more than $16,000, as well as rebates and low financing rates. Such incentives, conceived as short-term sales boosters, have created long-term problems by cutting profits and creating the air of distress sales. Some form of rebate or incentive is now involved in 90 percent of all vehicle sales, according to Autofacts, a consulting firm in West Chester, Penn.
Manufacturers say that funds they have set aside for incentives can be put to better use in leasing specials to move particular models. A $199-per-month lease special on Grand Ams earlier this year enabled Pontiac to quadruple lease deliveries on that model over three months. This more targeted use of incentive dollars means that "manufacturers feel they get more bang for their buck with leasing," said Bill Jensen, executive director of the National Vehicle Leasing Association in Culver City, Calif.
Leasing earned a bad reputation in the early 1970's because then, the contracts were "open-ended" -- if the car depreciated more quickly than expected, customers had to make up the difference, sometimes paying several thousand dollars.
By the late 1970's, fuming holders of open-ended leases prompted many dealers to stop offering consumer leasing altogether. "It was a pretty rough time," said Art Spinella, director of automotive research for CNW.
Leasing was reinvigorated by tax law changes in 1981 that gave benefits such as investment tax credits to companies writing leases. A rush of players entered the market, competing ruggedly on financing rates and predicting that their cars would retain more value than a competitor's. "Closed-end" leases, in which the car company or bank is liable for the residual values it set, also evolved.
But many lessors miscalculated. When the cost of cars, especially imports, began rising quickly in the early 1980's, lifting the residual values of used cars, banks and finance companies bet that the trend would continue into the mid-1980's. It didn't. Used-car and residual values started falling, mirroring new-car prices, slashed by cash rebates and low financing terms. The average residual values of 18 models tracked by one leasing guide tumbled more than 8 percentage points between 1983 and 1987. A Pontiac Grand Prix, predicted in 1983 to retain 40 percent of its value after four years, was estimated in 1987 to hold only 29 percent after four years.
Still, most lessors did not feel the full ill effects of that reversal until the investment tax credits were eliminated in 1986. That wiped out the cushion against too-rosy projections of residuals, causing big losses on cars under leasing contracts. For Volvo Finance, those losses approached $2,000 each on some cars, said Michael T. Duke, president of Volvo Finance North America.
For Audi, the pain of unrealistic residuals was aggravated by 60 Minutes's allegations in 1986 that some of its cars were prone to unintended acceleration. The company lost up to $5,000 on some models when they were traded as resale value faded. "For us, it was a huge corporate loss," said Joseph H. Tate, general sales manager of Audi of America. "That's the roulette you play with leasing."
Losses were so great in fact that many banks retreated from the business. Marine Midland, which had built its leasing portfolio to $6 billion by 1989, ultimately lost $100 million on the program, according to Mr. McCathren of Bank Lease. Marine Midland, Citicorp, KeyCorp are among the banks that have since left the business or scaled back.
The banks' share has also been eroded by the "captive" finance arms of the car makers. Captives now finance about 80 percent of the leases written at dealerships, up from just over half in 1988, according to CNW data. Banks account for the other 20 percent of leases offered through dealers.
With the heady car-selling days of the mid-1980's behind them, and the mistakes of the decade still catching up with them, banks and captives alike say they are taking a more realistic approach, making more conservative projections of residual values. "Some of the mistakes of the past have not been repeated," said Joseph F. McPartlin, director of leasing for GMAC.
But Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York, said that anyone who predicts residuals is playing an inherently risky game because of the economy's unpredictability. "The risk is there. It may be small, but you're still going to own that thing at the price you guaranteed four years down the road," he said. Some leasing experts also contend that car makers are still supporting unrealistic residual values on some models to win market share.
Industry analysts predict that leasing companies will continue to devise new wrinkles for lease contracts to better match the way customers want to use their cars. Lexus, for example, has added a 30-month lease to offer another choice between 24- and 36-month leases. Ford is contemplating offering lower charges for excess mileage to be paid up front by customers who think they will use those miles, rather than annoying them with higher penalties at lease-end. GMAC has a fledgling lease program for people who lease luxury cars for limited use as second or third cars; the lower mileage projections allow GMAC to lower the customers' monthly payments.
Mr. Spinella of CNW believes that leasing companies will soon find a better solution for customers who decide to exit their leases early. The cost of doing so often angers customers and sends them to another car company for their next vehicle, what he terms the weak point in current programs. "And at the weak point," he said, "there's always somebody willing to come up with a program to solve it."
 
 
MORE ACTION AT THE AUTIONS
 As short-term consumer leasing grows in popularity, car dealers and banks are taking back more cars when leases expire. That means business for used car wholesalers that hold auto auctions.
Auto auctioneers liken their business to a financial exchange. Cars brought in are driven through lanes as auctioneers work the crowd of dealers and brokers to find the best offer. Dealers often come to simply trade some of their used-car inventory for vehicles they think will sell better. The swelling inventory of end-lease used cars, according to dealers, is no problem since most of the cars are relatively young, with 60,000 miles or less on the odometer.
Robert A. McDevitt, vice president of sales and marketing for Anglo American Auto Auctions in Nashville, one of the nation's biggest auctioneers, said that inventory from consumer leases, nonexistent 15 years ago, now comprises 25 percent of the company's business.
And with more luxury cars coming back from consumer leases, Anglo American has added a new lane at some of its gatherings. "We decided we can do a better service to our dealers to showcase them," said Mr. McDevitt. The volume of premium cars handled by the company has grown to about 5 percent of its business, he said.
Anglo American has dressed up its "HighLine" lanes with carpeting and floodlights. "We've kind of spruced up the lane where the higher quality dealer will be," said Mr. McDevitt. Tuxedoed staff served champagne at one HighLine auction, and give away black and gold T-shirts, golf shirts and golf hats.
The trappings are not free, however. While auctioneers typically charge companies about $100 to sell a car, the fee is raised to $250 for the premium lane.

HEADLINE: All About/Translation Services;
The Growing Gelt in Others' Words

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
WITH America's export engine revving up, the nation's translation services are reaping the benefits. To make money abroad, more and more companies are tailoring their products to local markets. That means having legal contracts, technical information, instruction manuals and other materials translated into and out of dozens of foreign languages.
The largest translation companies say demand has grown rapidly in recent years, changing what was once a cottage industry of dozens of tiny firms into a full-fledged business with a myriad of small- and medium-sized competitors fighting for market share. 
 Companies like All-Language Services in New York, which was founded in 1946 with five translators, have been flourishing. All-Language, which is privately held, now has 90 translators working in 59 languages. Its revenues -- it does not disclose dollar figures -- have tripled since 1980, according to Lorraine Kennedy, executive vice president. The company's growth has been spurred on by a fourfold increase in the volume of Japanese translated since 1986.
"There has always been a good deal of sophistication about language in the Fortune 500 companies," said Victor J. Hertz, president of Corporate Language Services, a privately held company in New York with affiliates in Europe. "What you're witnessing now is a burgeoning of interest from middle-level and small businesses."
The maturing of the translation business has also been reflected in a spate of recent consolidations. Since the mid-1980's, the translation division of Berlitz International, the subsidiary of Macmillan Inc., best known for its language schools, has bought six translation companies in the United States and Europe. Berlitz now has about $30 million in revenues from translations.
Another industry leader, Alpnet Inc., based in Salt Late City, is publicly traded. Alpnet, which had $22.5 million in 1990 revenues, has also grown through acquisitions overseas.
Despite its growth, the translation business is highly competitive and very fragmented. Experts say that the industry is so diffuse -- from tiny outlets to major companies -- that there are few reliable estimates of its size. If corporate and government translation divisions are included, "the total industry could be as high as $10 billion," said Michael J. Mulligan, a vice president of the translation division of Berlitz.
 
U.S. Firms Abroad
The Advantage Of Native Ability
 Even for companies that have all their operations in the United States, professional translation is very much an international business, employing for the most part people translating into their native language. Industry officials say that only by maintaining such a standard can they insure that a translation is competent.
Translation companies like Berlitz, with offices around the world, take this requirement a step further by insisting that most translations be done by native speakers in the country where the item is to be read. For example, a service might fax or send electronically to its Paris office a document that needs to translated into French.
"If you're not in country, then you don't speak the same language that they're speaking in that country," said Mr. Mulligan. Berlitz has 250 translators working in 19 offices in 13 countries.
The move over the last few years to sending work to other countries has been helped by fax machines, modems and computers. Businesses can now take their work formatted on a desktop publishing program to a translation service that sends it electronically to an office in another country. The translators then return the work ready for printing. Rates in the industry vary widely, depending on how complicated the document is, the language it is to be translated into and what other services, like editing or desktop publishing, are required.
The largest translation companies usually charge 10 cents to 50 cents per word, though rates may be higher for the most difficult work and for technical and legal documents.
Some languages also cost more to translate than others. Asian and Scandinavian languages are often more expensive: the Asian ones because they are complicated and the Scandinavian ones because of high labor costs in those countries.
 
The Speed Premium
Building Business On Flexibility
 Industry leaders say much of their growth has been sparked by the increasing sophistication of American companies, particularly the smaller ones, as they explore the export market. While large companies can set up their own translation departments, smaller ones do not have the resources for such an undertaking and must seek help elsewhere.
"Translation is no longer an afterthought," said Thomas F. Seal, the president of Alpnet, which has 22 offices in nine countries. "When companies are designing products upfront, they are realizing the need to do translation. We've seen a large increase in contacts from the development phase."
One such company is Maynard Electronics of Lake Mary, Fla., which makes computer software and hardware for backing up data. Maynard, which had revenues of about $100 million last year, recently began aggressively pushing into the European market.
The company found that its distributors in Europe were not translating its manuals adequately or fast enough, so it hired Alpnet to create German, French, Dutch, Spanish and Italian versions of the documents.
"The key was that we needed to get translations out sooner so we could get a good edge on the market," said Dawn Woods, a translation specialist at Maynard.
 
Surviving Change
Bring the U.S. Up to Speed
 While pleased with growth in recent years, industry leaders complain about the haphazard nature of the translation market. Demand for a language may rise or fall because of political or economic changes in a country. For example, the integration of Europe into a single market has led to an increased demand for German, French and Spanish translations.
The business is also oriented toward projects -- with clients providing work in fits and starts -- so it is often difficult to plan.
Over the last decade, many translation services have specialized, employing people who concentrate on translating legal work or technical and scientific documents into a specific language.
"If somebody needs a love letter translated, they can go to a next-door neighbor," said Ms. Kennedy, of All-Language Services. "But 99 percent of the stuff we do is very specialized. You can't rely on dictionaries for this stuff."
And the industry remains extremely competitive. Large outfits with hundreds of full-time translators and offices around the world might vie for the same contracts as small services that keep costs low by employing a freelance staff.
"The fact that the industry is fundamentally fragmented means that there is always somebody with relatively low overhead willing to do a project for relatively low costs," said Mr. Mulligan of Berlitz.
Moreover, even though American companies are using translation services more, many remain less familiar with the importance of language in exporting than their rivals in Europe and Asia.
"The main message now is that in Europe and Asia, you are dealing with people who are very language savvy," said Richard Huarte, the executive director of operations in the United States for Inlingua, a Swiss company with 250 offices in 22 countries, including 24 in the United States.
"The United States is really in its infancy in this area," he said. "We've come a long way, but we're still quite behind."
 
 
 
A GLUT OF GOVERNMENT WORK

To communicate with new immigrants who continue to move to the United States, Federal, state and local governments must translate documents into dozens of languages. This business has been an area of rapid growth.
"Our translation business from government agencies has at least doubled in size in the last six years," said Edward Nef, the director of the Washington office of Inlingua, the American subsidiary of the big Swiss translation service. Inlingua has bid on contracts for the United States Customs Service and the Social Security Administration.
Some agencies, like the Immigration and Naturalization Service, have their own translators. But in an age of immigration, even those offices cannot keep up with the number of languages spoken in the United States. For example, last year, the Office of Special Counsel for Immigration-Related Unfair Employment Practices, a division of the Justice Department, had to translate documents into Arabic, French, Spanish, Korean, Japanese and Chinese. Some of these documents are used by workers to file legal complaints against their employers.
Government agencies also use translation services because they are quicker than waiting for the government to do the work itself, said Tyrone Harrison, an administrative assistant at the Office of Special Counsel in New York. "Translation services have made things easier because once the documents are written in English, we can go ahead and proceed with a case more rapidly," he said.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Soldiers Return to the Workplace

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
KENTUCKY FRIED CHICKEN has a formal program to recruit junior military officers as area restaurant managers. "They are accustomed to managing the kind of young, inexperienced people that we employ," said Richard M. Detwiler, director of public affairs.
The Harris County Sheriff's Department in Houston held a job fair at nearby Fort Hood to encourage departing soldiers to apply for guard work at its new jail. "Military people are drug-free, disciplined and used to abiding by rules and regulations," said H.R. Barrera, the department's recruiting officer. 
 Schneider National Carriers, the huge Green Bay, Wisc., trucker, has hired more than 1,500 ex-soldiers as drivers. "An over-the-road trucker has to be away from home a lot, and that's a life style that many soliders are used to," said Thomas E. Vandenberg, the company's general counsel.
Apparently, skills shortages and employment dislocations make even stranger bedfellows than politics. After nearly 20 years of mutual indifference bordering on disrespect -- a legacy of military bungling during the Vietnam War, and of industry's greed-stained handling of environmental issues and defense contract padding -- industry and the Army are again eying each other as allies. "We realized we're hammering the same nail," said Frank P. Doyle, senior vice president of the General Electric Company.
Indeed, while industry girds for a critical shortage of skilled workers, the Army is poised to pour thousands of trained soldiers into the workplace. Over the next few years a Washington-mandated downsizing of the Army will result in the "involuntary separation" -- military talk for firing -- of some 50,000 enlistees and 18,000 officers. More than 300,000 others are expected to take early retirement or otherwise not re-enlist. Cuts to the Navy, Air Force and Marines will be miniscule in comparison.
All told, about 400,000 soldiers will be job hunting. The Army's immediate goal is to help all of them find jobs. And, its long-term goal is to permanently position itself as a great jumping-off point for a career.
"If we prove that we can transition people to civilian life, we'll have an easier time recruiting," said G. Kim Wincup, Assistant Secretary of the Army for manpower.
Thus, the Army has mounted an all-out publicity blitz. It has tapped CBS correspondent Charles Osgood to narrate a promotional film about soldiers. And, two weeks ago it co-hosted, with the Committee for Economic Development, a day-long seminar for business people at which it touted such statistics as the $1.3 billion it spends each year on training, and the fact that 98 percent of Army people have high school diplomas.
"Remember, these are the same people who so dazzled and impressed the world during Desert Storm," Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney told the seminar.
The Army has also set up mechanisms to hook employers up with jobless soldiers. It has sent a book to professors teaching military science to students in the Reserve Officer Training Corps, that lists companies interested in hiring the students.
It also has 61 Army-run transition assistance offices, which offer Army people and their families career counseling and assistance with job-hunting skills. And it has contracted with private companies to run 55 Job Assistance Centers, both fixed and mobile, at various Army bases. In addition to counseling, these centers offer computer access to hiring requirements and names of primary contacts at more than 2,000 companies.
By the end of the year there will be an electronic bulletin board that soldiers and their families can check for news of job fairs or anything else pertinent to job-hunting.
And when all else fails, it is willing to apply subtle pressure to get its people jobs. Global Associates, a technical support company in McLean, Va., recently received a contract to train Army reserve medical units to use new types of equipment. It plans to staff the project with a high proportion of Army people, for three reasons:
"They know Army equipment, they know Army rules -- and we got a strong hint from the wording in the contract about who we should hire to do the training," said Walter Berry, the project's training manager.
 
 
 
THE FITS, AND POSSIBLE MISSES
 On the surface, the fit between Army experience and corporate jobs seems right. Army people have relocated families, run foreign outposts, competed globally, managed diversity, worked with advanced technology, handled joint ventures with foreign partners -- many of the very problems that business now faces. And there is a lot of transferability between the technical training the military provides, and the technical knowhow that industry needs.
But cultural fit is less obvious. Some executives question whether military people, who are trained to give and follow orders, can adapt to private industry, where the trend is to empower workers to do what the customer, not necessarily the boss, wants. "I'm not sure the Army breeds creative thinkers," said the personnel chief of a chemical company, who insisted on anonymity.
Pentagon honchos find that kind of skepticism galling.
"Our soldiers make instantaneous decisions whether to shoot at a tank or not, yet we still have this Beatle Bailey image," said Col. Robert Magruder, executive officer to the assistant secretary of the Army for manpower and reserve affairs.
Lieut. Gen. William H. Reno, deputy chief of staff for personnel, expects that the good publicity reaped by Desert Storm will dissipate that image. "Sergeants in the desert made more decisions each hour than a general makes in a week," he said.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Tulsa;
Schools in U.S. And Russia Set Up An Exchange Plan

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla.

 BODY:
The Russian city of Zelenograd has just about everything an entrepreneurial wannabe could want: an electronics industry ready to convert from military production to consumer products; a work force willing to join a free market economy, even a business school. What it doesn't have is a B-school curriculum that teaches Western marketing and management skills. That is what four delegates from Zelenograd came to the University of Tulsa last weekend to get.
"This university knows American business very well, and its curriculum and syllabus answers all questions on the free market system," said Anatoly Larionov, director of the Zelenograd Business School and a member of the delegation. "That's why we came here." 
 Mr. Larionov said the delegation hopes to establish a Master of Business Administration program in Zelenograd and a student and faculty exchange with Tulsa. He said the schools also plan to serve as mediators between Soviet and American business executives, as Zelenograd and Tulsa work to become sister cities.
The joint B-school venture is the first of its kind involving academic institutions in the United States and the Soviet Union, said Robert Hisrich, a business professor at Tulsa who during the summer signed the agreement to start the project.
"This agreement should establish us as a major player in the U.S. technical system and in the conversion and liberalization of the Soviet economy," said Robert H. Donaldson, president of the university and a specialist in international politics with an emphasis on Soviet and American foreign exchange.
 
Closed to Foreigners in Past
 In a four-day flurry that ended last Sunday, Mr. Larionov and Zelenograd's mayor, or "prefect," Alesky A. Ishchuk, along with two Soviet professors, met with Tulsa's Mayor, Rodger Randle, university administrators and B-school professors, and spoke with business students attending classes in international marketing. The delegates discussed Zelenograd's conversion to a consumer economy and said they hoped to become sufficiently familiar with Western marketing techniques to use them in a city "still continuing its struggle for democracy and peace."
According to Mr. Ishchuk, Zelenograd, a city with 12 microelectronic research centers, was closed to foreigners until December 1990 because of the secrecy of military weapons designed there.
Professor Hisrich and Mr. Larionov said they hope to complete the school curriculum next month; but it will not be put into effect until next fall. Student and faculty exchanges should start in January and student internships in May or June, said Professor Hisrich, who was instrumental in establishing a business school and exchange program last year in Hungary.
Each school will pay the expenses of the visiting students and professors. Mr. Donaldson said the university may also be eligible for several Federal grants.
Besides Mr. Larionov and Mr. Ishchuk, the visiting delegation included Lyubov V. Yakovleva, faculty member of the Institute of Electrical Technology, and Nadezhda I. Emelyanova, department head in the Institute for Professional Technical Education of the Russian Republic. Yelaina Khripkov, a Tulsa professor of Russian studies, served as interpreter.
"We probably will initially give more than we can take, but this will be an incredible cultural experience," Professor Hisrich said.
Mr. Larionov added, "In business, we are only making the first steps."

HEADLINE: Most Arab Capitals Welcome Talks

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Most Arab capitals today welcomed the announcement of peace talks with Israel, marking a significant change in the public Arab attitude toward the nation most Arabs have boycotted for more than 40 years.
The vocal and open support for the peace talks reflected a new balance of power that has emerged after the Persian Gulf war, giving moderate Arab nations the upper hand in this region. 
 The crisis has also produced much bitterness against Arabs, including those in the Palestine Liberation Organization and Jordan, who supported Iraq after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. These sentiments were evident today in commentaries cautioning Palestinians not to waste this opportunity to make peace.
"Israel and the Arabs must put away their historic enmity and resort to the logic of interests," Al Riyadh, the Saudi daily, said today. That echoed the strong support signaled by King Fahd on Monday for the United States effort to convene a peace conference, another sign of Saudi Arabia's newly assertive attitude in Arab politics.
 
Fahd Praises Baker
 In a remarkable departure from the usually discreet style of Saudi diplomacy, at the end of a Cabinet meeting Monday night, King Fahd lavishly praised Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for the diplomatic mission that produced the invitation to a peace conference. The King also stressed that Saudi Arabia would make every effortto insure that the peace talks are successful.
Arab officials in the gulf region have also reiterated over the last few days their willingness to take part in the peace conference and to consider the end of the Arab economic boycott of Israel.
In Amman, Jordanian officials said Jordan today formally accepted the invitation to the conference.
A statement issued after a Cabinet meeting said Jordan had decided "in principle" to accept the invitation, and the Information Minister, Mahmoud al-Sharif, said in a telephone interview that some "procedural matters" remained under discussion. He said Jordan's representatives in the joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation would probably be announced in the coming week.
In Cairo, the Egyptian press quoted President Hosni Mubarak as telling all parties in the Mideast conflict that "peace deserves any concessions that may avoid the shedding of blood, violence and extremism and which allow us to turn to the development of our countries."
Editorial writers went further than ever before in stressing the need for compromise and signaling to the Palestinians in particular that they may have to settle for a great deal less than their stated aims of the past: recovering all the occupied territories taken by Israel in the 1967 war and establishing their independent state.
In the gulf, such comments reflected lingering bitterness at the support given by the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq during the gulf crisis.
"In the past we thought that the Palestinian leadership had its calculations and vision," wrote Ahmad Jarallah, editor of Al Siyassah, a daily in Kuwait. "But now we know that, unfortunately, the Palestinian leadership has regrettably used the Palestinian cause to play politics and interfere in the internal affairs of Arab nations. Therefore, the decision must be in our hands. We will enter the talks and dialogue with Israel whether the Palestinians accept or reject and whether they come or stay away."
Some editorials also cautioned against high expectations and stringent demands by the Arabs in the talks.
"There are those who say it is possible to recover Palestinian lands even if they are the site of Jewish settlements, as indeed it happened in the case of Egypt, which recovered the Sinai and the city of Taba," Al Nadwa, a Saudi daily, commented today, referring to Egypt's peace treaty with Israel in 1979. It said that times had changed, however, and that such expectations might be wrong and should be revised.
"To those people we say that the situation is different and time is to the benefit of the Israelis," Al Nadwa said. Government radio in Oman tonight praised the peace talks, proclaiming that they are the clearest evidence of the Arabs' desire to seek peace and put the Arab-Israeli conflict behind them.
Only Iran, which is a Muslim but non-Arab gulf power, vehemently attacked the talks and condemned any compromise by Palestinians with Israel. The Iranian rejection of peace talks with Israel was the subject of a special conference on "Palestine" that began today in Teheran.
In a speech on Friday, President Hashemi Rafsanjani told a large crowd in Teheran: "The United States is seeking today to save Israel and eradicate Palestinian aspirations by crushing half a century of struggle by the Palestinian people in the name of peace. It is seeking the recognition by Arab and Muslim states of the illegitimate state of Israel."

 
Arafat in Damascus
 BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- Mr. Arafat arrived in Damascus today on his first visit to Syria in three years and held talks with President Hafez al-Assad about the Arab position at the conference.
Syria's state radio, monitored here, said the P.L.O. leader's visit was at the invitation of Mr. Assad, who has been in contact with other Arab leaders regarding the peace talks.
A high-level P.L.O. delegation accompanied Mr. Arafat to Damascus. The delegation may try to mend fences with Syria and Damascus-based radical Palestinian guerrilla factions opposed to Mr. Arafat.
The P.L.O. chairman was expelled from Damascus eight years ago over a policy conflict with Mr. Assad. He has not been back since in a formal capacity, although he was allowed to return in April 1988 for the funeral of a top aide.
