HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Power In Europe

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
France and Germany presented their allies with an unexpected and intriguing proposition last week. Either it means something, or nothing. Whichever, it will have far-reaching repercussions for the future of NATO, West European unity and America's voice in Europe.
The French-German idea is to enlarge their existing joint military brigade as a step toward creating a separate West European army. They propose to house this force under an energized Western European Union, comprised of 9 members of the 12-member European Community. Most importantly, the Western European Union would report to the E.C. and not to NATO, where American power holds sway. 
 If this diplomatic verbiage is real, it would boost efforts for a united Western Europe with a common foreign and defense policy -- and would be the beginning of a premature end for NATO. If this is the usual European security blather, NATO and the U.S. will continue to lead in Europe -- and full West European integration, including defense, will be put off further into the future.
Faceless institutions are boring. But NATO, like many, represents the most profound power. Which is why President Mitterrand of France, Chancellor Kohl of Germany and President Bush have told their diplomats to wink at the French-German initiative and avoid frontal assaults -- for now.
Paris, as always, wants to reduce American influence in Europe. Bonn does not; but as Germans push for West European unity, it will have the effect desired by the French. In any event, both insist that their initiative is fully in keeping with agreed NATO declarations on developing a European security identity.
More, both say it is essential for West European integration. They argue that they cannot reach complete economic unity without political unity, and that political unity requires an independent European defense posture. Besides, both see an inevitable decreasing American presence in Europe with the passing of the cold war and therefore less of a security role for NATO as well.
The U.S. has always supported the drive toward West European unity, but maintains that it can and must proceed without any diminution in NATO's role and authority. Washington says NATO policy calls for a West European military identity midway between NATO and the European Community, not one attached to Europe alone. Otherwise, U.S. power will be diminished in Europe far too soon, something no one wants -- not West or East Europeans, not Soviet republics, not anyone save Paris.
Bush Administration officials believe France is isolated. They also expect the Germans, as is their pattern, to start backpedaling on the military proposal as soon as they see the reaction on the continent. Meantime, the Administration knows it can count on the British to slash away at the French-German proposal, so no need to haul out American guns. No one is more devoted to NATO and the U.S. than London, and no one less eager for full West European unity.
Stripping aside the diplomatic niceties, the issue comes down to this: The French and some Germans believe a uniting West Europe must establish a stronger security identity -- even at the expense of NATO and the U.S. The U.S. believes it is essential to preserve a dominant role for NATO and the U.S. until Europe is genuinely prepared to step in -- even with risks for West European unity.
Washington has the much stronger case, for reasons the French and others prefer to ignore.
Europe is not ready for a diminished NATO. Despite its rhetoric, France will not abandon its independent military identity. Tellingly, Europeans could not get their act together to stop the fighting in Yugoslavia. Most importantly, everyone fears a power vacuum that can be filled only by Germany, however reluctant Germans may be.
And when all the dust settles in the East, the Soviet Union or Russia or several of the largest republics will still have significant military power. Even if all turn out to be benign, Europe will not wish to rely on their good will.
For Soviet republics, for Germans and for all, NATO remains the only group on the horizon that can keep the door closed to renewed militarism and saber-rattling. Only with a strong NATO can Europeans and Americans have the quiet to concentrate on solving their other growing woes.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Minnesota;
Conflict Escalates Over Organization Devoted to Racism

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
Weeks of oral clashes between supporters of a white student union and demonstrators escalated into a brawl involving about 30 people Thursday at the University of Minnesota, while the union's founder was giving an on-campus radio interview, the campus police said.
No one was arrested, but at least three people were injured in the fight, in which tear gas was used by some of the brawlers. Two were treated for head injuries, the campus police said. 
 The fight was the latest confrontation between the union, whose founder, Thomas A. David, a Minneapolis senior majoring in ancient history, has publicly supported racial separatism, and its critics, who consider the group racist, fascist and white supremacist.
Hecklers all but drowned out Mr. David as he spoke at an Oct. 14 campus forum on white supremacy and five days earlier at least 500 university students gathered on campus to condemn the recently formed union.
Conflict began after a controversial Sept. 25 opinions piece by Mr. David, was published in the university's student newspaper, The Minnesota Daily.
Mr. David called for a separation of the races in the United States and wrote that immigrants "come here to suck the blood of hard-working White people, who are forced to pay higher taxes to support these third worlders."
 
'You Don't Feel Safe'
 The essay and Mr. David's thrice-weekly recruiting notices placed as classified ads in the paper have struck a nerve of fear in the minority communities on campus, said several coalition members.
"As an Asian here, you don't feel safe anymore," said Chanthala Insisiengnay, a Minneapolis sophomore in studio arts and a member of the Lao Student Association. "The environment is hostile. We contribute to the economy too. We pay taxes. We work."
In an interview last week, Mr. David said the mission of his organization, which he says has about 10 members and is not registered as a university student group, is to promote the white culture and fight affirmative action and quotas on campus.
"I have no desire to harm the nonwhite races," Mr. David said, "I simply think it would help everyone to separate." That extends to interracial dating and marriage, he said, adding, "I don't want to be a mud race in this country, and I will fight to the death against that."
The university has taken no official stance on the White Student Union, said Marvalene S. Hughes, vice president for student affairs. "To the extent that we can protect First Amendment rights to one group, we will protect the First Amendment rights to all groups," Mrs. Hughes said.
But the university president, Nils Hasselmo, speaking at a Board of Regents meeting on Oct. 11, called on the university community to join continuing efforts to combat racism.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Amherst;
'Need-Blind' Policy On Admissions Is Reconsidered

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
The president of Amherst College, Peter R. Pouncey, and Jane E. Reynolds, dean of admissions, met last week with about 100 students, faculty members and administrators to discuss changing the college's admission and financial aid policies because of budget deficits.
The college officials said they were responding to growing campus concern over the future of "need-blind" admissions and the way financial aid policy decisions are made. Under the need-blind policy, an applicant is considered for admissions without regard for whether he or she can pay. Those accepted who cannot afford the fees are then given financial aid based on need. 
 President Pouncy said the policy is in jeopardy as a result of the college's efforts to increase cultural and socio-economic diversity in the student body.
"This is a problem we invited," he said. "We made a very determined effort to broaden the base of the school, and students who can't afford Amherst on their family incomes make up 90 percent of America."
 
$21,290 a Year
 The college's comprehensive fee, including tuition, room and board, is currently $21,290 for an academic year. Forty-six percent of Amherst students now receive need-based aid from the college, which will spend $8.5 million in scholarship grants to students this academic year.
Mr. Pouncey outlined two possible alternatives to the need-blind process. Financial aid awards, he said, could be "watered down" so that students would receive less scholarship money, which they do not repay, and be forced to take larger loans.
Or, he said, Amherst could admit students on a need-blind basis until the financial aid runs out. At that point, he said, the admissions staff would begin looking at applicants on the waiting list and admit only those who could pay their own way.
In an interview, Mr. Pouncey said that the college could insure that there would be enough money to cover students on the acceptance list by shortening it. That would lengthen the waiting list and mean that fewer acceptance letters would go out in April.
"Is it conceivable that someone on the wait list would be rejected because he had no money? Yes," Mr. Pouncey said. "And is it also conceivable that someone on the wait list would be accepted because he or she was fee-paying? Yes."
He added that since "all of this is presumably played out honestly and in a forthright manner," people on the waiting list with little demonstrated need could rescind their request for financial aid.
 
Worried About Elitism
 Jorge Armenteros, a junior from San Juan, P.R., majoring in political science, said he worries that either alternative would be the start of a larger movement back "toward a more elitist, white, Anglo-Saxon college." Mr. Armentero said, however, that he favored a policy in which all students on financial aid "share the burden equitably."
By contrast, Megan Carr, a junior in history from Toledo, Ohio, said that changing financial aid packages would be less desirable than using a longer waiting list. But she said, "The concept is kind of disgusting that you can buy your way off the wait list."
Last week's meeting was a response to a request from the Financial Aid Coalition, which comprises 14 different student groups concerned with the future of admissions policies and financial aid at Amherst.
"It's the college's responsibility to both inform students about how these decisions are made and have a dialogue with students," said Anthony E. Wright, a junior in English and sociology from the Bronx and a coalition organizer. "I think that's happening now."
 
Budgetary Problems
 Some students said they saw the meeting as a counterweight to an Oct. 3 meeting between trustees and students, about 150 of whom showed up. Billed as an informal gathering, the meeting became an often-antagonistic discussion in which students accused the administration of failing to inform them about financial aid issues.
Last week, Mr. Pouncey said Amherst must decide on a new financial aid policy by January, when a cap will be placed on what has become a runaway part of the budget; the new policy would effect freshmen entering in 1992. Financial aid increased 32 percent over the last three years, Mr. Pouncey said. By contrast, total expenditures, not including financial aid, rose only 1.7 percent in the same period.
Ms. Reynolds acknowledged that changes in financial aid policies could affect how prospective students perceive Amherst.
"If you are a student from a lower socio-economic background," she said in an interview, "and you're reading articles or have heard through the pipeline that Amherst has changed its financial aid policy and has no resources, you may take yourself out of the competition even before it starts, thinking that Amherst has no money for you." She added, "That is not true and that is a perception we have to guard against."

HEADLINE: HARASSMENT CASES CAN GO UNNOTICED

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Federal law requires companies to have policies prohibiting sexual harassment, but employers that vigorously try to enforce their own rules are few and far between, experts say.
The policies at many companies lack specifics as to what behavior is offensive, or what remedies are available. Some companies train and educate only their top managers, rather than the entire work forces. 
 "It's the unique company that takes it seriously enough to spend time and money to train their work force to let them know about the policy, instead of just tacking it to a bulletin board," said K. C. Wagner, a consultant to businesses on sexual harassment in Oakland, Calif.
The Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court have greatly intensified the debate on this difficult issue.
 
Offensive Behavior Persists
 Even at the companies with the strongest programs, those with long-established policies on sexual harassment and elaborate procedures and strict penalties to deal with it, offensive behavior continues.
It is striking that although such cases often come down to one person's word against another's, many companies with strong programs find that virtually all complaints have merit.
For example, A.T.& T., which has won considerable respect for its policies, says 19 of every 20 complaints received are valid.
And at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, Edward S. Bardzik, senior consultant for diversity education, said: "Except for where there has been a broken office romance, we get very few, if any, complaints that don't have at least some merit. Most women who come forward are feeling something very uncomfortable in the environment at a minimum and often more than that."
Companies with tough policies on sexual harassment say morale and productivity are both improvong. At the same time, the companies say they are addressing complaints before these develop into litigation.
Why aren't the programs at the tougher companies more successful in eliminating sexual harassment?
The social stigma attached to the subject inhibits discussion, investigation and elimination of the problem, consultants and corporate executives say. Until society in general understands and rejects sexual harassment, corporations will not eradicate it.
Dr. Virginia A. Sadock, director of New York Medical Center's Program in Human Sexuality, referring to the Senate committee's proceedings, said, "As the hearings demonstrate, in general in our society, it is not the behavior of the harasser that has been questioned but that of the victim."
To be sure, women in the work place are rarely subjected to the sort of overt sexual harassment confronted by women miners when they first entered the mines 20 years ago. Like their male colleagues, they were stripped down and slathered in axle grease in a hazing ritual. Unlike the men, they were tied spread-eagled to wooden supports.
But neither is sexual harassment now merely a matter of misinterpreted flirtations or off-color jokes. Nude pinups of women remain in precinct locker rooms and on Wall Street trading floors and more than one female professional can recall a male supervisor who promised advancement and perquisites in exchange for sexual favors.
Some people simply live in the dark ages. When Colleen McMahon, a partner at the New York law firm of Paul Weiss, Rifkin, Wharton & Garrison, began advising a leading investment bank about sexual harassment, she was struck by the difficulty the officer in charge of the program had in convincing bank officers that pictures of naked women festooning the trading desks were inappropriate.
The difficult economic environment is preoccupying many companies these days. Dr. Baila Zeitz, one of the authors of "The Best Companies for Women," a 1988 book that evaluated companies' commitments to halting sexual harassment, said she strongly suspected that fewer companies today were concerned about detailed policies and procedures on sexual harassment.
"Corporations are more concerned about putting out fires now because of the changes in the economy that have occurred since my research in 1986, 1987 and 1988," she said. "They're not concerned with the niceties as much."
She and most other experts on sexual harassment in the work place said one important element of any corporate program is a clear commitment from the most senior levels of management. On Oct. 11, as Anita F. Hill was testifying on the Thomas nomination, A.T.& T.'s chairman and chief executive, Robert E. Allen, sent a message into his employee's computers, reiterating the company's lengthy, very specific policy forbidding sexual harassment and spelling out the penalties -- including "dismissal" and "personal legal and financial liability."
 
Afraid of Discussion
 Consultants say such a response was uncommon even after the hearings. Most executives keep the issue of sexual harassment at arms length, afraid that any discussion will feed the perception that harassment is pervasive.
One of the most highly regarded programs for dealing with sexual harassment is at Du Pont, which provides a telephone hotline that employees can use to report incidents and discuss options for redress anonymously.
About 65,000 of Du Pont's 100,000 American employees have participated in half-day training programs that deal with preventing sexual harassment and discrimination. Since the program began in 1988, the company has handled more cases internally and fewer in the courts.
Du Pont employees are told to report harassment complaints to any supervisor or manager, who is obligated to take prompt action. If an employee's accusations warrant an investigation, the company will interview other employees and the person accused.
In 1986, the Supreme Court clarified its definition of sexual harassment to include subtle forms of intimidation -- lingering, intimate touches, repeated sexual innuendo or comments about aspects of a person's physique -- that can create a "hostile environment."
That ruling gives to victims of sexual harassment a role in establishing boundaries. The less blatantly offensive the behavior is, the more responsibility the recipient has to speak out against it, said Susan L. Webb, a consultant with Pacific Resource Development Group Inc. in Seattle.
"Nobody has to tell their supervisor, 'Please don't tell me stories about bestiality and group rape,' because he should know better," she said. "But telling someone, 'Please don't call me Babe; my name is Susan,' helps clarify your feelings about a situation that might make some uncomfortable."
The courts themselves are beginning to try to illuminate the boundaries around offensive behavior. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, has ruled that any verbal or physical behavior that a "reasonable woman" would regard as offensive is covered by the law. The judge writing the opinion noted, "Conduct that many men consider unobjectionable may offend many women."
Still, many lawyers for plaintiffs and women's groups note that corporate policies against sexual harassment are intended as much to protect the company as to protect victims.
 
Element of Self-Interest
 "While corporations claim to react sensitively and promptly to these sorts of complaints, their sensitivity is often not to the victim," said Mitchell Green of King & Green, the San Francisco law firm that successfully pressed a sexual harassment case against the the Securities and Exchange Commission. "Instead it's a sensitivity to protecting their rear if the employee does go forward with a lawsuit."
Lawyers who advise companies on their sexual harassment policies contend that the element of self-interest insures that companies will take great care to address complaints. "Given the liability that a company can incur if it doesn't protect the secretary who complains that her boss is harassing her, those interests are one and the same," said Ms. McMahon of Paul Weiss.
Some women involved in harassment cases see it differently. One woman executive represented by King & Green has filed a lawsuit in Federal Court in New York against the subsidiary of one of the country's largest banks, charging in part that it failed to address the complaints she filed.
The woman, who insisted on anonymity, said an executive solicited sexual favors, threatening that he would ruin her career if she did not comply.
She decided to report the incident "just to get it on the record," but asked the company not to investigate.
Soon after she filed her report, her career degenerated into a succession of demotions, denied transfers and smaller bonuses. In August 1990, her job was ended.
"My advice to a young woman would be not to come forward," she said. "You will be labeled a troublemaker, you will be persecuted, your career will be ruined."
 
 
AN EXPLICIT POLICY TOWARD HARRASSMENT

 
A.T. & T.'s sexual-harassment policy, considered by experts to be well-written and specific.
 "A.T. & T.'s sexual-harassment policy prohibits sexual harassment in the workplace, whether committed by supervisory or non-supervisory personnel. Specifically, no supervisor shall threaten to insinuate, either explicitly or implicity, that an employee's submission to or rejection of sexual advances will in any way influence any personnel decision regarding that employee's employment, wages, advancement, assigned duties, shifts, or any other condition of employment or career development.
 "Other sexually harassing conduct in the workplace that may create an offensive work environment, whether it be in the form of physical or verbal harassment, and regardless of whether committed by supervisor or non-supervisory personnel, is also prohibited. This includes, but is not limited to, repeated offensive or unwelcome sexual flirtations, advances, propositions, continual or repeated verbal abuse of a sexual nature, graphic verbal commentaries about an individual's body; sexually degrading words used to describe an individual; and the display in the workplace of sexually suggestive objects or pictures.
 "Sexual harassment in the workplace by any employee will result in disciplinary action up to and including dismissal and may lead to personal legal and financial liability. Employeess are encourage to avail themselves of A.T. & T.'s internal Equal Opportunity complaint procedure if they are confronted with sexual harassment or any prohibited form of harassment. Such internal complaints will be investigated promptly, and corrective action will be taken where allegations are verified. No employee will suffer retaliation or intimidation as a result of using the internal complaint procedure.
 -- Robert E. Allen, chairman

CORRECTION-DATE: October 22, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Sunday about sexual harassment in the workplace misstated the Federal law regarding harassment. Although the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission strongly urges all companies to have policies against sexual harassment, there is no Federal law requiring them.

HEADLINE: Film Maker's Work Is Imbued With Look and Feel of New Jersey

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
A STAR-CROSSED romance between two teen-agers -- the daughter of a Jewish doctor and the son of an Italian sanitation worker -- who meet in a Trenton high school. A bittersweet reunion of seven 1960's radicals who were on their way to march on the Pentagon when they were arrested in Secaucus. A compassionate look at Shoeless Joe Jackson, one of the eight Chicago White Sox who threw the 1919 World Series and wound up, unrecognized, in the minor leagues in Hoboken.
Movie buffs are bound to get the titles at once -- "Baby, It's You," "Return of the Secaucus Seven," "Eight Men Out" -- and identify the writer and director, John Sayles, whose recently released exploration of contemporary urban blight, "City of Hope," takes place in a hypothetical Hudson City. 
 No matter their actual locations, most of the seven films that bear the imprint of Mr. Sayles, who was been acclaimed as "the godfather of independent film makers in this country," are permeated with the look and feel of New Jersey.
Even though "City of Hope" was shot in Cincinnati ("too expensive and too congested" to do it in New Jersey, according to the film's publicity materials), it is presumed to reflect Hoboken, where Mr. Sayles owns a home. The movie, though, by extension, is intended to represent the problems and politics of change that he has observed in small cities all over, especially Schenectady, where he grew up, and Atlanta and East Boston where he later lived.
"You see the links," Mr. Sayles said. "And when you think of New Jersey, you think of small cities with a melting-pot tradition, without major league baseball teams and where the media doesn't play that big a role. Incidents here don't become national news. I feel like the press is a day or two behind things. In New York, the minute the girl is chained up, they're in the living room -- and it comes out that day. So, in a way, when a city in New Jersey is on the screen, it almost automatically says to people, 'Oh, this isn't Chicago or L.A. and we're not renaming New York City.' But here -- in Jersey City and in Trenton and in Camden and in Newark -- we've got all the problems of a big city, without the economic base."
By interweaving relationships among a multiplicity of characters with conflicting agendas, "City of Hope" is a search for morality in a chaotic, crumbling community. Although the title is but once mentioned by a fading representative of a white establishment in decline -- "the second most indictable mayor in the state" -- during a fund-raising dinner, his speech is interrupted by a black city councilman who bursts in, leading a constituency that has joined him once he has compromised his ideals.
Intimations of real hope suffuse Mr. Sayles's epic narrative. A police officer is incorruptible. A young mugger is contrite. But a reconciliation scene between a corrupted father and his rebel son turns into a death scene, and in an ambiguous, absurdist-like ending, a homeless schizophrenic man wails for help in the night. Who will hear him? Who would listen? In his most ambitious film, Mr. Sayles, characteristically, tempers sleaze with sentiment, mixes polemics with melodramatics and illuminates grimness. There is hope and there is no hope. Nothing is simple, or simplistic.
 
Hopes Is in the Vision
 Hope is operative in Mr. Sayles's vision. Esperanza (the Spanish word for hope) is the name of his production company, and one of the two plays he has written is called "New Hope for the Dead." "The movie's working title in my head was 'Sex, Lies and Urban Renewal, ' " Mr. Sayles said, mentioning a variation of "the best title I ever heard -- even if the movie wasn't good, I'd go see it."
But "City of Hope" finally came out of the mayor's speech and, he said, "I thought it's true and ironic at the same time; a lot of phrases sound most cynical coming out of a politician's mouth because they lack meaning -- and the hope lies somewhere between the believers and the cynics."
"I see hope occasionally coming from the ground up," Mr. Sayles said. "I don't see it coming from the top down right now. I really feel a resurgence of tribalism in cities. People who used to be able to find some kind of coalition are finding they get their power from their own group, and people who are also finding a way to rise above their own little tribe. You can't expect help from above, whether it's religion or the Federal Government, and nobody's going to fall out a spaceship. But on the next block, that's where to look for it at least."
Mr. Sayles's block is "on the bus side" of Hoboken, where he has been living in a three-story brownstone for 12 years, with Maggie Renzi, co-producer of his films and actress in some, and assorted "revolving roommates who find it too tough or too expensive to stay in New York."
 
Spends One-Third of Time in Hoboken
 To get to his New York office ("I've been there twice"), or to the big studios rented for editing and sound mixing, he takes the No. 126 bus. "It used to be the 63 until inflation came," he said. "If I'm on the other end of town, I take the PATH."
Hoboken, where Mr. Sayles now figures he spends one-third of his time when he is not "on the road or retreating to his house in upstate New York," has been his alternative to the "stressful and assaultive" life in New York, which he dismisses.
"Here, there's a little more sharing of power, even if it's just the power to make noise," he said. "I see community organizations and manage to do some cohesive things, and I have seen some kind of median ground between the real-estate blitz that was forcing people out of their apartments. That changes a real tight neighborhood, the idea that you, or your kids, can't afford to live there anymore. But the kind of Oklahoma land rush that was happening seven or eight years ago has slowed down. So it's changed, but we still have the old-fashioned Hoboken nights and the yuppies. "
"And people here are better informed about what's going on and they have a say, so that things -- like developing the waterfront and where are we going to park -- are not left in the hands of one or two politicians or developers or the school board," Mr. Sayles continued. "And in the one mile square city, things are more manageable. Stuff gets out in the air quicker." Mr. Sayles and Ms. Renzi are on the board of advisers of the Hoboken Renegade Company.
 
A Commitment to Communities
 In talking about his concerns -- estrangement and, a running theme in his films, a commitment to communities -- in his life and in his art -- Mr. Sayles finds political involvement and personal relationships "inextricable." "Of people we know, we were the first to move to Hoboken and then a lot of our friends moved in, but as they had kids, they moved farther out into Jersey," he said. "The big thing I see happening -- and it's reflected in the movie is that as ethnic groups move in and out, the people who are sending their kids to school are not represented among the teachers, who live in the suburbs and they're still Irish and American and they're teaching black, and Hispanic and Asian kids and there aren't that many black and Hispanic and Asian teachers. Like it or not, there's a lack of accountability there. " he said.
Assimilation ("What do you give up when you join a larger group?") provides another connection among his films. And throughout his films, one senses a renewal of innocence and a need to reclaim the past, as exemplified in "Brother From Another Planet," wherein a black, mute, but all-seeing angelic extraterrestrial lands in Harlem with an eye on the drug scene. And in "Baby, It's You," Mr. Sayles made the comment, "High school is the last bastion of democracy."
And then there are his novels. The third, "Los Gusanos (The Worms)," which concerns Cuban liberation, was published in June, marking him as an independent novelist as well. He acted as his own agent, stipulated that no editorial changes, or movie sale -- "I don't want to complain about someone else's crummy movie version" -- would take place, and he got a six-figure advance. And the assorted short stories (some anthologized in "The Anarchists' Convention"). And the early screenplays for other directors ("Alligator," "The Howling"). And the first episodes of a television series. ("Shannon's Deal").
"Secaucus Seven," which was made in 25 days for $60,000 in 1978 and grossed several million, was his first venture as an independent film maker. "City of Hope" took five weeks and cost $3.1 million. "I've been able to keep my overhead low enough so I don't have to take jobs to eat," Mr. Sayles said.
 
'I Do Stuff I'm Interested In'
 His comment on the extraordinary diversity of his work is simply, "I do stuff that I'm interested in and I'm interested in a lot of stuff, but I'm not interested in movies that are just about who shot who; I'm interested in movies that are about who shot who and why."
Leave the comments about the remarkable authenticity of "City of Hope" to the critics. "The shift of accents alone is dizzying," noted one; another referred to "ear-perfect conversations."
"I don't go out to do research," Mr. Sayles said. "I just live and pay attention and that stuff gets into my work. And when you work for yourself, that's not work."
Work or not, it has been intensive. "Matewan," a highly praised film that was released in August 1987, was about a 1920 coal miner massacre in West Virginia, and "Thinking in Pictures," which was published in November 1987, was his chronicle about the making of "Matewan."
His work has been acknowledged with various prizes for short stories and the "Secaucus" screenplay, capped by the John D. and Catherine T. McArthur Foundation "genius" award at 32. "I'm an ex-genius," he said. Which does not speak of Mr. Sayles's appearances in most of his films. "I tried to play the characters who come in and do their damage and then leave," he said. "There's no time to write their history if I'm directing." An actor before he was a writer or director, Mr. Sayles did a short summer stint as Tom in the 'Glass Menagerie" in the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts several years ago, opposite Joanne Woodward and Karen Allen, with Paul Newman directing.
 
'Hardest Thing to Write Well'
 He admits that his plays are the "hardest thing to write well."
"Even if you direct your own play, the actors carry the ball," he said. "You can't freeze it in time."
Mr. Sayles, who became 41 last month, may not yet have crossed over from cult to mass celebrityhood. "And my terms of being successful don't even show up on the radar of a major studio," he said. "What you hope is there's a track record that you build up and people say, 'Oh, this guy makes good movies.' "
"And I can go to the movies and stand on line, and nobody recognizes me, and that's fine," he said. "The Secaucus Mall is my local theater, but most of the movies I've written and directed don't go there, -- most of them made at least half their money -- only 'Eight Men Out,' which was released by Orion, did.
"But I do what I want and I live where I want, and one of the reasons I choose to live right here in a real house is that this can still exist as a fairly diverse community. It hasn't turned into a boutique."

HEADLINE: Shift in Status for Architects and Designers

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
WHO'S who in the design field? For years, the distinction between interior decorators, interior designers and architects who do space planning has been blurred. But now a new state law, which requires interior designers to take a tough test for state certification, should help the public distinguish the work of professional interior designers from that of self-styled decorators.
"It's a very important distinction," said Elizabeth A. Dresher, who graduated from college with a degree in interior design. "Until now, anyone, the owner of a wallpaper store, someone who has had no training at all, could call themselves an interior designer. But there is more to interior design than picking out wallpapers and fabrics." 
 Ms. Dresher, who is the senior designer at Planned Expansion Group, an architectural and design firm in White Plains, said planning interior space involves such things as knowledge of building codes and fire exits. "The new law will give academically trained interior designers credibility," Ms. Dresher said.
In order to become certified by the state, designers, even those with years of experience, will be required to pass two stiff examinations: a design qualifying exam and a test on state fire, safety and building codes. A state board for interior design will be appointed by the Board of Regents.
 
Known as the LaValle-Koppell Bill
 Yet few Westchester architects are in favor of the LaValle-Koppell bill, as it is referred to.
"When it was presented in its original form three years ago, we lobbied strongly against it," said John P. Sullivan, president-elect of the Westchester/Mid-Hudson Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, who has his office in Valhalla.
"It was worded in such a way that it would have permitted designers to stamp drawings that would be accepted by building departments without a review by an architect or an engineer, which we thought was absolutely dangerous," Mr. Sullivan said. "We negotiated back and forth and finally the language of the bill was made a little clearer. However, as architects, we still feel the bill gives these interior designers too much responsibility for design. The authors of the bill claim it is for the welfare of the public, but we feel public safety is not foremost, as the bill ignores aspects of interior construction which should be solely the province of the architect."
The law defines the type of interior construction that designers can do as "not materially related or materially affecting the building's system." That definition is too vague, Mr. Sullivan said.
"You may have individuals without the necessary training opening up interior space with no idea how it will affect the structure of the building," he said.
 
Shortcomings of the Law Cited
 Joseph Kiel, who has been an architect for 40 years and now has a practice in Hartsdale, agreed with Mr. Sullivan. Mr. Kiel added that he thought the law did not go far enough.
"It's supposed to be for the protection of the public, yet anyone can still call themselves a decorator," Mr. Kiel said.
"It doesn't restrict the uncertified from going into business," he added, "and it doesn't prevent those untrained, self-styled decorators from the sleazy practice of rubber-stamping, which is getting an architect to stamp their drawings."
Calling rubber-stamping a disgrace, Mr. Sullivan said, "Our chapter is getting close to procedures that when we put them into effect will carefully monitor and eliminate the rubber-stamp practice, which we deplore," he said.
Mr. Kiel also said the bill doesn't require designers to carry malpractice insurance.
"The state insists that architects have it," Mr. Kiel said, "and if designers are allowed to plan space, they should be required to have it, too."
Matthew E. Kroin is an architect for and president of the Planned Expansion Group, which he said is a firm that specializes in corporate interior architecture and development of retail stores shopping centers. He said the competition for interior-design assignments has exacerbated the friction between architects and designers.
 
Collaboration Is Favored
 "Times are tough; building is way down," Mr. Kroin said. "Given the state of the economy and the recession, it's understandable that architects are anxious to protect every bit of their turf. But I strongly believe that collaboration between the two disciplines benefits both.
"I know it has worked for us, because for 15 years that's how we have run our practice. We have 25 people on staff, and four of them are interior designers who work as equal members of a team with architects on our space-design projects. The interior-design people have training that architects don't have and complement one another."
Mayda Horizny, an architect on Mr. Kroin's staff, said she thought certification would put interior designers "on a better footing with other professionals."
"I see it as a chance for improving the working environment," Ms. Horizny said. "It may change the way people regard interior design, which I think of now as a field dominated by women, secondary to architecture -- a field they perceive as dominated by men. But there are many designers who are men and many women like myself who are architects. We all complement one another."
Nancy W. Clark, head of the Clark Design Group in Rye, has been an interior designer for 32 years. She said that she not only welcomed certification but also lobbied hard for it to become law.
"I want to be accredited and be known as a qualified professional, which I am," Mrs. Clark said. "I have a degree in interior design from Cornell University, and I have completed large projects such as planning the executive offices for General Mills in Minneapolis and doing the offices of various General Electric facilities around the country."
Certification, Mrs. Clark said, will ultimately benefit the public. "In the past we've all been lumped together," she said. "Designers, decorators and people who own retail stores have been put in the same category. People don't know who to hire for design jobs."
 
Protecting a Market
 In recent years, Mrs. Clark said, architects began making a profit from interior-design work.
"Part of the problem is they don't want to lose that market, especially today," she said. "But I work a lot with architects, and I don't think the new law will change that. I will continue to do so."
Jacqueline Cutler, an interior designer in Scarsdale who has been in business for seven years, said she was in favor of the bill because it elevates designers by giving professional standing to those who pass the test.
"I fully intend to take the exam," Ms. Cutler said. "I majored in interior design at Syracuse University, and I want a professional accreditation. I certainly don't think I'm going to take any work away from architects," she added. "I don't see any conflict, since I specialize in residential work, making use of antiques."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Matthew E. Kroin, an architect who is president of Planned Expansion Group, stresses collaboration between the two design disciplines involved in his firm's projects. With him is Mayda C. Horizny, seated, an architect, and Elizabeth A. Dresher, interior designer, as they reviewed a building design at the firm's offices in White Plains. (Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Yonkers Chamber Forms A Political Action Group

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
STEPPING boldly into the election fray, this city's Chamber of Commerce last month cast aside a 98-year tradition of watching from the sidelines and formed a political action committee. Tomorrow, the business organization's new PAC is to announce endorsements for mayor and Council members.
"There has been a feeling that we've been spectators for too long," said Thomas J. Caramadre, president of the 700-member chamber and secretary of the PAC. "The time has come for us to be players." 
 Prompted by what many consider to be the most important city election in a half-century, the chamber's board of directors voted in early September to form the nine-member PAC to act aggressively by interviewing and endorsing candidates and to solicit campaign funds for its choices.
With this move, the Yonkers chamber becomes the first chamber in the county to take an active role in campaign politics. In the state, only chambers in some of the larger cities or regions -- Syracuse, Rochester, Buffalo, New York City and the Nassau-Suffolk County area, for example -- have PAC's.
 
Reflects a Growing Trend
 Nationwide, however, the new role adopted by the Yonkers chamber reflects a growing trend, officials report. Increasingly, business organizations are seeking political involvement, evaluating candidates and contributing to campaign funds, said Michael J. Carman, senior legislative affairs manager for the eastern division of the United States Chamber of Commerce in Manhattan.
"The trend among chambers that are worth their salt is not to bury their heads in the sand," Mr. Carman said. "The time for the business community not to be involved is over."
Because issues such as child care, job opportunities, economic development and the environment involve the business community, Mr. Carman said, chambers should have more influence in the political process.
For the Yonkers chamber, the impetus to form a PAC was generated by a structural change in the city's government. The city manager position, created 50 years ago, is being eliminated, and many of the duties will be taken over by the newly elected mayor, who will serve for four years instead of two.
"What happens in November will affect Yonkers until 1995," Mr. Caramadre said. "The issue of our forming a PAC has been under consideration for 10 years. This year, though, we decided the time was right."
 
Questionnaires for Candidates
 After voting 15 to 0, with one abstention, to form the PAC, the chamber proceeded to mail a 13-item questionnaire to 24 candidates -- four running for mayor, four for Council president and 16 for the six City Council seats.
The nominees were asked their opinions on a range of subjects, including the city's income-tax surcharge, its real estate transfer tax, the formation of an independent school district, a citywide reassessment of property, the role of the State Emergency Financial Control Board and the adequacy of police and fire protection.
The candidates were also asked what they would do to increase economic and industrial development efforts in Yonkers, how they would rate the image of the city and what role they saw for the chamber in government. Mayoral candidates were asked what changes they would make, if elected, under the new strong-mayor form of government.
After the questionnaires were returned to the chamber, candidates were interviewed for 45 minutes each by members of the PAC. The proceedings were taped, because not all members of the PAC were present for all interviews.
While the response to the chamber's new political involvement has been "generally very positive," Mr. Caramadre said, some people have expressed skepticism, questioning what might happen if the chamber backed a losing candidate.
 
'Work to Develop a Relationship'
 "If a candidate who was not our choice wins, we will work to develop a relationship," the chamber's president said. "There doesn't need to be any hostility. But, at the very least, people seeking public office should know what the business community needs and expects from them."
Three of the four mayoral candidates in the November election agreed that the victor would have to be attentive to the needs of the now politically active chamber, even if the new city leader were not endorsed by the PAC.
Angelo R. Martinelli, a member of the chamber of commerce and a former Mayor of Yonkers for six terms, who is running as an independent, said: "Up to now, the chamber hasn't been taken seriously. With a PAC, the organization has clout."
Peter A. Chema, majority leader of the City Council who is running as the Republican-Conservative candidate, said he admired the chamber's new level of commitment but acknowledged that the PAC was "a risky venture." He said, "As far as I know, most chambers remain apolitical."
And State Assemblyman Terence M. Zaleski, a Democrat, said he would be "disappointed but not crestfallen" if he failed to win the PAC's endorsement. Whoever wins the election, he added, should develop an effective working relationship with the business community.
 
5 Republicans, 2 Democrats
 Thomas Byrne, the Right-to-Life Party candidate for mayor, did not respond to the questionnaire and was not interviewed by the PAC.
Of the PAC's nine members, five are Republicans: John Kulacz, an accountant; Eben Walker, president of a graphite metalizing company; John Fazio, president of a travel agency; Andrew Carlin, a lawyer, and Dominick Carbone, vice president of Sarah Lawrence College and chairman of the PAC.
Two are Democrats: Barbara Soares, owner of a design company, and Patricia Sadler, a director of the local Y.W.C.A.
Two members are independents: Howard Berman, a lawyer, and Edith Klein, vice president of a paper-products concern.
"We picked members who are representative," Mr. Caramadre said. "The fact is that among business people, there are generally more Republicans."
The members were selected by Mrs. Killilea and approved by the chamber's board of directors. Some PAC members will serve for one year, others for two, with the PAC electing new members as terms expire. The staggered terms are expected to permit continuity when new members are appointed.
 
Some Concern Over Labels
 Reservations about being viewed as partisan have deterred other chambers from forming or activating PAC's. In White Plains, the 3,000-member Westchester County Chamber of Commerce has had a PAC structurally in place for two years but has chosen not to use it, said Harold E. Vogt, the organization's president and chief executive officer.
"There is some concern that we would be labeled a Republican, Democrat, independent or Liberal organization, and we don't want that," Mr. Vogt said. "We want our group to be issue oriented without any party affiliation."
With that in mind, Mr. Vogt said, his organization chose not to activate the PAC to raise campaign funds for candidates. "We keep members apprised of pending legislation," he said. "We represent our views to officeholders. And we feel that is the level of involvement that is appropriate at this time."
According to Federal law, chambers are incorporated, tax-exempt organizations and are forbidden by the Internal Revenue Service from raising political funds, unless they establish a PAC.
 
Up to $5,000 a Year
 Under state law, businesses and corporations may contribute up to $5,000 a year to a PAC, whereas there is no cap on individual donations, said Daniel B. Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York State, an umbrella organization in Albany for business groups and chambers.
The Yonkers Chamber of Commerce PAC is asking for minimum donations of $50, to be given to the endorsed candidates' campaign funds. The chamber, as an association and not a corporation, needed only to change its bylaws in order to establish the PAC.
An advantage of making political contributions through a PAC, Mr. Caramadre said, is anonymity. Campaign contributions over $99 are published in newspapers. But if a company or an individual gives the money to a PAC, only the amount the committee gave will be listed.
Robert J. Galterio, a member of the chamber's board of directors who voted for the PAC, said he had "some initial concerns" about the organization's venturing into new fund-raising activities. "My fear," he said, "was that the PAC would be soliciting funds from the same people we ask to help support our other endeavors. You can't keep going to the well. Enough is enough. This is not the greatest of times as it is."
 
Expansion Is Planned
 Early last week, about $2,000 in donations to the PAC had been received. Mr. Caramadre suggested that the amount might increase significantly once the endorsements were announced.

HEADLINE: Now Playing: Real Life, the Movie

BYLINE: By NEAL GABLER; Neal Gabler, the author of "An Empire of Their Own: How the Jews Invented Hollywood," is at work on a biography of Walter Winchell.

 BODY:
Fade in on New York Harbor off The Battery on a muggy June day. A young man jumps from a launch into the roiling water and disappears beneath the surface. Within seconds divers in scuba gear plunge in after him. Boats converge on the scene. A helicopter hovers overhead. But the man never surfaces.
Fade in on five toughs rampaging down the mean streets of Washington one night. The gang encircles a dazed man. One of them rears back and unleashes a savage punch. The victim falls stiffly, like a tree being felled. 
 Fade in on a snowy slope in fashionable Aspen. We see two figures in ski parkas silhouetted against the sky: a man and a woman. Suddenly, another woman appears. She wheels on the first woman and hisses, "Stay away from my husband!"
These are all scenes from recent movies, but you wouldn't have seen any of them at your local theater. The first was a rescue drill conducted by the New York Harbor Police; according to some accounts, the policeman playing the victim had foregone a life jacket to make the rescue look more authentic for a German television crew shooting the action. The young man drowned. The second was a video made by a gang of Washington youths during a so-called wilding. And the third was the famous confrontation on the slopes between Ivana Trump and Marla Maples. The reason you wouldn't have seen any of these scenes at your local theater is that they were playing on a different kind of screen. These movies were playing on the screen of life.
Reality has always had a way of challenging fiction and frequently outflanking it. But by the "screen of life" I mean something much more self-consciously theatrical than chance invention. I mean that life itself is gradually being transformed into a medium all its own like television, radio and print. And we are becoming both performance artists in and audiences for a grand, ongoing entertainment that is often richer, more complex and more compelling than anything in the conventional media. Or, as Philip Roth put it in his story "On the Air": "What if the world is some kind of -- of show! . . . What if we are all only talent assembled by the Great Talent Scout Up Above! The Great Show of Life! Starring Everybody! Suppose entertainment is the Purpose of Life!"
Philip Roth was writing more than 20 years ago, but the evidence has steadily mounted ever since that politics, religion, news, education, warfare, crime, everything are really branches of, well, call it show biz. Everywhere the fabricated, the inauthentic and the theatrical have gradually driven out the natural, the genuine and the spontaneous until there is no distinction between real life and stagecraft. In fact, one could argue that the theatricalization of American life is the major cultural transformation of this century. Devoured by artifice, life is a movie.
 
Reality Management
Enter Fantasy, Riding a TV Set
 It is difficult to pinpoint precisely when the process began. Surely as soon as America first emerged as a mass industrial society there were individuals who saw no reason to let the vagaries of life govern when one could orchestrate life to one's benefit. Soon public relations experts were manufacturing events and manipulating reality, and over the decades these small contrivances, established on a thousand fronts from business to news to politics, metastasized. Before long everyone in public life had a P.R. rep and everything in public life seemed the product of premeditation.
It was this sort of image-mongering and reality management that the historian Daniel Boorstin deplored in his path-breaking 1961 study "The Image: A Guide to Pseudo-Events in America." For Mr. Boorstin, Americans increasingly lived in a "world where fantasy is more real than reality." And he warned, "We risk being the first people in history to have been able to make their illusions so vivid, so persuasive, so 'realistic' that they can live in them." Mr. Boorstin believed that by letting artifice displace experience, we were debasing our culture. Still, he assumed that if one lifted the scrim, one would find a reality behind the counterfeit. What he could not have foreseen was that the scrim would become the reality.
Partly, he underestimated the extent of the theatrical in America because he underestimated the power of television to dictate the terms of our discourse. As Neil Postman has observed in his powerfully argued screed against television, "Amusing Ourselves to Death: Public Discourse in the Age of Show Business," "We are now a culture whose information, ideas and epistemology are given form by television, not by the printed word." And Mr. Postman went on to say that television, unlike print, "has made entertainment itself the natural format for the representation of all experience." Television not only welcomes artifice, it demands it. Inherently visual, inherently visceral, television abhors dead air. It requires that everyone on it -- newsmakers, authors, generals, criminals, academicians -- keep us entertained or we'll tune out.
Television certainly has contributed to the frenzy of role-playing in America, if only because the lone standard to which television holds anyone is the standard of performance. (Mr. Postman says that Richard Nixon was done in by television not because he was a liar but because he looked like one.)
In a famous commercial a few years back, a soap opera star announced, "I'm not a doctor but I play one on TV." Today, when it seems everyone is engaged in one sort of performance or another, that could serve as the nation's motto. "I'm not a hero but I play one," says Oliver North. "I'm not a football star but I play one," says Brian Bosworth. "I'm not a journalist but I play one," says the local news anchor. "I'm not a President but I play one," says Ronald Reagan.
Since the media transmit these performances, it is tempting to blame them for the theatricalization. But doing so is mistaking symptoms for causes. Life is the medium, television an important but component part. And life hasn't become a form of entertainment because P.R. men learned to stroke our cultural G-spots or because wily television executives learned how to lobotomize us into grinning idiots. We have been complicit in the whole process and for good reason. It works.
If theatricalization accelerated at roughly the same time that America was emerging as a mass industrial society, it was also a time when American life was becoming less manageable, more complex. With the old verities of 19th-century small-town America suddenly under siege, people needed techniques to help them understand the changing social order and possibly dominate it.
A painless way to make sense of this new world was suggested by one of the modernizing forces itself: the movies. The movies offered many forms of guidance to confused Americans, particularly to immigrant urban dwellers; they became a virtual manual for acculturation. But one of the most important and most subtle services the movies offered was to serve as a popular model of narrative coherence. If reality was overwhelming, one could always carve it into a story, as the movies did. One could bend life to the familiar and comforting formulas one saw in the theater.
Beginning in the 1920's, the tabloids and then magazines and television provided dozens of real-life plots, from kidnappings and murders to political scandals, to crimes in executive suites, to election campaigns, to World War II, to the cold war, to Watergate, to the recent Soviet coup attempt. Today, virtually all the news assumes a narrative configuration with cause and effect, villain and hero, beginning, middle and provisional end, and frequently a moral. Events that don't readily conform, the savings and loan scandal, for example, seem to drift in foggy limbo like a European art film rather than a sleek commercial American hit.
That is why reading the news is just like watching a series of movies: a hostage crisis is a thriller, the Milwaukee serial murders a morbidly fascinating real-life "Silence of the Lambs," the Kennedy Palm Beach case a soap opera, a fire or hurricane a disaster picture.
One even suspects that Americans were riveted by the Clarence Thomas-Anita Hill hearings last week not because of any sense of civic duty but because it was a spellbinding show -- part "Rashomon," part "Thelma and Louise," part "Witness for the Prosecution."
But as with movies, if "formularizing" reality is a way of domesticating it, it is also a means of escaping it. Michael Wood in his book "America in the Movies," described our films as a "rearrangement of our problems into shapes which tame them, which disperse them to the margins of our attention" where we can forget about them. By extending this function to life itself, we convert everything from the kidnapping of the Lindbergh baby to the marital misadventures of Elizabeth Taylor into distractions, cheap entertainments that transport us from our problems.
But before disapproving too quickly, one is almost compelled to admit that turning life into escapist entertainment has both a perverse logic and a peculiar genius. Why worry about the seemingly intractable problems of society when you can simply declare, "It's morning in America" and have yourself a long-running Frank Capra movie right down to an aw-shucks President? Why fret over America's declining economic might when you can have an honest-to-goodness war movie that proves your superiority? Movies have always been a form of wish fulfillment. Why not life?
When life is a movie, it poses serious questions for those things that were not traditionally entertainment and now must accommodate themselves. Politics, for instance. Much has already been made of the fact that Ronald Reagan came to the White House after a lifetime as a professional actor. Lou Cannon, in his biography of Mr. Reagan, "President Reagan: The Role of a Lifetime," details just how central this was to Mr. Reagan's concept of the Presidency and what it suggests about the new political landscape.
 
Performance Politics
Good Vibes From the Oval Office
 "What he wanted to be, and what he became, was an accomplished presidential performer," writes Mr. Cannon. Everything was scripted for Mr. Reagan, from press conferences to quips; even in personal conversations he read from note cards. When the President did wing it, he was vague and often incoherent.
Of course President Reagan was not the first politician to have been a consummate performer. One thinks immediately of Franklin Roosevelt. But for Roosevelt the performance was always a function of the Presidency -- a means to sell his policies. For Mr. Reagan, the Presidency was a function of the performance. What the Administration was selling was what movies sell: good vibes.
None of this was lost on Mr. Reagan's advisers. They knew that his primary function was to star in the movie of his Presidency and offer genial reassurance that everything would be O.K. In this escapist entertainment there would be no racial divisiveness, no economic calamity, no education crisis, no AIDS.
We acquiesced not because we were deluded but because it was a pretty good movie as movies go: well executed, thematically sound, deeply satisfying, fun. "You believed it because you wanted to believe it," President Reagan once told a columnist who insisted he had seen the young actor on the set of the movie "Brother Rat," even though Mr. Reagan had not been there. "There's nothing wrong with that. I do it all the time."
Psychologically speaking, the President may have been right. Politically speaking, though, the Presidential movie is a far more vexing proposition for a democracy. In the first place, turning the Presidency into performance art changes the way we measure the Presidency from the efficaciousness of the Administration's policies to the power of its performance -- that old TV gauge. In this the media were happy to collaborate. Throughout the Reagan years one heard ad nauseam about the effectiveness of the President's delivery, about his popularity, about his charm until, as Professor Kiku Adatto noted of the press corps during the 1988 Bush-Dukakis campaign, the reporters had become theater critics, dissecting the stagecraft of the campaign rather than its substance.
In the second place, if performance art turns the Presidency into a movie, it also turns Americans into an audience. "You like the audience," Mr. Reagan once mused after his Presidency. "You want to please the audience." But audiences, unlike citizens, have neither responsibilities nor obligations. There are no minority rights either. The majority rules, and if you don't enjoy the movie you can just skedaddle. Anyone who has the temerity to stand up during the show and criticize it for not being relevant is likely to seem irrelevant himself. This movie isn't about relevancy. This movie is about escape.
Were President Reagan the author of this phenomenon, one might pass it off as a weird blip on the political screen. But, again, Mr. Reagan is the symptom, not the cause. From now on every President will be drafting the script of his Presidency. For President Bush it is the story of a self-effacing American Everyman, half Yankee, half Texan, whose common demeanor belies a steely toughness.
 
War: The Mini-Series
Casting for the Gulf Was Impeccable
 Just as every movie blockbuster comes with its own set pieces, the movie within the movie, so the Bush Administration devised its set piece: a staggeringly successful mini-series called the gulf war, which demonstrated on an unprecedented scale how events might be given the narrative shape and heady rush of a good action picture.
It is odd, unseemly even, to describe a war as "telegenic," but that is precisely what the gulf war was. Each network introduced its war coverage with music, a logo and a title -- "Crisis in the Gulf" on ABC; "Showdown in the Gulf" on CBS before the hostilities and "War in the Gulf" after the hostilities had begun; "America at War" on NBC. For them it was a new series, and even the correspondents, notably CNN's Peter Arnett and Wolf Blitzer and NBC's "Scud stud" Arthur Kent, gained a star's celebrity.
Certainly the gulf war was a lot more telegenic than Vietnam. Vietnam was a long, logy hallucination of a movie -- the good guys indistinguishable from the bad, the plot dribbling away to entropy. The Pentagon had learned that if it were to control the media front it couldn't let that happen again. The next war was going to be short, sharp, its narrative lineaments clean, happily unconfused as to heroes and villains. The next war was going to be an entertainment.
The casting was impeccable. Articulate, brilliant, rugged, sensitive, heroic H. Norman Schwarzkopf was a figure of Herculean proportions, especially when placed beside the Vietnam commanders William Westmoreland and Creighton Abrams. On the other hand, Saddam Hussein resembled the evil mastermind from a Saturday afternoon serial. As for actual combat, the action we saw, primarily bombs hitting targets, was antiseptic and precise.
Formulated like a World War II movie, the gulf war even ended like a World War II movie, with the troops marching triumphantly down Broadway or Main Street, bathed in the gratitude of their fellow Americans while the final credits rolled. Nor did the movie analogy end with the parades. The gulf war, like "Star Wars," had its ancillary markets: trading cards, T-shirts, video cassettes of the action.
Nevertheless, there is one distinction between this "movie" and the conventional movies that helped keep the home fires burning during World War II, other than the obvious one that those played in theaters and this one played in the medium of life. Those movies had a purpose besides entertainment. They were designed to mobilize support and forge a consensus for the real war being fought overseas. But when the war itself is a movie, when its real-life objectives are murky and mercurial, the war "movie" mobilizes support for . . . what?
For itself, one supposes, which is why the real point of this war may not have been to liberate Kuwait, insure the flow of oil or eliminate Mr. Hussein. It may have been to restore our confidence, to make us feel good -- which is, of course, traditionally not the function of warfare but of the movies or TV. "General Sherman had it all wrong," editorialized The Nation earlier this year. "War ain't hell -- it's entertainment."
 
When Life Upstages Art
Elizabeth Taylor's Celebrity Theory
 When life itself is an entertainment medium it also forces adjustments from the stars of films, TV, records and the rest of the conventional media. How do you hold your own in the life movie when the President, businessmen like Donald Trump, alleged mobsters like John Gotti, the Kennedys, even mass murderers compete for public attention? When everything is entertainment, what can you provide that these new entertainers cannot?
The answers come from an unlikely source: Elizabeth Taylor, who may be as close to a theorist of the life movie as there is. Ms. Taylor's life has long seemed like real-life soap opera of the most lurid hue. A childhood in Hollywood, marriage after marriage, the tragic death of her one true love, bouts with illness, obesity, drug addiction, recovery -- the list goes on.
All these things had kept Ms. Taylor in the public view. More, they had kept her a first-rank celebrity. In fact, Ms. Taylor's life was so much more entertaining than anything she could do on screen that she didn't have to work in movies or TV to hold our interest. She just had to live.
In "The Image," Mr. Boorstin noted that the celebrity "will be destroyed, as he was made, by publicity," the idea being that publicity is perishable; once the celebrity passes from public view there are no lasting accomplishments to survive him. But Elizabeth Taylor understood that one never need pass from that view; that one could keep unraveling the long skein of one's life; that one could make of one's own life a movie and that so long as it was entertaining, one would never be passe. "I am my own industry," she once declared, and she was absolutely right. (A marketing executive recently described an in-store promotional movie Ms. Taylor made for her new White Diamonds perfume as "a theatrical event," complete with tickets and popcorn.) When was the last time you went to see a real Elizabeth Taylor movie? When was the last time you read about her?
In the old days of celebrity, we seldom went to see a movie solely because we were curious about a star we had read about; on the contrary, we were curious about stars because we had gone to see their movies. Today the life is almost always a teaser for the work -- when there is any work to tease. No one I know rushes out to see a Mickey Rourke picture, few were tempted by the recent Farrah Fawcett-Ryan O'Neal sitcom, and Dolly Parton hardly rivals Madonna's popularity -- to name some recent cover subjects of Vanity Fair, the chronicle of the celebrity life movie. But they each have stories to tell and lives to sell.
Demi Moore, the actress-wife of Bruce Willis, didn't even have a picture in release at the time of her controversial Vanity Fair cover, but the magazine aptly described her yet-unborn child as "her next project." Julia Roberts did have a movie in release when she suddenly aborted her impending marriage to the actor Kiefer Sutherland. The picture, "Dying Young," did disappointing business. But as Caryn James pointed out in these pages, Ms. Roberts's life movie was booming. The tabloids and People got everyone gossiping about the young woman's romances just as they once did about Ms. Taylor's.
In effect, the life now is always usurping the work just as one suspects that for the celebrities themselves the life movie is always usurping whatever "real" life there is. "It's not easy being Cary Grant," the actor was once alleged to have said, meaning, presumably, that it wasn't easy for an ordinary mortal to live up to his screen image. Grant was assuming, of course, that there was a difference between the man and the image. It is much easier being, say, Cher because that assumption doesn't hold. When life is a movie, image and life conflate. The stars aren't projecting anymore. They seem to be living for us, opening their lives to public inspection, letting us in on their secrets, entertaining us.
But "entertainment" may be too limiting a word for these life movies. As mindlessly voyeuristic as all this may sound, the stars are also providing a kind of art as well as entertainment. Semioticians who study language and signs have long held that culture itself could be "read" as a vast text. Similarly, lives can have themes as well as plots, and these themes can be a major part of their appeal: the content that informs the story.
One of the appeals of Elizabeth Taylor's life is that it forcefully conveys the theme of survival. No matter what happens to Liz, she always triumphs. One of the appeals of Cher's life is that it conveys the idea of self-renewal: from a motley-dressed rock-and-roll star to a sex object to a serious actress. Sylvester Stallone's life has had the thematic amplitude of a Greek myth. He is the shepherd (actually deli waiter) who becomes the gods' (actually Hollywood's) favorite and then, succumbing to his overweening pride and to Circe (actually Brigitte Nielsen), must be punished for his hubris. Now, according to last year's Vanity Fair profile, "Sly's Cry From the Heart," he is chastened and newly sensitive.
No doubt stars could keep recycling the formulas if there weren't someone to push the edge of the celebrity envelope. Madonna's life is as soap operatic as the best of them, and it is ripe with thematic possibilities: sexual role reversal, hedonism with impunity, the wages of celebrity, to name a few. But Madonna has added a brilliant Pirandellian wrinkle to the old formula. She has made her life work about her life movie.
In the documentary "Truth or Dare," Madonna admits that she is not the best singer, dancer or actress and adds disingenuously, "Who do I think I am, trying to pull this off?" But Madonna knows exactly who she is. She is a conceptual performance artist whose truest art is the art of manipulation. That alone might not make her any different from Cher, Mr. Stallone, Ms. Taylor or the rest, save this: Madonna gleefully reveals her manipulation to us. She luxuriates in it. Like the magicians Penn and Teller, who are constantly debunking their magic, she invites us to see the mechanisms behind the tricks, until all we see are the mechanisms. It is the shamelessness of it that makes her so appealing to her fans.
"She doesn't want to live off-camera, much less talk," her then-boyfriend, the actor Warren Beatty, complains in "Truth or Dare." Mr. Beatty himself has always pretended to be secretive. He lurks at the edges of the frame here as he has lurked at the edges of the press for decades. Yet lurk he does. Not for nothing do we know not only Mr. Beatty's romantic entanglements, but even his love-making techniques. It is part of his life movie as legendary Lothario. What he cannot see is that Madonna is Mr. Beatty without the hypocrisy.
In fairness, though, not even Madonna always gets it. In "Truth or Dare," Kevin Costner saunters backstage to pay his respects after a concert. Flashing that big lopsided Costner grin, he tells her the concert was "neat," then apologizes for having to get back home to the kids. No sooner has Mr. Costner left than Madonna is sneering incredulously, "Neat?" and sticking her finger down her throat to gag. Madonna didn't seem to realize that she had momentarily become a guest star in Mr. Costner's life movie, believing instead that he was a guest star in hers. "Neat" was deliberate and probably ironic. It is the sort of thing one expects Mr. Costner to say. And the excuse about getting back to the children is as central to the Costner "movie" as sex is to the Beatty "movie."
Life couldn't be a movie if it were limited to the famous and powerful. Americans have always emulated their stars in fashion, behavior, attitude. Now, consciously or not, they are emulating the stars' theatricalization. Recently I heard about a party where the hosts' 8-year-old daughter roamed about with a video camera. As the party was breaking up, the girl called the guests to attention, popped a cassette in the deck and showed them the edited video version of their party, complete with titles, effects and soundtrack.
 
Ordinary People
Cultural Footprints Exit Into the Video
 And a recent article in The Times reported what must surely be the frontier of this domestic theatricalization: a young man asked his divorced parents to step in front of the camcorder and re-enact happier times so that their granddaughter could see how it was before the breakup.
These are the new entertainments and the new arts, spun in life from life. It is even conceivable that these, more than our novels, films and paintings, may be the cultural footprints we leave behind. Someday, perhaps, future generations will be retelling the sagas of Elizabeth Taylor, the Kennedys, Nancy Reagan, Donald Trump and Sylvester Stallone, or watching the videos of that divorced couple playing themselves in better days. Someday they may be parsing the meanings of these narratives as we interpret Greek myths.
Meanwhile, we edge ever closer to Philip Roth's dark, prophetic vision -- ever closer to the time when entertainment will be the only purpose of life and everything else will be dispersed to the margins and forgotten.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Trade Group Head Sees Deeper, Longer Slump

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
"No one I talk to in the advertising business sees the remotest sign that we're out of the economic slough of despond," John O'Toole, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, said in a speech to the trade organization's 53d annual Western Region Convention in San Diego over the weekend.
Mr. O'Toole listed the differences between this recession and previous ones that "point to a deeper and longer recession." Among them, he said, were the severe decline in advertising revenues being suffered by the media and the decision of advertisers to divert money normally spent on consumer promotions to trade promotions. 
 Still, Mr. O'Toole said, he expected aggressive advertisers to "use the recession to increase brand share at bargain prices," which would get "competition and advertising budgets growing again." That process helped end previous recessions, he added, and "there's no reason to assume it won't happen this time" -- eventually.
