HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Burden of Chicago Sun-Times: Being No. 2

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
At The Chicago Sun-Times, the national recession and widespread advertising drought have added pressure to the newspaper's fundamental handicap of being No. 2 to the dominant Chicago Tribune in advertising and circulation.
And last week, the paper narrowly averted a strike that would have strained its finances even further. 
 Indeed, the prospects for No. 2 papers in the few cities with newspaper competition took on a particularly somber cast Friday when the Gannett Company announced that it had sold The Arkansas Gazette, the No. 2 paper in Little Rock, to the owner of The Arkansas Democrat, which then closed it.
 
Strong Franchise Is Seen
 Still, Sam S. McKeel, publisher of The Sun-Times, said Friday that even though his paper had problems, they were not terminal. He asserted that The Sun-Times still had a fundamentally strong franchise, with particular power in such areas as automotive advertising.
"The paper is not in danger of collapsing, has a very positive cash flow and has thus far met all its debt-service obligations," said Mr. McKeel, who said the private company does not release performance figures.
As a tabloid focused on the city, The Sun-Times has traditionally had particular strength in Chicago and Cook County. But this has proved less important in recent years as residents moved to the suburbs, where The Tribune has traditionally had more muscle. Cook County lost about 250,000 in population in the 1980's, according to the 1990 census.
The Sun-Times has mounted large cost-cutting efforts twice in the last year that whittled 115 jobs, and Mr. McKeel said another significant round of cost-cutting was imminent.
Since June, The Sun-Times has been in intense negotiations with the Newspaper Guild, which represents about 245 newsroom employees, and a strike seemed almost inevitable at one point last week.
 
Details of the Contract
 "On Thursday at 11:30 in the morning, I announced in the newsroom, 'A strike is a virtual certainty,' " said Daniel J. Lehmann, a Guild spokesman. A contract settlement was reached at 5 P.M.
On Friday, the union approved a three-year contract with no increase the first year, a 2 percent increase the second year and 2 percent for each six months of the third year. While the agreement had some sweeteners, including a $550 bonus for each union employee upon ratification, the Guild received far less than it had asked. Management, pleading financial duress, said the union got all the newspaper could afford to give.
The last decade has been a time of turmoil for The Sun-Times, which has had three owners during that period. Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation acquired the paper from the Field family in 1984 for $75 million and then sold it two years later to Adler & Shaykin, a New York venture-capital company, for $145 million when newspaper profits were high and prices for papers were at a peak. Among the limited partners in the venture is the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
 
The Tribune's Lead
 Since 1986, The Tribune has increased its circulation lead, mostly because The Sun-Times has lost about 100,000 subscribers, both daily and Sunday. The Sun-Times's daily circulation is 538,000, compared with 741,000 for The Tribune, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The Sun-Times's Sunday circulation is 559,000, compared with more than 1.1million for The Tribune.
The Tribune claims to have 80 percent of the total advertising revenue generated by the two papers and 90 percent of the help-wanted classified advertising.
Mr. McKeel said The Sun-Times's bankers, with Citibank as the lead banker, had been quite cooperative in restructuring the debt that exists from buying the company.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Need Is Generally Seen For Nudging Economy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
With the economy showing few signs that it is doing little more than limping along, some analysts are becoming increasingly convinced that a measured dose of fiscal stimulus is needed to insure a modest recovery.
That view is also held by the Bush Administration, which last week made plain its intention to introduce a number of measures it contends will stimulate growth. 
 The steps mentioned last week are a familiar lot and include a cut in the capital gains tax, incentives for new home buyers and expanded Individual Retirement Account deductions.
But looking to the Federal Government for help is not without risk, the analysts acknowledge.
 
Impact on Rates
 After previous recessions, Congress and the White House have tended to pile on goodies like tax cuts and new spending programs, not measure them out in dollops.
The Administration insists its proposals will be "revenue neutral," and the huge budget deficit would seem to be an effective check on an impulse to overdo the economic stimulus. But the risk is there.
Adverse reaction from the financial markets is another potential problem. Any stimulus package that is perceived as excessive will almost certainly drive up interest rates, making the medicine less effective.
But those are risks worth taking, the analysts said, because current conditions seem to defy description.
"Economists don't have a good term for where we are," said Gail W. Fosler, chief economist at the Conference Board, a business organization. "The recession is over, and the recovery has yet to begin. Fiscal stimulus, in the form of a capital gains cut and a multiyear reduction in Social Security taxes, is needed."
 
'Stimulus Is Called For'
 Most economists expect that the Commerce Department will report that the economy grew at a fairly respectable rate of 2.5 percent to 3 percent when it releases its preliminary estimate of gross national product in the third quarter on Oct. 29.
But much of that growth was a result of a slowdown in inventory liquidation, they argue. Moreover, the steady decline in important sectors over the last few months is not synonymous with robust health.
"Recent data suggest the economy is staggering," said Alan Sinai, president of the Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc.
"Manufacturing seems to be fading, exports have fallen for the past three months and consumer spending is lagging," he said. "The economy needs help. A small dose of fiscal stimulus is called for."
Mr. Sinai said no more than $10 billion to $15 billion should be used to move the economy to a somewhat faster rate of growth.
Like Ms. Fosler, Mr. Sinai favors a cut in the capital gains tax and a reduction in Social Security taxes for middle- and low-income workers. Extending unemployment benefits should also be part of the package, he said. A sizable chunk of the package would be financed by a 5-cent increase in gasoline taxes.
"That amount of stimulus would give us about a percentage point of growth over the next year," he said. "By my projections, that would get the economy growing at a 2 percent rate."
 
Some Economists Dissent
 The view that fiscal policy needs to be more stimulative is not universally shared, however.
Indeed, many economists insist that given more time, the steady slide in interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve Board since the middle of 1989 will adequately bolster the economy.
But a fiscal package of modest proportions would not necessarily drive up interest rates, they said.
"We think the economy will make it without fiscal stimulus," said Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, "and that the interest rate decline we have had will propel us to 3 percent growth or more by early next year."
But, she added, "if the markets remain very skeptical about prospects for recovery, and the Administration were to propose something of modest dimensions, I don't think the markets would mind too much."
With the Presidential election little more than a year away, the political need to insure recovery is clear.
Still, Gordon Richards, chief economist at the National Association of Manufacturers, said there was little that could be done in the short-term that would have a measurable impact. And the long-term need to cut the deficit remains, he added.
 
A Similar Pattern
 "Given the choice of blowing last year's budget deal and letting the deficit escalate, or leaving fiscal policy as it is, I suppose we would come down in favor of the latter," Mr. Richards said. "In the long term, getting the deficit under control is a very high priority."
Moreover, there is reason to suspect that the current state of the economy is really little different from conditions that have existed in the early phases of past recoveries.
"One of the lessons of history is that in the last 25 years every time we start a recovery, we get very nervous and throw additional billions into the jaws of what seems a very anemic expansion," said Jay N. Woodworth, senior domestic economist at the Bankers Trust Company.
"But lo and behold, by the time the legislation percolates through Congress, it is clear that the expansion is not anemic at all, and we ratchet up inflation. From an inflation perspective, I am very nervous about the possibility of a fiscal package."

HEADLINE: No Pickup Expected For Hiring

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The nation's manufacturers say that while production has risen in recent weeks for many products, the pickup is so modest and uncertain that hiring new workers -- an essential step if the nation is to shake off the recession -- might be delayed indefinitely.
In interviews with more than 20 executives at the semiannual directors meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers, which ended in Atlanta on Saturday, the story was essentially the same: production for home consumption, apart from exports, is 1 percent to 3 percent above the summer's levels. 
 Manufacturing is the healthiest sector in a weak national economy, and those numbers suggest the recovery is finally at hand. But the executives held back from making that pronouncement.
Instead, they greeted the improvement with skepticism and with doubt that it would last. "You have to look pretty hard to find it," said Harry A. Hammerly, an executive vice president at the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the tape maker.
 
P.&G.'s Uncertain Gains
 The Procter & Gamble Company, for example, finds that sales are up 2 percent or more since June for all its numerous consumer products: foods, beverages, soaps, paper items and beauty aids. But Marvin Womack, a Procter vice president, said the company did not know yet whether Americans were consuming more, or Procter was simply taking sales away from competitors, with no net national gain. "You need the disposable income and the will to spend it to increase national consumption," he said. "Neither seems present."
Similarly, the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the copper company, has experienced what Douglas C. Yearley, the chairman, described as a surge in orders over the last four months for wire used in autos, electric motors and home construction. "That's surprising, since we don't see the end demand," Mr. Yearley said, adding that much of the wire might have been earmarked for the 1992 model cars.
"Now we are getting signals from the auto companies' purchasing people that if they don't get better car sales, they won't maintain the order level," he said.
Reflecting a view apparently widely held among the 150 executives at the two-day meeting, those interviewed said a gradual rise in production means that companies are not forced to hire workers or even to pay much additional overtime. A surge in demand and in production -- the pattern in the early months of previous recoveries -- would force companies to expand their work forces quickly.
But when sales grow slowly, that leaves time to increase production through labor-saving strategies: more automation and rearranging of work assignments.
"If the business comes back slowly, as ours is now, we can phase in these productivity improvements, which take time," said Wallace Barnes, chairman of the Barnes Group Inc., headquartered in Bristol, Conn., a maker of metal springs and precision parts that go into numerous products. "That is not good news for the nation's employment statistics, but it is good news for our competitiveness."
 
Counter to Bush Plan
 The resistance to rehiring -- indeed, the Barnes Group, which employs 5,000 people in the United States, is still reducing its staff through attrition -- runs counter to the dynamics for a recovery that have been outlined by the Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve and many economists. Even with a weak recovery and a slow improvement in factory production, they had expected that overtime and new hiring would soon kick in.
The resulting rise in income, in turn, would fuel more demand, more purchases, greater production and still more hiring, making the recovery a solid reality by year-end. The manufacturing sector, in particular, has been counted on to lead the way in rehiring, given that the service sector is laying off thousands of workers to become more efficient, the construction industry is in the doldrums, and state and municipal governments are reducing staffs because of budget problems.
But manufacturing employment has risen by only 67,000 workers, to 18.4 million, since the recession's low point earlier this year, and remains well below its 19.2 million level when the recession started in July 1990.
 
Problem Recognized at Fed
 Recognizing the problem, David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Fed, said in an interview last week, "There is a real question whether the rise in production will catch hold in employment." He added that the third-quarter gross national product, measuring the nation's economic growth, could show as much as a 3 percent rise, at an annual rate, when the G.N.P. figure is announced on Oct. 29. But despite the likelihood of this good news, which would represent the first growth in the national economy in a year, Mr. Mullins was pessimistic. "It bothers me," he said, "that we might be running out of steam" and the economy might "fall back."
Whatever the future, the present exhibits sharp differences among manufacturing industries. While sales of P.& G.'s small consumer items rose, production of appliances fell from December until the summer and is now "dragging along the bottom," neither rising nor falling, said Gary L. Rogers, senior vice president of General Electric appliances.
"People are buying only what they have to, and they are always looking for lower-priced models," he said. "Even if production rises 3 percent to 4 percent next year, there would not be much hiring."
 
Sales Double for Jack Daniels
 Factory sales of Jack Daniels and other whiskies made in the South by the Brown-Forman Corporation also fell all year, but in September they suddenly doubled. A higher Federal excise tax helps to explain the sales decline, but Stephen F. Thompson, the company's executive vice president, said the September rebound was beyond his understanding. "If we have another month in a row like this, it might mean something," he said.
Restocking for Christmas might be an explanation, Mr. Thompson said. And export growth is helping many other manufacturers. Even before the recent mild turnaround in the nation's manufacturing production, export growth had made manufacturing industries the strongest in a recessionary economy.
Air Products and Chemicals Inc., a manufacturer of industrial gases, exports 15 percent of its $2 billion annually in domestic production, and exports had been rising at a rate of roughly 6 percent a year, while domestic sales began to rise only in late summer at a much slower pace. "Our turnaround would not hold up if exports were to fall," said Dexter F. Baker, the company's chairman and also the newly installed chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Baker, left, the new chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, speaking with Jaime Jose Serra, Mexico's Secretary of Commerce, at the group's semiannual meeting in Atlanta. Mr. Serra spoke to the group about the proposed North American free-trade pact. (Erik S. Lesser for The New York Times) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Westinghouse's Sour Experience

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
In real estate circles, Westinghouse Electric's real estate lending business is regarded as one of the great disasters of the 1980's, up there with boom-and-bust savings and loans and oil-patch banks.
And many analysts say the worst is not over. Never mind that twice this year, the big Pittsburgh-based company has been forced to reconcile itself to huge losses from misguided loans by its Westinghouse Credit subsidiary for suburban hotels, motels, apartments and office buldings. Two weeks ago, it earmarked $1.68 billion as a reserve against additional loan losses, bringing to $2.66 billion its total addition to reserves this year. 
 "If the economy continues to be one in which real estate values continue to plummet and highly leveraged companies continue to have problems funding themselves, then they could have more problems," said Fred Pastore, a analyst at Moody's Investors Service who has been given access to the mountain of junk bonds and real estate loans in the Westinghouse Credit Corporation's portfolio.
 
Interest in the Pieces
 With a difficult financing road ahead, more problems could mean that Westinghouse will have to sell several of its non-core businesses and might be significantly changed in a restructuring. Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the powerful New York leveraged buyout firm, is already reviewing some of Westinghouse's businesses.
More than half the giant conglomerate's real estate loans, amounting to about $3 billion, are not paying all, or any, of the interest they are supposed to pay. Westinghouse Credit's real estate loss reserves equal about 68 percent of its underperforming real estate assets, but the company also has another $1.7 billion of off-balance-sheet credit commitments that it may have to finance if the market continues to trample its investments.
"We think they may need half a billion to a billion dollars more in reserves," said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with County NatWest. "In order to solve the problem, they are going to have to put the bad loans in a separate, self-funding company."
In an attempt to buttress the company's cash position and forestall more big losses, Paul E. Lego, Westinghouse's chairman, announced a plan to speed the recovery of the financial services group, which handles the real estate portfolio.
Mr. Lego has replaced William A. Powe, 54 years old, the high-powered salesman who oversaw most of the failed property investments, with Leo W. Yochum, 64, the company's former chief financial officer, who is coming out of retirement.
Mr. Lego, who declined to be interviewed, has also begun a financing plan that includes private placement of new equity, reduction of short-term debt and expansion of bank credit facilities. The company hopes to improve its cash flow by $500 million by the end of next year, in part by issuing $400 million in Westinghouse stock instead of cash to the company pension fund. Mr. Lego has refused to rule out the need for yet more loss reserves.
 
Overvalued Hotel Properties
 How did this corporate giant, better known for making complex electronic equipment, stumble so badly?
Executives and analysts who have worked with Westinghouse or seen portions of its property portfolio said about 200 loans, or about a quarter of its portfolio, are in limited-service, franchised economy hotels like Hampton Inns, one of its largest borrowers, and Embassy Suites, Days Inn and some Marriott Courtyard motels. These loans, many of which went to small operators, were made on inflated appraisals in the late 1980's and too often represented a high portion of the appraised value, often between 75 percent and 95 percent.
Sometimes developers who were looking to squeeze a little more cash out of their buildings would get a first mortgage for, say, 70 percent of the property from a bank or insurance company, and then go to Westinghouse Credit for a second mortgage secured by the additional 30 percent of value.
In this depressed real estate market -- hotel property values have fallen by at least 30 percent in the last four years -- nearly all of Westinghouse's second mortgages have been wiped out, those familiar with Westinghouse's holdings said. Even many first mortgages are worth substantially less.
Westinghouse Credit, along with the Japanese leasing companies, developed a reputation in the commercial real estate community as a lender of last resort: If you borrowed from them, you would have to pay higher loan fees, but they would make loans that banks would not make.
In addition, credit companies can often close deals quicker because they are not subject to Government supervision as banks or insurance companies are. As a result, many of the big property syndicators and partnerships, like VMS Realty, the troubled Chicago real estate company, went to Westinghouse.
"All the credit companies got into the hotel business in the mid-80's, when they saw the great returns they could get and the real estate climbing in value," said Dan W. Daniele, director of hospitality consulting services for Ernst & Young. "So they made five- to seven-year mini-perm loans and thought they could flip the hotels when the values rose. Now every credit company has a large portion of its underperforming assets that are hotels."
All this has left Westinghouse Credit with a mountain of nonperforming mortgages secured by buildings that cannot, and will not for the forseeable future, support the debt. Meanwhile, its inventory of foreclosed real estate, valued at about $195 million in June, is rising as more developers walk away.
"Westinghouse viewed it as a business like making lightbulbs or any other business," said a real estate executive. "It doesn't seem to have occurred to them that the reason they got such big fees was because the deals they were financing were incredibly risky."
If the economy slows further, many of the hundreds of millions of dollars of mortgages that Westinghouse recently renegotiated to give borrowers more manageable terms may nevertheless become delinquent.
"They were high-value lenders," said a banker who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "and their premise was that even if income were to go down, values would be sustained. But that didn't happen. Westinghouse underwrote income at very small margins, so if the income went down, they were in trouble."
 
Need for More Financing
 Many people in the commercial property business said that Mr. Powe and the go-getters he assembled at Westinghouse Credit were aware of the risks but were counting on ever-increasing property values and Japanese and other willing foreign buyers. Now the Japanese have their own sour real estate investments to fret about, and Mr. Powe is out.
And even assuming that Westinghouse is successful in its plans to raise $900 million, unknowns loom about the parent company's balance sheet, suggesting it will have a strong, continuing need for large amounts of bank financing. Even before the real estate reserves, the operating profits at the company's businesses were down 30 percent as of September. Last week, about 80 banks that lend to Westinghouse held preliminary discussions on the company's problems and near-term financial needs.
Westinghouse has about $5 billion in short-term debt and commercial paper that will come due and need to be rolled over next year. The banks that will be asked to provide more credit will want to be certain that the company's liabilities and its real estate problems have been sufficiently provided for.
Those liabilities include about $1 billion in unfinanced company pension fund charges, an estimated $500 million to $1 billion in environmental cleanup costs for some 57 sites and another estimated $500 million charge related to employee health-care benefits that must be addressed by Jan. 1, 1993.
With a book value of about $3 billion plus another $900 million if the financing plan goes through, Westinghouse will be squeezed over the next year as some of these charges hit its bottom line. The net present value of the company is difficult to determine with these liabilies, but it seems clear that the banks will have to come to the rescue because the commercial paper market is effectively closed to Westinghouse.
The company has had repeated downgradings of its credit ratings and has had trouble persuading investors that they should buy its commercial paper, the corporate i.o.u.'s that help manage its cash and liquidity.
On top of that, Westinghouse Electric faces a class-action suit that contends the company failed to adequately disclose the extent of its real estate problems when it sold 21.5 million shares of common stock in May. At that time, Westinghouse traded at around $28 a share. On Friday, it closed at $16.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Nine-Month Loss
 Real estate woes were almost entirely responsible for Westinghouse Electric's $1.25 billion loss for the first nine months of this year on revenues of $9.37 billion. That compares with a net profit of $717 million, or $2.44 a share, on revenues of $9.21 billion for the comparable 1990 period.
Mr. Heymann, the NatWest analyst, estimated that his previous worst-case prediction for the company's dividend -- that it would be cut in half, to 70 cents a share -- is now the best that can be expected. In fact, he and others believe the dividend may be temporarily eliminated.

HEADLINE: Bank Sues Salomon and Travelers

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
A Philadelphia savings bank has accused Salomon Brothers Inc., the Travelers Corporation and some top executives at both of colluding to deprive the bank of money it is owed by four real estate partnerships.
The dispute involves real estate partnerships that had attracted investments from more than 200 of Salomon's most prominent current and former employees and comes as the Wall Street firm is struggling mightily to rebound from its admission that it behaved unlawfully in several recent Treasury auctions.
 
Secret Negotiations
 The Meritor Savings Bank in Philadelphia, in a little-noticed lawsuit filed in June in Philadelphia County Common Pleas Court, contended that the Salomon group was secretly negotiating to release Travelers and its Prospect Company investment unit from obligations that would insure that the partnerships' loans to Meritor are repaid. 
 Meritor charges that in return, the Salomon group was negotiating to receive payments that could help reduce adverse tax consequences it now faces.
To satisfy Meritor when the deal was struck in the mid-1980's, Salomon arranged for Prospect, which had a financial stake in the projects, to cover any shortfalls should the rental properties the four partnerships invested in fail to generate enough income to pay their debts. Travelers, the big insurance company, had issued a so-called comfort letter advising Meritor that its policy was to make sure its subsidiaries fulfilled their obligations.
Nonetheless, the Meritor loans, which totaled $59 million, went into default last April.
"In essence," the complaint says, "Traveler, Prospect and Salomon Brothers intend to abandon their obligations and commitments to Meritor in order to minimize their own losses, while leaving the investment partnerships without sufficient funds to satisfy their obligations to Meritor."
 
No Comment
 Spokesmen for Travelers and Salomon said over the weekend that it was their companies' policies not to discuss pending litigation.
According to partnership documents filed with the New York County Clerk's office in Manhattan in 1984, at least 216 former and current Salomon employees would have been participants in the real estate deals. They include many of Salomon's top officials at the time, including John H. Gutfreund, Thomas W. Strauss, John G. Meriwether, Paul W. Mozer, and Donald M. Feuerstein, all of whom left the firm shortly after the Treasury market scandals in August.
Other investors were Henry Kaufman, Salomon's former chief economist, and Lewis S. Ranieri, the father of its mortgage-backed operation, who was immortalized in the best-selling book, "Liar's Poker."
Many Properties Purchased
The partnerships were used to buy office buildings in Tampa, Fla.; Denver and San Antonio, as well as an apartment complex in Irving, Tex., long before problems in the real estate market and tax-law changes in 1986 made such deals unattractive.
The partnerships were but a few of the many investment vehicles in real estate and in oil and gas that Salomon often offered its wealthier employees.
"They were good investments," M. Jack Perkin, a former Salomon managing director who quit in 1988, said yesterday. He helped select the properties and remains an investor in the deals. "Back in the early 1980's, there was a lot of syndication going on, and this was another vehicle for key employees to invest in," he said.
 
Defaults and an Injunction
 For some time, the properties have not been generating enough income to pay the partnerships' debts, including the $59 million in Meritor loans. Prospect was thought to have been making up the difference up until April, when the loans defaulted.
Meritor, a savings institution rebounding from financial difficulties in the 1980's, in July had disclosed $59 million in new problem loans, a 13 percent increase to its nonperforming assets.
But the savings bank did not disclose the identity of the borrower or the nature of the problem, even though it had already won a temporary injunction from the Common Pleas Court.
The June 5 injunction bars the defendants from "entering into any agreement or understanding with one another" that would violate the partnerships' agreements to Meritor and prohibits the partnerships from making any distributions to the defendants.
 
Earnings Due Today
 Meritor investors who learned of the lawsuit last week were told the bank would disclose more information about the loans today when it reports its third-quarter earnings.
"I just think it's interesting that Travelers is running full-page ads saying you can rely on us, and they're just walking away from an obligation," said Gary E. Hindes, the chairman of the Delaware Bay Company, a Meritor stockholder.
Mr. Hindes said he was disappointed that the Salomon partnerships might have been slow to pursue Travelers for the money.

HEADLINE: Bentsen Calls For Tax Cuts And I.R.A.'s

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Finance Committee, called today for a tax cut intended to provide relief for middle-income taxpayers and provide a stimulus to the economy.
The measure by Senator Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, would reduce taxes by $72.5 billion over the next five years by allowing a tax credit of $300 for each child 18 years old or younger in a family and restoring the availability of Individual Retirement Accounts to all taxpayers, regardless of income. The cuts would be paid for by a 5 percent reduction in military spending.
 
Improved Odds for a Tax Change
 Given that President Bush and the Republican leaders in Congress renewed their call just last week for a capital gains tax reduction to create more jobs, Mr. Bentsen's proposal would appear to improve the chances for passage of some kind of tax legislation this year.
But an aide to Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said Mr. Rostenkowski did not expect Congress to be able to act before adjourning in about a month. Mr. Rostenkowski is preparing an alternative proposal.
In addition, the Republicans are likely to oppose Senator Bentsen on the ground that he is making a gesture to take advantage of a political issue on which the Bush Administration may be vulnerable.
Mr. Bentsen denied such political motivations, maintaining in an interview: "I've been saying for months that I would introduce a bill to provide relief for middle-income Americans. I'm concerned very much about a double dip in the recession. The Administration is just now talking about a stimulant."
The White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, repeated the Administration's preference for a cut in the capital gains tax and incentives for investment in research and development, when he was asked about the Bentsen proposal today on the ABC News program "This Week With David Brinkley."
Mr. Sununu, speaking of the lagging economic recovery, said, "The problem is that our job growth is not as fast as we would like it." But he asserted that "the turnaround occurred back in May and June."
 
Seeks to Stimulate Economy
 Senator Bentsen issued his proposal in the form of a statement released by his office staff here and discussed it today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." Later, in a telephone interview from San Diego, he said his plan was not an attempt to pre-empt the Republicans on the question.
"They've been trying to talk their way out of the recession," he said. His own plan, he said, would "help give a jump-start to the economy."
The committee that Senator Bentsen heads has among its responsibilities the writing of tax measures. The Texas Democrat said he had discussed his proposals on Friday with both Mr. Rostenkowski and George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority leader in the Senate.
Mr. Bentsen said that neither had seen details of his plan but that both were in favor of tax relief for middle-income Americans.
 
Other Ideas for Military Savings
 The aide to Mr. Rostenkowski said that he and the other Democratic leaders in the House were indeed in favor of such tax relief for the middle class but were not in favor of achieving it by using all the expected savings from military spending cuts.
Mr. Rostenkowski's alternatives, his aide said, would call for using part of the expected military savings to finance some new domestic programs and to help reduce the Federal deficit.
Senator Bentsen said his proposal would encourage Americans to save more, while reducing the taxes of the middle class and stimulating the economy. His proposed tax cuts and I.R.A. modifications would go into effect Jan. 1, while the reductions in military spending would start next Oct. 1.
Senator Bentsen estimated that the tax credits for families with children 18 years old and younger would cost the Treasury $60 billion over the next five years, while the I.R.A. changes would cost $12.5 billion.
A family of four with an annual income of $35,000 would save $600 on taxes a year, or 25 percent of their tax bill. Such taxpayers, he said, had seen their taxes rise during the last decade while their income fell by 5 percent, factoring in inflation.
Current law limits tax deductions for I.R.A.'s to individuals with annual incomes under $25,000 and families with incomes under $40,000, and only if they are not covered by a pension plan. Senator Bentsen seeks to allow all taxpayers to put up to $2,000 a year in I.R.A. accounts and deduct that amount when calculating their taxes.
 
A Return to Pre-1986 I.R.A.'s
 His proposal would return the Individual Retirement Account to the status it held before the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Under the 1986 changes, the tax breaks on I.R.A.'s were restricted to lower-income people in order to reduce the cost to the Treasury.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a Democratic member of the Finance Committee, suggested today on the ABC program that he supported the Bentsen proposal, though not with enthusiasm. "Nothing the matter with it," he said, adding with deliberate understatement that it "would do no harm."
But Senator Moynihan said the larger issue on which the United States ought to be focusing is the mounting interest on the national debt. "It's eating us alive," he said.

HEADLINE: Citing Corruption by Kenya Officials, Western Nations Are Canceling Aid

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Corruption among top Kenyan Government officials has become so pervasive that Western donors, no longer confident that their assistance is reaching the people it is intended for, are cutting their aid programs, Western diplomats and economists say.
Further, corruption is a deterrent to new investment in Kenya, economists and foreign officials say, and a Bush Administration official says the American Embassy here has told Washington in a report that it believes that President Daniel arap Moi and some of his top aides and relatives are the main offenders. 
 The problem of corruption in third-world nations is not a new one. But Kenya, with its capitalist economic practices and relatively efficient infrastructure, was long regarded by Western donors as a success story amid the economic rubble of Africa. The country has been rewarded with large increases in Western aid, both from the World Bank and individual donors.
 
Denmark Halting New Aid
 But now that story has changed, as shown by these developments:
*The Danish Government, until recently one of the biggest donors to Kenya, said Friday that it was immediately ending its 17-year support for rural development in Kenya after an audit showed that most of the nearly $40 million in that aid program "disappeared because of corruption." Last month, the Danes said they were freezing all new aid to Kenya.
*The British Government, the former colonial power, decided this year not to give Kenya money to subsidize oil prices for consumers, a European diplomat said, because British officials feared that the money would go to a powerful politician instead.
*For similar reasons, two Western diplomats said, the World Bank decided against an ambitious $100 million program with the Moi Government to promote the domestic energy production.
*The American and British embassies had to intervene to keep Citibank from leaving Kenya after a dispute with a Cabinet minister over repayment of loans, Western diplomats said.
 
'A Deleterious Effect'

"I don't know if Kenya is at the head of the class when it comes to corruption but they're a contender," the United States Ambassador, Smith Hempstone, said recently. "The state of the economy is extremely fragile, and corruption has a deleterious effect."
The first President of independent Kenya, Jomo Kenyatta, and his family amassed a large fortune in land, precious gems, ivory and casinos during his rule from 1963 to 1978. But economists here say the Kenyatta dealings were small compared with the systematic hold that Mr. Moi and some colleagues have acquired over the larger Kenyan economy of the 1980's and 1990's.
Even so, Kenya, which gained independence from Britain in 1963, has appeared attractive to Western aid donors because of its remarkably strong economy, especially as seen next to those of its war-torn neighbors, Somalia, Ethiopia, the Sudan, and Uganda and impoverished Tanzania.
Thus, foreign aid jumped from $200 million in 1986 to $1 billion in 1989. But a Western diplomat said that when Western donors meet in Paris next month to decide Kenya's aid for next year, they are likely to give Kenya less than it requested, in large part because of the corruption.
The practice of politicians demanding a share of a business is a deterrent to the new large-scale investment that Kenya needs to deal with its accelerating unemployment, a Western economist here said. A Western donor country's assessment said that private investment in Kenya fell by 12 percent last year. It was the first overall decline since 1982, when there was an attempted coup, the assessment said, although American officials noted that American private investment has been dwindling for the last decade.
In response to the pressure from aid donors, the Kenyan Government has announced that it is establishing an anticorruption unit to ferret out bribe takers. In a speech on Oct. 10, celebrating his 13th year in power, President Moi made special note of corruption.
"My Government is already aware of this problem and is taking appropriate measures to deal with it," he said in the speech at a crowded stadium here.
Last year, a Bush Administration official said, the American Embassy here reported to Washington in a cable that a "get rich now" philosophy pervaded the top echelon of Mr. Moi's Government.
The official said the embassy wrote that it was almost impossible to document the wealth of Kenyan officials. But the Embassy reported in another cable that the British High Commission estimated the wealth of Energy Minister Nicholas Biwott to be "hundreds of millions of dollars," chiefly in offshore holdings. As Cabinet Minister in charge of energy, Mr. Biwott's official monthly salary is 21,033 Kenyan shillings, about $750. A member of the Kalenjin tribe, to which President Moi also belongs, Mr. Biwott is considered to be President Moi's closest political confidant.
The Administration official said the embassy had reported in the "get-rich-now" cable that officials believed that four Kenyan Government officials and three relatives of Mr. Moi had greatly enriched themselves through their public office or access to officials. The embassy listed the officials as Mr. Moi; Mr. Biwott; Vice President George Saitoti, and the Permanent Secretary in the President's Office for Internal Security, Hezekiah Oyugi.
Efforts to interview Mr. Moi and Mr. Oyugi were unsuccessful. Mr. Biwott said by telephone that he would consider an interview, and when asked about being described by a Western embassy as having enriched himself through public office, he said: "I'm not aware of such cables. If you have any I will answer accordingly."
An Assistant Minister, John Keen, who works in the Office of the President, said in an interview that he could not comment on the specific names mentioned in the cable to Washington.
Mr. Keen, who has been criticizing recent anti-Western comments by Mr. Biwott and other Government officials, said he believed all Kenyan public officials and their wives should be made to declare their assets. He described the recent announcement to set up an anticorruption unit as falling "far below expectations."
"Either the cancer of corruption is killed or it will kill the state," Mr. Keen said.
The American Embassy here, describing what it called an example of personal financial gain through public office, reported that Mr. Moi was believed to be a partner in an oil refinery in Puerto Rico with an Israeli businessman. The embassy said two Kenyan businessmen were believed to operate as front men for the President and "cut" the President in on their deals. The embassy said Mr. Moi, who comes from a humble background and was a teacher before entering politics, is believed to have a share in a Nairobi casino and a hotel in the Masai Mara game park. The embassy also said it was believed that Mr. Moi had received a "seven-figure" commission when Kenya bought two airplanes from the European consortium Airbus Industrie in the late 1980s.
It is not illegal for public officials in Kenya to engage in private business.
Western diplomats in Nairobi as well as local businessmen said it was common for a handful of senior politicians to demand a share in the start-up of a company or to demand control once a company became successful. "If you come into Kenya and make a lot of money you are a target," a Western diplomat said.
 
Britain Denies Fuel Grants
 As Energy Minister, Mr. Biwott is in charge of a large section of the Kenyan economy, ranging from the oil industry, hydroelectricity, coastal development, pipeline construction and one of the largest government enterprises, Kenya Power and Lighting. Through this commanding position, Western diplomats and economists said, Mr. Biwott has been able to amass a large private fortune.
In response to a request for an interview, Mr. Biwott said he would grant an interview after a public inquiry into the killing of former Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, who was slain in February 1990. Government corruption has become an issue in the already lengthy Ouko inquiry, which lawyers here said they believed could last another six months.
At the height of the Persian Gulf crisis, when gas prices rose, the British Government decided not to grant about $7 million to Kenya for subsidizing consumer fuel costs. The British made similar grants in neighboring Uganda and Tanzania, but a European diplomat said the British felt that such a grant in Kenya would be siphoned off by the interests of Mr. Biwott.
Two Western diplomats said the World Bank had proposed spending about $100 million for domestic energy production, but could not get a commitment from Mr. Biwott that the program would be properly audited and thus canceled the plans.
In what Western diplomats described as the most disturbing intrusion into the private sector by a politician that they could explicitly document, companies belonging to Mr. Biwott brought legal action in June against the Nairobi branch of Citibank. Both the American and British embassies had to intervene to keep Citibank from leaving Kenya, the diplomats said.
The trouble arose when Citibank sought to collect on $14 million in loans to some of Mr. Biwott's companies. Western diplomats said Mr. Biwott's lawyers went to Kenya's High Court and got an injunction that blocked the bank from collecting on the loans, of which $11.2 million worth was secured by letters of credit in a Swiss bank account of Mr. Biwott.
 
Threat From Foreign Banks
 An American diplomat said a senior official in the embassy complained about Mr. Biwott's actions to the Vice President, Mr. Saitoti, saying Citibank and other foreign banks would leave Kenya if Mr. Biwott was able to avoid payment in this fashion. Western diplomats said a senior British diplomat conveyed a similar message to the Chief Judge of the High Court, Alan Hancox. Mr. Biwott held larger loans with the Nairobi branch of the British bank, Barclays, the diplomats said.
The injunction was then lifted at a court hearing before the judge who had granted it.

(The Daily Nation); State Department officials believe that the corruption in President Daniel arap Moi's Government is a deterrent to new investment. (Camera Press)

HEADLINE: TURKEY'S LEADERS TRAIL OPPOSITION

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Monday, Oct. 21

 BODY:
President Turgut Ozal's eight-year domination of Turkish politics, which saw a radical transformation to free-market economics and the establishment of a close working relationship with the United States, appeared to be in jeopardy today as early results pointed to his party's defeat in Sunday's parliamentary elections.
A loss could usher in a weaker coalition government that might thwart some of the economic reforms and policies that have raised Turkey's profile among Western nations. 
 It appeared unlikely that any of the three main political parties would win more than 30 percent of the vote. Turkish television said unofficial results from about 15 million votes counted gave the opposition True Path Party 27.6 percent of the vote compared with the governing Motherland Party's 24.1 percent.
The True Path Party is led by Suleyman Demirel, who has been Prime Minister six times and was twice removed from office by the military.
 
Kurdish Rebels an Issue
 True Path leaders, who spent most of the campaign attacking President Ozal, advocate tougher measures against Kurdish insurgents in the southeast and promise to end what they say is rampant corruption and nepotism in the Government.
Mr. Demirel, the party leader, told reporters at his home early today that he expected to win about 30 percent of the vote, but refused to discuss possible partners in a coalition government.
"It's too early to say if we can come to power by ourselves," he said.
" can't say anything about a coalition at the moment . . . "You can't cut cloth for the nappy of an unborn child," he added, quoting a Turkish saying.
The Social Democratic Populist Party, which rejects the privatization of remaining state enterprises, was in third place with 20.8 percent of the vote. In fourth place with 16.3 percent was the Welfare Party, a coalition of a religious fundamentalist party and a right-wing nationalist party. The Welfare Party could influence the makeup of any coalition government.
Because of complicated election rules, it may be a week before seats in Parliament are officially parceled out. Under Turkish election law, it is possible for a party to acquire a clear majority in the 450-seat Parliament without taking a large percentage of the popular vote.
In the last election in 1987, the Motherland Party did just that, taking 65 percent of the seats with only 35 percent of the vote. Parties need at least 10 percent to seat candidates.
 
A Referendum on Ozal
 The elections were largely a referendum on the political future of Mr. Ozal, a close ally of the United States and the man who has championed Turkey's transition to a free market and its opening to the West.
He gave strong backing to the allied effort in the Persian Gulf war, allowing American planes to conduct bombing strikes against Iraq from Turkish soil. He has softened Turkey's stance in the Cyprus dispute with Greece, and has lifted some of the restrictions on the country's 10 million Kurds.
Opposition candidates across the political spectrum have pledged to remove Mr. Ozal from office, playing on fears that he might give up Turkish claims to Cyprus and hand the country's Kurds enough power to slip out of Turkish control. The opposition charges that in shifting the country's domestic and foreign policy, the President has exceeded the constitutional powers of his largely ceremonial office.
"Our first priority," said Erdal Inonu, the head of the Social Democratic Populist Party, "is to change the Constitution and have Parliament elect a new President."
Mr. Ozal's term ends in 1996, but opposition candidates charged that his election in 1989 by the Parliament that his party controls was unconstitutional. To order new elections, the opposition will have to have two-thirds of the 450 parliamentary seats.
The election is the third since 1983, when the country returned to civilian rule after a military coup in 1980.
 
Political Paralysis Feared
 The coalition partners that ruled in the 1970's before the coup often bickered and threw the government into near paralysis, something Western diplomats fear could happen again if there is no clear winner in this election.
Turkey's next government faces major economic and political challenges, including maintaining ties to the West in the post-cold-war era.
Turkish officials are worried that the country's strategic importance to the West could decline now that the Soviet Union, Turkey's neighbor, poses much less of a threat to global security.
The demise of President Ozal's Motherland Party could well see a cooling of relations with Washington, but what worries Western diplomats most is a weak coalition government that would usher in a period of instability, throwing one of the West's most important regional partners into turmoil.
Turkey's transformation over the last decade has been dramatic.
The Government has installed a working phone system and electricity in most of the remote corners of the country.
 
Stores Now Well Stocked
 Stores, whose shelves once housed a few shabby locally made products, are overflowing with foreign imports and Turkish-made products that sell competitively in Europe. An increase in exports and tourism have taken some of the strain out of the country's payments on its $43.7 billion foreign debt.
But the country is also wracked by a 71 percent inflation rate, and many voters, as well as members of the governing party, resent the accumulation of power and wealth by many in Mr. Ozal's family.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Voting yesterday in Turkey's elections were, from the left, Erdal Inonu of the Social Democratic Populist Party, President Turgut Ozal of the Motherland Party and Suleyman Demirel of the True Path Party. (Associated Press; Agence France-Presse; Reuters)

HEADLINE: Hollywood Journal;
City Tosses Bit of Beauty at Its Blight

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 20

 BODY:
For decades, illusion has made this town famous. Now, the ability to blur the line between what is and what seems to be has been enlisted in a campaign to transform Hollywood. The result can be glimpsed at the corner of Hollywood Boulevard and Western Avenue.
There, the Community Redevelopment Agency of Los Angeles has created what just might be the quintessential Hollywood amenity. Its sole purpose is to look good. It is temporary. And it will be seen primarily by people driving by. 
 The agency spent $50,000 to turn a menace and an eyesore into a garden. It replaced a trash-strewn empty lot frequented by homeless people, muggers, crack dealers and prostitutes and with sculptures, bougainvillea, oleander and flax.
The site, dubbed Metro Gardens, makes for a lovely street corner view, but it is only a view. No one will stroll, picnic or sit there. Fearful the danger would return and the same people who once made the lot an embarrassment would ruin its new features, the redevelopment agency surrounded it with a high iron fence. In 1994, the garden, the fence and the artworks will give way to a station on Los Angeles's new subway line.
"This was one of the worst crime-infested places anywhere," explained Councilman Michael Woo, the Los Angeles official whose district includes Hollywood. "We couldn't have a real park there. We couldn't afford the 24-hour-a-day security that would be necessary to guarantee people's safety. I'm satisfied this was the best use we could make of it."
Felicidad A. Guzman, whose apartment overlooks the lot, said: "There was always these guys selling drugs, asking for money. I just didn't want to walk by. Now you can walk by."
At street level, Hollywood shows little of the glamour associated with its name. South of the hills dotted with mansions lie areas of poverty, homelessness and crime. Gangs, once limited to the southern and eastern parts of Los Angeles, are now fixtures.
Five years ago, the city and the redevelopment agency approved a 30-year, $922 million program to return Hollywood to its former glory, but the promised commercial and social revival will take years. Until then, Mr. Woo and the redevelopment agency plan to make small-scale beautification projects like Metro Gardens a regular sight.
If the trees and shrubs of Metro Garden seem to deny the surrounding reality, Adam J. Leventhal, the sculptor commissioned by the agency, confronted it. In his "Homeless Ghost," a pair of disembodied hands pushes a shopping cart. "It's all about how we make our problems invisible when we can't deal with them," he said.
The redevelopment agency would not win any popularity contests around Los Angeles. It has a reputation of catering to developers while imperiously disregarding the poor. Residents in Hollywood fear the agency will do there what it did in the 1960's to downtown Los Angeles, where thousands of people were evicted to make way for skyscrapers.
But a recent demonstration against Metro Gardens at its dedication attracted only four protesters against use of tax money for landscaping and art. The project was just an attempt to cover up the problems of the poor, they charged, and fencing off the lot would only force the criminal element to move down the block.
Mr. Leventhal disputed their conclusions. "If people think that by keeping an empty lot open they're helping homeless people, that's pretty weak," he said.
He added: "The city is absolutely not doing enough about the problems that affect people who don't have money. But it's not a choice between that and art. You have to have both. I think Los Angeles is on the verge of total entropy, of breakdown, of becoming a completely dysfunctional city. But I also think art is an issue of survival."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Adam J. Leventhal with his sculpture, "Homeless Ghost," which was commissioned as part of a project in Hollywood to convert an empty lot that was considered an eyesore into a garden. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Louisiana Puts Ex-Klan Leader In Runoff Race

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
State Representative David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, won a spot in the runoff election for governor of Louisiana on Saturday, but Republican officials in Washington disavowed him today as a racist who would win no support from the national party.
Mr. Duke finished second in the open primary on Saturday and today promoted himself as a new leader of the Republican Party's conservative mainstream. He will face Edwin W. Edwards, a former three-term Governor who is a Democrat, in a runoff election on Nov. 16.
 
Thanking the Rank and File
 
 Gov. Buddy Roemer, who was elected four years ago as a Democrat and who became a Republican in March, finished third in the primary, despite the public backing of President Bush and the national Republican Party. The state party, however, backed Representative Clyde C. Holloway.
In unofficial returns with all but two of 3,927 precincts reporting, Mr. Edwards led the 12-candidate field with 516,119 votes, or 34 percent; Mr. Duke had 484,923, or 32 percent; Mr. Roemer had 408,904, or 27 percent, and Mr. Holloway had 82,785, or 5 percent, The Associated Press reported.
"The rank-and-file Republicans of this state voted for me, and the rank-and-file Republicans in this country believe the way I believe," Mr. Duke said at a news conference today.
"I think I offer a tremendous opportunity for the Republican Party," he said. "I am the first Republican candidate that actually bridges the gap between fiscal conservatives and labor."
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, was among several Republican leaders in Washington who tried to distance themselves from Mr. Duke today. "The President is absolutely opposed to the kind of racist statements that have come out of David Duke now and in the past," Mr. Sununu said on the ABC News program "This Week."
Mary Matalin, the chief of staff of the Republican National Committee, said when asked in an interview if Mr. Duke would receive any assistance from the party, "unequivocally, it is not possible." She added: "He is not a Republican. We never considered him a Republican. There will be no involvement in his campaign whatsoever."
The results of Saturday's voting represented a major setback for the Republican Party in its highly publicized effort to make inroads in this historically Democratic state.
 
Bush's Help Didn't
 Mr. Roemer was defeated after a switch to the Republican Party last spring that was partially engineered by Mr. Sununu. He lost despite the fact that his campaign was managed by professional Republican organizers dispatched from Washington. Even personal appearances by both President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle did not hand Mr. Roemer the Republicans' core vote in Louisiana.
It was Mr. Duke who amassed much of the vote in Republican strongholds like the lakeside suburbs of New Orleans and in Mr. Roemer's home territory in northwest Louisiana.
According to Louisiana law all candidates regardless of party affiliation appear on the same ballot in an open primary, and if none win a majority of the vote the top two candidates face each other in a runoff.
Mr. Edwards, a flamboyant Cajun who has been a towering presence in Louisiana politics for 25 years, won with heavy support from black voters in what proved to be a tight, highly polarized election.
Defeated by Mr. Roemer in the 1987 election amid accusations of corruption, Mr. Edwards, 64 years old, hammered at what he called Mr. Roemer's unfulfilled promises from that campaign. Calling Mr. Roemer "pompous and preachy," Mr. Edwards depicted the incumbent as an ineffective leader who had failed to enact much of his own agenda.
A Harvard-educated technocrat, Mr. Roemer, 48, focused much of his campaign effort on promoting his education policies. However, his most recent initiative in that field was a new teacher evaluation system that produced a bitter conflict with the Legislature and the teachers' unions. As with his efforts on the environment and tax reform, Mr. Roemer had a hard time pointing at obvious accomplishments.
Mr. Roemer lost the election in the state's major metropolitan areas, where he ran more poorly than expected, ceding the votes of many affluent, well-educated whites to Mr. Duke.
 
Veiled References to Race
 While proclaiming that a religious conversion had led him from the hate-filled beliefs of his youth, Mr. Duke, 41, waged a campaign that played on the economic fears and racial biases of white working class voters.
Although he rarely made explicit references to race, Mr. Duke used thinly veiled racial code words to make blacks his scapegoats, for example promising to cut the costs of social services by reducing "the illegitimate welfare birthrate." Yet, Mr. Duke also echoed positions taken by President Bush and other Republican leaders when he vowed not to raise taxes and labeled racial hiring quotas as unfair to qualified whites.
Although he has repeatedly been disavowed by both the state and the national Republican Party organizations since he marched onto the political stage two years ago, Mr. Duke told a victory rally early this morning, "We are Republicans, and we are committed to equal rights."
His supporters serenaded him with rousing renditions of "Dixie" and the "Battle Hymn of the Republic."
Pronouncing himself unconcerned that national Republican leaders would deny him assistance in the runoff campaign, Mr. Duke said, "I don't think they have helped any Republicans by getting involved so far."
Mr. Duke's involvement with the Klan dates back to his teen-age years. He reached the rank of grand wizard before quitting in 1980. In the 1970's he openly espoused Nazism.
 
A Yeltsin? 'I Like That'
 Now that he is seeking an electoral platform for his views, Mr. Duke's attempt to portray himself as a mainstream Republican serves several political purposes, said Ed Renwick, a professor of political science at Loyola University in New Orleans.
"First of all, Duke clearly wants to set himself up as a national figure and may be thinking about entering the Presidential primaries or something like that," Mr. Renwick said. "Also, he is trying to get respectability by putting on the clothes of a Republican candidate as opposed to the wardrobe of his unsavory past."
In this campaign Mr. Duke repeatedly touted himself as the leader of a new conservative political movement. "What we are doing down here in Louisiana is going to have a lot of impact all over the United States of America," he said at his news conference today. "I think the working people of this country are ready for a real change in government."
He said he saw this movement extending across the world, with him as a leader. "One person described me as the Boris Yeltsin of American politics," he said. "I like that."
 
Two Checkered Pasts
 In his concession speech early this morning, Mr. Roemer spoke of Mr. Duke's appeal to voters without ever identifying his opponent by name. "I would not discount this state," he said. "There is a lot of anger and anxiety in America. It is something that must be dealt with, and politicians have to do a better job of that."
James Brady, chairman of the Louisiana Democratic Party, said today: "There is no doubt that people, particularly middle class whites, are frustrated with government in general. They don't see government as on their side. I think Duke capitalized on that, promoting every buzzword available."
Mr. Duke and Mr. Edwards had a chance encounter at the Louisiana Superdome today, where the New Orleans Saints were playing football. The two candidates were smiling and cordial with each other despite the fact that they represent radically different political views and constituencies.
Indeed, since the primary results put them in the runoff against each other both have repeatedly stated that they will refrain from personal attacks based on their pasts.
While Mr. Duke is trying to shed his Klansman's image, Mr. Edwards is trying to bury his image as a rapscallion figure who was a habitual Las Vegas gambler and who was twice tried, but never convicted, on Federal corruption charges in the 1980's.
Mr. Edwards said today, "I want it well understood that I will not run any kind of negative campaign. It is useless to dwell in the past."
But there is a fundamental difference between the two candidates that may affect how their pasts play out in the campaign. Mr. Edwards has held high elected office in this state many times, and many times the voters have overlooked the more rakish aspects of his character. Mr. Duke is now for the first time seriously contesting a position of major responsibility.
"Duke has been an easy protest vote so far," Mr. Renwick said. "But this time voting for Duke can't just be a protest. It will be a vote to make him governor of the state and to give him all the executive power of that office."

HEADLINE: Tiny Babies, Big Problems

 BODY:
One can see them in neonatal intensive care units all over the country: tiny babies hitched up to a bewildering array of tubes and monitors. Some are too frail even to wail. Most will live long enough to leave the hospital; the majority of the very tiniest will have neurological damage; and many will incur staggering medical bills.
The price some of their parents pay in emotional anguish, and that some of the babies may pay in physical pain, is of course beyond reckoning. Although a neonatal intensive care unit can be a place of joy, the smallest of these babies usually face a grim future -- or no future at all. 
 The tragedy is that many of these too-early births could have been prevented with better prenatal care for the mothers or more widespread contraceptive services to protect teen-agers.
Every year the United States sees the birth of 45,000 babies weighing less than three and a half pounds and more than two months premature. As recent articles by the New York Times reporters Elisabeth Rosenthal, Gina Kolata and Jane E. Brody point out, the smallest of them can pose profound ethical problems.
When, for instance, should one cease treating a tiny baby whose setbacks after birth -- brain bleeding, say, and cardiac arrest -- make a grim prognosis even grimmer? Who should make the decision? One mother concerned about her desperately ill premature infant was told by the doctor: "You don't make these decisions. We do."
How much better it would be if such suffering could be headed off at the start. By contraception, for example. Children born to mothers who are still children tend to be very small. Yet every year some 35,000 babies are born to girls under the age of 15. After discounting for inflation, Federal funding for contraceptive services has fallen by almost two-thirds since 1980.
Better health care could help. Many children born to crack-addicted mothers are dangerously underweight. But drug treatment slots for the pregnant are few and far between. More broadly, millions of American women don't get comprehensive prenatal care that is routine in Western Europe.
Those programs are costly. But the cost cannot match the price America now pays to care for very-low-birth-weight babies. Intensive care for premature infants costs more than $2,000 a day, and the medical bills can run to nearly half a million dollars. If the premature baby suffers long-term damage, the cost of continuing care and education may be formidable.
Medical technology has met the challenge of keeping tiny babies alive. The greater challenge is to reduce the need for those marvelous machines.

HEADLINE: Coming Back;
Get Guns Off the Street

 BODY:
Last year, gunfire killed 1,559 New Yorkers, including numerous innocents hit by bullets meant for others. The gunfire did something else, just as destructive in its own way: It raised the fear level among seven million New Yorkers.
Hoodlums with guns have long been part of New York City. But suddenly the guns are more ubiquitous and powerful, the hoodlums younger and more volatile. Citizens who might once have challenged someone smoking on the subway hesitate now, for fear of a lethal response. Guns are drawn over aggressive driving, casual insults, petty thefts. 
 Removing illegal guns from the streets would dramatically enhance safety and reduce fear. New strategies for gun control are acutely needed; most can be pursued within current budgets, if the Mayor and Police Commissioner will focus on the need. The gun problem has assumed emergency proportions. It demands an emergency response.
New York City's Sullivan law, one of the nation's strictest, licenses only people who show clear need to carry guns. But tough licensing is not enough when social and economic forces expand the trade in illegal guns as a deadly side effect of drug traffic. Crack dealers, younger and wilder than the old-line gangsters who managed the heroin trade, consider 9-millimeter semiautomatic handguns, sawed-off shotguns and military assault rifles essential.
As the crack culture grew more entrenched, gun toting became something even for "good" kids to emulate. No one knows how many illegal guns are on the streets, but homicide statistics confirm the alarming trend: In 1990, guns were used in 69 percent of homicides; in 1980, it was 58 percent.
Unchallenged, the spread of guns makes a joke of existing laws. A state law imposing a one-year sentence for illegal gun possession has had little effect. And so far, police have taken a number of well-intended but inadequate steps. A year-old task force of 12 officers working with 12 Federal agents has arrested 154 traffickers and seized 496 weapons. And the department keeps pushing to close legal loopholes, like one permitting gun traffickers to obtain Federal licenses although unlicensed locally.
But given the thousands of illegal weapons on the streets, those are bare gestures. Much remains to be tried. In theory, it would seem desirable to increase police authority to search citizens for guns and confiscate any illegal weapons so found. But confiscation raises difficult legal and policy issues. By long tradition, the N.Y.P.D. has resisted mass arrest sweeps or "stop and frisk" strategies sometimes attempted in Los Angeles and other cities. The state's highest court has set high thresholds of suspicion that must be met before police can search for illegal guns, based on constitutional issues not easily altered by new state legislation.
Even so, there's room for much more to be done. The department might, for example, encourage people fearful of neighbors with guns to report confidentially over a citywide hot line. Minimal follow-up like review of criminal records could develop enough data to justify searches, confiscations and arrests. New Orleans operates such a hot line successfully; a well-publicized line in New York could yield hundreds of calls.
Police could also move more forcefully against students carrying guns to school. The schools can afford metal detectors in only 15 of 120 high schools. Those detectors sharply reduce gun-related incidents. If the city can't turn up the needed money, private donors might be approached. In the meantime, police and school safety officers could do more to identify armed students and confiscate guns.
Officials might also persuade owners of bars and clubs to install metal detectors where patrons are known to carry guns. Metal detectors might be used at post offices, welfare centers, the Department of Motor Vehicles and other high-traffic agencies. The Transit Authority might even find a way to incorporate weapons detection in new turnstiles.
Illegal guns, fast becoming New York's top public safety problem, provide a perfect target for Police Commissioner Lee Brown's new emphasis on problem-oriented policing. Concentrating even a small part of the department's new resources on confiscation and suppression of guns could yield a lopsided payoff in preserving the quality of New Yorkers' lives. And their lives.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Breaking the Logjam

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
No one who knows the Middle East will celebrate yet. The substance of a successful negotiation, the give-and-take needed to make it work, is still hard to envisage. But there are going to be negotiations, starting next week in Madrid, and that is remarkable enough.
For the first time in its 43 years as a state, Israel will meet face-to-face with each of its Arab neighbors -- and with representative Palestinians. All the issues between them will be on the table: peace, security, land, people.
It is going to happen now because of George Bush and James Baker. Secretary of State Baker spent much of the last five months wheedling and pushing the intractable parties. But his success was possible only because the President had the vision and the courage to commit himself to this conference.
Mr. Bush seized the moment, after the Persian Gulf war, for a new effort at Arab-Israeli peace. He understood that some fundamental power relationships had changed. Those changes, still going on, offer hope for an onset of reason in the Middle East.
The end of the cold war has had an immediate impact on the region. Soviet military support for Syria has ebbed, making President Assad look to improved relations with the United States. Israeli and American fear of Communist influence has abated, making possible a joint Soviet-American invitation to Madrid that in the past would have caused alarm.
The decline in Soviet power is also having a profound impact on U.S.-Israeli relations. It has weakened, or removed, one basis for the close ties of recent decades and for massive U.S. aid: the idea that Israel was a strategic asset for America in a vital part of the world.
The gulf war showed that U.S. armed forces could act in the Middle East without Israel. In that war, indeed, Israel was a complication rather than an asset in U.S. military calculations.
Americans are still committed to help Israel, for reasons of history and conscience. But it is clear that a more detached relationship is developing, one in which America will more freely weigh its own values and interests. The Economist wrote last month:
"Americans still express their moral commitment to Israel's survival; but Israel's moral case grows steadily weaker as it refuses to extend to the Palestinians the right of self-determination that has become a cornerstone of the emerging world order. A peace which left Israel ruling over millions of voteless Palestinians has become unthinkable."
Israelis are increasingly aware that they cannot expect unconditional support from the United States -- that they can maintain the vital American connection only by paying attention to American interests. President Bush made that bluntly clear when he postponed consideration of loan guarantees: too bluntly, most Israelis thought, but they understood the larger point.
In this new relationship, the territories occupied by Israel since 1967 are the crunch. U.S. policy is to end Israeli control of the West Bank and Gaza and their more than 1,500,000 Palestinian inhabitants. Prime Minister Shamir and much of his Government are committed to creeping annexation of the territories.
A new political choice is therefore shaping up for Israel: Keep the occupied territories or keep American support.
Economic realities are also pushing Israel to make a choice about the occupied territories. The reasons are explored in depth by Bernard Avishai in the forthcoming November-December issue of the Harvard Business Review.
The $10 billion sought from the United States in loan guarantees is to build housing for Soviet immigrants to Israel. But if those immigrants are to have jobs, Mr. Avishai says, Israel will need two or three times that much in investment capital from the world. And Israel will have to change its protective economic policies and become part of the global market, using its special scientific and intellectual talents.
But there will be no large-scale foreign investment, Mr. Avishai writes, and no long-term contracts with Israeli firms, while the world sees insecurity over the issue of the occupied territories. "Israel can have the Whole Land of Israel or it can have a piece of the global economy."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
