HEADLINE: Essay;
Reading Mario's Mind

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
When I was in Tokyo last month, they asked me what the possibility was that I would run for President. I told them that question was too easy.
If they had asked me, "Do you think there is a possibility that while the Governor of New York is in Japan there will be an earthquake and a typhoon in two days?" I would have said, "Not likely." But of course -- there was an earthquake and a typhoon in those two days. So the unlikely sometimes happens.
But I can't get away with this cuteness routine forever. I've been saying I have no plans to run, and no plans to make plans, but now it's a year to Election Day and it's time to stop playing Hamlet and start playing for keeps. 
 Of course I'm running, and not just for the exercise; this thing gets more winnable every day.
The media are so naive. They phrase their questions in convoluted ways to be first to drag an announcement out of me, and they miss the opening of the campaign that's been going on for months in California.
That's where the nomination (and the election) will be won. It's the biggest state, plenty of ethnics and minorities, where I can win big. I want the California primary to be moved up early in the spring, so I can put the nomination on ice quickly and focus on Bush.
Of course, the President knows that, and wants me to lose a few Southern primaries, which is why his California Republicans are trying to keep their primary in June. That's the first skirmish of the campaign of '92, and the pundits, typically, are waiting around for a press release.
I like the Democrats now in the field running to be my running mate. Rockefeller or Gore might have been trouble, but these new guys are perfect for clearing out the political underbrush.
Harkin of Iowa, the old-line liberal, doesn't have a chance, but he has the best one-liner so far. "George Bush was born on third base and thinks he hit a triple." Great line, not only about Bush's rich childhood, but about taking credit for seven Presidents' battle against Communism. I'll give Harkin full credit, but I'm the one who played semi-pro baseball and that gag belongs in my stump speech.
Clinton of Arkansas is the best organized, and he has his centrist message together. Him I like, and I need a Southern WASP, but he's another Governor, and the damn gossipmongers will be all over him. Be a good campaign chairman, nice contrast to Sununu or Mosbacher.
My man is Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska. Lost part of his leg winning the Medal of Honor -- untouchable. Can you just see my Kerrey up against Bush's Quayle? Let Bush try to wrap himself in the flag again; "my running mate Senator Kerrey, who doesn't have to remind you that he won the Medal of Honor in Vietnam . . ."
Now about strategy. We'll jujitsu Bush on his claim to foreign policy experience: America doesn't need a President of the World, we need a President of the United States. And his foreign policy has been overrated: he totally misread the breakup of the Soviet Union, and after all the fuss about defeating Saddam Hussein, the dictator is getting more dangerous because George Bush choked up at the end.
I'll hit him with the "Dirty Dozen." Bush's veto of the unemployment insurance bill was one; his veto of the bipartisan civil rights bill will be two. The Democratic leadership should pass 10 more bills the people need and want -- health, housing, education -- let the no-man in the White House do his "dirty dozen vetoes." I'll pledge to sign those 12 bills on Inaugural Afternoon -- and I'll keep my promise, unlike that phony no-tax promise that he won on and broke.
Let him try his Dukakis stuff with me, sailing around New York harbor and whatnot -- he'll never know what hit him. George Bush stole $6 billion from the states this year, on top of being the slowest-growth President since Hoover. Are you better off than you were four years ago with "Mr. Veto" in the White House, paralyzed in the face of recession?
You think I'd sit tight like those bozos when Bush's hatchet men smeared Anita Hill? Not a chance. Americans like a scrapper, an underdog in the polls who will stand up against the smug no-men, and just watch those polls turn around when I make my prime-time speech at the convention in New York, and when I get to him in those televised debates.
I can hardly wait. Then what am I waiting for?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 968 words

HEADLINE: After Judging Thomas, Senators Face the Public

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The Senate Judiciary Committee's heated hearings into Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court and whether he was guilty of sexual harassment reverberated well beyond Capitol Hill.
Record numbers of viewers watched the televised sessions for hour after riveting hour, and by the end of the inquiry, judgment was being passed not only on Judge Thomas but also on members of the Judiciary Committee, the judicial nominating process and the Senate generally. 
 While Judge Thomas eventually won confirmation, visits to four states make clear that the drama is not over for members of the Judiciary Committee.
The offices of many Senators have been inundated by phone calls, letters and telegrams from constituents who were pleased or angered by the hearings. The volume and tone of the communications are such that they cannot be ignored, particularly by those senators who face re-election next year or who have never been on particularly solid political footing in their home states.
At least one poll, conducted by the Gallup Organization after the hearings, found that roughly one of every two viewers who watched a significant amount of the inquiry came away feeling less confident about Congress and the Congressional process.
Further, the poll found that of the leading members of the Judiciary Committee, only its chairman, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, won a favorable rating from a majority of all viewers. Sixty-three percent said they were well impressed by his performance.
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, won a favorable rating of 48 percent, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, won a 41 percent favorable rating and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts won a 22 percent favorable rating, the lowest recorded. The poll, conducted on Oct. 14, was based on telephone interviews with 612 adults and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Following are reports on how the hearings affected these legislators in their home states.
 
Massachusetts
Kennedy Assailed on Effectiveness
Senator Edward M. Kennedy has an entirely new political problem because of his muted role in the latest hearings on the nomination of Clarence Thomas for the Supreme Court.
He has been criticized, and ridiculed, for not taking a more active role in attacking Judge Thomas and defending Prof. Anita F. Hill, who accused the judge of sexual harassment.
But he also has a familiar and critical political advantage, the reluctance of formidable challengers. Gov. William F. Weld, the popular Republican who has been telling the Senator for months he would not oppose him in 1994, told his own staff last week that he would run for re-election as Governor then. He told them not to talk of him as a Senate possibility, a Weld intimate said Saturday.
And Mr. Kennedy has advantages of his own doing and position. No one else in Massachusetts could have done what he did tonight, holding a dinner for President Mary Robinson of Ireland, whom he hailed as also "the president of Irish everywhere." Scores of voting Irish-Americans were also his guests at the John F. Kennedy Library, looking across the harbor their ancestors crossed on the final yards of their trip to America.
Still, the issue of his effectiveness, or lack of it, in the Thomas fight is a political concern because it offers a new legitimacy to discussions of his personal life. As one supporter, Beverly Copeland, a management consultant from Brockton, said Saturday: "He has done a good job as a Senator. If he could just keep his private life private."
The new charge of ineffectiveness is also a concern politically, if only because it breaks unfamiliar ground. For nearly three decades, the angriest attacks on Mr. Kennedy have concerned what he did or tried to do, from passing civil rights bills to blocking Robert H. Bork's Supreme Court nomination to seeking national health insurance.
 
Many Complaints Remain
 There are still plenty of those complaints. Some long-time haters, like Mike Lopez, an East Bridgewater plumber, gleefully seize on the Thomas episode as evidence that "he's all washed up."
But fundamental Kennedy supporters also have their doubts now. Jim Canavan, a typesetter from Quincy, said, "He's still pushing for health care." But he added, "I think he's slipping a bit. It's his private life -- a little ridiculous for a man of his age."
Even more unkindly, an editorial in today's Boston Globe, a devoted ally over the years, accepted the general belief in Washington that his low profile in the hearings was caused by his own "reputation as a womanizer." That showed that "neither he nor his supporters can again assert that his private life has had no impact on the discharge of his public duties," the editorial concluded.
The Globe said, "It is exactly because he has been such an effective Senator" that his relative silence mattered.
More than anyone else on the Judiciary Committee, Mr. Kennedy is a national figure, and national criticism reverberates here.
But there are staunch voices of support, too. Ann F. Lewis, a consultant here, reminds disappointed feminists that it was Mr. Kennedy's staff that was in on the initial discovery of the accusation against Mr. Thomas. She said no other Senator was as dedicated a supporter of women's issues. "When someone has been your champion for a long time, you don't turn on him," she declared.
The Kennedy organization, while startled by such tokens of vulnerability as The Globe editorial is hard at work on the 1994 campaign. Mr. Kennedy is usually in the state three weekends a month, blaming President Bush for the sluggish economy, and no appropriations bill that helps the state passes without a press release.

Kennedy won a 22 percent favorable rating, the lowest recorded. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times; Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Judging Thomas, Senators Face the Public

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ERIE, Pa., Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Senate Judiciary Committee's heated hearings into Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court and whether he was guilty of sexual harassment reverberated well beyond Capitol Hill.
Record numbers of viewers watched the televised sessions for hour after riveting hour, and by the end of the inquiry, judgment was being passed not only on Judge Thomas but also on members of the Judiciary Committee, the judicial nominating process and the Senate generally. 
 While Judge Thomas eventually won confirmation, visits to four states make clear that the drama is not over for members of the Judiciary Committee.

Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts won a 22 percent favorable rating, the lowest recorded. The poll, conducted on Oct. 14, was based on telephone interviews with 612 adults and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Following are reports on how the hearings affected these legislators in their home states.
 
Pennsylvania
A Split Decision On Specter's Role
 Mary Hosack and Margaretta Moore, both retired teachers, came to a union meeting on Saturday to talk about health benefits and pensions. It took very little to get them talking about the Thomas confirmation hearings instead.
"I think he did a very great deed," Mrs. Hosack, a Democrat, said of Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican. "He performed as he was asked to do."
Mrs. Moore, a Republican, disagreed. If he runs for a third term next year, she said, she does not plan to vote for him again.
"I thought he was unnecessarily nasty," she said as she left the early morning meeting. "His attitude was just mean-spirited."
The difference in opinion -- which often seems to have little to do with sex or party affiliation -- is typical of the debate in Mr. Specter's home state as the people he represents assess his role as Prof. Anita F. Hill's chief inquisitor during Judge Clarence Thomas's confirmation hearings.
Mr. Specter, who concluded publicly that Professor Hill had committed perjury while appearing before the Judiciary Committee, has been defending his statements and behavior ever since.
A moderate Republican who favors abortion rights and has long enjoyed the support of women's groups, Mr. Specter has ended up in a near no-win situation in his home state. Many women are mad at him; and while conservatives are pleased, even they still do not quite trust him.
And as Mr. Specter prepares to face a likely primary challenge next year from a conservative anti-abortion state legislator, Steven F. Friend, it has become crucial that he shore up his political base.
He made his first stab at that here Friday night, flying in from Washington to speak to a group of Erie County Republicans and to local reporters at a news conference.
In both forums, he spoke of the Thomas hearings and offered his defense of the high-profile role he was asked to take on.
Mr. Specter said in an interview last week that he became convinced that Professor Hill's credibility was questionable after he tried to pin her down on the details of her contacts with Democratic committee staff. "It was like a floodlight going on," he said.
 
Defense of Questioning
 He said in the interview that he had been just as tough on Judge Thomas.
"I asked him a lot of very strong questions," he said. "A lot stronger than I asked Miss Hill."
But conservatives still have suspicions about Mr. Specter, going back to his decision to vote against confirming Judge Robert H. Bork in 1987.
"Arlen usually gets all kinds of grief from the conservative part of the party," said Ann DiTullio, who works in the district office of Representative Tom Ridge, the Republican from the Erie area. "He's going to have 50 percent of the people mad at him all the time."
But the political down side could be limited. "Many of the people who are furious at him were never Arlen Specter voters," said Rick Robb, who ran the Reagan-Bush campaign in Pennsylvania in 1980 and 1984.
And Specter supporters see a man who did the honorable thing and who can only benefit from the national exposure he received.
Denise Illig-Robinson, a Republican member of the Erie City Council, said, "What helps him is that his name and his face were on CNN for that long."

Kennedy won a 22 percent favorable rating, the lowest recorded. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times; Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Judging Thomas, Senators Face the Public

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Senate Judiciary Committee's heated hearings into Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court and whether he was guilty of sexual harassment reverberated well beyond Capitol Hill.
Record numbers of viewers watched the televised sessions for hour after riveting hour, and by the end of the inquiry, judgment was being passed not only on Judge Thomas but also on members of the Judiciary Committee, the judicial nominating process and the Senate generally. 
 While Judge Thomas eventually won confirmation, visits to four states make clear that the drama is not over for members of the Judiciary Committee.
The offices of many Senators have been inundated by phone calls, letters and telegrams from constituents who were pleased or angered by the hearings. The volume and tone of the communications are such that they cannot be ignored, particularly by those senators who face re-election next year or who have never been on particularly solid political footing in their home states.
At least one poll, conducted by the Gallup Organization after the hearings, found that roughly one of every two viewers who watched a significant amount of the inquiry came away feeling less confident about Congress and the Congressional process.
Further, the poll found that of the leading members of the Judiciary Committee, only its chairman, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, won a favorable rating from a majority of all viewers. Sixty-three percent said they were well impressed by his performance.
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, won a favorable rating of 48 percent, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, won a 41 percent favorable rating and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts won a 22 percent favorable rating, the lowest recorded. The poll, conducted on Oct. 14, was based on telephone interviews with 612 adults and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Following are reports on how the hearings affected these legislators in their home states.
 
Delaware
Biden Is Hearing Plenty of Support
When Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. dropped by the Ranch House on Friday morning for a cup of coffee, the waitress scurried to meet him with a big hug.
"You were great," crooned the waitress, Ruth Martin. "You're my guy."
Almost everywhere the Delaware Democrat went on his home turf, he found a warm greeting and a good word for his efforts as chairman of the Judiciary Committee in its inquiry into the Supreme Court nomination of Clarence Thomas.
There were plenty of harsh words for other committee members, for the confirmation process in general, and for Judge Thomas and his accuser, Prof. Anita F. Hill. But for Mr. Biden, there was almost universal praise, with "fair" and "evenhanded" the words heard most often.
Some members of Congress and some students of the Congressional process have criticized him for calling the second round of Thomas hearings, or for not scheduling it sooner, or have accused him of running things too strictly or too loosely. But there is little of that criticism at the grass roots.
"Great job!" a Metroliner passenger called out in Union Station in Washington as the Senator, who commutes daily between Wilmington and Washington, hastened through.
 
'Natural' and 'Real'
 A woman struggling with two bags veered toward him.
"You did fine," she panted. "But you tell Specter and Hatch they're in trouble with the women of America."
In conversations with Mr. Biden about the Thomas hearings, few people mention his eventual vote, which was against Judge Thomas. Rather, the talk is mainly about the tone of the hearings and who was telling the truth.
"You tried to help everybody," said Phyllis Greenberg of Wilmington as Mr. Biden worked the booths and tables of the Ranch House restaurant. "I've got a place for you in my heart."
Another Ranch House patron, Don MacDonald, a retired chemical worker, said he was "tired, just tired" of watching Congress at work because so little progress was made and because many Congressional procedures had become acrimonious talk-fests. But even though he votes Republican, Mr. MacDonald had no harsh words for Mr. Biden, saying instead that the job of the Judiciary Committee chairman was "untenable given the group that's there to work with."
Since narrowly winning election to the Senate in 1972, Mr. Biden has never been in any real political difficulty in Delaware, easily winning three re-election victories. Last year he captured 63 percent of the vote, despite the baggage of an embarrassing 1988 run for President that he ended prematurely when he was accused of plagiarizing some passages in his speeches.
Still, at least one columnist, Norman A. Lockman of the News Journal in Wilmington, warned Mr. Biden that he must find a way to reform the judicial confirmation process, "or be held responsible for the corruption of a national governmental trust."
Mr. Biden says he intends to hold hearings on reform. He also wants to meet with President Bush to discuss the issue.
"We haven't heard the last of this," he said.

HEADLINE: After Judging Thomas, Senators Face the Public

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 17

 BODY:
The Senate Judiciary Committee's heated hearings into Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court and whether he was guilty of sexual harassment reverberated well beyond Capitol Hill.
Record numbers of viewers watched the televised sessions for hour after riveting hour, and by the end of the inquiry, judgment was being passed not only on Judge Thomas but also on members of the Judiciary Committee, the judicial nominating process and the Senate generally. 
 While Judge Thomas eventually won confirmation, visits to four states make clear that the drama is not over for members of the Judiciary Committee.
The offices of many Senators have been inundated by phone calls, letters and telegrams from constituents who were pleased or angered by the hearings. The volume and tone of the communications are such that they cannot be ignored, particularly by those senators who face re-election next year or who have never been on particularly solid political footing in their home states.
At least one poll, conducted by the Gallup Organization after the hearings, found that roughly one of every two viewers who watched a significant amount of the inquiry came away feeling less confident about Congress and the Congressional process.
Further, the poll found that of the leading members of the Judiciary Committee, only its chairman, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, won a favorable rating from a majority of all viewers. Sixty-three percent said they were well impressed by his performance.
Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, won a favorable rating of 48 percent, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, won a 41 percent favorable rating and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts won a 22 percent favorable rating, the lowest recorded. The poll, conducted on Oct. 14, was based on telephone interviews with 612 adults and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
Following are reports on how the hearings affected these legislators in their home states.
 
Wyoming
Simpson Assailed For Speaking Out
The unvarnished style of Senator Alan K. Simpson has long been revered here as pure Wyoming, as stark and rugged as the untamed high plains. To some voters, his pugnacious performance on the Judiciary Committee last weekend marked him as a rare politician who really says what he thinks, rather than affecting a phony civility.
But to others, Mr. Simpson's behavior reflected something else about the state: the ferocious, howling wind. In interviews this week, many said his attacks on Prof. Anita F. Hill seemed cruel. And his shouted diatribe against Nina Totenberg, who reports on the Supreme Court for National Public Radio and first interviewed Professor Hill's about her accusations of sexual harassment against Judge Clarence Thomas, did not square with his image as a tall, self-effacing cowboy from Cody.
"I thought he made a total ass of himself, and he won't get my vote again," said Barbara Martin, a 42-year-old secretary for an oil company. "He was completely out of line."
To be sure, many other voters still regard the third-term Senator as a hero. "Simpson is almost like God in this state," said Joe Yoksh, a 24-year-old bartender who usually votes Democratic. "He's like the people out here. He's a good old boy -- plain-spoken, regular and honest as they come."
 
Politics With Personal Feel
 In this thinly populated state, where almost everyone can claim to have met Mr. Simpson and he is simply called Al, politics has a distinctly personal feeling. Personality can count for as much as a voting record. And it was Mr. Simpson's style, not his political leanings, that has been the talk across Wyoming.
Before, during and after the Senate confirmation hearings, Senator Simpson figured in one highly publicized sideshow after another. After appearing on the ABC News program "Nightline," he followed Ms. Totenberg into the parking lot and lambasted her for disclosing the accusations.
In a television interview, he said that Professor Hill was a "dupe" of liberal forces opposing Judge Thomas. In a remark that was widely condemned as unfair, Mr. Simpson alluded to a sheaf of affadavits that he said would discredit Professor Hill's character and reveal her "proclivities," a loaded word that prompted harsh criticism from one Wyoming newspaper.
In an editorial, The Wyoming Eagle in Cheyenne characterized Mr. Simpson's remarks as an "appalling fashion for a politician who repeatedly stresses the need for fairness." The editorial went on, "It was a remarkably cheap shot in a hearing that was dominated by such action."
A spokeswoman for Mr. Simpson said that during and after the hearings there had been thousands of calls to his office in Washington, , and added that they had been running about even, for and against.
But Marcia White, 54, who owns a vitamin manufacturing company in Douglas, said critics of Mr. Simpson simply do not understand the man.
"The feminists are upset with him, but he is truly very respectful of women," she said.

HEADLINE: Seeking the Serum to Cure Hospital Emergency Room Crises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I commend your Oct. 8 editorial addressing what has become a crisis in this city's hospital emergency rooms, and the emergency that prevails at Kings County Hospital. The hospital lies within my Congressional district, and I have participated over recent years in many community efforts to improve staffing and care, only to see these attempts at a cure fail for lack of the one serum that could do the job: adequate financing. 
 Kings County Hospital's Emergency Room is by far the busiest in New York City and, unfortunately, many thousands come to the E.R. because past recommendations for more decentralized clinics have been ignored, and these people have no other source for medical services. The community suffers from too many who are unemployed or too poor to pay for health care; thousands of others have low-paid jobs but, like some 30 million workers in this country, they have no protective health care insurance. I have invited community leaders to meet with me to reinstate an Emergency Care Task Force and to establish a special subcommittee to cope with the problems of the embattled Kings County Emergency Room.
The key to a long-range solution lies in legislation to establish a universal health care system for all Americans. I am a co-sponsor of the Russo bill (H.R. 1300), which represents the most promising move in this direction.
 
MAJOR R. OWENS
Member of Congress, 12th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Oct. 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The Latin Market Comes Back

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
FOR decades, Latin America was a hugely important marketplace for the United States -- one that largely shut down in the 1980's when the Latin nations fell far behind in their debt payments. These countries are still deeply in arrears. But nearly a decade after the onset of the foreign-debt crisis, Latin America is re-emerging as a big buyer of American goods and a big borrower.
The comeback is quite bullish. This month alone, the Latin nations have borrowed nearly $900 million abroad. And United States exports to Latin countries are approaching the levels of the golden 1960's and 1970's, when they accounted for more than 15 percent of all American goods sold overseas. The beneficiaries of these new exports, of course, are American manufacturers, which, in a recession year, have enjoyed a windfall of $3 billion in extra sales from an unexpected quarter. 
 Various reasons are offered for what C. Fred Bergsten, president of the Institute for International Economics, calls "the 180-degree change in the business and investment climate." Such swings occur periodically in Latin America, but in the view of many economists this one seems likely to endure longer than most.
The rebirth of the Latin marketplace began in the late 1980's, when unpaid bank debt was converted into longer-term Treasury bonds. In the process, debt payments were reduced and postponed, freeing up money to take on new debt.
With this foundation coming into place, Latin America has increasingly embraced free and open markets, dismantling the state capitalism that had predominated since World War II. The phenomenon is most evident in Mexico, but is also well along in Chile, Venezuela, Colombia and Argentina.
The free-market embrace is drawing new dollars to Latin America in several ways. Government deficits have been reduced through layoffs at state-owned enterprises and cutbacks in public services. With less money printed to cover shrinking deficits, inflation has declined and currencies have strengthened, thus making foreign investment less risky. Privatization of state-owned companies is also in full swing, and the dollars paid into Latin treasuries to purchase these companies help to pay for imports and to service new debt.
What's more, privatization makes new lending more attractive, says John Purcell, a research director at Salomon Brothers. "A lot of these enterprises were money losers as state enterprises," he said, "while in private hands they are more likely to be profitable, a prospect that makes the bonds they sell seem less risky to investors."
Finally, trade barriers and tariffs have been removed or lowered, so that an imported General Electric dishwasher now often costs no more than a poor-quality, inefficiently manufactured Argentine or Mexican version. As a result, exports to Latin America in the second quarter reached $15.6 billion, or 15 percent of total United States exports. Through most of the 1980's, they rarely exceeded 14 percent of the total.
But the new activity is a gamble, one that counts heavily on Latin America becoming part of a free-trade zone linked to the United States economy. The soon-to-be-negotiated free trade agreement with Mexico is the first step in this process. As if it were already signed, northern Mexico is quickly becoming a United States manufacturing center, populated by American-owned manufacturers shipping numerous products back home.
"Mexico is the prototype," said Harley Shaiken, a University of California economist. "There might be losers, but for the moment everyone is lowering barriers and seeking agreements that will also plug them into the American economy."
So far, Mexico is also the major Latin importer of American goods, and the biggest borrower, accounting for $4.4 billion of the $6.7 billion in new Latin debt floated since November 1989, says Latin Finance, a Miami publication. But rather than foreign bank loans, the debt this time is through bonds sold by Latin governments and companies and purchased mainly by individuals abroad.
Most of these bonds require repayment in five years or less and offer yields above 10 percent, reflecting their riskiness and attracting American investors who once purchased high-yield corporate junk bonds in the United States, until that market declined. The bonds' riskiness suggests the possibility of a future debt crisis, which could damage the reputations of the American companies -- among them Salomon, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Morgan Stanley & Company -- that have played major roles in underwriting the bonds.
"We do in a way have to stand behind them," Mr. Purcell of Salomon said. "You are supposed to believe in an issue that you bring to market; you lose your customers if you don't."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Broad Advances for Dollar On Prospect of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against other major currencies yesterday, helped by hopes that United States interest rates would move higher.
Gold prices jumped overseas -- by $4.20 in London, to $364.25 -- but rose less sharply in later New York trading. Gold rose $1.60 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $363.80 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $363.25, up $1.50. 
Foreign exchange analysts said the dollar had moved higher in response to surging market interest rates, which can lead to higher rates elsewhere in the economy. The dollar, like other currencies, draws support from higher interest rates.
 
Long-Bond Rates
 The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond, used as a basis for setting a variety of other rates, jumped to 8.07 percent in late trading yesterday from Friday's 7.95 percent.
John McCarthy, chief foreign exchange dealer with ABN-AMRO Bank N.V., said the dollar was also helped by a feeling in the market that "there are potential inflation problems down the road."
He noted that precious metals prices moved higher in recent weeks and oil prices were at their highest levels since the gulf war.
Although the Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates to aid the sputtering recovery, many traders believe that if inflation accelerates, the central bank will be forced to push rates up.
The markets are waiting for fresh economic news, particularly durable goods orders from September, which are scheduled on Thursday.
The dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen, rising to 130.80 yen in New York, from 129.65 on Friday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.75 yen, closing 130.60 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 130.70 yen.
The British pound fell against the dollar, slipping to $1.7165 in New York from late Friday's $1.7270. In earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.7185 from $1.7245.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6933 German marks, up from 1.6865; 1.4835 Swiss francs, up from 1.4750; 5.7750 French francs, up from 5.7490; 1,266.00 Italian lire, up from 1261.25, and 1.12625 Canadian dollars, down from 1.12675.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Tax-Cut Talk Sends Prices Down

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Talk of tax cuts to revive the economy rattled investors in the Treasury bond market yesterday, and prices of long-term securities fell by more than a point, while yields rose above 8 percent.
"The debate about fiscal stimulus is sending a cold chill through the market," one government securities trader said. "If we are going to focus in on what is going on in Washington, that is going to hurt." 
 Last week Bush Administration officials began to suggest it would seek a number of tax changes, including a cut in the capital gains tax, to stimulate the economy. The debate was joined over the weekend by Democratic legislators, including Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who called for tax cuts for middle-income families and fully deductible I.R.A.'s.
Reaction to the proposals was seen first in Asia, where market participants sold securities during overnight trading. The selloff continued when activity shifted to Europe and then to the United States.
Congress is to adjourn for the year in little more than a month, and analysts acknowledged that tax cuts are unlikely to be more than a talking point until sometime in 1992.
But for credit market participants the implications of the discussion seem ominous.
"If the talk represents a shift from monetary to fiscal policy, it suggests there will be less of a reliance on the Fed to lower short-term rates," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
"Second, with huge budget deficits lurking around the corner, the talk of tax cuts suggests the burden on the market would be even greater."
Thus far, the tax cut talk in Washington has emphasized that the changes would not worsen the deficit. Financial market participants are skeptical.
"Anyone in the market would be happy if tax cuts were matched with revenue cuts," said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting firm. "But most in the market seem to believe that we will see the former and not the latter."
With no important economic reports released yesterday, the negative Washington talk dominated the session.
"There was no good news to offset this," Mr. McCarthy said.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 100 19/32, down nearly 1 1/2 points, or almost $15 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.07 percent. Late Friday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 7.95 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 22/ 32, down 7/8 point, to yield 7.62 percent. And the 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9.32, down 1/8 point, to yield 5.96 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the new three-month securities were sold at an average discount rate of 5.04 percent, up from an average rate of 4.99 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 5.11 percent, up from the average rate of 5.03 percent at the sale a week ago.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Philip Morris Companies offered $350 million of 12-year notes at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Merrill Lynch & Company won the securities. They were reoffered to investors with a coupon of 8.25 percent, and were priced at $99.582, to yield 8.305 percent, 75 basis points, or 75 one-hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, mature Oct. 15, 2003. They are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The slide in Treasury prices spilled over into the corporate and tax-exempt municipal bond markets.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues dipped by about 1/8 point in light trading.
In the municipal bond market, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues fell by about 3/8 point.

HEADLINE: Montgomery Ward Plans Return to Catalogue Trade

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Montgomery Ward & Company wants to muscle its way back into the crowded catalogue business.
The big Chicago retailer, which closed its unprofitable catalogue division in 1985, said yesterday that it was teaming with the Fingerhut Companies, a mail-order concern, to start a company to produce nearly a dozen separate catalogues a year. 
 Unlike its previous "big book" general-merchandise catalogue, which included 100,000 different items, Ward now plans to mail separate, narrowly focused catalogues for clothing, electronics, jewelry and cosmetics and other merchandise.
Bernard F. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Ward, said he expected the sales of the new company, called Montgomery Ward Direct, to reach $500 million in five years.
In pursuing the specialty mail-order business, Ward hopes to avoid the problems of the troubled catalogue divisions of Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J .C. Penney Company. The country's last two large general-merchandise catalogues are performing poorly. Sears's unprofitable mail-order business, which includes some specialty catalogues, still does the bulk of its business from its 1,600-page fall and spring catalogues.
When Mr. Brennan closed Ward's catalogue operation in 1985, it was losing $75 million a year on sales of $1.2 billion.
"In 1985, I said that general-merchandise catalogues were no longer viable," Mr. Brennan said yesterday. He said that was even more true today, with specialty merchandisers supplanting generalists at both the catalogue and the store level. "It is just impossible to satisfy a customer today with a broad array of merchandise," he said. Mr. Brennan has considerably narrowed the focus of the Ward's stores.
But Montgomery Ward is entering the catalogue business at a difficult time. With the cost of setting up a mail-order operation comparatively low, the field is crowded. There are 8,000 catalogue companies in the country, according to the Direct Marketing Association, a trade group in New York.
In addition, there was a substantial increase earlier this year in the third- class postal rates used by catalogue mailers, and the weak economy has hurt many retailers, including mail- order merchants.
"You've got three negatives on the horizon that you didn't have four or five years ago," said Richard Pyle, an analyst in Minneapolis with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. "It's more difficult to make the kind of profit margins that you used to in the business."
 
'Perfect Timing'
 Weaker companies are beginning to fall by the wayside, retail experts said. But the turmoil makes it "perfect timing" for the new venture to enter the market, contends Theodore Deikel, chairman and chief executive of Fingerhut, based in Minneapolis.
"As those that still have the big books try to figure out what to do and struggle for direction," Mr. Deikel said, "we are jumping in."
The lure of the mail-order business is considerable, with more and more time-pressed shoppers buying merchandise over the phone or through the mail. While only sketchy numbers exist, the Direct Marketing Association said that mail-order sales exceeded $25 billion last year. The trade group said that half of the consumers in the country shop by phone or by mail at least once a year.
 
Chances of Success
 Some analysts said that Montgomery Ward's name and considerable resources gave the venture a good chance of success.
"It is a very smart and strategic move," said George Rosenbaum, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a research firm in Chicago.
Ward plans to send catalogues primarily to its 10 million credit card customers. Fingerhut will supply the expertise of running a mail-order business.
Fingerhut is known for catalogues featuring knickknacks and arts and crafts supplies aimed largely at the blue collar market. Stock in the company, which had $1.2 billion in sales last year, rose $1.125, to $29.375, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
Ward was taken private in 1988 in a $3.8 billion management buyout led by Mr. Brennan. The company had $5.5 billion in sales last year and profits of $153 million, Mr. Brennan said.
Ward and Fingerhut described the new venture as a partnership that would be equally owned by affiliates of the two companies. The mail-order business will have headquarters in Minneapolis. The first catalogue will be mailed out early next year.
Mr. Brennan said the company would be profitable in its first year of operation.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls By 16.77, To 3,060.38

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices pulled back yesterday from Friday's record levels, with analysts citing a weak bond market, rising inflation fears and some gloomy corporate earnings.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.77 points, to 3,060.38, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index declined by 1.27, to 214.88. 
 But the declines came without heavy selling, as volume was significantly off last week's heavy pace. Trading on the Big Board was a moderate 154.2 million shares, down from 205.3 million on Friday. Losers outpaced gainers by 1,014 to 626.
 
Looking to Interest Rates
 In trying to explain the decline, Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president and head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers, pointed to the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond, which rose to 8.07 percent yesterday.
"Above 8 percent, it sent a message to the market that the Fed may not be so accommodating" in moving to lower interest rates, he said.
Most traders do not expect stocks to rebound until Treasury security prices stablize. "Today's pullback should not be a surprise to anyone," Mr. Grennan said. "Each time this year that the Dow has reached a new high, the market has sold off."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.48, to 390.02, while the American Stock Exchange composite slipped 0.71, to 381.78. Trading in smaller issues was also down. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter trading was down 1.94, to 536.96, and the Russell 2000 index off by 0.44 to close at 182.97.
 
Rally in Blue Chips
 Blue-chip stocks, which were down in early trading and throughout most of the day, made a strong comeback, helping a Dow that was off as much 34.66 points in afternoon trading cut half its losses.
Poor earnings hurt both Owens-Corning Fiberglas, down 4 1/2, to 20 1/4, and International Rectifier, down 5, to 13 1/4. Owens-Corning reported on Friday that it would increase 1992 asbestos litigation reserves. Traders also said that Jonathan Goldfarb, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, had lowered his recommendation and slashed his 1991 and 1992 earnings estimates for the company.
But some stocks rose on better earnings, including U.S. Healthcare, up 1 1/8, to 29 1/2, and Thorn Apple, a food concern, which closed up 1 1/4, to 42 1/2. Chase Manhattan's third-quarter earnings of $136 million, compared with a loss of $623 million in last year's third quarter, pushed that stock up 1/2, to 19.
Traders said Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, lowered his estimates on Wells Fargo and two other California banks, citing the slow pace of recovery in that state's economy. Wells Fargo stock fell 5/8, to 69 7/8.
 
Gain for Time Warner
 Time Warner, still wrestling with a heavy debt burden, rose 1 1/2, to 85 7/8. Although the company reported a third-quarter loss of $62 million, compared with a loss of $91 million in the period last year, analysts saw surprising earnings strength in the company's publishing operations, where more than 600 jobs are being cut and the company has taken a $60 million restructuring charge.
But the market took exception to Keystone International's flat earnings outlook for the fourth quarter. The stock in the maker of flow-control systems fell 5 3/4, to 25 1/2.
Robert M. Goldman at Dean Witter Reynolds said he was repeating his "buy" recommendation for U.S. Surgical based on information from a conference of the American College of Surgeons, which opened yesterday in Chicago. U.S. Surgical, which makes surgical stapling devices and sutures, rose 5 1/8, to 91.
Lockheed rose 1 7/8, to 43 1/4, as Michael Lauer, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, upgraded the company to a "trading buy."

HEADLINE: Amoco Off 45.3% on Woe In Oil Patch

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that its earnings fell 45.3 percent in the third quarter. It was the first report in what analysts said would be a two-week stream of sharply lower earnings results from the nation's major oil companies.
Prices for crude oil fell by an average of about $5 a barrel during the quarter ended Sept. 30 from the level of a year ago, when they had surged following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. 
 Amoco, the largest producer of natural gas in North America, was also hurt by a plunge in gas prices in midsummer. Gas prices fell to the lowest level in 15 years, at less than $1.10 for 1,000 cubic feet, before rebounding in September.
 
'Worst Quarter in 10 Years'
 "We think this will be the worst quarter for oil-company earnings in 10 years," said Frederick P. Leuffer, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence Inc.
But with prices climbing in recent weeks, the third period will mark the industry's lowest point for the year, he said. Unofficial figures indicate that gasoline demand rose by at least 1 percent in the third quarter, the first increase for the year, he said, and it appears headed higher.
The November contract for domestic crude traded at $24.04 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up nearly $4 from the average posted price for the third quarter of $20.30 a barrel, and just below the average posted price for domestic crude of $25.50 a barrel in the third quarter last year. Natural gas prices have risen to $1.55 for 1,000 cubic feet, a 30-cent increase from the average in the third quarter.
Amoco, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, said net income fell to $290 million, or 59 cents a share, from $530 million, or $1.04 a share, in the quarter a year ago. Revenues fell 11.3 percent, to $7.01 billion from $7.90 billion.
 
Charge for Shutting Refinery
 Earnings for the 1991 quarter were depressed by a $76 million expense related to the shutdown of a refinery in Casper, Wyo. Paul Mlotok, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said Amoco's operating income was better than expected because of lower exploration costs. "Under the circumstances, the performance was quite good," he said.
Amoco's refining and marketing operations showed gains because crude costs were lower than a year ago. Profits in that unit rose to $169 million, from $129 million, but income fell in chemicals, to $13 million, from $37 million in the 1990 period. Mr. Mlotok said demand declined because of the recession.
Amoco's share price fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $53.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
1,200 Layoffs At Wal-Mart

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that it was laying off up to 1,200 workers in what it called a normal payroll adjustment and not a response to the weak economy.
It appeared likely that Wal- Mart, which has a work force of 367,000, took the step to keep costs in line. Wal-Mart, one of the nation's largest retailers, has built its reputation and success on lower prices, which are dependent on reduced expenses. 
 Don Shinkle, a Wal-Mart spokesman, said from the company's headquarters in Bentonville, Ark., that the cuts were made in the Sam's Clubs warehouse division. About 25 jobs were cut at Sam's headquarters, while the others were spread out among the 192 Sam's outlets, he said.
"You look at your payroll and you make various periodic adjustments, depending on the market and other criteria," Mr. Shinkle said. He said Wal- Mart would be adding sales help for the holiday season.
Analysts were surprised by the layoffs, but said the retailer was probably trying to insure that costs remained under control. "As far as I know, they're certainly not having any problems," said Joseph Ronning, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
Besides Sam's, Wal-Mart operates more than 1,600 Wal- Mart discount stores and four Hypermart USA outlets.
Wal-Mart's shares were down 12.5 cents, to $49, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chain of Mental Hospitals Faces Inquiry in 4 States

SERIES: Psychiatry for Profit: Trouble at Private Hospitals -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Law enforcement officials in several states have begun investigations of one of the nation's largest private psychiatric-hospital chains on charges that it systematically misdiagnosed, mistreated and abused patients to increase its profits from insurance claims.
Over the last decade, the company at the center of the investigations, Psychiatric Institutes of America, the operator of 73 hospitals and treatment centers across the nation, has been regarded as one of the most modern, profitable and prestigious enterprises in the fast-growing industry of private psychiatric hospitals. 
 Its Fair Oaks Hospital in Summit, N. J., for example, is widely known as a center for research and treatment of drug addiction. In the 1980's, celebrities praised their treatment there and its doctors were models to many health professionals of a new generation of psychiatrists as entrepreneurs.
The investigations, under way in New Jersey, Texas, Florida and Alabama, involve complaints from those and other states, law enforcement officials say.
The company says that complaints against its hospitals and drug and alcohol treatment centers are overblown or inaccurate. It says they are not guilty of any wrongdoing.
But health authorities say that questions about these institutions are part of a broad, accelerating crisis in the private, for-profit psychiatric-hospital industry, an enterprise that has grown rapidly in the last decade. At its heart is a fierce argument about their quality of care, rising costs and attempts to balance the needs of patients with the search for profits.
Concern about the possible abuse or overuse of mental-health services is especially great now because the costs associated with these practices have become an important factor in driving up the nation's overall health costs -- now 12 percent of the gross national product.
"One of the big questions facing American psychiatry is whether or not the profit motive in hospitals drives people to do things that are unacceptable ethically," said Dr. Paul Fink, a former president of the American Psychiatric Association. "That doesn't mean every private psychiatric hospital is bad. It means that some people who tie their jobs and their world to the bottom line are going to seek patients in every way they can."
In more than 200 complaints to law enforcement officials in New Jersey, Florida, Texas and Alabama, and in an extensive series of interviews, former patients, their relatives and former staff members made these charges, among others:
*The company's hospitals in New Jersey, Florida and Texas admitted patients who did not need hospitalization. In Texas, the State Attorney General says the hospitals hired "bounty hunters" who "kidnapped" patients with medical insurance.
*In Florida, former patients and their families charged in lawsuits that the hospitals kept patients against their will, or even against the wishes of their families, including, in one case, a 3-year-old child.
*The company's hospitals in New Jersey and Florida crafted diagnoses to meet patients' insurance coverage, investigators said.
*In some cases, the hospitals kept patients until their insurance ran out, whether they needed such hospitalization or not, according to law suits and former staff members in New Jersey, Florida and Alabama. In other cases, the hospitals are said to have released patients as soon as their insurance was exhausted whether they were ready to be diswhether they were ready to be discharged or not.
*Hospitals in a number of states awarded bonuses to top staff members as incentives to keep patients for longer stays, former staff members said.
 
Company Defends Treatment
 A spokesman for the company, which is a subsidiary of National Medical Enterprises Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif., said that charges against the hospitals were made by a small number of former employees and that treatment at most of the chain's hospitals was beyond reproach.
"Patients are admitted by physicians when physicians determine that it is medically necessary to do so," said the spokesman, David Olson. "The overwhelming majority of patients are the subject of outside third-party utilization review or case management."
Charges of kidnapping, altering diagnosis, or any altering of medical tally false, he said, adding that it is ending the practice of paying staff bonuses on the basis of the number of patients in hospitals.
Nonetheless, Mr. Olson said, the company recently hired two law firms to conduct a review of practices at all its hospitals, and the top executive overseeing the psychiatric hospital subsidiary, Norman A. Zober, left his post on paid leave earlier this month.
Mr. Olson said that National Medical Enterprises did not comment on cases of individuals. In Florida, dozens of former patients from the company's two hospitals in Palm Beach County have registered their complaints, often in public demonstrations outside the hospitals. Bill Coakley, an organizer of the demonstrations, pointed to a number of examples. These and other former patients made themselves available for interviews after several of them found they had had similar experiences, formed patients' advocacy groups and decided their stories should be made public.
 
Admitted for Anorexia
 Kelly Dewald, a Palm Beach County resident, said she voluntarily admitted herself to the company's Lake Hospital of the Palm Beaches in Lake Worth for treatment of anorexia four years ago when she was l7 years old. She said she received little treatment for the eating disorder but instead was put on antidepressants that brought on hallucinations and paranoia. After 34 days, when her insurance ran out, she said she was summarily discharged and told her treatment was over.
"At this point I was left with nothing," she said. "But one week after I stopped taking medication, the violence, the fear and paranoia disappeared."
Her bill, for nearly $26,000, included charges of $3.75 for one Bufferin tablet and 30 biofeedback sessions at $150 each. She said that she had been unable to get anyone at the hospital to take her complaints seriously, and that she had talked to a lawyer who said she would probably lose if she went to court.
Charges at Psychatric Institute hospitals in Florida and New Jersey often run from $700 to $1,000 a day. The costs of residential treatment vary greatly at other hospitals, but according to Dr. Charles E. Riordan, a clinical professor of psychatry at Yale University, public or not-for-profit private hospitals often charge $400 to $500 daily.
In another Florida case, Eileen Vinsand, the wife of a Palm Beach County firefighter, said the stay of her 10-year-old son, Jimmy, in the company's Fair Oaks Hospital in Boca Delray turned into the worst conceivable family horror. A school guidance counselor recommended that Fair Oaks evaluate the boy in 1988 for hyperactivity and behavioral problems.
 
Asked About Insurance
 She said the hospital's first question was whether he was covered by insurance and when that was confirmed he was promptly admitted. Mrs. Vinsand, who had been trained as a nurse, said she was subsequently told that she could not visit her son. But she said she forced her way into his room and that what she saw were actions unlike anything she had seen in him before: "He was having what looked like grand mal seizures. He was terrified. He was flipping his head back and stuttering and his eyes were running back into his head."
She said she demanded his release but the doctor in charge told her that her son had brain damage and if she removed him the hospital could have her rights of custody to the child taken away.
"I believed it," she said. "They play off your emotions. They have M.D.'s after their names. They are God."
Her son was released several days before his insurance ran out. She said Jimmy soon regained his normal health and has now outgrown his hyperactivity.
Why did she not sue? Because the child got better so quickly and "you don't sue God."
 
Threat Is Reported
 Last January in Anniston, Ala., W.T. Gable, a retired insurance agent, said he took his 73-year-old wife, Elsie, who was having repeated nightmares, to the psychiatric ward at the Regional Medical Center. The ward is operated by Psychiatric Institutes of America.
Mr. Gable said that after a week he wanted to take her out of the hospital but that the doctor in charge refused to allow her to leave and quoted him as saying: "If you do, I'll fix it so that no a doctor in town will touch her."
Mr. Gable said, "I have witnesses who heard that." Mr. Gable said from the day of admission, a chart listed Mrs. Gable's release date as Feb. 6 -- the day her insurance ran out.
"Their intention was to keep her until the 6th," he said, "even before they knew what was wrong with her."
Last year, the medical director and the head psychologist on the ward resigned, saying patients were kept until their insurance ran out.
Psychiatric Institutes of America is one of several major companies that rapidly developed chains of investor-owned psychiatric hospitals in the 1980's. The number of beds in for-profit psychiatric hospitals in the United States grew to 37,500 in 1990 from 21,400 in 1984. The total number of such hospitals grew to 440 in 1988 from 220 in 1984.
 
Increased Public Acceptance
 The growth came as a result of increased public acceptance of psychiatric care, the growth of health insurance plans that paid for psychiatric treatment and the widespread deregulation of the hospitals in several states.
In places like Palm Beach County, one of Florida's affluent vacation spots, for example, the number of free-standing private psychiatric hospitals grew from one to seven, while other general-care hospitals also opened up psychiatric and drug and alcohol units. The same increase, from one to seven, took place in Dallas.
Although scattered complaints have been made about other companies, officials say they have not identified other for-profit hospitals for investigation.
And medical authorities are quick to point out that some of the new entrepreneurial hospitals are providing excellent care. Still, many psychiatrists said they were troubled by the companies' generally aggressive advertising campaigns and the premiums they put on getting and keeping patients with insurance.
 
Florida Investigations
 A spokesman for the Florida Attorney General's office said yesterday that his state's investigation was being handled by the its consumer litigation division, focusing on Fair Oaks and Lake Hospitals. The state insurance company's fraud division said it had begun its own investigation.
In Texas, where Psychiatric Institutes of America operates 13 hospitals, the Attorney General's office is suing the company to stop payment of $3.1 million in funds from a crime victim's compensation fund, which pays for victims' psychiatric services. The suit involves at least 125 patients.
In the suit, the state charges that patients were "subjected to unnecessary and expensive treatment programs, some of which are administered by persons not trained to safely conducte such programs." The state says it is also investigating charges that the company hired people it called bounty hunters to "infiltrate" meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous to find patients.
"They would simply kidnap various persons who didn't need treatment of any kind," said Ron Dusek, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office. "And once they got them into the hospital they held them against their will until the insurance claims ran out."
 
Settlement in New Jersey
 In New Jersey this summer, Psychiatric Institutes of America, which owns Fair Oaks Hospital in Summit, together with doctors there, agreed to pay a $400,000 fine to the state, the largest such settlement in state history.
Both sides agreed not to discuss the basis for the payment but the state said the investigation came in response to complaints from patients and staff members.
Officials familiar with the New Jersey inquiry said that in recent weeks Federal agents and the United States Attorney's office in Newark had joined a new investigation of Fair Oaks that involved charges of criminal insurance fraud.
Louis Parisi, who heads the New Jersey Insurance Department's investigation division, said the department had received more than 300 complaints from around the country about hospitals owned or operated by Psychiatric institutes of America.
Among the charges being investigated in New Jersey, state officials say, are those of Dr. Robert Stuckey, a psychiatrist who served as the medical director of the alcoholic unit at Fair Oaks from 1975 to 1985.
In an interview yesterday, Dr. Stuckey said patients were admitted who did not need treatment and that their diagnoses were shaped to take advantage of insurance coverage.
 
'Analysis of Insurance'
 "The starting point was always their remarkable analysis of insurance," Dr. Stuckey said. "They were geniuses at assessing and diagnosing insurance."
He added: "They took people who didn't need psychiatry. "They took people who couldn't defend themselves and kept them in hospitals for months."
Critics of the hospitals in Florida say that the plight of patients may be best illustrated by the case of three children whose parents were divorced and who were were being confined unnecessarily at Fair Oaks at Boca Delray.
The children's father, George Pallay, has sued the hospital, saying that his children, aged 3, 8 and 9, had been held for six weeks until their insurance coverage ran out.
Mr. Pallay's lawyer, Theresa DiPaolo, said an investigation by insurance companies later found that the children did not need psychiatric hospitalization.

HEADLINE: Ex-Backers of Ousted Haitian Say He Alienated His Allies

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 15

 BODY:
When the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide won Haiti's first democratic presidential elections in December, his landslide victory sent tens of thousands of Haitians coursing through the streets waving branches stripped from trees and crowing like the rooster that was their leader's campaign symbol.
One of the new President's first acts was to declare a "marriage" with a long-troublesome Haitian Army, whose enlisted soldiers, he was fond of pointing out, shared a dirt-poor background with his core supporters. 
 Summoned by signs of hope that the country had rarely seen, planeloads of skilled Haitians were soon returning from exile to offer their services to their largely illiterate homeland. Even skeptical diplomats had begun to express admiration for the leftist priest's unexpected moderation in many of his economic and foreign policies.
But now, in the time since he was deposed by a rebellious army on Sept. 30, many who had supported the eight-month presidency of Father Aristide say the collapse of Haiti's brief experiment with democracy was hastened by an insular and menacing leader who saw his own raw popularity as a substitute for the give and take of politics.
 
Froze Out Other Officials
 While President Aristide performed as expected in combating the corrupt vestiges of the political class that flourished during the 29-year Duvalier family dictatorship, he also quickly froze out even those newly elected officials who had equally long records of fighting dictatorship.
Soon, he was governing a country of nearly seven million people with the aid of fear and a tight circle of friends. When political allies were needed to break his fall, none could be found.
"These guys were too taken with the politics of conspiracy to imagine how you can get things done by working with people," said Jocelyn McCalla, a Haitian human rights expert. "As things developed, Aristide grew increasingly isolated and the people around him saw every criticism as a plot to subvert them."
Just weeks before undertaking his candidacy, the 38-year-old Father Aristide, a longtime priest in Port-au-Prince's slums, was denouncing the coming elections as an American ruse to impose yet another puppet government that he said would exploit the country.
In a last-minute bid to defeat Roger Lafontant, a widely feared former Interior Minister under the Duvalier dictatorship, however, the Haitian left came together briefly and persuaded Father Aristide to be its candidate.
 
Knew How to Rouse Poor
 As an unbending foe of Duvalierism who had escaped repeated attacks by death squads, Father Aristide had strong credentials. And unlike many Haitian political leaders, he knew how to rouse the poor, who form the vast majority of the country's population.
Requiring a legal sponsor, Father Aristide's candidacy was rushed onto the ballots under the banner of the National Front for Change and Democracy, a left-of-center coalition of intellectuals and labor and grass-roots political leaders.
Once he gained office, however, the National Front, which would have instantly provided him with a large bloc of parliamentary supporters, was jettisoned by a President riding a tide of immense personal popularity.
Almost immediately, Father Aristide began intimating that political parties were not representative of the people. In place of the parties, the new President began to lean heavily on Lavalas, an unstructured movement of affluent idealists and long-exiled leftists who had helped finance his candidacy. Soon, he was invoking the group's name, which means torrent or flood in Creole, in everything from greetings to his speeches.
 
'Out of Another Era'
 "These folks came straight out of another era," a diplomat said of the Lavalas activists. "Their political models were Paris in 1968 and the Cultural Revolution in China."
Lavalas quickly became perceived as both gatekeeeper and ideological rudder of the administration, guiding everything from personnel decisions to the Government's increasingly disputatious relations with Parliament.
"For Lavalas, the Parliament became a negation of the power the people gave Aristide," said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a human rights advocate whose organization, Konakom, had supported the priest's candidacy. "They reasoned that Aristide should have had all the power because he was the people."
Drawing the most surprise and criticism was his choice of a close friend for Prime Minister, Rene Preval, who was little known.
 
Party Is 'Shut Out'
 "From the start, we were shut out of the process," Senator Jean-Robert Martinez said of the way his National Front party was treated. "The President didn't even want to talk to us."
Father Aristide's decision to govern without the help of political parties was quickly followed by other signs of unilateral actions, which sounded alarms from the National Assembly to foreign embassies over his commitment to democracy.
From judicial appointments to ambassadorial nominations, diplomats say, the President repeatedly sought to bypass the Assembly, whose advise-and-consent role in such matters was clearly established in the 1987 Constitution.
When the legislature refused to back down, a crowd of at least 2,000 Aristide supporters surrounded the National Assembly on Aug. 13, roughing up two deputies and threatening to burn others alive if they moved ahead with a planned motion of no confidence against Prime Minister Preval.
That week, the offices of the National Front, Father Aristide's onetime electoral allies, were sprayed with bullets while a meeting was being held inside. The offices here of Mayor Evans Paul, a National Front leader, were stoned, and the headquarters of a labor union that had backed Father Aristede's candidacy was burned by his supporters.
A Senator's home was also attacked by a mob and a deputy was threatened with "Pere Lebrun," or burning alive by a group armed with used tires and a bottle of gasoline.
For months, Father Aristide had justified the practice of Pere Lebrun as a "legitimate expression" of outrage by a people who had no other recourse. Now, many felt his supporters were reinstating terror as a central motif in the country's political life.
As the President's troubles with civil society grew, so did his problems with the army. Much as he resisted submitting senior Government appointments to the legislature for its approval, the President never formally nominated Brig. Gen. Raoul Cedras, whom he had appointed to command the army.
 
Financing of Coup
 While mutual suspicions grew between the general and the President over the nomination delay, Haitian political leaders and diplomats say, the growing climate of vigilantism as well as increasingly strident statements by Father Aristide blaming the wealthier classes for the poverty of the masses encouraged a group of traders to finance a coup attempt.
Using the President's own words about Pere Lebrun, which he had praised three days before as "a nice instrument," plus warnings that he was planning to eliminate their jobs, the coup leaders were able to incite enlisted men into setting off the revolt that overthrew Father Aristide, diplomats say.
In the National Assembly, which became the focus of Haitian politics as soon as the army made clear that it had no desire to hold on to power, a sigh of relief could be heard among senators and deputies who had come to loathe a heavy-handed President they had only recently celebrated.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Says Hong Kong Can Return 222 Refugees by Force

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The British Government announced today that it had persuaded Vietnam to let the authorities in Hong Kong fly 222 boat people back to Vietnam against their will next month, and that it would keep trying to persuade Hanoi to take back tens of thousands more.
Britain had hoped last week to announce an agreement in principle with Vietnam accepting involuntary repatriation. This would permit the authorities in Hong Kong to begin deporting most of the 64,000 Vietnamese who are being held in 12 camps after arriving by boat and asking for asylum. Few have any prospect of being admitted to the British crown colony as refugees from political persecution. 
 Officials here in London offered no explanation for the failure so far to reach this broader agreement.
"Discussion on the detailed arrangements for repatriating other non-refugees in Hong Kong continues," the Foreign Office said today. "The Vietnamese Government has confirmed that no illegal immigrant who returns to Vietnam will face persecution and that it will continue to facilitate the monitoring of returnees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and others to insure that these guarantees are fully respected."
 
'Just the First Step'
 "This was just the first step," a British spokesman said, adding that the Hong Kong Government would probably wait until November to give the Vietnamese a chance to make arrangements for receiving the 222 to be returned.
The desire of London to send them back has put it at odds with Washington, which opposes involuntarily repatriations to Vietnam for any reason. The British argue that most of the boat people these days are fleeing economic conditions, not political repression. "Frankly, I find the American opposition to be incomprehensible," Alistair Asprey, the Hong Kong Government official in charge of security, said at a news conference there today.
Some British officials also point to recent decades of Vietnam's military history in making their arguments.
American forces withdrew from South Vietnam in 1973 after eight years of combat intended to prevent a military takeover by the Communist North. Two years later, the North Vietnamese Army swept down through the central highlands and then captured Saigon, ending three decades of civil warfare and uniting Vietnam under a Communist Government in Hanoi.
Sir Peter Blaker, a senior member of Parliament from the governing Conservative Party, recently described the American opposition to a forced return of Vietnamese from Hong Kong as an irrational reaction to that military defeat.
 
Talks With Washington
 But Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said this month that officials were discussing the situation with Washington and hoping to persuade the Bush Administration to acquiesce in an involuntary repatriation if they went ahead with it.
Today's agreement, the Foreign Office said, covers only Vietnamese who had come to Hong Kong once before, had been returned, and had then re-entered Hong Kong illegally a second time. Of a total of 322 people in this category, 92 have volunteered to return and 8 are awaiting screening, leaving 222 subject to return against their will, the Foreign Office said.
Of 64,000 Vietnamese asylum seekers now in Hong Kong, only 5,000 have been able to convince authorities in the overcrowded colony that they fled their homeland for political rather than economic reasons and thus qualify for refugee status. Of the rest, 41,500 are awaiting screening and 17,500 have been classified as non-refugees. The British want the Vietnamese to agree to accept them all back even if they do not want to go.
Reports from Hong Kong over the weekend said that passions were running high in the camps and that some refugees had threatened to commit suicide rather than go back to Vietnam against their will.
Britain deported 51 boat people from Hong Kong to Hanoi in December 1989, provoking protests from the United States and violence in the camps in Hong Kong. The British authorities then suspended involuntary repatriations, and began negotiating with the Vietnamese on procedures to make the process less painful.
