HEADLINE: America Grows Gloomier on Economy, Poll Shows

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
As the Presidential campaign season begins in earnest, Americans are even more deeply troubled than they were earlier this year about the state of the nation in general and of the economy in particular, according to a New York Times/ CBS News Poll.
The number of Americans who say that "things" in the country have "pretty seriously gotten off on the wrong track" has increased from 31 percent who said so in January to 42 percent in March and to 60 percent in the latest poll. And a plurality of 44 percent says things in the country are generally going worse than they were five years ago; that is up from 31 percent who expressed the same view in March. 
 Underlying this wave of pessimism is anxiety about unemployment, the recession, the Federal budget deficit and other aspects of the economy about which participants were asked. Forty-one percent of Americans say the health of the economy is the most important problem facing the country, and many predicted it would only get worse.
 
Bush's Approval Remains High
 But that deep concern for the economy does not appear to have significantly affected their political choices. Participants in the latest poll indicated that they still overwhelmingly approved of the way President Bush was handling his job, and many people said they knew little or nothing about the current Democratic Presidential contenders. Mr. Bush's overall approval rating stood at 67 percent.
The depth of concerns about the future of the country showed, however, that the President could be vulnerable next November if the economy did not rebound. Just 33 percent say they approve of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, while 57 percent disapproved.
Although Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York is not an announced candidate for President, he was the favorite among those polled who say they usually vote in Democratic primaries. These say by a 2-to-1 margin that he should run for President in 1992.
For the poll, 1,280 adults from across the political spectrum were questioned nationwide by telephone from Oct. 15 to Oct. 18. It included 991 people who say they are registered voters and 420 people who say they vote in Democratic primaries or caucuses. The survey carries a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points for all registered voters and a margin of plus or minus 5 percentage points for Democratic primary and caucus voters.
In this first temperature taking on attitudes about the 1992 Democratic Presidential field, it is clear that most voters are not yet paying much attention to the campaign.
Asked to choose among the six declared candidates at this early stage, 47 percent of the respondents who say they vote in Democratic primaries say they had no preference; 64 percent say that they are not satisfied with the candidates now running and that they wish there were more choices.
 
Rating the Democrats
 When these participants were asked to choose among eight possible contenders, the two who drew the most support may not even run: Governor Cuomo was preferred by 27 percent; the Rev. Jesse Jackson followed with 13 percent, and each of the others tallied in single digits. Although Mr. Jackson was second in the polling, respondents by a 2-to-1 margin say that he should not run, in a somewhat ambiguous result that can be attributed to the public's familiarity with his name.
Indeed, at this early stage, support for the six declared candidates generally reflects name recognition. Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former California Governor who announced his candidacy today, led with 12 percent, followed by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, with 8 percent; Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, 7 percent; Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, 5 percent; Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, 3 percent, and Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts senator, 2 percent.
In a hypothetical trial heat, Mr. Bush enjoyed an advantage of about 20 percentage points over an unnamed Democratic opponent; 49 percent of registered voters say they would probably vote for Mr. Bush, while 28 percent say they would probably back his opponent. But in an indication that Mr. Bush would be vulnerable if the economy does not rebound, 79 percent of registered voters say domestic issues "will matter more in deciding how" they vote than would foreign policy matters.
While the poll was taken in the week that the Senate was under fire for its handling of Judge Clarence Thomas's Supreme Court nomination, it does not appear to reflect this criticism.
For example, 30 percent of Americans approved of the way Congress was handling its job in a Times/CBS News Poll in August. There was very little change in early October, when 27 percent expressed the same view. And in the latest survey, 29 percent indicated approval.
Similarly, by a 55 percent majority, Americans say they trust the Senate more than the President to make the right decisions about who should sit on the Court. That is the same proportion reflected in a New York Times/CBS News poll taken in September, before the Thomas hearings.
 
A Small Slide
 More remarkable is the finding that 25 percent of the respondents say they trust the President more than they do the Senate on Court nominations, in a decline of six percentage points since the September survey. Sixty-one percent agreed with the Senate's confirmation of Judge Thomas, although 63 percent say they disapprove of the way the hearings were handled.
Nevertheless, the public found something of value in the proceedings, with 54 percent saying there is a greater likelihood that women who feel they have been sexually harassed will report the incidents.
In one shift in respondents' beliefs about Congress, 68 percent of participants in the survey say they support a term limit of 12 years for lawmakers; this represents a 12 percentage-point increase from a year ago.
Most striking was that in every question on the economy, people offer more pessimistic views than in the most recent survey, taken in June. Sixty-five percent say the economy is "very bad" or "fairly bad." This was 8 percentage points more than in June. Forty percent say it is getting "worse," in a rise of 11 percentage points.
The results on questions about Mr. Bush's performance were mixed. The President's perceived strength in international affairs has kept his approval rating at 67 percent. But his efforts on the economy continue to be rated relatively poorly and he is being faulted for his emphasis on foreign policy.
These concerns could spell trouble for Mr. Bush, whose support does not seem particularly solid. Although the President begins the campaign season with a substantial lead, about four in 10 of those respondents who say they favor Mr. Bush also say they can imagine circumstances under which they would vote for a Democrat.
 
Campaign Isn't a Focus
 The reason most people know little about the Presidential landscape is reflected in that few say they have focused on it. Sixty-six percent of registered voters chose "not much" when asked to describe the attention they have paid to the campaign thus far, and only 8 percent chose "a lot."
Although Governor Cuomo and Mr. Jackson had high name recognition among respondents, many more people say they believe Governor Cuomo should run than say that Mr. Jackson should. By a split of 45 percent to 22 percent, the Democratic primary voters say Governor Cuomo should run. By a split of 30 percent to 60 percent, these same respondents say Mr. Jackson should not run.
Mr. Cuomo has a balance of 29 percent favorable impressions and 9 percent unfavorable among Democratic primary voters. For Mr. Jackson, the unfavorable ratings outweighed the favorable ones, 41 percent to 29 percent.
In a result that could be significant for Governor Cuomo, who insisted last week that he would have to resign the Governorship if he ran for President, 53 percent of all registered voters say candidates currently serving as governors could not run and also fulfill their duties to their home states.
Regarding the kind of candidate that would be favored, a plurality of the Democratic primary voters say they want to see their party nominate a moderate. And in answer to a separate question about the declared candidates, 54 percent of respondents say they are "pretty much alike" rather than having "important differences."
While most people say they know very little about the Democratic field, primary voters who know the candidates say they like Governors Clinton and Wilder and Senators Harkin and Kerrey. In the cases of Mr. Brown and Mr. Tsongas, favorable impressions among Democratic primary voters were counterbalanced by a roughly equal level of unfavorable impressions.

"How the Survey Was Conducted"
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 15-18 with 1,280 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those who say they vote in Democratic primaries or caucuses, it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Talk About Tax Breaks Is . . . Just Talk

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
All the talk in the last few days about new tax breaks is mostly political positioning on the eve of the 1992 election campaign.
The basic theme of Republicans and Democrats on tax policy is the same as it was generations ago: Republicans want to give tax breaks to the wealthy, saying that to do so would improve the economy and thus benefit all Americans. Democrats want to redistribute income away from the rich and toward the poor and middle class, maintaining that fairness makes the economy run more smoothly. 
 The evidence supporting either tenet is shaky at best. But the arguments -- which boiled up anew on television on Sunday when Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, offered his latest tax cut proposal -- sound good in a campaign speech.
 
Differences Within the Parties
 This year, the differences over taxes are not only between the parties but within them.
President Bush would rather concentrate on foreign policy and let the economy take care of itself. But his hand has been forced by the conservatives in his party like Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia who despise last year's budget deal because it makes lowering taxes so difficult.
Most liberal Democrats take issue with Senator Bentsen. Rather than cut taxes, they want to expand social programs with whatever peace dividend grows out of the end of the military threat from the Soviet Union. But the moderate wing of the party in the Senate, led by Mr. Bentsen, Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Al Gore of Tennessee, has decided that tax cuts for the middle class is where the votes are.
How all this will work out is unclear, but this much is certain: nothing of substance will happen for months, just more and more talk about taxes and the economy.
This should be favorable ground for the Democrats. After all, the economy is still sour, the middle class does feel overtaxed and polls show that most people believe important domestic programs are being ignored. Even more important, it draws attention away from foreign policy, where Mr. Bush is most secure.
Indeed, on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" on Sunday, Senator Bentsen first took a shot at Mr. Bush. "The economy is dead in the water," Senator Bentsen said, "and we do have to jump-start it. The Administration has been trying to talk their way out of it, and that hasn't worked."
But the plan Mr. Bentsen then outlined -- a $300 per child tax credit to American families, a renewal of tax-deductible individual retirement accounts for all Americans and a 5 percent cut in military spending over five years to pay for the new tax breaks -- is sure to generate as much opposition as support within his own party. Until the Democrats develop a unified position, it will be hard to turn the issue against Mr. Bush.
 
Little to 'Jump-Start' Economy
 Whatever the political virtues of the Senator's proposals and whatever their value as a matter of tax policy, they would do little if anything to "jump-start" the economy.
First, it will be well into next year if not later before any tax changes can be enacted and put into effect, much too late to give a quick boost to today's sluggish conditions. Second, tax cuts will do little to stimulate the economy if, as Mr. Bentsen proposes, they are offset dollar for dollar by cuts in Government spending. Third, more generous deductions for I.R.A.'s would theoretically encourage saving, not spending, normally the wrong prescription for an economy struggling to get out of recession.
Further, Mr. Bentsen seems to be giving up the line of attack on tax fairness that proved so advantageous to the Democrats in last year's budget battle.
Mr. Bentsen did not even give a nod to the poor, as much a part of Democratic tax dogma as help for the rich is part of Republican philosophy. And the $72 billion that would be lost through lower taxes is money that could not be spent for better medical care, education, highways and other programs that Democrats advocate.
So none of the Democratic Presidential candidates endorsed the Bentsen ideas today, and Democrats in the House of Representatives, led by Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, stayed at arm's length.
 
Meant for Public Consumption
 At the White House, the recent flurry of activity on economic issues, including the President's highly publicized meetings with bankers, business executives and his top economic advisers, was also meant more for public consumption near the start of the election campaign than as a genuine effort to bring about policy changes.
"There's a feeling he hasn't been visible enough on this issue," one adviser said of Mr. Bush. To keep the Democrats from stealing the march on tax cuts, the President in the next week or so will offer what he calls a "growth package," his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today. The centerpiece, no surprise, will be a lower capital gains tax rate.
Republican doctrine holds that the economy will expand and jobs will be created if investors can keep more of their profits, instead of having them taxed away.
Whether giving these people a tax break in the form of a capital gains cut would induce them to invest more and help the economy to grow is an open question. All that is for sure is that most of the tax savings would go to the rich.
Mr. Fitzwater said again today that Mr. Bush did not want to violate the cardinal principles of last year's budget agreement, that all tax cuts would be balanced by equivalent spending reductions and that money would not be shifted from the military to the domestic side of the ledger.
But on this score, the President may have to relent. Most politicians believe that a budget written when the Soviet Union was a serious military threat is no longer pertinent now that the cold war has ended. Senator Gramm, no antagonist of a strong military, said today: "Do I think a 5 percent defense saving over the next five years is realistic? Yes, I do."
So the battlefield for the election campaign becomes how to use that money, perhaps $70 billion to $100 billion. Should it go for tax cuts, and if so should they be concentrated on the poor, the middle class or the rich? Should money be used for domestic programs? Or should some of it be set aside to reduce the budget deficit?
The deficit? It is expected to hit a record $350 billion this year. But no one is mentioning it nowadays. It is a dreadful word on the stump.

HEADLINE: The Newest Fashion in Urban Transportation: Ferryboats

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Long before dawn, commuters arrive at the dock in Weehawken, N.J., first one by one, then in briskly moving masses. Briefcases in hand, they board a blue and white ferry marked "Midtown." And for the next five minutes, until the Port Imperial ferry docks at West 38th Street in Manhattan, serenity seems to settle over the crowd.
"Before the overwhelming assault on my senses, I just like to have a few Buddha-like moments," said one woman who sat on the upper deck, her eyes closed and her face lifted into a breeze rolling off the Hudson River. 
 Downriver, another ferry shuttles between Weehawken and New York's financial district. And a third moves between Hoboken, N.J., and Battery Park City in Manhattan. On the East River, an airport ferry brings travelers from Manhattan's East Side to La Guardia Airport, bypassing the often congested highways in Queens.
Except for the 70,000 weekday riders of the Staten Island Ferry, most of the more than 3 million commuters who come and go from the city's business district each day still travel by land: in crowded trains, or in buses and cars that cram through tunnels and over bridges. But a small and growing number -- more than 15,000 -- have begun making the trip across the Hudson and East Rivers by ferry.
"It is a kind of renaissance," said David Phraner, a transportation planner for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "It isn't a panacea for all the urban transportation problems that we have, but ferries are an important part of a big picture."
 
An Attractive Alternative
 The idea of ferries criss-crossing New York's rivers like bootlaces is an old idea made new, an idea finding favor not just here but in other American cities where planners are looking for ways to curb pollution, reduce traffic and attract tourists. In the past five years, the ferry business here has been built up by private entrepreneurs who sensed a market among commuters weary of traditional mass transit. About 75 percent of the ferry riders say they switched from publicly financed mass transit and about 25 percent say they are now leaving their own cars at home or in the ferry parking lot, the New York City Transportation Department said.
The ferry's newfound popularity harkens back to the city's earliest days, when a rowboat ferry carried the area's new Dutch settlers across the East River between Brooklyn and what was then known as New Amsterdam. By the mid 1770's, several ferry lines -- powered by oars, sails, poles or horses on treadmills -- linked Manhattan, Long Island and Staten Island with the mainland and with each other. New York later became home to the world's first steam ferry, and by 1909, just before the Hudson and East River railroad tunnels were opened, the ferries were moving as many as 2,000 passengers at a time across a bustling harbor.
"Ah, what can ever be more stately and admirable to me than mast-hemm'd Manhattan," wrote Walt Whitman in his poem, "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry."
 
Better Technology
 But as tunnels, bridges and cross-river transit lines proliferated, all but the Staten Island ferry died out.
Now, transportation experts said, ferries are making a comeback, not just in New York but in Boston, Seattle, San Francisco and San Diego.
"The technology for the ferry boats is getting better, so you have a more comfortable ride," said Henry S. Marcus, chairman of the Ocean Systems Management program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. "In many areas, driving to work is not ideal and is getting worse. People are thinking a little more about ferries, and so I think, in general, the number of people using them has been increasing."
Martha A. Reardon, a director of the International Marine Transit Association and a ferry consultant, said ferry ridership in the United States is now about 200,000 a day, mostly because commuters -- and municipal officials -- are looking for alternatives to traffic gridlock.
"There just isn't any more room," she said. "People are looking at bridges and saying, 'Do we doubledeck it or do we look for an alternative?' "
 
Concerns About Profitability
 In New York alone, seven ferry services now shuttle riders between Manhattan, Brooklyn, New Jersey and La Guardia Airport. Several more, including a commuter catamaran service between Haverstraw, N.Y., and lower Manhattan, are being planned. And the New York City Transportation Department, with help from a $180,000 Federal grant, is working on a study that is expected to call for six new ferry routes.
But for every city or company that has successfully revived its ferry services, dozens of others have failed.
Of the 13 or so New York City ferry routes that began operating in 1990, at least four have been closed down -- mostly because of low ridership. Several ferry companies have gone out of business.
Transportation experts say that without Federal or state subsidies, many commuter ferry services are not economically viable. George Haikalis, a transportation consultant, describes them as "money losers."
One success story is the Port Imperial Ferrybus line.
Standing on the dock of the Port Imperial ferry terminal in Weehawken, Arthur E. Imperatore, the owner and real estate magnate, waves to a group of morning commuters as they board his ferry to midtown.
"Look at what we've done and not a dollar of public subsidy," says the 66-year-old Mr. Imperatore, who recalls taking the old Weehawken ferry for four cents when he was growing up in West New York, N.J. Today, the ferry he runs costs $4 each way to midtown, $5 to downtown, and an extra $4 for parking.
Inside the terminal -- a restored ferry painted with historical murals -- passengers can sit in the cafe or bar, drop off clothes for dry cleaning or get tickets from a travel agency. When they get to Manhattan, a fleet of minibuses whisks them to other points throughout the area, where they can walk to work. Since 1986, Mr. Imperatore's business has grown from 23 people to more than 7,500, and. Mr. Imperatore expects the ferry to make a $1 million profit this year.
 
The Aesthetic Edge
 On the Hoboken Ferry, a joint venture between Mr. Imperatore's company, Arcorp, and Hartz Mountain Industries, daily ridership between New Jersey and Battery Park City has risen almost 40 percent since last year to 7,000.
"We are able to make this work because we have the right location," says Mr. Imperatore, who owns land on either side of the river. "And you have to try to get people to change commuting habits that have been ingrained. It's hard to change those habits quickly."
But for passengers, profits are not being measured in dollars.
"This is the nicest thing that ever happened to me," said William Kremer as he boarded a Weehawken Ferry for Manhattan. "I drove for more than 26 years and I'd get stuck for at least 45 minutes twice a week. My nerves were totally shot."
"I tried the bus," he said. "But I just couldn't take it. I wasn't fit for work by the time I got there. This relaxes me."
Keiji Tsuchida, a Wall Street banker, said that after years of taking trains in Tokyo, the ferry from downtown Manhattan to Weehawken was an exercise in stress reduction. "Even at rush hour in the morning I can read the paper and eat donuts and drink coffee. That's different from Tokyo, where people are always pushing. It's a nightmare."
Richard Maxwell, an insurance broker who was boarding the afternoon ferry to Highlands, N.J., is another convert. "I used to take the train, then the car, and it was a killer," he said. "This is much better. It has changed my life."

HEADLINE: Study Says Iraq's Child Mortality Rate Has Tripled

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

 BODY:
A new public health study by American and other Western experts in Iraq says the country's child mortality rate has nearly tripled and perhaps even quadrupled as a result of the Persian Gulf war, civil strife and international sanctions.
Such an elevated mortality rate could mean tens of thousands of additional deaths in Iraq's population of more than three million children under five years old, officials who took part in the survey said, although they declined in their study to make specific projections of overall deaths. 
 The study, a comprehensive follow-up to a smaller survey in May organized by faculty members of Harvard University's school of public health, said Iraq's serious public health deficiencies had improved little if at all.
In the earlier study, the Harvard team estimated that compared with prewar times as many as 170,000 more children would die this year from disease and from the "catastrophic" breakdown of the health-care system. But some public health experts criticized the estimate, based on surveys of hospital wards, as too speculative.
 
9,000 Families Interviewed
 The new study, a copy of which was made available last week before its release today, is based on interviews conducted in more than 9,000 Iraqi households by Arabic-speaking interviewers. The survey was conducted between Aug. 25 and Sept. 10 and provided a data base of more than 16,000 births to study from the standpoint of disease, development and nutrition.
"The medical team wanted to show the proportionate change of child mortality in Iraq in the most current period, and the best way to do that is through a direct survey," said Sara Farnsworth, a spokeswoman for the team, adding, "But that doesn't necessarily produce a reliable number of overall deaths."
Based on the sample, the health survey found that disease and poor nutrition increased the 1991 mortality rate for children to 80 deaths per 1,000 of population, compared with a prewar rate of 20 to 30 deaths per 1,000.
"The acute shortage of infant formula, powdered milk and essential medicines, as well as the rise in the price of food, may have contributed to this elevated risk of mortality among Iraq's children," the study said. "The results presented here suggest that children under the age of 5 in Iraq are receiving sufficient food to avoid acute starvation, but are still severely malnourished."
 
A Million Malnourished
 The study found that malnutrition, measured by body weight and size relative to the age of children, was evident in 29 percent of the population under 5, which translates into nearly one million children significantly undernourished. Nearly 120,000 Iraqi children fell into the category of severely and acutely malnourished.
The group of 35 professionals, largely from universities in the United States and Britain, was financed by grants from the MacArthur and Merck foundations and called itself the International Commission on the Gulf Crisis. Eight separate studies were compiled, including reports on the effects of war and crisis in Iraq on child psychology and on women in Iraq.
The study pointed out that while top Iraqi officials from President Saddam Hussein to senior officers in the military and ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party are exempted from suffering by special access to food imports and hard currency, the majority of Iraqi households are in a state of crisis over food and health because of rampant food-price inflation. An economic study said Iraqis had seen their purchasing power erode 15 to 20 fold.
In this state, most Iraqi families are spending all their income on food, and it is still not enough. Monthly government food rations that typically run out after 10 days are the only thing preventing the outbreak of famine in Iraq, the study asserted, and millions of Iraqis are going hungry for part of each month, the survey found.
 
Harvests Declining
 The major additional findings of the study are these:
*Despite efforts to increase grain harvests to make up for food shortages, the output from Iraq's farmers in 1991 has declined 75 or 80 percent because of breakdowns in the irrigation system and shortages of electricity, fertilizers, pesticides and seeds.
*Iraq's herds of cattle, sheep and goats, the principal source of high-protein meat for the population since the United Nations-imposed economic sanctions, have shrunk by 50 to 60 percent because of increased rates of slaughter, the spread of disease and shortages of veterinary medicines.
*Millions of Iraqis still are drinking water contaminated by sewage. A survey of drinking water in 158 randomly selected households nationwide showed that 106 of the samples tested positive "for gross coliform contamination," a key factor in the spread of diarrheal diseases like typhoid and cholera.
*Most infectious diseases are "thriving" and water-borne diseases like typhoid still are epidemic in southern Iraq. The country's hospital system remains devastated and short of medicine, food and staff.
*The country's electrical generation system, heavily targeted by allied bombers during the war, has been partly revived and recently has been generating 68 percent of its prewar peaks. But a detailed examination of power plants showed that Iraqi engineers had exhausted their supply of spare parts and faced inevitable deterioration of electrical output.
Power losses have a direct effect on public health in Iraq because of the power requirements for water and sewage treatment.
 
Issue of Oil Sales
 The study is one of the most extensive health surveys in the aftermath of modern warfare and is likely to be cited by some United Nations officials who have been arguing that the Security Council should allow Iraq to sell more than the $1.6 billion in oil for humanitarian purchases approved last week.
After paying reparations to Kuwait, Iraq will have about $933 million left to purchase urgently needed supplies of food and medicine under the plan. If Iraq goes ahead with the oil sale -- a move that is in doubt given Baghdad's objections to the terms -- it will be the first major sale since August 1990. Iraq has been trucking small amounts of crude oil to Jordan for barter since the end of the war.
In an editorial note sounded by the authors of the economic survey, the continued United Nations sanctions policy was challenged on the basis of human rights.
"If humanitarian needs are those defined by our basic rights as human beings," it argued, "they go much beyond what the Iraqi economy can deliver as things stand."
Adding that carrying out the cease-fire resolution "is a serious issue," the report says: "The safe disposal of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, demanded by this resolution, is a particularly legitimate concern. But it would be tragic if this concern unleashed the destructive power of another weapon of mass destruction -- the effective withdrawal of food and other necessities from the Iraqi people."

HEADLINE: Ex-Klan Leader's Vote Sends Message to a Pained G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Suddenly, the high theater of Louisiana politics has become deadly serious to both parties.
For national Republican leaders, the second-place finish by State Representative David Duke in Saturday's primary for governor, which puts him in the runoff election on Nov. 16, is a source of deep embarrassment. Even as the White House and the Republican National Committee sought to distance themselves from the former Ku Klux Klan leader today, he was making the rounds of the morning talk shows -- as a Republican, he insisted. 
 "I think there are millions of Republicans who agree with me," Mr. Duke said on ABC's "Good Morning America."
 
Democrats Seize Opportunity
 Democrats were quick to reach for the moral high ground today, asserting that Mr. Duke's success in Louisiana is the logical outgrowth of years of Republican attempts to build on racial divisions, with issues from school busing to prison furloughs to the current debate over racial hiring preferences.
But there was little partisan chortling in the capital today: the Louisiana governor's primary had daunting lessons for both parties. Both Republican and Democratic analysts cautioned that Louisiana is the most idiosyncratic of states, with a long history of protest politics and an economy that has been ailing for years.
But these analysts also said that the primary reflected, in extreme form, a powerful anti-establishment mood growing around the country, fed by the recession and evident in developments like the drive to limit Congressional terms. The Duke phenomenon obviously has much to do with race, these analysts said, and the way economically insecure white voters can respond to angry talk about welfare and affirmative-action programs. But it also transcends this, some argued.
On the most immediate level, the Duke phenomenon was a political problem to be managed by the Republicans. From the White House, from Vice President Dan Quayle, and from the Republican National Committee came several painful disavowals, all the more pained since the man Mr. Duke squeezed out of the runoff election was Gov. Buddy Roemer, the Democrat-turned-Republican who was the White House's prize catch earlier this year.
Despite the warm welcome from the White House, including campaign visits by President Bush and Mr. Quayle in recent weeks, Mr. Roemer finished third, behind Mr. Duke and former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, the flamboyant Democrat seeking a comeback after surviving two trials on corruption charges. The state's Republican Party endorsed another candidate, Representative Clyde C. Holloway.
Clayton K. Yeutter, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, said grimly this afternoon: "We simply do not have a horse in that race today. We do not consider Mr. Duke to be a legitimate representative of the Republican Party."
But Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserted that the Republicans' "tepid disavowal" of Mr. Duke "is not nearly enough." Mr. Brown asserted, "Frankly, he's running on the same kind of wedge issues that Jesse Helms and George Bush himself ran on."
Natalie Davis, a poll taker at Birmingham-Southern College in Alabama who is a member of the Democratic National Committee, echoed other Democrats in asserting that "Republicans want it both ways": credit for appointing Judge Clarence Thomas, a black man, to the Supreme Court and political gain from issues like Willie Horton, the black convicted murderer used as a symbol of Democratic crime policies.
 
Harkin Sees a Connection
 Some Democrats clearly intend to make Mr. Duke a powerful symbol of the divisions that, they assert, the Republicans seek to tap. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, a Democratic Presidential contender, asserted that Mr. Bush's divisive policies led "directly, directly" to Mr. Duke's success.
There were other lessons drawn from the Duke vote. James J. Brady, chairman of the Louisiana Democratic Party, said: "Part of his vote is just a hard-core racist vote where if there was some candidate further to the right of Duke they'd be with him. That's probably 30 percent of his vote. But the rest of it is he's appealing to the frustration with government, and that takes on a lot of different variances among different groups, from taxes to affirmative action to the general perception of how government treats people."
Geoffrey Garin, who conducted polls for Senator J. Bennett Johnston in his race against Mr. Duke last year, said that interviews conducted after that election found that the crucial variable was how voters felt about government.
"There wasn't a lot of difference between how pro-Duke whites and anti-Duke whites felt about their economic sitaution," Mr. Garin said. "But there was a big difference in how they felt about their political representation."
Don Sipple, a Republican consultant, agreed. "I think he's a vehicle for a lot of disaffected voters who are growing in their numbers," he said. "It's frustration with the system."
Eddie Mahe, another Republican strategist, said this makes his national party's problem all the more acute: As the establishment attempts to come down on an anti-establishment candidate, it could only feed his appeal. "I think we've got ourselves into a very difficult one," Mr. Mahe said.
Almost no one in politics wants to underestimate Mr. Duke, who has made a career of defying predictions. Susan Howell, director of the Survey Research Center at the University of New Orleans, said her analysis of returns from heavily white parishes on Saturday indicated that Mr. Duke got 42 to 44 percent of the white vote, Mr. Roemer got about 30 percent and Mr. Edwards got 17 to 18 percent.
The overall results, according to the Associated Press, showed Mr. Edwards with 34 percent of the vote, Mr. Duke with 32 percent and Mr. Roemer with 27 percent.
Mr. Duke's past -- he is a former national grand wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and founder of the National Association for the Advancement of White People -- is well known in Louisiana.
But Mr. Duke asserts that he has since moderated his views; he says, as he said this morning on national television, that he is "not a racist" but simply believes in "equal rights."
Many Louisianians said they were hoping that as their state's voters focused on actually electing a governor, rather than sending a message, Mr. Duke would falter.
But in the meantime, many national analysts are studying what the Duke success might say about disaffected, angry voters. Stan Greenberg, a Democratic poll taker, asserted that there is great frustration among white men who have not gone to college, whose incomes are dropping in real terms and who feel that neither party is speaking to them.
"Race is just one piece of it," Mr. Greenberg said, "But if politics in general doesn't respond to those voters, it leaves them available to the extremist candidates."

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Belmont Ends on a Declining Note

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Belmont Park rang down the curtain for the year yesterday with stirring memories but with fading numbers: attendance for the 48-day fall season was down by 3.2 percent and wagering by 5 percent, continuing the decline that has afflicted thoroughbred racing in recent years.
But Jerry Lawrence, executive vice president of the New York Racing Association, suggested that "the figures reflect a general malaise in the economy." And he said they implied that "people are being much more careful with their money during this recession." 
 The stately old track on Long Island will stay closed until next May, as it has every year. But the horses will keep running in New York without pause because the Aqueduct track in Queens opens its fall and winter season tomorrow, with the first race booked for 12:30 P.M.
 
Running in the Red
 New York shifts scenes in racing four times a year: in May, from Aqueduct to Belmont; in late July, from Belmont to Saratoga; in late August, from Saratoga back to Belmont, and in late October back to Aqueduct. But wherever they've been running, the horses have been running in red ink.
The New York Racing Association reported these numbers yesterday as it closed Belmont for the winter:
Attendance at the track during the 48-day meeting totaled 510,606, a decline of 3.2 percent from last year's fall season. Betting at the track totaled $117,756,759, a decline of 5 percent. Even statewide betting, which includes Offtrack Betting offices and wagering from one track to another, declined by 2.2 percent to a total of $327,459,609.
 
Careful Spending
 "The figures reflect a general malaise in the economy," Lawrence said. "Ontrack handle is down more than attendance, which leads me to believe that people are being much more careful with their money during this recession.
"Other spectator sports in the New York area have suffered declines this year, some much more radical than ours. Anyone in the sports or entertainment industry has definite concerns about the current economic climate."
"Actually," he added, "business has rebounded since earlier this year. At Aqueduct this spring, both attendance and handle were down in double-digit figures. We are making inroads, but it is a tough battle. Hopefully, business will continue to rebound at Aqueduct.
"Last year's Belmont meet also had the additional advantage of building to a climax with the Breeders' Cup. We did not have that advantage this year."
 
Artistic Success
 The Breeders' Cup, rotated among leading tracks each year, will be held on Nov. 2 at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky. Next year they will be staged at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla.
But Belmont's fall season at least ended as an artistic success. It was highlighted by 31 stakes races that offered more than $6 million in purses and numerous dramatic highs.
In Excess, who opened the year in California, became a star this summer in New York. He extended his winning streak in major races to four when he won the Woodward Stakes last month, and intensified his campaign for the ultimate prize, the title Horse of the Year.
The handicap star Festin won the Jockey Club Gold Cup. The filly Versailles Treaty succeeded Meadow Star and Lite Light as the heir apparent in their division. And Strike the Gold kept running gamely, but was still chasing his first victory since the Kentucky Derby last May.

HEADLINE: Balance of Nature? What Balance Is That?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
ECOLOGISTS are increasingly abandoning the popular concept of the balance of nature and are replacing it with the image of a natural world in which plant and animal communities perpetually fluctuate. Disturbances like climatic change, fires, storms and disease, some scientists say, seldom give these communities the chance to settle into a state of equilibrium.
And anyway, others contend, populations of plants and animals are inherently unstable and would not achieve equilibrium even in the absence of external disturbances. Now, taking the question a step further, ecologists at the University of Minnesota say they have demonstrated that under some conditions, populations of certain grasses, following an internal dynamic, rise and fall in the irregular, unpredictable patterns that scientists call chaos. 
 The effect of the findings, some scientists say, is to undermine further the idea that nature will settle into a neat, harmonious balance if humans leave it alone. The findings are also viewed as an encouraging step in the attempt to understand the patterns of ecological systems.
In this case, Dr. David Tilman and Dr. David Wedin of Minnesota report in the current issue of the British journal Nature that they experimentally manipulated populations of a native American wild grass, Agrostis scabra. Farmers call it pant-creeper because its seeds have thorns that make them crawl up one's leg.
In 1985, the experimenters sowed Agrostis seeds at two different initial densities on plots containing 10 different levels of nitrogen, the plants' main nourishment. After the plants appeared, those in low-nitrogen soils maintained a fairly stable amount of above-ground biomass, meaning all the plant that appeared above ground as measured by dry weight. The biomass of grass in richer soil oscillated more, its amount expanding and contracting from year to year over the five-year period of the experiment. Those in the richest soil, displaying the wild oscillations that scientists associate with the chaotic behavior of dynamic systems, exhibited a 6,000-fold crash, to nearly zero, in 1988.
 
The Problem With Litter
 Scientists in the young field of chaos theory say that in dynamic systems, chaos begins when increasing velocity or energy forces the system to a certain point. A familiar example is the turbulence that begins when a smoothly flowing stream of water reaches a certain velocity. In the case of the Agrostis plants, said Dr. Tilman, the greater boost of energy provided by the richest soil kicked the oscillating population of grass into a chaotic fluctuation.
He described the mechanism by which this happened: The higher nitrogen level spurred greater plant growth. When the above-ground parts of the plants died in winter, they left a heavy layer of litter. The next spring, this layer prevented the new shoots of the perennial grass from growing, causing the crash. The lower the levels of nitrogen, the smaller the oscillations. Only those plant populations in the richest soil crashed.
This pattern illustrates another hallmark of chaotic behavior, said Dr. Tilman, namely that any small difference in initial conditions will be magnified -- in this casecausing the biomass of the plants in the different plots to diverge more sharply as the dynamic process unfolds.
This dependence on initial conditions, as chaos theorists call it, was also reflected in another aspect of the Minnesota experiment. Among the plants in the richest soil, the ones that plunged into chaos, those originally planted at a lower density recovered more rapidly, their population trending more sharply upward in the last two years of the experiment.
None of four other grass species growing in the experimental garden suffered a crash or lapsed into chaotic behavior, Dr. Tilman said, suggesting that the behavior was not caused by environmental conditions.
"I never imagined I would find chaos," he said. "I imagined it would grow up to equilibrium. This has changed my world view, to be blunt about it."
 
More Work Is Needed
 The study demonstrates "that ecologists are now ready to think this way," said Dr. Daniel Botkin, an ecologist at the University of California at Santa Barbara. "If someone did this 15 or 20 years ago," he said, "it would have been abandoned as a failed experiment. There wouldn't have been any basis for interpreting the results. Now scientists in this area are beginning to look at their experiments in a new light. That's the really important thing" about the Tilman-Wedin study.
Dr. Tilman said that chaotic patterns might not occur all the time in an ecological context, and the Nature paper says that more work is needed to determine how general they are. But, he said, "chaos might be much more likely in natural systems than we imagined five years or so ago," adding, "There is a good chance that many ecological systems are going to have chaotic dynamics in them." In ecosystems with more than one species, he said, chaos is even more likely.
Other experts said that while the new study provides one of the most vivid bits of evidence yet of chaos in ecological systems, the Minnesota ecologists have not yet nailed it down unequivocally. "I think he's demonstrated that there may be chaos," said Dr. William M. Schaffer of the University of Arizona. "The data are highly suggestive and very interesting. I think this is very exciting."
In the early 1970's, Dr. Schaffer was a pioneer in probing the role of chaos in ecological systems, notably in an investigation of the chaos factor in the waxing and waning of measles epidemics.
Scientists have been investigating the role of chaos in many areas of science, from chemistry to weather and climate, to fluid dynamics to astronomy to economics, even to physiology, where some investigators believe it may play a role in disturbance of heart rhythms. The term chaos is used by scientists not in its conventional sense of total disorder but in a specialized way. It deals essentially with the concept of order within disorder. Turbulent, chaotic systems may look as if they behave randomly and with total disorder. But scientists say they exhibit an underlying, long-term order that is neither wholly deterministic nor wholly random.
 
A Lack of Crispness
 The study of chaos in ecological systems is especially difficult because they do not behave with the crispness of, say, a chemical reaction or the flow of fluid in a tube. For a long time, said Dr. Schaffer, ecologists looked at chaos as a mathematical curiosity. For this reason, he said, the Tilman-Wedin paper is likely to provoke skepticism.
But, he said: "I think that if you're going to look for this sort of thing in ecological systems, this is the only approach. It's going to have to be an experimental approach with semi-natural systems." In nature, he said, it is impractical to study the dynamics of a population or an ecosystem because it takes too long for the dynamics to unfold.
What does it matter? "There is this widespread perception that there is a balance of nature, that in the absence of human interference, systems are going to settle down at this mythical balance point," Dr. Schaffer said. "To the contrary, the evidence is that many species fluctuate an enormous amount with regard to their densities."
Whether this is an inherent property of the system or the result of external disruption is a big question, he said. But either way, he said, the possibility of ecological chaos suggests that in principle, at least, ecological processes can be analyzed and understood.
"It really cuts the legs out from underneath this position that all we really have to do is leave these systems alone and everything's going to be ducky," he said. "What we have to do is understand how these systems behave and then we as people can decide what we want, how to manage them appropriately."
While the balance-of-nature concept remains strong in general circulation, many scientists have discarded it. For his part, said Dr. Tilman, he has long since abandoned the notion. "That phrasing hasn't been used much in 20 years. The issue is more one of what is controlling the patterns we see in nature."

 When the above-ground parts of teh plants died in winter, they left a heavy layer of litter. It kept light from the new shoots the next spring, causing a crash in population. HEADLINE: Observer;
Return With Us Now . . .

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Meanwhile, back at the recession leading economists, leading political leaders and leading President George H. W. Bush are at grips with the most vital question of the day. That question: Is there a recession, and if so, who cares as long as the polls show the election is in the bag?
As we join them, little Jane and Jimmy too have just galloped up to the White House unaccompanied by their usual cohorts, leading 1935 radio cowboy star Tom Mix and Tom's wonder horse Tony. A leading economist, prone to saying what everybody but the audience has known for days, speaks: 
 "Little Jane and Jimmy too! You rode off with Tom to find the answer to the most vital question of our generation: to wit, who leaked the F.B.I. report on Anita Hill? Yet now you return without either Tom or Tony."
The President, a mite testily: "Now wait a minute! Just because Tom isn't with them doesn't justify the media in saying America is in a state of Tomlessness."
Leading White House sycophant: "Or Tonylessness either, Mr. President. Anyhow, even if it is, what about Chappaquiddick?"
Little Jane and Jimmy too, who have the annoying habit of speaking as one, have an alarming tale: "While studying a cold campfire for clues to the source of the monstrous leak, Tom was taken unawares by three statesmen --"
"At this point in time nobody says 'taken unawares,' " says a leading economics prose master. "You mean that events outside Tom's parameters of expectation converged to limit his previous mobility. In short, if he's now unemployed, it's his own fault."
Little Jane and Jimmy too: "They weren't parameters that seized Tom, sir. They were three statesmen, Senators three: Simpson, Specter and Hatch. 'Don't try to get by with a scurrilous lie,' we heard them tell Tom with a hair-raising cry, 'for remember with fear what is written quite clear: "A tooth for a tooth and an eye for an eye." So best tell the truth or you'll be the prize catch of the statesmen three: Specter, Simpson and Hatch.' "
Leading White House aide John Sununu suggests that since Tom is now unable to keep tots chowed down at the bunkhouse, little Jane and Jimmy too now do something unglamorous for the Administration and take jobs as hamburger flippers. Though not as exciting as riding the range for justice, he says, it will hold down the unemployment statistics.
"But," wail Jimmy too and little Jane, "Tom is being held prisoner in the old mine shaft while Senator Simpson reads him a code of media ethics night and day."
Leading President Bush, suddenly alert: "I can't believe it! Tom Mix mixed up with the media crowd? A great American like Tom, riding a great American wonder horse like Tony to say George Bush cares more about foreign policy than he does about the domestic agenda? Say it isn't so, little Jane and Jimmy too!"
Hangdog intonations subtly enter the voice of little Jane and Jimmy too, for, being 1935 children, they believe in legends and admire George Washington, so cannot tell a lie. "As radio people," they say, "we are all inescapably, alas, media: Tom, Tony the wonder horse and we two too, little Jane and Jimmy too."
A leading White House handler of Supreme Court nominees says, "There wasn't any media in 1935 --"
"Not 'wasn't any media,' " says a leading Republican pedant. "It's 'weren't any media.' Media's plural. Needs a plural verb."
"That was one of the few great things about 1935: There weren't any media," says a leading White House sentimentalist. "There were Orphan Annie, the Singing Lady, Bobby Benson, Chandu the Magician, and while most people knew a little Latin, everybody still spoke English."
"No wonder the Republicans lost every election that came along," says a leading campaign consultant and master of the science of clouding men's minds. "Speaking of which, shall we meet again next week after studying some fresh polls for an answer to the most vital question of the day: to wit, is there a recession, and if so, so what?"
Meanwhile, at a faraway California ranch, Tony the wonder horse is being turned away by a former leading American President with the explanation, "There's no free oats."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Double Standard

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The double standard in the Middle East has become built into American diplomacy and journalism. It is so taken for granted that hardly anybody notices.
It is time to notice, the most important of times. The Israeli-Arab talks supposed to start at the end of this month can be an important step in the Mideast. The credit goes to the persistence of President Bush and Secretary of State James Baker, the willingness of the Israeli Cabinet to take plain risks for peace, and the decision of some Palestinians not to let yet another opportunity pass them by. 
 At last Palestinians and Jordanians will, in a joint delegation, face the Israelis. At least in theory, a basis of the talks will be the only solution possible for some years -- Palestinian self-government for five years, hedged by Israeli military presence but meanwhile given broader horizons by negotiations about what-next.
If these talks are to get a fair chance, American diplomats, politicians and journalists of conscience, who will assess the talks day by day, ought to examine the double standard now -- in justice not simply to Israel but to all who ache for peace in the Middle East.
In some important part, the double standard comes out of the nature of Israeli society and is a great asset to the country. If a higher standard of ethics and conduct is demanded of Israelis, it is because even its antagonists know it judges itself on democratic and political standards unknown elsewhere in the Middle East. Without those self-imposed standards Israel would have no greater claim to support and affection than any other small nation.
But throughout its existence, and increasingly, the double standard has not been just a debate about ethics. It became a whole arsenal of deadly weapons against Israel that the world chooses to ignore -- vicious racial and religious insult, terrorism, boycott and embargo, refusal to abide by elementary diplomatic rules of conduct and, now, sabotage of the peace talks.
For almost a half-century Israel has been bombarded with filth -- from the ceaseless and still-continuing anti-Israel and anti-Jewish campaign in almost every Muslim country, worldwide. Filth from mouth, the press and the airwaves is meant to dehumanize a nation and make its extinction desirable. The world says nothing, does nothing.
In the United States -- even in America -- cartoons appear in the mainstream press that could have run in German Nazi papers. One showed an ugly Yitzhak Shamir beating a prostrate, tied Palestinian with a mace from which swung a menacing Star of David. The Star of David is a routine symbol of oppression now for some American cartoonists. Publishers do nothing; readers, nothing.
A Saudi Arabian is elected president of the U.N. General Assembly. Before the Foreign Minister of Israel speaks, the Saudi prostitutes his position by absenting himself from the rostrum. If an Israeli had by some mad chance been elected president of any U.N. body, and withdrawn not to soil his eyes and ears with an Arab speaker, the critics of Israel, from the most vulgar to the toniest, would have howled. I didn't hear any howls about the absent Saudi.
Israel is asked to pay heavily, in land, for the normal trade and diplomatic relations that every other country gets as an automatic mark of nationhood. Pay to end the embargo, pay to get credits, pay to receive ambassadors. What payment did the U.S. get from Saddam Hussein for pushing credits to Iraq just before the invasion of Kuwait?
And now, Syria announces its boycott of half the peace conference, possibly the more important half -- the regional discussions among Israel and her neighbors on arms control, water, economic development.
If Israel had done that -- oh my, Washington and the journalistic critics would have positively danced with rage. I see not a step.
Instead it is Israel that gets the new barrage of warnings -- shape up or starve, or as some fellow put it with such sensitive wit in The Washington Post, beggars can't be choosers.
So the anti-Israeli double standard already has made it a half-conference. The Arab states note American acquiescence. If Americans keep applying the double standard, what's left of the conference won't have much of a life expectancy.

HEADLINE: If Stability of Revenue Is the Main Goal, Choose the Sales Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In recent months -- most recently in "Who Will Pay in Connecticut?" (editorial, Oct. 8) -- you have told us that sales taxes provide "highly unstable revenue." Heavy reliance on sales taxes can be criticized on several grounds, but revenue instability is not one of them.
The truth is the opposite: the sales tax is the most stable tax base available to American state and local governments. Over the last 30 years, personal consumption expenditure for durable and nondurable goods less food -- a reasonable proxy for the base of the sales tax in most states -- has never declined from one year to the next. The average year-to-year increase has been about 7.5 percent, and there were only five years in which it was less than 4 percent. 
 In contrast, the average year-to-year change in Federal taxable personal income in the 20 years before the 1986 tax reform law was close to 10 percent; for corporate income the average yearly change in the base was nearly 12 percent, with frequent year-to-year declines. If stability of revenue is the main goal, choose the sales tax.
 
DICK NETZER
Prof. of Economics and Public
Administration, New York U.
New York, Oct. 8, 1991

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Science Desk

LENGTH: 2494 words

HEADLINE: Pentagon Wizards of Technology Eye Wider Civilian Role

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A HIGH-STAKES ideological skirmish is heating up over a little-known Federal agency that some see as the savior of America's high-technology industry and others see as another example of misguided Government meddling in the economy.
The tiny agency, credited as the unseen hand in shaping many major technical innovations, from computers to materials science, is a high technology arm of the Pentagon known as the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa. The White House, Congress and some of the nation's top economists and scientists are battling over whether Darpa should explicitly try to invigorate civilian industry so the United States can better compete with international rivals, especially Japan. 
 The proposed task is challenging since Darpa has no laboratories of its own, no research scientists and no study centers. With a staff of only 150 people housed on three floors of a nondescript building in Arlington, Va., a few blocks from the Potomac, it nonetheless is widely seen as a lean, mean wizard of high technology.
The agency works by searching the land for hints of promising research and then paying select companies and universities to push back high-risk, high-payoff frontiers. Successes to which Darpa has contributed since its founding 33 years ago include Stealth aircraft, cruise missiles, tiny satellites and fundamental strides in computers, electronics, robotics, artificial intelligence and new materials.
The present battle is over whether Darpa should narrow its focus to technologies of purely military interest or broaden it to include spurring such advanced commercial technologies as high-definition television, computer chips, flat displays and fiber optics.
"It's urgent that we get a consensus," Dr. Lewis M. Branscomb, a Harvard professor and former chief scientist of I.B.M., said in an interview. "The Government and Darpa should be able to support a large category of technologies without any sense of guilt or hesitation. If not, we'll go the way of Britain, of lost markets and relative national decline."
The United States once enjoyed a commanding lead in high-technology industries, but it increasingly faces challenges in such fields as electronics, computers and aerospace. In 1990, the top holders of United States patents were all Japanese companies -- Hitachi with 908, Toshiba with 891, Canon with 868 and Mitsubishi with 862. General Electric, which once dominated the top spot, ranked fifth with 785 patents.
The Democratic-controlled Congress has backed a broadening of Darpa's mission, fearing that the United States is fast losing its technical edge and that Darpa carries a hope of reversing the slide. But the Republican White House has resisted that push and instead fought for a narrowing. It says market forces, not unqualified Federal bureaucrats, should chart the course of the nation's industrial growth.
"Government has demonstrated no capacity for choosing among promising new technologies," Murray L. Weidenbaum, a former White House adviser who is an economist at Washington University in St. Louis, recently told Congress. "To a significant degree, Darpa has succeeded by virtue of its ability to bypass much of the Pentagon bureaucracy. If it gets much larger, it likely would loose that special characteristic."
Pressure to broaden and enlarge Darpa is nonetheless rising for a host of reasons. The end of the cold war is seen in some quarters as relaxing the need to keep pushing the outer envelope of military technology, while the ailing economy and stiff competition from abroad are heightening hopes in Darpa's vaunted power to create new high-technology industries.
Perhaps most important, a number of Congressional attempts to form new civilian agency modeled on Darpa -- most notably an effort by Senator John Glenn of Ohio -- have failed in the last few years, leading to a drive to reshape the model itself.
"There is a very strong aversion to the growth of the Federal Government in the country at large," Bobby R. Inman, a retired admiral who was director of the National Security Agency and chairman of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, said in an interview.
"So you try to alter missions to deal with the problem. The leanest and most flexible of the research institutions in finding new technology is Darpa. So it's become the focus."
 
The Question
Should Darpa Become Narpa?
 Recently, Admiral Inman served as chairman of a 15-member task force of the Carnegie Commission on Science, Technology and Government that called for Darpa to be transformed into the National Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Narpa. The new entity would support high-risk technologies of commercial value, helping the military as well as other Federal agencies.
"The end of the cold war and the relative decline in our technical position call for new policies," Admiral Inman told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee last month in making the Carnegie plan public. "In the future, both economic and military security will depend on commercially driven technology."
Congress is now weighing legislation to turn Darpa into Narpa, although no one is predicting quick passage.
"The Federal Government is a very undiscriminating purchasing agent for the American people and will damn near buy anything," Representative Richard Arney, a Texas Republican, said last month while disparaging the Carnegie plan, adding that a Narpa would simply expand the sphere of ineptitude.
Despite such arguments, the Government over the decades has managed to pioneer a wide variety of technologies that have found civilian uses, including rockets, jet engines, communication satellites and photovoltaic cells. It has also had debacles. The $25 billion space shuttle program is still largely a technology in search of a mission. Synthetic fuels and the breeder reactor suffered a similar fate.
 
The Track Record
Smart Weapons And Computers
 Darpa, more so than most Federal agencies, has a remarkable record for spurring innovation. Moreover, its technologies have often found civilian as well as military uses because the agency has long assumed that a healthy industrial base and vigorous basic research are the sinews of national security.
Darpa almost single-handedly founded the fields of materials science and computer science in the United States, paving the way not only for the smart weapons of the Persian Gulf war but the personal computer industry.
An example of its serendipity is the technique of packet-switching. Using the technique, networks for computer data break information into billions of tiny bits and direct them to their destination across a host of different routes. If there is a pause or some other fluctuation in the electronic flow on one wire, say, when a remote computer user goes to the washroom, then the network fills the void with messages destined for someone else so as not to waste valuable time. The wire is thus always working at nearly full capacity. As a result, costs are far lower than with regular telephone lines.
Darpa pioneered packet-switching in the mid 1960's. By the early 1970's it had created Arpanet, a Defense Department network that inexpensively tied together hundreds of military computers. In the 1970's and 1980's, there was an explosion of commercial spinoffs around the world, including services known as Telenet, Tymnet, Graphnet, the Bell System's Advanced Information Service, Uninet and the I.B.M. Information Network, as well as similar systems in France, Britain, Spain, Canada and Japan.
 
A Change of Pattern
Civilian Industries Overtake Military
 Darpa's traditional role in developing so-called "dual use" technologies, of value to both military and civilians, started to undergo some criticism with the arrival of the Reagan Administration in the early 1980's. Its laissez-faire conservatives preached the virtues of free enterprise, some arguing that Darpa should be focused more narrowly.
At the same time, however, an important reversal occurred in national patterns of research spending that had, and continues to have, huge implications for the military. For the first time, beginning in 1980, American industry pulled ahead of the Federal Government as the nation's main supporter of research. As a result of this and other factors, civilian strides increasingly began to outpace the military's. Moreover, foreign civilian industries started to pull ahead even faster.
By the late 1980's, some Pentagon officials saw an ominous gap opening up that they believed would ultimately endanger national security as the military fell further behind.
"I felt if we didn't have a broad industrial base, we were going to die," recalled Dr. Robert B. Costello, who in 1988 became Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition.
Dr. Costello, to whom Darpa reported, used his influence to fight for an expansion of the agency's agenda, advocating such things as its financing of Sematech, a consortium of computer chip producers, as well as high-definition television, which provides a picture that has a crispness and a clarity comparable to that of films. It was seen as having numerous uses in civilian life as well as the battlefield.
Congress liked that approach, too. Beginning in 1988, it gave Darpa more money than the Administration wanted and mandated special attention to commercially significant technologies like advanced television, high-temperature superconductivity, new materials, manufacturing technologies and X-ray lithography for etching computer chips.
Dr. Costello, meanwhile, championed a scientist who shared his views to become Darpa's director. Dr. Craig I. Fields, then 42, took the post in May 1989, speaking out vocally in behalf of Federal sponsorship of technologies with clear commercial links.
In the Bush Administration, the lingering tensions between the free marketers and the technology planners soon exploded. The White House learned that Dr. Fields had Darpa invest $4 million in Gazelle Microcircuits Inc., a Silicon Valley electronics company working on super-high-speed computer chips made of gallium arsenide.
Under an experimental program approved by Congress, the agency made its investment much like a venture capitalist, expecting to receive a payback if the company became successful. The deal also allowed Gazelle to deflect an investment from a Japanese company, which might have entailed transferring the technology to Japan. But Administration officials wondered why the Pentagon was investing when another private company, albeit a Japanese one, was willing to put money in.
In May 1990, Dr. Fields was removed as head of the agency, ending an increasingly bitter fight with top White House officials. The Administration also diverted to other uses much of the $30 million Darpa had devoted to advanced television and sought to focus Sematech more clearly on defense needs.
 
The War Isn't Over
One Senator Tries To Be a Bridge
 The opposition to a Federal role in so-called industrial policy is said to emanate from Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and John H. Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff.
The war over Darpa is far from over. A recent victim is Dr. Michael J. Kelly, who directed Darpa's manufacturing division until it was disbanded and its parts dispersed a few months ago.
"Darpa is a fantastic organization," Dr. Kelly said in an interview. "It has outstanding people. But the greatest risk to the nation is not military. It's economic. Darpa should be doing much more to enhance the industrial base."
Dr. Kelly said he had been accused of "focusing too much attention" on that goal. After his division was disbanded, he left Darpa to direct the Manufacturing Research Center at the Georgia Institute of Technology.
What is emphasized at Darpa now are technology projects with more direct bearing on the military. For instance, the agency is financing the development of a small rocket, the Taurus, that is to be a low-cost and reliable way to send small military satellites into space.
It is also working to perfect a new type of propulsion for submarines. Known as magnetohydrodynamics, it has no moving parts, is virtually silent and promises great reliability at relatively low cost. The process works when a powerful magnet exerts a force on sea water, driving water out the back of a long tube and creating forward motion.
Darpa, thanks to Congressional largess, also still gets much money for civilian technologies, although these are now often pursued in ways that are somewhat surreptitious. For instance, its budget is growing for "high-definition systems," a fairly obvious code name for advanced television. And the programs in its manufacturing division have simply been distributed throughout the agency, not killed outright.
Congress generally gives high marks to Darpa's current director, Dr. Victor H. Reis, for walking a diplomatic line between fiercely competitive forces. "He's always going to emphasize the defense requirement," said a House aide who closely follows the agency. "But a lot of times he does dual-use projects under the guise of defense."
But Dr. Costello, the former Under Secretary of Defense, who is now at the Hudson Institute, said Darpa's efforts were often too timid to make a difference.
"If you want a flat-panel display now, you have to buy it from the Japanese," he said. "The military should have aggressively pursued them. It needs them in F-15's, in tanks, in the White House and on the backs of the Marines who are going to scurry into Iraq next time. Instead of that, we're still saddled with old equipment that does not meet the military's needs."
A member of Congress who is trying to bridge the gap between opposing camps is Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat who has pushed for dual-use Darpa programs in which research costs are shared by industry, allowing some attention to market forces. Last year he promoted a $50 million package for the development of pre-competitive technologies by industry consortia. Darpa put the money into ceramic fibers, optical electronics, superconducting electronics, linguistic data processing, parallel computers and advanced memory chips.
"The areas chosen are critical," Senator Bingaman said in a recent statement. "It is clear Darpa will be leveraging significant private sector resources in the six consortia."
Still, the Carnegie Commission would go further, transforming Darpa into a much more diverse agency. It is a proposition most analysts expect to be a hard sell with the Bush Administration, given its preference for the invisible hand of the free market.
"What does scare me," Dr. Weidenbaum told Congress, "is that once you open this door, there is no limit to the expansion of the Government's role in this major area of the economy."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Science Times yesterday about Murray L. Weidenbaum, an economist who discussed the success of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, misstated his university affiliation. He is at Washington University, not the University of Washington.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bobby R. Inman, former director of the National Security Agency, calls Darpa the "most flexible" research institution. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times); Murray L. Weidenbaum, economist at University of Washington in St. Louis, believes Darpa would lose its advantage if it grew larger. (Bill Stover for The New York Times) (pg. C11)
 
Graphs: "Trends in Research Spending" shows overall U.S. research and development from '56 to '90; DARPA's Government support from '83 to '91 (Source: Defense Department) (pg. C11)
 
Diagram: "An Engine of Invention, Running Behind the Scenes"
 The Pentagon's little-known research finance agency, Darpa, has backed winning technologies for the military; many have found wide civilian use.
 
1. TRANSMITTING DATA
In the 1960's, Darpa backed development of packet switching, which breaks computer data into tiny bits and routes them over networks in the most efficient fashion. Civilian spinoffs exploded in the 1970's and 1980's, including well-known networks like Telenet and Tymnet.
 
2. HIGH-TEMPERATURE METALS
Darpa-financed researchers largely originated the field of materials science and pioneered work on advanced crystallography, ceramics and metalurgy, including titanium-based alloys and nickel aluminide, a metal of great strength even at high temperatures.
 
3. STEALTH WEAPONS
Darpa was the force behind radar-evading aircraft, developing absorbent materials, dispersive coatings, shaping strategies and flight prototypes. The work resulted in the B-2 bomber and the F-117 fighter, which bombed Baghdad with impunity during the Persian Gulf war.
 
4. COMPUTER CHIPS
Darpa fostered the field of computer science, paving the way for the U.S. computer industry. In addition, it advanced critical areas of materials science that turned semiconductors into the computer chips at the heart of smart weapons and personal computers.
 
5. LASERS
Darpa advanced the strength and usefulness of lasers after their inital demonstration in 1960. It focused on developing laser materials and high-powered devices that might be useful in war. This research helped inspire interest in "Star Wars" anti-missile defenses.
 
6. COMPOSITES
Darpa's materials-science push helped pave the way for high-strength, light-weight composite materials that are finding their way into everything from tennis rackets to jet aircraft. It has explored complex weaves as well as random arrays of particles and fibers. (pg. C1)
